lead_paragraph: Wednesday was the second day, of the meeting of the New-York Jockey Club. The two, great events on the cards being the three near old sweepstakes, mile heats, and the Jocsey Club purse, single dash of two miles for all ages, for which the sole contestants were the famous mare Idlewild and the equally famous horse Reporter. Each had beaten the other in previous contests, and the chief interest of Wednesday's racing was centered in the renewal of their encounter, which proved to be a most hollow affair, Reporter winning on any terms he pleased. The attendance was slim, owing to the utter lack of tact or good faith on the part of the Jamaica Railroad Company. The following is an epitome of the day's proceedings:

abstract: The arrangements for the celebration of the Fourth of July, by the army and navy, in this vicinity and elsewhere, are progressing rapidly. On Governor's Island, the old headquarters of the Department of the East, a salute will be fired at the usual time, a dress parade may come off if the day is fine, and the Declaration of Independence will not be forgotten. The soldiers of the regular army look forward with joy to the anniversary of the nation's birthday. The navy will honor the occasion by saluting and dressing ship. The magnitude of the war fleet in harbor at present renders it likely that a more picturesque display of bunting was never seen in our harbor than can be witnessed on the coming Fourth. The receiving ship North Carolina, the old razee Savannah, now our local school ship; the steam-frigate Niagara, and 50 sail beside, will contribute to the show. The commandants of the foreign fleet in port will be formally informed by Admiral PAULDING, on the 2d, of the approaching festival, and will fire salutes of course. In San Francisco, Callao, Hong Kong, Spezzia, Rio Janeiro, Queenstown, Lisbon, Alexandria, Southampton, and 20 other commercial rendezvous, such of our naval vessels as have been spared from blockading duty, will fire for the home of the free. It is not improper to say that an experience of four years' cruising in an American man-of-war has proved that no holiday is welcomed with more genuine friendliness, by sailors and soldiers everywhere, than ours.

abstract: The United States steam-transport Merrimack, Capt. SAMPSON, from New-Orleans and the Balize, June 23, with passengers to United States Quartermaster, June 24, lat. 26° 28′, long. 86° 01′, arrived yesterday. She passed a bark bound northwest, showing a red burgee with white letters; same day, steamers Mississippi and Yazoo, bound south; 26th, lat. 25° 54′, saw three ships, one bark, two brigs and five schooners, bound north; 29th, lat. 38°, long. 74° 30′, passed bark American Eagle, for New-York.

abstract: Atlantic, of Brooklyn, vs. Umpire; Championship
snippet: Atlantic, of Brooklyn, vs. Umpire; Championship
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Capitoline Ball Grounds, at Bedford, L.I., was visited by at least four thousand spectators, including a large number of ladies, to witness the important contest between the above noted prominent ball associations. It was in the year 1857 when these clubs played their last match, and as both have changed in players since that date the present match was of more than ordinary interest. The Atlantics, who, by-the bye, were short the services of C. SMITH (third base) and CRANE, (centre,) playing substitutes opened the game at the bat, and obtained five runs. The Empires got two runs in their first bout, when the Atlantics added three in the second innings. But now, unfortunately, a heavy shower of rain put a stop to the play, but in about half an hour the players again came on the ground, the result being that the Empires made eight runs in their third innings, which made them ten to eight. The rain again stopped the play, when the game stood a tie in five innings, as follows;

abstract: On Saturday morning last the rebel Gen. WHARTON, with 2,500 men, made a raid on SHERMAN's rear, and interrupted, for a time, his communications. Five freight trains, loaded with army supplies, were captured between Ringgold and Dalton, and destroyed. The rebel cavalry are very active, and occasionally meet with success. Their chief aim appears to be to raid on the communications of our army. About a week ago Capt. GLOVER made a dash at the railroad five miles from Resaca, and succeeded in capturing and destroying two trains loaded with provisions. SHERMAN feels secure in his position, and his lines are steadily advancing. Fighting occurs every day. The boom of cannon and the rattle of musketry are heard in the early dawn, and the thundering echoes and bright flashes make grand the twilight hour. The rebels hold their strongly fortified position on the Chattahootchie River. SHERMAN will take Atlanta by a dextrously-executed flank movement. We learn from a gentleman just arrived from the front, whose connection with the army affords every facility to learn of its movements, the above facts. He was in Atlanta one week ago, and states that the citizens of that place feel insecure, and are moving further South. The Governor of Georgia is becoming sensitive in regard to the invasion of the State. He is out with a proclamation in the Atlanta papers, warning the Confederate authorities, and JOE JOHNSTON in particular, not to attempt to destroy Atlanta or the railroads extending from the city. He says that they are the property of the State, and he will use every means in his power to preserve them for the State. If necessary, he will call out the militia, and recall the Georgia troops in the Confederate service, to aid him in enforcing his proclamation. This sounds much like buncombe, and we presume it will so be regarded by the Confederate authorities. Our informant says that if JOHNSTON is driven from the Chattahoochie, he will not attempt to make a stand this side or Atlanta, or even at the city. Cedar Bluff, nine miles below the town, has been strongly fortified, and is considered impregnable. JOHNSTON will at once retreat to this position, if forced from his present stand, and will there offer battle. The Bluff can never be taken by assault. It will require a long and tedious siege to effect its downfall.

abstract: VALI takes her benefit, and makes her last appearance but one at Niblo's to-night. It will also be the last opportunity but one the public will have of witnessing the successful drama of "Bel Demonio," which will be withdrawn on the termination of the current week. The energy, perseverance, continuous industry, and the well-merited success she has achieved warrant the belief -- which amounts to a certainty -- thatMadame VESTVALI will be the recipient of a valedictory ovation this evening.

abstract: Corps Composing
snippet: Corps Composing
lead_paragraph: There are four corps in Gen. JO. JOHNSTON's army, now opposing SHERMAN. HARDEE's corps is composed of CHEATNAM's, CLEBURN's, WALKER's and BATES' divisions; HOOD's corps, of STEVENSON's, STEWART's and HINDMAN's divisions, POLK's, of LORING's and TENCHS divisions, and another of different commands; and WHEELER's cavalry corps consists of the divisions of KELLY, JACKSON and MARTIN. There are also two independent cavalry divisions, respectively commanded by RODDY and LEE, which act in concert with WHEELER in the field, though distinct in their organizations. The Georgia infantry, or "Gov. BROWN's pets," as they are called, are sold to number between ten and fifteen thousand; they are principally employed in erecting breastworks, and as yet have done but little fighting. The other corps are each said to be about 20,000 strong. The rebel cavalry have not, until recently, effected much harm to our rear. The burning of the bridge at Tilton and the destruction of the trains there, and WHARTON's dash last week, have been the only damage since the burning of the mule train at Cassville. Gen. SHERMAN has issued an order in relation to the punishment of guerrillas, bush-walkers and murderers, which will fully meet the requirements of the situation. -- Louisville Journal.

abstract: Daniels, Isaac; Revolutionary Veteran
snippet: Daniels, Isaac; Revolutionary Veteran
lead_paragraph: ISAAC DANIELS, the last of the Revolutionary heroes residing in this City, aged 109 years, died on Wednesday at the residence of his son-in-law, Mr. JOHN A. HOVER, on Goerck-street. Mr. DANIELS served during the Revolutionary war under the immediate command of Gen. WASHINGTON, and was conspicuous for his bravery in the battles of Monmouth, Trenton and White Plains. He was one of the first who entered the City of New-York after its evacuation by the British, and assisted in hauling down the enemy's flag and planting the Stars and Stripes in its place. Mr. DANIELS also served through the war of 1812. He was born in Westchester County, this State, in 1754; was by occupation a farmer, but had resided in this City for the last sixty years. He was married young, and was the father of nine children, seven of whom are now living. He led a temperate life, retained all his faculties up to within a short time of his death, and died of old age. The funeral of the old soldier took place yesterday afternoon, from the house in which he died, and was largely attended. The following veterans of the war of 1812, acted as pall-bearers: Gen. H. Raymond, Col. Abraham Dally, Col. William Buttery, Lieut.-Col. Wm. Corbire, Capt. J.B. Fox, Capt. Henry Baker, Aid-de-Camp Thomas L. Watson, and Chaplain Joseph Hall. There were several other veterans present. The body was taken to Cypress Hill Cemetery, where it was interred in the veterans' burial ground.

abstract: Needed; School of Mines Opened
snippet: Needed; School of Mines Opened
lead_paragraph: On the 15th of November next, Columbia College will open a School of Mines. This will be a novelty in our City, but its utility cannot be too strongly asserted. There is no considerable country except our own, which has not a school applied to mining science. Not even the smallest States in Europe are deficient in this sort of instruction. The Imperial School of Mines at Paris, is familiar to Americans, many of our youth having frequented the lectures given there, although not more than two or three have ever taken diplomas, and the title of Engineer of Mines, from that school. The most celebrated in Germany, are the well-known ones of Freiburg, in Saxony, and Clausthal, in the Hartz. Hungary has a seat of instruction at Schemnitz. England established a Mining School in 1851, in connection with the National Museum of Geology. It was a necessity for the development of her East India possessions. This instituted a new calling and career for a large class of her gentry, who entered upon it with ardor. A School of Mines seems to be useful to all capitalists, who, when urged to invest in mining operations, are dependent upon the reports of interested parties. A professional mining engineer is wanted, to give an unprejudiced opinion derived from thorough examinations and soundly scientific analysis.
headline: {'main': 'A School of Mines.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A School of Mines.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The people will breathe more freely -- hope, almost worn out, will revive with the intelligence of to-day -- Mr. CHASE out of, and Gov. TODD in the Treasury Department! Heaven be praised for this gleam of national sunshine. It is more precious, even, than a military victory. It is a glorious financial achievement. The long, weary day of despotism is over. One clog is removed. A man who did not desire a restoration of the Union is out of the Cabinet. We can begin now to penetrate the darkness which has so long shrouded the political horizon.

abstract: Public Career of; Resignation of; On Sec Chase's Resignation and Offer to Mr Tod
snippet: Public Career of; Resignation of; On Sec Chase's Resignation and Offer to Mr Tod
lead_paragraph: We have no reliable information as to thecauses of Mr. CHASE'S resignation of the Treasury Department, though the fact itself seems to be sufficiently authenticated. We do not ascribe it to any anticipation of difficulty in carrying the financial department of the Government through the crisis which circumstances seem to have created for it, because Mr. CHASE is not the man to shrink from any duty or responsibility in which the honor and welfare of the nation are involved. The more threatening the aspect of affaire in his department, the more likely would he have been, other things being equal, to stand by the helm and do everything in his power to avert impending dangers. He has become involved, it is true, in a very embarrassing controversy with the State banks throughout the country, and has committed himself, perhaps too unreservedly, to certain theories of finance in connection with the war; and he may have thought that some other person could more gracefully introduce changes of policy, which experience has shown to be indispensable, than he could himself. But this is a very different thing, and has a very different motive, from abandoning the Ship of State because it seems to be threatened with danger.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Chase's Resignation.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Chase's Resignation.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Class-day of 1864
snippet: Class-day of 1864
lead_paragraph: The Harvard man has one fault to find with all almanacs, to wit: They make no mention of Harvard Class Day. The college caliender, to be sure, gives notice of this famous carnival time, but all others fall to recognize it, and consequently have to meet the condemnation of our under-graduates, who hold it settled beyond dispute, that Harvard College is the greatest college in the land, and her Seniors' Class Day, the happiest time of all the year. For them it has attractions far beyond any that a Christmas, Thanksgiving Day or Fourth of July can offer. When Freshmen they learn what Class Day is, but having to keep in the background, little is the enjoyment that it brings them. They get a large foretaste of its pleasures in their sophomore and junior years, and with the advent of their senior year set to work in real earnest to lay all their plans for the eventful ime. Then all their college labors will be over, they will have all their relatives and friends about them, and with a fair sky, pipers, caterers to assist, they are to try then to make the day as merry as can be, Of course, they always succeed, but those who last Friday listened to the srator and poet of the day, who feasted on unstin[???]ed delicacies, joined the light fantastic rounds on the green, and at evening strolled leisurely by the witching light of Chinese lanterns, are of the opinion that the success then was greater than ever.

abstract: The steamer Belvidere will be ready at the foot of Spring-street, North River, at 12 M. to-day, to receive any sanitary stores for the Army of the Potomac. The steamer will leave on Saturday morning. Mr. C.C. COMSTOCK goes in the steamer to attend to the distribution of the stores. Fresh vegetables will be gratefully received. As this is a Fourth of July offering to the army, we trust it will be a good one.

abstract: Col. C.S. HANSON, commanding the Third Brigade, First Division, District of Kentucky, arrived in Lexington with a portion of his brigade, on Thursday night, after a toilsome pursuit of MORGAN's men through the mountain regions of the State. After the battle of Cynthiana MORGAN divided his forces. The forces that menaced Frankfort, supposed to be under the command of a Col. GILTNER, was pursued by Col. HANSON by order of Gen. BURBRIDGE, Col. HANSON had three hundred select men with him, who untiringly and perseveringly pressed onward in their weary march for many days and nights, but the rebels, about equal in number, had some forty miles the start, and made their escape through Crank's Gap with a number of horses. The rebels had fresh horses all the time, having started with some two hundred and fifty unmounted and led. They escaped, however, with but a small number. Col. HANSON gave up the pursuit at the Gap, finding it impossible, with the jaded condition of his men and horses, to proceed further.

abstract: There is very little war news of interest this morning. Affairs in front of Petersburgh still remain quiet. There has been no severe fighting now for a week, and the latest dispatches mention that the troops had been relieved ...
lead_paragraph: There is very little war news of interest this morning. Affairs in front of Petersburgh still remain quiet. There has been no severe fighting now for a week, and the latest dispatches mention that the troops had been relieved somewhat from their sufferings from the heat by cooling showers. Gen. HANCOCK has again resumed command of his famous corps. The Weldon Railroad is reported now to be positively in our possession, which leaves LEE only the Danville Railroad, and that has been thoroughly disabled by our cavalry.

abstract: St George, New-York, vs Willow of Brooklyn
snippet: St George, New-York, vs Willow of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: These clubs played a match on the Bedford cricket ground yesterday, the result being in favor of the St. George's eleven, as the game was agreed to be one days' play, and the result of the first innings in this case decided the game. If it had been a regular two days' match the Willows would probably have pulled the game in their favor. In the first innings the St. George's scored 146 runs to 62 for the Willow. TODD got 68, and J.W. GORDON 30 for the former club in good style. In the second innings, which was not concluded at 7 o'clock -- the time for drawing the stumps -- the Willows' had scored 173 runs for the loss of seven wickets, out of which NORTH added 42; PEARCE 34; C. GISBORNE 21; and TORRANCE (not out) 34. Umpires -- Messrs. HUDSON and H. WRIGHT.

abstract: The Royal Mail steamer Arabia, which left Liverpool on the 18th, and Queenstown on the 19th of June, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. In the House of Commons, Mr. MILNER GIBSON stated that a bell buoy would be placed on Daunt's Rock, where the City of New-York was wrecked, and the light at Roche's Point improved. In the House of Lords, on the 17th, the Earl of ELLENBOROUGH stated that he thought it was incumbent on England to maintain the proposition she had made for the settlement of the Danish question, and insist on its adoption, and wished to know whether the British fleet was in a state to proceed at once to blockade the German ports. Earl RUSSELL said, in reply, that he was sorry it was not in his power, during the sittings of the conference, to give such explanations as he could wish, and which he thought would dispose of the grievous misrepresentations afloat in regard to the conduct of the British Government, and that the fleet was ready to go anywhere. Capt. SEMMES, of the pirate Alabama, has written a long letter to the London Times in defence of his actions, from which we make copious extracts in another column.

abstract: on the Cleveland and Baltimore Platforms
snippet: on the Cleveland and Baltimore Platforms
lead_paragraph: WENDELL PHILLIPS, though not personally present in the Cleveland Convention, was by far the most noted man connected with it. On that account, solely, it is worth while to know his estimate of its actual doings, as compared with those at Baltimore. We say solely, because the peculiarities of his intellect and disposition, naturally disqualify him from a fair judgment of any public movement with a practical purpose. He was made only to be a gadfly to the body politic.

abstract: to his Patrons, London Times
snippet: to his Patrons, London Times
lead_paragraph: The letter addressed by SEMMES, of the Alabama, to the British people, through the columns of the London Times, is as strange a jumble of impertinence, false assertion, and contemptuous disregard of those who have been his most consistent patrons, as can well be conceived. We publish sufficient of its text this morning, principally to show how susceptible of grateful feeling toward the British community, Capt. SEMMES really is. It is a singular return, this same letter, for the facilities first of all accorded to SEMMES and his masters in British ports, for making their first start as privateers. He charges the British Government not only with issuing orders of neutrality which bear unequally upon the rebel cause, but with having forced Spain and France, as well as the smaller commercial Powers, to similar orders. He derides the English people on their boasted fair play, and sneers at what he calls their "pious horror" of seeing innocent merchantmen burnt at sea. Nothing, he thinks, would have been easier or more natural than to have had his prizes brought into any convenient neutral port, quietly to lie there until they should be adjudicated on; and this simple arrangement, while bringing him profit where he has had none, would have saved much property from needless destruction.

abstract: The commencement exercise of the graduating class of this excellent school took place, in the presence of several hundred friends, at their elegant hall, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock. The room was decked with wreaths of natural flowers, festoons of evergreens, floral basket, and patriotic mottoes. When the four hundred smiling pupils, dressed in white -- each girl wearing a Union badge, and holding a bouquet -- were seated, the school room seemed quickly changed into a fairy bower. On the platform were observed the City Superintendent, the school officers of the Twentieth Ward, and several distinguished friends of popular education. Commissioner HASTIE presided. The music, which was of the highest character, was under the direction of Prof. MARCUS COLBURN. The exercises consisted of vocal and instrumental music, essays, addresses, and the presentation of diplomas to the sixteen young ladies who formed the graduating class. The whole programme gave the liveliest satisfaction.

abstract: A MERITED REWARD. -- The Senate, on Thursday, confirmed Col. JOSHUA S. CHAMBERLIN, of the Twentieth Maine Volunteers, to be Brigadier-General, "for gallant and meritorious conduct in leading his brigade against the enemy at Petersburgh, Va., when he was dangerously wounded, to date from June 11, 1864." This is a fit reward to an officer of the highest patriotism and most distinguished gallantry. Gen. CHAMBERLIN left an honored position in Bowdoin College to serve his country in the field. He was appointed Lieutenant-Colonel of the Twentieth Maine Volunteers, commanded by Colonel,now General, AMES, of the regular army. Succeeding to the command, he soon became senior Colonel in the famous Third Brigade of the First Division, Fifth Army Corps, originally organized by Major-Gen. BUTTERFIELD; and it was while bravely leading this brigade that Gen. C. was severely wounded in both legs. The Government honors itself by honoring such men.

abstract: RESUMPTION OF RECRUITING. -- On Tuesday morning next, at 10 o'clock, Supervisor BLUNT will again open the City Hall Park Recruiting Station, and business will be resumed as of old. The amount subscribed on the last loan, authorized by the Supervisor,amounts to nearly a half million dollars, and the Comptroller is receiving new bids daily. The prospects are exceedingly encouraging that the whole sum ($2,000,000) will be taken within the next thirty days. The Hancock Substitute Recruiting Committee is getting along much better than was at first anticipated -- an average of ten men being received daily. It is expected that some arrangement will be made between the Supervisors and this committee to mutually assist each other in the business of recruiting. A point has arisen concerning drafted citizens who were absent at the time of the last call -- the quota being now filled. The following, from a letter addressed by Provost-Marshal-General FRY to Supervisor BLUNT will explain the matter: "A drafted man, failing to report, is a deserter, and liable to arrest at anytime. The man drafted in his stead is credited on the quota drafted for at that time. If the deserter be subsequently arrested and held, he is credited on future quotas. Every deserter, however, must be arrested, without regard to circumstances."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Senate bill to reimburse the State of Pennsylvania for expenses in calling out the militia during the rebel invasion in 1863, and which had been amended so as to embrace New-York and New-Jersey militia, was taken up, argued at length, and some amendments made. The Gold Act was repealed by a vote of 24 against 13. The East Tennessee Bill was taken up for discussion. The bill to guarantee to certain States Republican governments was then brought before the House, and the consideration of it continued until the Senate took a recess.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Senate bill to reimburse the State of Pennsylvania for expenses in calling out the militia during the rebel invasion in 1863, and which had been amended so as to embrace New-York and New-Jersey militia, was taken up, argued at length, and some amendments made. The bill to guarantee to certain States Republican governments was then brought before the House, and the consideration of it continued until the Senate took a recess.

abstract: British Ultimatum
snippet: British Ultimatum
lead_paragraph: By the English mail, received yesterday, we have an accumulation of evidence that the British Government has at last determined to give material aid to Denmark in the event of the Germans refusing to give up North Schleswig -- that is, making the Schlei the dividing line. Lord ELLENBOROUGH, in the House of Lords, puts the case in a nut-shell, and interprets British public opinion with thorough correctness, when he says (speaking on the 17th:) "There is only one way to make Prussia give up its hold on Jutland and North Schleswig, and that is by distinctly intimating that the British Government will not only protect the islands, but will protect Jutland and Schleswig."
headline: {'main': 'Denmark and Germany The Ultimatum.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Denmark and Germany The Ultimatum.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news from the armies is still very meagre. No important operations are reported, either from Virginia or Georgia. Some details of Gen. WILSON's recent cavalry expedition are given this morning. It was quite as successful as has been reported. The Danville road was reached, and twenty miles of track, bridges, &c., destroyed. The road was laid with strap rail, and by burning the sleepers the iron was thoroughly destroyed. Gen. WILSON met with little resistance until he reached the crossing of the Weldon Railroad at Ream's Station, on his return. Here all the rebel cavalry had concentrated to cut off his retreat, and as he could not pass by them, he engaged them in battle, sending word of his situation in the meantime, to Gen. MEADE, who at once dispatched the Sixth Corps to his relief.

abstract: Lieut. SINCLAIR, of the Fourteenth Regular Infantry, was wounded recently in the thigh, and now lies in hospital. The rifle bullet that hit him passed through his pocketbook, which contained four hundred dollars in greenbacks. Each note is perforated in two places, and the portraits of President LINCOLN are stained with the Lieutenant's blood. He values this money a little above par. They ought to be redeemed in specie, to say the least. -- Washington Republican, June 26.

abstract: Two excellent iron-clad vessels have been built in a shipyard of this City for the Italian Government, and the Russian Government also have had some fine vessels built in this country. We now learn from a Berlin journal that the Prussian Government, in view of the belligerent aspect of affairs in Europe, is making earnest endeavors to obtain ships-of-war from the United States. Our own navy is not generally considered to be very effective, nor very creditable to the country; but it seems that we yet have men capable of turning out first-class war-vessels. Perhaps, in this emergency, the Prussians might be induced to buy up our double-enders, our light-draft monitors, and some of our heavy-draft monitors. If they did so, there is no doubt that somebody would suffer.

abstract: White, A. L., Murdered by Guerrillas in Tennessee
snippet: White, A. L., Murdered by Guerrillas in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: -- On the 5th of June, about midnight, four armed men, disguise with blackened faces, entered the house of Mr. AMOS L. WHITE, in Henry County, Tenn., and demanded $10,000 booty as a ransom for his life. As so much could not be found by them after a thorough search, they seized Mr. WHITE and dragged him from his bed, carried him a short distance from the house and shot him dead, three bullets entering his body. What conversation passed between these fiendish assassins and their victim is unknown, as Mrs. WHITE, his wife, who [???]ed after them, was driven back upon peril [???] [???]ing the late of her husband. Mr. [???] was a planter, and had resided in [???] a few years. He was raising [???] one hundred acres of cotton. He was born in this State, was the son of JOHN WHITE, and was about 42 years of age. He resided several years in Johnston, and was educated in the manufacturing business at Simmonsville, under the guidance of BENJAMIN PIRCE, Esq. After becoming prepared for the management of a mill, he and his family removed to Bahia, Brazil, where he was engaged in cotton spinning for about two years, when he returned to his native State and took charge of the Simmonsville mills for a short time. Thence he removed to Barnesville, Ohio, where he built a mill and engaged in the manufacture of wick, twine, yarn, batts, bags and wadding. The business was very successful, and his mill was the only one of the kind in the vicinity, and the articles were readily taken for home consumption. He removed thence to Tennessee, where he was brutally murdered.

abstract: -On last Friday evening, while the festival given by the ladies of the Presbyterian Church was being held in the parlors of the St. Joseph Hotel, one of the large chandeliers fell from the ceiling, with a crash, striking upon the marble-top centre-table, demolished lamps and chimneys and some vases which were standing upon the table, and saturated everything in the vicinity with oil, which, taking fire upon the carpet, for a time created considerable consternation among those assembled. Providentially, none of the ladies' dresses took fire, though several were thoroughly soaked with the unctuous fluid, else we might have to record a fatal accident. As it was, the damage to the furniture and carpet was considerable. The accident was the result of the chandelier not being securely attached to the ceiling, the hook by which it was suspended barely going through the plastering. -- South Bend (Ind.) Register, June 23.

abstract: Gov. O.P. Morton, Indianapolis, Ind.:  DEAR SIR: I return you my most grateful thanks for your prompt assistance during MORGAN'S recent raid. The timely arrival of the Forty-third Regiment Indiana Volunteers gave us entire relief against all apprehensions of danger. Although the citizens had repulsed the rebels, yet the large numbers still infesting this section at the time of their arrival, kept us upon constant vigil, and serious apprehension of another assault.
lead_paragraph: COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY, EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, FRANKFORT, June 22, 1864.

abstract: Mrs. DAVID HOOD committed suicide at about 5 o'clock yesterday morning, by drowning herself from the end of Whipple's Wharf. A shawl and hat were found on pile of lumber on the wharf, at about 5 1/2 o'clock, and being taken to a neighbor's house were recognized as belonging to Mrs. HOOD, who had been missing for some hours, parties being then in search of her. Her body was shortly after discovered floating in the water. No cause is known to exist for the melancholy act. That she had contemplated it for some little time, as least, is believed, from the fact of her having asked her husband on Sunday what time it was high tide. Mrs. HOOD was a woman much respected by all who knew her, was about 35 years of age, and leaves a family of four children. -- Boston Journal, June 23.

abstract: The municipal arrangements for the celebration of our national anniversary this year are on a less extensive scale than usual. The City Government, it is understood, has wisely refrained from spreading itself a feast at the public expense to-morrow; and has also made no preparations for the customary speeches in some of our public halls. It has restricted its expenditure to a grand display of fireworks, which, it is claimed, will exhaust the sum of ten thousand dollars usually appropriated for the celebration.

abstract: The chief business done yesterday in both Houses was the final agreement on the Enrollment Bill. The Conference Committee reported the bill as agreed upon by them, which fixed the time at fifty days, which the President shall allow after making a call, and before ordering a draft. Loyal States may recruit in all the rebellious States except Tennessee, Arkansas and Louisiana. The House promptly adopted the report. The Senate at first rejected the report, and then reconsidered its action and adopted it by a strong vote.

abstract: -- On Friday last, FRANCIS C. SPENCER, who murdered RICHARD TIN[???]ER, the Warden of the Maine State Prison, on the 14th of May, 1863, was hanged at Thomaston, Me. Before his death he confessed that his real name was COUILLARD. He had previously served out a sentence of six years in this State, and acknowledged that he sharpened the knife which killed the Warden of the Massachusetts State Prison. SPENCER, who met his fate with remarkable co[???]iness, manifested some signs of repentance. This is the first enforcement of the death penalty in Maine since 1832.

abstract: Verses in Hartford Courant; Manifesto and the Declaration of Independence; Extract from; "Let Me Alone," Political, from Hartford ???
snippet: Verses in Hartford Courant; Manifesto and the Declaration of Independence; Extract from; "Let Me Alone," Political, from Hartford ???
lead_paragraph: When our forefathers felt it their duty to sever the ties which bound them to Great Britain, they declared that "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind" required them to set forth the causes which impelled them to the separation. The rebels of our day have claimed that the mantle of our fathers has fallen upon them, but we, for our part, see not a vestige about them of our fathers' garments. Respect for the opinions of mankind could not be a very prominent feature among those who, in their very outset, trampled upon principles which civilization and Christianity have prized most highly, and who have never hesitated to declare that if the "opinions of mankind" did not sustain them in their love of Slavery, it was so much the worse for mankind. But they have recently put on a little show of respect for those opinions, for the rebel Congress has issued a manifesto, which we find in the Richmond Whig, the purpose of which is declared, in the preamble to the resolution by which it was adopted, to be "to enlighten the public opinion of the world with regard to the true character of the struggle in which they are engaged, and the dispositions, principles and purposes by which they are actuated."

abstract: Puritan, Iron-clad, Launch of
snippet: Puritan, Iron-clad, Launch of
lead_paragraph: The United States iron-clad battery Puritan was successfully launched yesterday morning at Greenpoint. The previous attempts to get her off having failed, a very large assemblage was present; among the rest Admiral GREGORY, Commodore RODGERS, Capt. BOGGS, and Capt. ERICSSON himself. At about 9 o'clock the huge hull glided gracefully into the water, and went half-way across the river before the force of her descent became exhausted. Miss GREGORY, daughter of the gallant Admiral, did the christening. The launch over, efforts were made to haul in the ship, which, considering that she weighs 6,000,000 pounds, could not have been trifling, but they succeeded. The spectators dispersed, much relieved that one of the noblest illustrations of creative genius was safely afloat.

abstract: The steamer Belvidere sailed yesterday afternoon from the foot of Spring-street for the James River, with a rich cargo of stores for our army and navy, including nearly two thousand barrels of vegetables, procured with the voluntary subscriptions of our citizens. This cargo, which includes nearly eight hundred barrels of onions, constitutes only the first installment of what is to be provided for our brave soldiers and sailors through the generosity of our citizens. The Belvidere, a large and commodious vessel, will reach James River on the morning of the 4th, and her cargo may be discharged by noon of that day. The following is a list of the articles comprising her cargo: Four hundred barrels of potatoes, (from the Sanitary Commission;) seven hundred and thirty-six barrels of onions; three hundred barrels of turnips; twenty-one barrels of beets; fifty boxes of lemons, and from seven to ten thousand heads of cabbage. Other contributions have been made by citizens, of which no report has been received. The distribution of the cargo will be under the superintendence of Mr. DAVID A. NASH and two assistants.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Belvidere sailed yesterday afternoon from the foot of Spring-street for the James River, with a rich cargo of stores for our army and navy, including nearly two thousand barrels of vegetables, procured with the voluntary subscriptions of our citizens. This cargo, which includes nearly eight hundred barrels of onions, constitutes only the first installment of what is to be provided for our brave soldiers and sailors through the generosity of our citizens. The Belvidere, a large and commodious vessel, will reach James River on the morning of the 4th, and her cargo may be discharged by noon of that day. The following is a list of the articles comprising her cargo: Four hundred barrels of potatoes, (from the Sanitary Commission;) seven hundred and thirty-six barrels of onions; three hundred barrels of turnips; twenty-one barrels of beets; fifty boxes of lemons, and from seven to ten thousand heads of cabbage. Other contributions have been made by citizens, of which no report has been received. The distribution of the cargo will be under the superintendence of Mr. DAVID A. NASH and two assistants.

abstract: Palmerston, Lord, and House of Commons
snippet: Palmerston, Lord, and House of Commons
lead_paragraph: The strength of parties in England was brought to a tolerably effective test in the House of Commons on the evening of Friday, the 17th of June. A motion was introduced on that evening by a private member, Sir JOHN HAY, on which it was found possible not only to rally the regular Conservative vote of the House, but various discontented members of the Ministerial party as well. Involving nothing in the shape of party political principle, the vote was precisely one on which malcontents of every degree might give vent to their personal grievances. It purported to censure the Government for a grave executive delinquency in landing forces on the African Gold Coast for the purpose of waging war against the King of Ashantee, without making sufficient provision for preserving the health of the troops. The case thus briefly stated was clearly proven. The utmost negligence was brought home to the War Department, and Lord PALMERSTON had to apply the "whip" to his following with no ordinary vigor to prevent the passage of what would have been equivalent to a vote of non-confidence. The best he could do was to come off with a majority of seven in a House of four hundred and fifty members -- a condition of party weakness, which but for two contingent events would be alarming. The first of these events is an early dissolution of the House. The next is the evident commitment of the Government to a war policy as the alternative of a rejection by Germany of the proposal to make the Schlei the territorial dividing line between her and Denmark.

abstract: Naval Investigating Committee's Report on Frauds
snippet: Naval Investigating Committee's Report on Frauds
lead_paragraph: The Select Committee, composed of Senators HALE, DOOLITTLE and BUCKALAW, appointed early in the session to investigate the subject of naval supplies, reported Friday. The report makes over fifty foolscap manuscript pages, and is supported by about a thousand pages of testimony. Mr. BUCKALEW mainly agrees with the report, but submits his views upon some points in about thirty pages of manuscript. Mr. DOOLITTLE also submits twenty pages, embodying his special opinions on one or two branches of the inquiry. The Committee say the Secretary of the Navy furnished them with every possible opportunity for investigation, and respecting that officer they conclude by saying they discovered nothing to cast a suspicion even upon his uprightness as a man or upon his integrity as an officer.

abstract: Escape from Rebels
snippet: Escape from Rebels
lead_paragraph: RICE, NINETEENTH MASSACHUSETTS VOLUNTEERS. -- Lieut.-Col. EDMUND RICE, of the Massachusetts Nineteenth Regiment, whose capture by the rebels at Spottsylvania Court-house and subsequent escape from the rebels have been mentioned in our columns, reached this city on Saturday evening in good health and spirits. He has given us the following particulars of the escape of himself and his comrades: -- They were in a box car about thirty miles from Danville. There were six in the party. In one of the doors stood the guard who had them in charge. The other door was a slat door. The escape was made on the evening of the 23d May. They got a number of their fellow-prisoners to stand up between them and their guard while they quietly cut off three of the slats of the door, and through the aperture thus made six of them lowered themselves out of the car, which was going at the rate of fifteen miles an hour. They were not injured in landing, but managed to get [???] to the swamps. One of their number could not be found, and it is not known what his fate was.

lead_paragraph: -- In this case the defendant and his wife had agreed upon a separation, and procured a deed to be drawn for that purpose. In this deed it was provided that in addition to the weekly allowance, the defendant should give his wife his note for the purpose of purchasing furniture, &c., and he accordingly gave the note in [???] payable to Mrs. Moneuse. The note was delivered to the plaintiff, without indorsement, in payment for furniture. Upon trial below, judgment was rendered in favor of the plaintiff, and the defendant appealed, contending that a note made by a husband to his wife was void, and that the note would have been transferred by a written assignment or by indorsement. On the other hand it was [???]ded that the wife became the agent of the husband in the matter, and that in all cases where a note is made payable to the person or bearer, title will vest in a third party who takes it for value by mere delivery.

abstract: Bergen, N J; Wyncoop's Drug Depot; $30,000
snippet: Bergen, N J; Wyncoop's Drug Depot; $30,000
lead_paragraph: A large building, known as Wynkoop's barn, in the town of Bergen, and used by WYNKOOP & CO., of New-York, for the storage of oils, drugs, &c., was totally destroyed by fire, together with the contents, on Thursday afternoon, involving a loss of about $30,000. A girl engaged in sealing bottles was using a kerosene lamp that leaked, and a portion of the burning wax fell into it, and set fire to some kerosene that had oozed out. The girl becoming alarmed, ran out, and the fire communicated to some inflammable oils stored on the premises, and in a few minutes the entire building was in flames. A number of buildings in close proximity were in great danger, but the firemen succeded in saving them.
headline: {'main': 'EXTENSIVE FIRE IN BERGEN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'EXTENSIVE FIRE IN BERGEN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Intervention, London Post and Herald on; Warning to South in 1860
snippet: Intervention, London Post and Herald on; Warning to South in 1860
lead_paragraph: The English Tories have again begun to talk very glibly of intervention on behalf of the South. The Morning Post, which, though it has always been an advocate of the Confederacy, speaks with far more weight and authority than the regular organ of the Davis Government, the Morning Herald, says that "there can be no doubt that the feeling in favor of intervention is growing apace. The only evidence it offers in support of this assertion is that Lord ENFIELD has presented a petition from a number of people in London -- or as it expresses it, "from the inhabitants of the Metropolis," in this sense; and that Lord BROUGHAM "has refused during the last three weeks to present similar petitions from various mercantile bodies, because he felt that the time to interfere has not yet arrived." This is not very strong proof, it must be admitted, that the feeling in favor of intervention is growing, for there is no doubt that any number of petitions of a similar character might have been got up, both amongst "the inhabitants of the Metropolis" and amongst "mercantile bodies" any day since the war begun. Moreover, the ground on which intervention is now urged is the very same on which it was urged two years ago, and is just as absurd now as it was shown to be then. It is neither more nor less than the greatness of the carnage by which the struggle is marked. It appears that the English Tories have established a maximum of slaughter which two foreign belligerents may be allowed to commit; but if they go beyond this, England is to interpose and force peace upon them by committing a little more slaughter herself. What this maximum is, they do not deign to mention. How many even England can conscientiously permit a foreign Power to kill or lose in action, has not yet been revealed; nor are we informed at what precise point in the progress of hostilities English humanity becomes so outraged, that the British Government has to fight itself to quiet the public nerves. We presume, however, that the revelation of these essential facts will be made in good time.

abstract: -- The "regular" physicians of Boston have advanced their prices for a single visit in cases of regular attendance from $2 to $3. For a first visit in consultation, the fee is fixed at from $5 to $10. For a visit in the night, or between the hours or 9 o'clock P.M. and 8 A.M., the fee will be from $5 to $10. Members of the Physicians' Association have the privilege of rendering their services gratuitously to persons in indigent circumstances, and it is held to be the duty of the practitioner in every case to make any deduction from these rates which he conscientiously believes that the circumstances of the patient render necessary. The East Boston Gas Company have advanced its price for gas to $4 per thousand. In the city proper the price is to be advanced to $2 75, -- Boston Journal, June 29.

abstract: versary of the National Association for the amendment of the Constitution of the United States, will be held on Wednesday, the 6th day of July next, at 10 o'clock A.M., in the Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, on Eighth-street, above Race, Philadelphia. The object of this meeting will be to discuss and adopt measures for most effectually securing such amendments to the Constitution of the United States as are contemplated by the association, viz: "Acknowledging Almighty God as the source of all authority and power in civil government, the Lord Jesus Christ as the Governor among the nations, and His revealed Will as the law of the land."

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Star, writing from Paris on June 10, says: "LA POMMERAIS was this morning executed at 6 o'clock, in front of La Roquette. Yesterday at 5 P.M. orders were given to carry it out, the Procureur-General having a few hours earlier announced the Emperor's decision not to alter the judgment of the Assize Court of the Seine. This was not told the unhappy convict before 5 o'clock this morning. The Governor of La Roquette then entered his cell, and briefly conveyed to him the Emperor's refusal to interfere with the decision of the law officers. LA POMMERAIS was awake when the door opened, and, on hearing his fate, merely replied, 'I am ready to meet it.' The chaplain next made his appearance. He threw himself on the prisoner's neck, and embraced him several times. A private conversation, or rather a kind of confession, ensued, which lasted for some minutes. It is not, however, confidently supposed that this proceeded from any change of faith, but rather from an impulse to speak confidentially to another human being; for the evening before, LA POMMERAIS, on being asked by the governor of the prison if he required the consolations of the Church he replied. 'Buh! religion is good for nine out children.' The conversation with the chaplain over, Mr. CLAUDE, the Director of the Police of Public Safety came forward and demanded if the convict had any revelation to make, to which an answer in the negative was given. La POMMERAIS was then handed over the executioner's assistants, who brought him into the 'robing-room.' His hands and feet were then pinioned and his hair cut. He submitted with apparent resignation to this operation. Before it was finished the Chaplain asked to cut off one lock for Mme. LA POMMERAIS. This request was granted, and before the relic was folded away, LA POMMERAIS kissed it, asking as he did so, that it should be forthwith given to his wife, from whom the priest in attendance read a most tender letter. At five minutes to six the prison doors were opened, and the condemned man was directed to proceed to the scaffold. He advanced with a firm step. His face was of a death-like pallor, and, owing to the chill air of the morning, and the light clothing which he wore, he shivered as he advanced toward the scaffold. The language of those non-official persons who assembled to witness this expiation of a greet crime was brutal to the last degree. They hissed and hooted as the convict was about to mount the ladder, and were loudest in their brutal demonstrations when the crucifix was pressed to his lips. The blade had scarcely severed his head from his body, when a rush was made to do violence to the trunk. The troops were obliged to interfere, and had some difficulty in repeling the crowd, which was excited by the sight of a 'gentleman criminal' to a pitch of savage ferocity. When all was over, the chaplain turned round, and in a loud voice, said: 'I am, I am glad to say, consoled by what has passed between us.' The Pays, in noticing this expiation of a great crime, states that the crowd retired in silence. But I am in a position to affirm that the contrary was the case. The Presse and some other journals bear out the information I have this morning received from a private source."

abstract: It is the prevailing opinion, and the more prevailing hope, in England, that the steamer now due will bring news of the thorough defeat of the Army of the Potomac. abstract: EXERCISES IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS. -- The annual exercises preceding the Fourth of July took place on Friday in the public schools of Brooklyn, and the event proved interesting to pupils, teachers and visiting friends. The usual studies were suspended and exercises, consisting of recitations, addresses, singing, and, in some cases, instrumental music, were substituted, A number of the school-rooms were finely decorated with flags, and all wore a cheerful holiday appearance. Members of the Board of Education were present, and short addresses were made. Certificates of good conduct, proficiency in studies and regular attendance were distributed among those entitled thereto. At the close of the proceedings the schools were adjourned until Tuesday next.

abstract: the Anglo-Maori War in
snippet: the Anglo-Maori War in
lead_paragraph: Our cousins over the water used to be particularly fond of abusing Americans for their too sanguine predictions touching the duration of the Southern rebellion, but it seems as if the "Britishers" themselves had no more of the prophetic gift than the Yankees, since not one of their anticipations as to the speedy close of the petty and wretched Maorian war has been realized.

abstract: a cousin by marriage to the notorious CHAMP FERGUSON, was arrested by Col. WEATHERFORD last Winter, at Burkesville, Ky., dressed in male attire, and forwarded to this city, charged with being a rebel spy. She was tried by a general court-marial, then in session in the city. The proceedings were forwarded for the approval of the proper authorities. The sentence has not yet been approved, and therefore cannot be divulged. Mrs. FERGUSON has been confined in the Military Prison since the arrest and trial. She was forwarded yesterday, under guard, to Lexington. She is a young woman, of limited education, not yet out of her teens. The expression of her face is frank and simple as a child's. One would never suspect her of being possessed of shrewdness sufficient to act the role of a successful spy. -- Louisville Journal, June 24.

abstract: Our special correspondent furnishes us with particulars of the late cavalry expedition of Gens. WILSON and KAUTZ, from which it appears that after accomplishing a work of destruction never equaled in its thoroughness, our forces met with a serious disaster on their return home, and that, too, within a short distance of our own lines.
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent furnishes us with particulars of the late cavalry expedition of Gens. WILSON and KAUTZ, from which it appears that after accomplishing a work of destruction never equaled in its thoroughness, our forces met with a serious disaster on their return home, and that, too, within a short distance of our own lines. When Gen. WILSON arrived at Reams' Station, on the Weldon Railroad, he found the whole rebel cavalry force under LEE and HAMPTON, concentrated to cut off his retreat. This force he fought with great gallantry, and repulsed all their charges and attempts to cut him to pieces. The next morning, however, before daylight, he was impetuously attacked by a large force of rebel infantry, which had reached the spot during the night. A retreat was now ordered, but the rebels having destroyed the bridges over Stony Creek, all hope of saving the artillery and trains was given up, the guns were spiked and abandoned and the wagons and ambulances were destroyed. All the wounded, too seriously injured to ride horses, fell into the hands of the enemy. Gen. KAUTZ and a large portion of his command succeeded in escaping, but up to Thursday night Gen. WILSON had not reported. On Tuesday Gen. WILSON sent for infantry support, and the Sixth Corps was sent to his relief. The latest intelligence is that they attacked the rebels with great vigor, and in the first charge captured six of the lost guns.

abstract: HEARING IN THE McCROW MURDER CASE. A hearing was had before Justice DODGE on Friday, in relation to the murder of HUGH McCROW, the facts of which case have been previously reported. CHARLES VAN SAUN (not VAN ZAUN, as before stated,) is charged with the homicide upon the evidence of MICHAEL BRADY.
lead_paragraph: HEARING IN THE McCROW MURDER CASE. -- A hearing was had before Justice DODGE on Friday, in relation to the murder of HUGH McCROW, the facts of which case have been previously reported. CHARLES VAN SAUN (not VAN ZAUN, as before stated,) is charged with the homicide upon the evidence of MICHAEL BRADY. The latter stated in his affidavit that VAN SAUN had acknowledged to him that he had shot MCCROW, and said further that the accused had made a similar acknowledgment to one ELIZA BROWN. BRADY also stated that a man named EZRA BROCKHURST had received the pistol from VAN SAUN with which the bloody deed had been done. BROCKHURST, who was in court, made affidavit that sometime in the month of June, 1863, (the month of the murder,) VAN SAUN came into the place where he was employed, No. 509 Broadway, and handed him a pistol, saying, "I have fired it two or three times round the corner, and see two or three men fall, but don't know how many I have shot." BROCKHURST kept the pistol for some time, but kept it locked up, and subsequently delivered it to a man named TURNER, who came for it in company with BRADY. Upon these affidavits, Justice DODGE committed VAN SAUN for examination this morning at 10 o'clock, and sent BRADY and BROCKHURST to the House of Detention for Witnesses.

abstract: We regret to hear of a probably serious accident on the river last night. The steamer City of Hartford, going down, was detained, so that on reaching East Haddam it was midnight; there, at the upper landing, a pleasure party of both sexes desired to be towed down to Goodspeed's, and this request was acceded to. It is said the strain was such that the bows of the boat were drawn open, letting the water in, and all hands went into the waves. The pilot, being forward, did not see the accident; screams were heard, but it was not known what was the matter until, on reaching Goodspeed's and drawing in the line, only a fragment of the wreck was found attached. How many were drowned, if any, we cannot learn. -- Hartford Times, June 28.

abstract: Chickamauga; Prisoners Shot by Rebels at; Barbarities; Shooting Prisoners at Chickamauga
snippet: Chickamauga; Prisoners Shot by Rebels at; Barbarities; Shooting Prisoners at Chickamauga
lead_paragraph: Gen. THOMAS recently sent out a fatigue party to the field of Chickamauga to inter, or rather reinter, the Union dead who fell in the fight last Fall. Most of them had been, buried by our troops after the battle of Missionary Ridge, but very lightly, and apportions of the bodies were, in a majority of cases, found protruding above the ground. The detail was accompanied by Mr. READ, the agent of the Sanitary Commission, who occupied himself in taking such notes of the bodies as might aid their friends in discovering their graves, or procuring their transmission to their homes if desired. He has recently sent in a report of his labors to Dr. NEWBERRY, the Secretary of the Commission in the West, and in it he states that they only in one instance discovered indications that any of our dead had been buried by the rebels, and in this the bodies were all found shot through the head, and their legs or arms tied or strapped together, affording all but conclusive proof that they had been massacred after capture and surrender. Incidents of this kind have frequently been reported before, but never, so far as we remember, in so authentic a shape as this. We mention this now, not for the purpose of urging upon the Government the propriety and duty of retaliation, but of placing on record, once more, an illustration of the character of the enemy with which we have to deal. The Administration has long had in its possession satisfactory evidence of the commission of the grossest atrocities by the rebels, and it has repeatedly threatened retaliation, but, so far, has never inflicted it. We have always thought, and think still, that some effort ought to have been made to inflict punishment at least on the guilty or presumably guilty parties. We think that, for instance, every prisoner taken from the gang which assaulted Fort Pillow ought to have had short shrift, and that it is neither just nor expedient nor humane to ask the negro troops and their white officers to incur greater risks than fall to the lot of the white soldiers, as long as we have it in our power to protect them from them.

abstract: This morning a terrier dog brought to the jail by one of the cooks was taken with a fit of hydrophobia, when a pan of water was given him to drink. He broke loose from the place he was tied, and ran inside the prison, first on the right-hand side, second story, where there was twelve prisoners, they scampering in every direction, climbing on the windows and to the top of the grated doors, the dog following some nearly to the top of the grates, and being kicked down by the prisoners. He then broke for the women's department, they scattering in every direction. He, however, did not enter there, but returned and entered the corridor where the murderers are confined. TUELL closed his cell door, keeping the animal out. PETER GOODIN clambered into the corridor window, the dog making several frantic attempts to get at him. GOODIN, however, kept him off by means of a tin plate he had in his hand. The dog after being beat back fell in a fit, when he was shot by Mr. FAYMAN, one of the officers of the jail. -- Washington Star, June 27.

abstract: Dix, Major-Gen.; Proceedings against
snippet: Dix, Major-Gen.; Proceedings against
lead_paragraph: The arrest of Maj.-Gen. DIX and several of his officers, as reported in the TIMES of Saturday, was made upon warrants issued on Wednesday afternoon, by City Judge RUSSELL. It will be remembered by our readers that as soon as Gov. SEYMOUR was informed that the Grand Jury had declined to investigate the seizure of the Journal of Commerce and the World newspapers, he addressed a letter to District-Attorney HALL, condemning the action of the Grand Jury, and requesting him to bring the matter before some proper Magistrate. Acting on this request, Mr. HALL made an affidavit before Judge RUSSELL, dated June 28, in which he declared, in the usual phraseology of such documents, that he had been informed that Gen. DIX, acting under instructions from the President, had ordered the siezure of the papers above named, and the arrest and incarceration of the editors. After enumerating the particulars of the arrests, and of the closing up of the offices of the World and the Journal of Commerce, the District-Attorney charges that Gen. DIX and Capt. BARSTOW are guilty of kidnapping, and other officers with Gen. DIX of inciting to a riot and forcibly detaining property: and he prays that action may be taken to sustain the dignity of the State.

abstract: The ocean monitor Puritan, two turrets, was successfully launched Saturday morning at the Continental Works, Greenpoint, in the presence of a large assemblage of people. At 9 o'clock the huge vessel glided gracefully into the water, and went half way across the river before the momentum gained in her descent could be checked. The Puritan is the largest and most powerful iron-clad ever constructed in the United States. The dimensions are as follows Length on deck, 351 feet; width, 50 feet; length of iron bull, 300 feet; measurement, about 3,000 tons. She will carry four guns, two in each turret. The ram at her bow is 19 feet in length and of enormous strength. Although intended for ocean service, the Puritan will carry no masts. The waves in a heavy sea will break over her deck, as in the case of the other monitors, the top of the iron hull being only a few inches above the surface of the water. But the apartments are so securely constructed that no leakage, it is thought, can occur even in the heaviest storm. The side armor is four feet in thickness, stronger than the combined mail of the Warrior and the Gloire. The armor on the turrets is fifteen inches thick. The pilot-house is defended by twelve-inch plates.
lead_paragraph: The ocean monitor Puritan, two turrets, was successfully launched Saturday morning at the Continental Works, Greenpoint, in the presence of a large assemblage of people. The ram at her bow is 19 feet in length and of enormous strength. Although intended for ocean service, the Puritan will carry no masts. The waves in a heavy sea will break over her deck, as in the case of the other monitors, the top of the iron hull being only a few inches above the surface of the water. But the apartments are so securely constructed that no leakage, it is thought, can occur even in the heaviest storm. abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Matanzas we have later Mexican news, giving some details of MAXIMILIAN'S progress toward the Capital, and the specially enthusiastic welcome accorded to him by the Indian population. SENTA ANNA is at St. Thomas preparing to enter upon his new duties as one of the Grand Marshals of the new Empire.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Matanzas we have later Mexican news, giving some details of MAXIMILIAN'S progress toward the Capital, and the specially enthusiastic welcome accorded to him by the Indian population. SENTA ANNA is at St. Thomas preparing to enter upon his new duties as one of the Grand Marshals of the new Empire. Gen. PEDRO SANTANA, former President of the Dominican Republic, is dead. By the Matanzas we have New-Orleans papers of the 25th, from which we make various extracts of interest, but not of special importance.

abstract: -- It is almost impossible to calculate the amount of reading matter absorbed by the American public in relation to the great national contest ROW demanding all attention. It is a curious fact that the publications having for their theme this momentous struggle are not circulated through the ordinary channels of the book trade, but are sold chiefly by agents and canvassers throughout the country, by direct application to the purchasers, and thus escape the notice that they would otherwise attract if seen in the bookstores and ordinary places of public literary resort. They are of two kinds as regards their form, being either published in numbers, as the Histories of the War, brought out by Messrs. HARPERS, Messrs. JOHNSON, FRY & Co., and many others, or are offered in complete volumes as the similar works of Messrs. HEADLEY, ABBOTT and GREELEY. The demand for the number works is said to be rather on the wane, the profound uncertainty that prevails, as to the extent they may reach if they endeavor to keep pace with the war itself, making prudent buyers cautious in incurring an outlay of unascertained extent. But the Volume Books are in the fullest tide of success, and the quantities sold far exceed anything previously known. One bookbinder in this City has done up 120,000 copies of ABBOTT's History of the War. The circulation of Mr. HEADLEY's first volume is very little inferior to this, while of HORACE GREELEY's book, business men, not ordinarily given to romance, are said to estimate the probable sale as something approaching to a quarter of a million copies.

abstract: New Rebel Invasion
snippet: New Rebel Invasion
lead_paragraph: The rebels, it appears, have undertaken an offensive operation which many people have for some time anticipated. Secretary STANTON conveys the bare information that they appeared yesterday at Martinsburgh, in the Shenandoah Valley, some dozen miles from the Potomac and Harper's Ferry; and our unofficial dispatches set forth that our small force guarding that locality has retreated to the north side of the Potomac. There are a number of highly sensational details in the telegrams. The invading army is estimated at ten thousand and at twenty thousand; the rebels have defeated SIGEL; they are going to invade Pennsylvania and Maryland, and so on. There is said to be intense excitement along the border.

abstract: Erie; Three Accidents in Two Days
snippet: Erie; Three Accidents in Two Days
lead_paragraph: THREE RAILROAD ACCIDENTS -- EXPLOSION OF AN ENGINE -- SEVERAL LIVES LOST. -- Three accidents are reported to have occurred on the Erie Railway, causing the death of several persons and involving the destruction of a considerable amount of property. The milk train, which left the depot in Jersey City at 8:45 o'clock yesterday morning with some fifteen freight cars and ten passenger cars in the rear, ran into a cattle train which was backing up at the slaughter-house, a short distance from the tunnel, demolishing a number or cars, killing a man named PURCELL in the employ of the company. Two newsboys, belonging in Paterson, were injured, one of them fatally, having had both legs badly crushed. He was sent to the New-York Hospital in a dying condition. The other boy was not dangerously injured. Quite a number of hogs were killed in the cattle train. None of the passengers were injured. The eastern bound train was delayed for some time in consequence of a car being thrown directly across the track. Some time during Saturday night a locomotive boiler is reported to have exploded on the Western Division, by which the engineer, conductor and fireman were killed. No further particulars could be ascertained. About 12 o'clock on Saturday night a passenger train in coming out of the Bergen tunnel ran into a freight train just ahead of it, breaking the head-fight on the locomotive and smashing up the rear car of the freight train.

lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the clerical and lay members of the Episcopal Diocesan Convention of New-Jersey, held immediately after the adjournment of said Convention in the city of Newark, May 26, 1864, Rev. R. M. ABERCROMBIE, Rector of St. Paul's Church, Rah- way, submitted a preamble and series of resolutions concerning the relations of the clergy to the military service, which were unanimously adopted. The preamble sets forth the sacred prerogatives of religion, and the danger of perverting them by secularization -- the necessity of a ministry for the administration of religious offices, and "the duty of the State to provide for the religious interests of its citizens." abstract: Among our telegrams yesterday were the two following dispatches, the first from Fortress Monroe, the other from Washington: -- "Maj.-Gen. BUTLER arrived at Fortress Monroe on Thursday evening, from Bermuda Hundred." "The Senate has confirmed the nomination of QUINCY A. GILLMORE, to be Major-General of Volunteers." This action of the Senate is the answer to the charges made against Gen. GILLMORE for not attacking with three thousand men the rebel line of works before Petersburgh.

abstract: Our Significance of
snippet: Our Significance of
lead_paragraph: These raids of our cavalry in Virginia have now a military significance, a practical purpose, and an immediate effect that did not appertain to many of our raids of other days. Formerly they were frequently almost purposeless, or, if they had a purpose, it was neither definite nor military. There were some exceptions to this, as in the raid of GRIERSON through Mississippi, the raid of CARTER into East Tennessee, and the raid of STONEMAN toward Richmond. But our remark will hold good as to scores and hundreds of vague raids into the Confederate territory.

abstract: Fourth of July and the War
snippet: Fourth of July and the War
lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July this year brings no such remarkable series of victories as did the corresponding date of last year, which was glorified at once by Gettysburgh and Vicksburgh -- the one saving the National Capital and the other securing the permanent triumph of our arms in the great Valley of the Mississippi. From that date to this, the Army of the Potomac has had but one great campaign, and that is yet in progress -- the campaign which opened with the opening of May, and which has been signalized by such terrible battles as those of the Wilderness, Spottsylvania, Cold Harbor, and Petersburgh. The Army of the West, since last Fourth, has had two great actions. It has sustained the reverse at Chickamauga under Gen. ROSECRANS, and won the victory of Chattanooga under GRANT. It began, in May, simultaneously with the advance of the Army of the Potomac, the campaign under SHERMAN, into Georgia, which it has carried on with eminent success, until now, as we learn officially this morning, it has entered Marietta, and is ready to take up its line of march for the Chattahochie.

abstract: In the Senate on Saturday a report from the Conference Committee on the Guerrilla Bill was concurred in. A report from the Conference Com-  mittee on the Enrollment Bill, agreeing essen- tially to the House bill, was concurred in.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate on Saturday a report from the Conference Committee on the Guerrilla Bill was concurred in. A report from the Conference Com- mittee on the Enrollment Bill, agreeing essen- tially to the House bill, was concurred in. In the evening session a number of bills were passed, including the House bill making an appropriation to carry into effect the law to prevent smuggling. The bill to establish a National Academy of Literature was postponed. The bill to provide for the completion of the Washington Aqueduct was passed. A report to adopt the House bill on emigration was concurred in. The bill to provide for the education of naval constructors and steam engineers was passed. The bill to impose a special tax on incomes was received from the House, and considered at length, but no action taken, after which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Locust Point Steamship Sunk by Collision; 19 Lives Lost
snippet: Locust Point Steamship Sunk by Collision; 19 Lives Lost
lead_paragraph: On the morning of the 3d inst. at 1 A.M., between Barnegat and Absecomb Lights, the steamship Lo- cust Point, HOFFMAN, hence 2nd inst. for New-Orleans, came in collision with the steamer Matanzas, Capt. J.RISGANG, from New-Orleans for New-York, causing the Locust Point to sink in 7 minutes, in 14 fathoms water. The Matanzas struck her amidships cutting her in two; boats were immediately lowered from the Matanzas, and after remaining around the wreck until 6 o'clock in the morning, succeeded in saving the following of the crew and passengers.

abstract: ASSAULT ON A POLICE OFFICER. -- Officer CUMMINGS, of the Eighth Precinct, attempted to arrest MARY ANN TEN BROCK, a colored woman, on Saturday night, when she made a desperate onslaught upon the officer, biting his hands, leaving off his shield and injuring his clothes. The officer was in the act of taking her in when THOMAS F[???]EBORN, also colored, stepped up and rescued her. Officer CUMMINGS rapped for assistance, and arrested both parties, and took them before Justice DODGE, who committed them, in default of $500 bail each.

abstract: The latest news from WILSON'S cavalry expe- dition is exceedingly satisfactory, and puts altogether a new complexion upon the reports which reached us on Saturday night. First of all, Gen. WILSON has rejoined the main army around Petersburgh, having got within the Union lines on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: The latest news from WILSON'S cavalry expe- dition is exceedingly satisfactory, and puts altogether a new complexion upon the reports which reached us on Saturday night. First of all, Gen. WILSON has rejoined the main army around Petersburgh, having got within the Union lines on Friday night. Instead of attempting to force his way through the strong column of rebel infantry posted at Reams' Station, Gen. WILSON determined to make his way back by a long detour -- passing by a point twenty-five miles south of Reams', where he crossed the Blackwater. His total loss during the entire raid -- including the casualties in KAUTZ's division -- being from seven hundred and fifty to one thousand men. Sixty miles of railroad were thoroughly destroyed during the expedition -- so destroyed that it would take at least forty days to repair them. WILSON brought back with him about four hundred negroes and a large number of the horses he had captured. His loss is a small wagon train used to carry ammunition -- besides his ambulance train and twelve cannon. His artillery horses were nearly all saved.

abstract: The various places of amusements yet remaining open are doing so badly that nothing but the hope of a good day's business on this, the National Festival of Independence, has induced their respective managers to persevere so long against hot weather and adverse times. After to-day there will be a general and judicious thinning out of theatres and shows. The Winter Garden, as our readers are aware, has already passed into the hands of the purifiers, and will remain closed until important changes have been effected in its internal arrangements and decorations. Mrs. WOOD's regular season came to a close on Saturday. It has been conducted with spirit and has ended prosperously. The company was not very good at the commencement, and had indeed to be reinforced for almost every new piece, but the conspicuous ability of Mrs. JOHN WOOD made all things bearable. For the present the house passes into the hands of an English opera company, composed of a portion of Mr. L.F. HARRISON's Philadelphia troupe. The opening opera is "Maritana," and although not in the managerial confidence, we think we may safely announce that the "Bohemian Girl" will speedily be produced. Mr. ANTHONY RIEFF, who has suffered and grown strong in the cause, is the musical conductor. Mile. VESTVALI has retired from Niblo's, and "Bel Demonio" gives place to the "Dukes' Motto" which is sure to draw a good house. Wallack's theatre is closed for rehearsals, but will reopen for a Summer season to-morrow night under the management of Mr. THEODORE MOSS. A new comedy, highly spoken of by the London press, will be produced. It is called the "Winning Suit." Miss AVONIA JONES plays the leading part, and will be supported by several members of the old Wallack company, and Mr. A.H. DAVENPORT, late of the Winter Garden. At the new Broadway theatre Mr. CHANFRAU takes his benefit and brings the season to a close. BOUCICAULT's five act play of the "Octoroon" is the attraction. Two performances will be given by Mr. HELLER at the Salle Diabolique, and then that establishment will shut up until September. At the Hippotheatron and the Broadway Academy of Music there are special entertainments of skill and daring, for further and more incomprehensible particulars of which we refer to our advertising columns.

abstract: CELEBRATION OF THE FOURTH IN BROOKLYN. -- The programme for celebrating the day in Brooklyn is a very meagre one. There will be no military parade. At a meeting of the officers of the Second Division it was contended that as the Fourth fell on Monday, many members of the different military organizations would leave the city on the previous Saturday for the purpose of enjoying themselves elsewhere, and would probably not return until Tuesday or Wednesday; that, therefore, there would be but a slim turn-out; and, taking this view of the matter, it was decided to postpone the parade until the 14th inst., upon which date the corner stone of the new armory in Williamsburgh will be laid. The church bells will be rung this morning, and salutes will be fired at sunrise, noon and sundown. In the evening there will be displays of fireworks on Fort Greene, and in eligible localities in Williamsburgh and Greenpoint, as selected by the Aldermen representing the Eastern District.

abstract: Alabama, the Destruction of
snippet: Alabama, the Destruction of
lead_paragraph: The pirate Alabama has at last gone to the bottom of the sea. After a bloody and lurid career of two years on the high seas in which career she has passed from one Continent to another, from the North and South Atlantic to the Indian Ocean, from the Gulf of Mexico to the China Seas, following in the wake of our commercial ships wherever they could be found, and burning and destroying them wherever they were overtaken -- she has been annihilated on the very first occasion that one of our ships-of-war was enabled to get an opportunity to measure metal with her.
