abstract: New-York; Wooster and Greene sts; $150,000
snippet: New-York; Wooster and Greene sts; $150,000
lead_paragraph: Between 9 and 10 o'clock on Monday evening a fire broke out in the large six-story brick warehouse No. 26 Wooster-street, occupied by Messrs. NEIDIG, DECKER & CO., as a place of storage for planos and general cabinet furniture. On account of the highly combustible nature of the contents, the flames spread with great rapidity, notwithstanding the efforts of the firemen. The light produced by the burning buildings added much to the illumination made by the rockets and other fireworks which the "City Fathers" caused to be burned throughout the City on that evening.

abstract: The eighty-eighth Anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in this City with less military and civic display than is usually witnessed on the Fourth of July. The absence of such glorious news as that which electrified the nation last year at this time, served to dampen in some degree that unbounded popular enthusiasm which has always hailed the recurrence of the National holiday.
lead_paragraph: The eighty-eighth Anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in this City with less military and civic display than is usually witnessed on the Fourth of July. The absence of such glorious news as that which electrified the nation last year at this time, served to dampen in some degree that unbounded popular enthusiasm which has always hailed the recurrence of the National holiday. Nevertheless, a stranger visiting our City, would have failed to notice any lack of enthusiasm. The streets were never more gaily decorated with banners and streamers, and only an experienced ear could have discerned a diminution from former years in the amount of din and racket in the streets. Of course the small and big boys were out in full force with their guns, pistols, Lilliputian artillery, torpedoes, firecrackers, and every conceivable contrivance for deafening the ear and giving nervous people the headache.

abstract: There is as yet no satisfactory reason given for the collision between the Matanzas and the Locust Point, which resulted in the sinking of the latter vessel and the loss of seventeen lives. The only blame attached to any person is to the mate, ROBY, who was lost. It was his watch, and the course of the vessel was directed by him. Capt. HOFFMAN at the [???] of the accident, was in his cabin conversing with a friend, to whom he remarked, as he was about retiring for the night, that he would step out on deck and see if everything was all right. The collision occurred while he was in the act of opening his door. The captain immediately ordered the small boats to be cut loose from their lashings, and, although he could have easily entered one of them, he refused to leave his sinking craft, and went down with her. As he could not swim, his life was saved by accidentally catching a trunk as he rose to the surface of the water. But the hero of the sad scene was the second mate, Mr. JACOB GUNSTONE, who, with the only boat afloat of the Locust Point, remained in the vicinity of the disaster until six o'clock in the morning, regardless of the fact that the Mantanzas was rapidly drifting from him. When seen in the morning he was nearly five miles distant from that vessel still endeavoring to rescue those who were yet clinging to pieces of the wreck. All credit is due to the brave man for his noble and self-sacrificing exertions. The passengers speak in high terms of praise of Capt. LIESGANG and his crew. It was principally owing to their watchful efforts that so many lives were saved. The Locust Point, although only 500 tons burden, was considered one of the staunchest vessels running between this point and New-Orleans. The following is a list of the names of the drowned:

abstract: The Inman steamer City of Washing arrived at this port yesterday morning bringing Liverpool dates to June 23d. In the House of Lords the Earl of Derby called attention to the case of a Montreal merchant named Levy, said have been arrested in Boston without cause. Earl RUSSELL said he would make inquiries into the matter. Mr. HENNESSY strongly condemned the efforts he believed Americans were making to induce emigrants to serve in the Federal army, and moved a resolution regretting the emigration from Ireland, and calling on the Government to devise some means to check it. The motion was carried.
lead_paragraph: The Inman steamer City of Washing arrived at this port yesterday morning bringing Liverpool dates to June 23d. abstract: -- Our special correspondent, writing from before Charleston on Thursday last, says: "Our guns at Cummings' Point continue to shell the city of Charleston, notwithstanding the announcement of the rebel SAM JONES that fifty Union prisoners (officers) have been placed within range of our fire." We have no other operation in the war at all analogous to this long-continued bombardment of the birthplace of the great rebellion. Naval operations were begun against the city at the close of 1861, and it is a year since Gen. GILMORE commenced its regular bombardment from land batteries. During the whole of that year our operations against it have been nearly ceaseless. The Charleston Courier of the 25th ult., heads one of its articles "Three Hundred and Fifty-first Day of the Siege." Hardly a day has passed that shot and shell have not been thrown into the city. The people that remain there have enjoyed neither rest nor safety, but have been in continual fear and peril. It were well for the wretched inhabitants, and for all concerned, that the place were captured.
lead_paragraph: -- Our special correspondent, writing from before Charleston on Thursday last, says: "Our guns at Cummings' Point continue to shell the city of Charleston, notwithstanding the announcement of the rebel SAM JONES that fifty Union prisoners (officers) have been placed within range of our fire." abstract: The London Conference has practically come to an inglorious end. It sat for some time on Wednesday, the 22nd of June, to hear the last propositions of Austria and Prussia, propositions which are described as being of a nature little less than insulting.
lead_paragraph: The London Conference has practically come to an inglorious end. It sat for some time on Wednesday, the 22nd of June, to hear the last propositions of Austria and Prussia, propositions which are described as being of a nature little less than insulting. It was to sit again on the 25th for the completion of formal business, but further negotiations are at an end. There is nothing for it now but an appeal again to the sword. Hostilities between the invaders and Denmark were to commence again on the 27th, and by that time the neutral Powers will doubtless have determined the respective parts they are to play in the second act of the tragedy.

abstract: The people of the United States will rejoice to learn, this morning, of the total destruction of the pirate Alabama, in an exciting naval fight with the United States gunboat Kearsarge, in the English Channel, nine miles off the French port of Cherbourg. SEMMES sought this fight, and his ship was cut to pieces and sunk in about an hour's ...
lead_paragraph: The people of the United States will rejoice to learn, this morning, of the total destruction of the pirate Alabama, in an exciting naval fight with the United States gunboat Kearsarge, in the English Channel, nine miles off the French port of Cherbourg. SEMMES sought this fight, and his ship was cut to pieces and sunk in about an hour's fight. The loss of the pirate was eight killed and seventeen wounded. The loss of the Kearsarge was three wounded. The English steam yacht Dearbound, belonging to and having on board a party of English, came out from Cherbourg to witness the fight. When the Alabama was found to be sinking, this vessel deliberately sent her boats to the aid of the pirate and took on board about forty of her officers and crew. The Kearsarge captured sixty-eight of the Alabama's men, and went into Cherbourg but slightly damaged. Our account is very full, especially the letter from our Paris correspondent, which is the only account received from loyal sources.

lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 21st, the Earl of DERBY called attention to the case of a Montreal merchant named LEVY, who arrived at Boston in a British passenger ship in May last, and was seized and imprisoned by a Federal officer before he had left the ship. No cause was assigned for the arrest, and after being confined for ten days, he was liberated. He (Lord DERBY) wished to know if any information had reached the Government in reference to the case, and whether reparation had been demanded or volunteered by the Federal Government.

abstract: The Fourth was observed in Jersey City by the firing of salutes, ringing of bells at sunrise, noon and sunset, and a display of fireworks at Hamilton square in the evening. During the day many thousandsof people visited picnics and other places of resort in the suburbs, and the city itself presented a rather deserted appearance. Very few casualties occurred. A boy named WATERS, residing in Railroad-avenue, shot off two fingers of his left hand. A lad, name not ascertained, fell from a tree at FATHER KELLY's picnic at Bergen, and was instantly killed. A boy named TOMMY MULLIGAN got upon the track of the New-Jersey Railroad at Bergen out, when he was struck by the engine of the 3:40 P.M. train, and had one leg cut off. He was taken to Newark. There were but three arrests made by the police for drunkenness and disorderly conduct for the twenty-four hours ending this (Tuesday) morning.

abstract: The United States transport Patapsco, Commander NEFF, arrived here yesterday morning from Point Lookout. She brought 400 rebel prisoners, who are to be transferred to Elmira, N.Y. abstract: Conference; The End of
snippet: Conference; The End of
lead_paragraph: -- The French official journals speak with great complaisance of the prospect of a war between England and the German Powers, while they all declare that France will certainly keep clear of the entanglement. The English are beginning to see that in event of such a war two or three privateers would sweep her commerce from the seas, as two or three privateers, built by her subjects and in her ports, have nearly swept the American flag from the seas. Now, this would produce an immense development of French commerce; and it is well known that the extension and enlargement of the commerce of France has been for the last ten years the principal aim of the present Emperor, in his colonial and foreign policy, in his foreign wars and aggressions, such as those in Cochin-China, in the islands of the Pacific, and on this continent. To this end he has made and is making the most gigantic efforts, and is expending vast sums of money. If an English war with Germany would practically consummate his great idea, why would he not encourage it?

abstract: "DUPLEX ELLIPTIC PICNIC." Probably the largest picnic excursion, ever arranged exclusively for the employes of a single manufacturing establishment in New-York, left the City on Saturday for MEYER'S Grove, Staten Island. It was the fourth annual excursion of a similar character which has been arranged by the Messrs. WESTS  BRADLEY, the man- ufacturers of the "Duplex Elliptic" hoop skirts.
lead_paragraph: "DUPLEX ELLIPTIC PICNIC." -- Probably the largest picnic excursion, ever arranged exclusively for the employes of a single manufacturing establishment in New-York, left the City on Saturday for MEYER'S Grove, Staten Island. It was the fourth annual excursion of a similar character which has been arranged by the Messrs. WESTS BRADLEY, the man- ufacturers of the "Duplex Elliptic" hoop skirts. The rendevous was at the foot of Chambers-street, North River, on three of the largest of barges, which had been chartered for the occasion. The number who accompanied the excursion was about twenty-four hundred, nearly all of whom were the employes of Messrs. WEST & BRADEEY's establishments. Dodworth's Band, numbering over thirty pieces, furnished the music. The barges moved down the Bay and the Kills to the grove, where the landing was made about midday. The party returned about 8 P.M., having had a day of uninterrupted enjoyment. The few guests who were fortunate enough to have invites, circulated among the unprecedented crush of "Duplex Eliptic" somewhat bewildered; large as is the number of females employed in the present factory, over three thousand will be employed in the new one which the firm is about erecting, and the next annual picnic will be a mammoth one. The invention of the "Duplex Eliptic" has largely increased the demand upon them.

abstract: In the Spanish Congress the Ministers stated, in reply to an inquiry, that the squadron in the Pacific Ocean will be reinforced, and the Chincha Islands be occupied until the assassins of JALAMBO are punished, and it is proved that the Peruvian Government was foreign to the attempt to take the life of MAZARIDO, Ex-Spanish Minister at Peru.

abstract: Renominated for Congress
snippet: Renominated for Congress
lead_paragraph: We see that Hon. SCHUYLER COLFAX has been unanimously renominated by the Union men of his district in Indiana. This will be the seventh time he has been a candidate. His constituents have good warrant for this marked and stedfast confidence in him. Few men in the public service have achieved higher success or more thoroughly earned distinction and public confidence than he. He has brilliant talents, a quick, keen and just judgment, fixed fidelity of principle and of purpose and untiring industry in the performance of public duties. As Speaker, he has won universal approbation and increased his already general and decided popularity. We give expression to these sentiments of appreciation of his character and services with the greater pleasure, because we were equally frank and explicit in expressing our disapproval of his action in offering, without consultation with his political friends, his resolution for the expulsion of Mr. LONG.

abstract: By arrival of the steamship Asia at Halifax yesterday, we have dates from Liverpool to June 25, and Queenstown 26th. The officers and crew of the Alabama captured by the Kearsarge were liberated on parole at Cherbourg. Capt. SEMMES has announced that he will embark on a new Alabama.
lead_paragraph: By arrival of the steamship Asia at Halifax yesterday, we have dates from Liverpool to June 25, and Queenstown 26th. The officers and crew of the Alabama captured by the Kearsarge were liberated on parole at Cherbourg. Capt. SEMMES has announced that he will embark on a new Alabama on the 15th of August next. It is generally believed that his next vessel will be the ex-British man-of-war Rappahannock. In London a committee has been fhrmed to present Capt. SEMMES with a handsome sword. The yacht Deerhound, which rescued Capt. SEMMES, is now thought to have been a tender to the Alabama. Capt. WINSLOW, of the Kearsarge, says the reason why he did not pursue the Deerhound was, that he did not believe any one carrying the flag of the Royal Yacht Squadron could act so dishonorably. The superiority of the Kearsarge seems to have attracted the attention of the English Parliament. In the House of Commons Lord HAY called the attention of the Government to the action and asked whether they would continue building vessels which could neither fight nor swing. The Admiralty are said to be anxious to examine the methoA which was used to strengthen the sides of the Kearsarge. The first English iron-clad is said to be a success. The Dano-German Conference held its last sitting on the 25th ult. It has succeeded in doing nothing, and hostilities will probably be immediately resumed. The documents relating to the Conference were to have been presented to Parliament on the 27th inst., the day after the Asia left. This German Powers, it is asserted, are still prepared to treat upon a line to demarkation, and to conclude an armistice for two months. Should Denmark accept these terms peace may yet be preserved. The new steamer Yeddo, believed to have been built for the rebels, at Bordeaux, is said to have left that port for Amsterdam. The death of the King of Wertemberg is announced.

abstract: the invasion of
snippet: the invasion of
lead_paragraph: We trust that the nerves of people at the North, are by this time sufficiently braced to enable them to witness the pending "invasion" of Maryland and Pennsylvania, without tremor or anxiety. It is on many accounts one the most desirable things that could have happened, and we, for our part, sincerely hope that the invading force numbers 20,000, as some say, rather than 6,000; as others believe. It must not be forgotten that the more rebels enter Maryland, the less there are in front of Richmond, and it is there that the heart of the rebellion lies. This is no longer a matter of dispute. It has been demonstrated by the desperate tenacity with which LEE holds his ground. If it was not of vital importance to him to be where he is, he would be elsewhere. If he thought the Confederacy could be saved by invading the North, he would now be on the Potomac, not with a single division, but with his whole army. Of this we may be sure. So that if we have 20,000 rebels in Maryland, and do not weaken GRANT in order to repel them, LEE is to all intents and purposes weakened to that extent.

abstract: There is no interesting news from the Army of the Potomac. Our special correspondent gives a readable description of the manner in which the Fourth of July was observed. Salutes were fired morning, noon and night, from double-shotted guns, right into the teeth of the enemy, who made no reply. We have private information to the effect that such results will soon be attained by Gen. GRANT as will greatly gratify all loyal hearts.

abstract: Intercepted Mail; Richmond Affairs
snippet: Intercepted Mail; Richmond Affairs
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent, H.J.W., at Gen. BUTLER's headquarters sends us several letters taken from a rebel carrier who had run the picket line with a large mail intended for Europe. He got into Norfolk, where he was fortunately caught and the contents of his mailbag were very naturally diverted from their original destination. Among the letters which have fallen to our lot is one from the Richmond correspondent of the rebel organ in London, the Index. It lacks the first page which bears the date, but as it can hardly be more than ten days old, its statements possess considerable interest and significance. The following paragraph which was undoubtedly penned before the effect of the recent raids upon the railroads had been fully felt, is important:

abstract: Patience Necessary
snippet: Patience Necessary
lead_paragraph: What now is specially needed is patience on the part of the people. Let loyal men throughout the North but possess their souls with the resolute spirit of their great military leader, and it is certain that the rebellion cannot hold out many months longer. We don't say this with any prophesying disposition. Predictions lie like broken potsherds along the whole path of this war. All sensible men have long since ceased to value them, come from what quarter they may. But a mathematical calculation from settled data is not a prediction. The present situation admits of such calculation, and therein it differs from all that have preceded it.
headline: {'main': 'Patience Necessary The Altered Situation-Final Success Sure.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Patience Necessary The Altered Situation-Final Success Sure.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wurtemburg, King of
snippet: Wurtemburg, King of
lead_paragraph: By arrival of the steamship Asia we have news of the death of King WILLIAM I. of Wurtemberg. He was born on the 27th of September, 1781, and in 1816 was appointed to the throne, succeeding his father, FREDERICK II., who had joined the cause of the allies. He granted the present liberal constitution in 1819, a permanent modification of which was unsuccessfully attempted by the estates during the revolutionary period of 1848-9. Always thoughtful and caring for his subjects, he was a most popular monarch and was beloved and respected by all his people. The news of his death was received with manifestations of deep regret and he will be long remembered as a just and upright King, who had always in view the welfare of his country and his people.
headline: {'main': 'Death of the King of Wurtemburg.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Death of the King of Wurtemburg.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The ablest State paper Lord RUSSELL was ever known to indite, was that in which he gave Europe good and sufficient reasons why the conference proposed by the Emperor of the French, a few months ago, should not be held. It was as clear a triumph of diplomatic argument as the history of modern Europe supplies. But see how NAPOLEON is avenged on his adversary to-day. This conference, which the Halifax telegraph this morning informs us finally broke up on the afternoon of Saturday, the 26th of June, was an expedient of Lord RUSSELL's own. What has it accomplished? It has enraged the Germans, and spurred their ambition. It has weakened the Danes, and left them thus far as isolated from European sympathy as before. It has estranged the good-will of France, and destroyed the entente cordiale. And, finally, from being a pacific conference, authoritatively speaking for Europe, it has drawn England herself into the vortex of war.

abstract: -The County Volunteer Committee open their recruiting office again to-day. They have on hand $465,000; but they need about five times that sum to insure the thorough success of the work they have on hand. That work is of a two-fold character. It means the furnishing of willing, active men for the National army as fast as they are wanted from the City and County of New-York. It means also the relief of the City and County of New-York from the draft. Surely these are objects that commend themselves to public sympathy and support. The American Exchange Bank yesterday subscribed $50,000 to the Volunteer Loan Fund.

abstract: Alabama, Deerhound, Yacht, Owned by Fraser. Trenholm >amp; Co.
snippet: Alabama, Deerhound, Yacht, Owned by Fraser. Trenholm >amp; Co.
lead_paragraph: -- We learn that the British yacht Deerhound, which happened to be so opportunely near the Alabama during her fight with the Kearsarge, and which rescued her commander, and at his urgent request took him into a British harbor of refuge, is owned by the firm of FRASER, TRENHOLM & CO., of Liverpool, who are the rebel agents for that port, and that she is thus almost as really rebel property as the Alabama herself. It probably was not wholly accidental that she happened to be on the spot at that particular time.

abstract: Maximilian and his Subjects
snippet: Maximilian and his Subjects
lead_paragraph: -- We have news to-day of the arrival of the new Emperor and Empress of Mexico at their Capital, and also details of the reception accorded to them at the chief points along their journey inland. What the Court journalist relates would seem to indicate that their Majesties assume a more than ordinary affability of manner and behavior in mixing with their new subjects. Whether the latter are found to come up to the full measure of loyal enthusiasm expected from them, it is difficult to derive from the highly-flavored Court Circular which records the Imperial progress thus far. There seems, however, to have been a tolerably effective display made at the Capital, as well as at other points on the route. And the aristocracy appear to have been fully alive to the occasion. Imperial decorations are already the order, and up to this writing all is apparently serene with the new Sovereigns.

abstract: Raiders North; Policy of Pennsylvania
snippet: Raiders North; Policy of Pennsylvania
lead_paragraph: We would respectfully suggest to the Pennsylvanians the propriety of keeping their militia under arms, or at least such portion of it as they think necessary to protect them from rebel raids, until the end of the campaign. This is the third Summer that they have been terribly frightened by an advance of the Confederates up the Shenandoah Valley, and it has been well known, ever since GRANT's campaign opened, that it was perfectly feasible for the rebels to make a dash into Maryland with a small foree, if they chose to do so. There is no way of guaranteeing that no body of them, great or small, shall under any circumstances cross the Potomac. There is, therefore, a touch of the comical -- to use a mild term -- in this calling out of the militia every year, after the enemy has actually crossed the border, and when he is threatening the State Capital, and when about thirty-six or twenty-four hours remain for recruiting, arming, equipping and drilling them -- a short space, it will be admitted, for the organization of a force which is expected to stand in the open field against such troops as EARLY's or EWELL's. What makes the matter worse, is that the volunteers are called out just at the moment when they themselves, as well as their friends and neighbors, are terribly scared, and busily engaged in removing their horses and other valuables, and when the air is thick with wild rumors of the enemy's strength and ferocity. They consequently "fly to arms," with imaginations in a splendid state of excitability, to march under officers whom they have perhaps never seen, and in whom it is quite safe to say they place no confidence, and meet the foe, as he advances, without drill, discipline or organization.

abstract: says Slavery Exists but in Name; Rebels Playing Possum
snippet: says Slavery Exists but in Name; Rebels Playing Possum
lead_paragraph: Capt. SEMMES, we are told by the London Daily News, on landing at Southampton, "anxiously asked what the people of England thought of the South, and said that Slavery, existed there but in name." Our intelligent Paris correspondent, "Malakoff," stated in a recent letter that the Secessionists in France now agree in representing that Slavery has been destroyed by the war, and no longer touches the merits of the case between the North and the South. The pirate in England, and the plotters in France, alike see the necessity of the subterfuge. It is felt that the Anti-Slavery spirit of the masses of the two nations is the chief obstacle to the recognition of the "Confederacy." It is realized that it is vain to continue the effort to change that spirit. A turn, therefore, is made; and it is pretended that Slavery is virtually at an end, and is no longer a matter of any practical account anyway.

abstract: DEATH BY INJURIES. -- Coroner BARRETT concluded an inquest yesterday, at No. 112 Second-street, E.D., on the body of Mrs. MARY ANN VYSE, 64 years of age, who came to her death by injuries. Mrs. V., in company with several members of her family, was out sailing on the East River, on the 4th inst., and came in collision with a schooner. Mrs. VYSE was knocked overboard, receiving injuries which subsequently caused her death. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

abstract: The news from the Upper Potomac this morning can barely be said to have taken a more definite shape than heretofore -- although we have a statement that yesterday the raiders appeared in considerable force five miles from Frederick City, that our forces discovering the rebel strength, retired, and were followed by the enemy to within one mile of the town. At this point, however, their progress seems to have been arrested by Gen. WALLACE, who was in a position effectually to foil the rebel plans.

At this point, however, their progress seems to have been arrested by Gen. WALLACE, who was in a position effectually to foil the rebel plans.

abstract: Matter of Amor J. Williamson. -- The argument on the return of the habeas corpus issued in this case for the relief of Mr. Williamson, was yesterday postponed until to-day. It will be remembered that Mr. Williamson, as one of the old Tax Commissioners, refused to deliver up the books and papers of the office as directed by an order of Justice Barnard. He was in consequence committed as for a contempt. He now claims that the writ of error allowed by Judge Davies, of the Court of Appeals, operates as a stay of proceedings, and that he should be accordingly discharged until after the case is disposed of on that proceeding.

abstract: LAWRENCE MORAN, a dock laborer, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Officer HANIFER, charged with having stolen a trunk containing the sum of $15,000. The circumstances attending the alleged theft are as follows: On Wednesday last Mr. J.W. GLEASON arrived in this city from Havana on the steamship Ocean Queen. Mr. GLEASON went ashore at Pier No. 3 North River, where he employed a hackman named DAVID JOHNSON, to obtain from the steamer his baggage, consisting of two trunks, and for that purpose the baggage checks were delivered to the driver. The latter proceeded to the steamer, got one of the trunks from the hold and deposited it on the dock; while he was gone for the other one, it is alleged that MORAN, who was at work on the pier, seized and carried away the trunk which Mr. GLEASON says contained the above sum in United States bonds and notes. When MORAN was arrested yesterday he denied, at first, knowing anything about the matter. Subsequently he stated to the officer that he could take him to the place where the property was deposited. At a house in Washington-street the stolen trunk was found secreted under a bed. It was conveyed to the Twenty-sixth Precinct Station-house, but owing to the fact that Mr. GLEASON was not in attendance, no examination of the trunk was made at the time. MORAN has been committed to await the result.

abstract: the Situation in
snippet: the Situation in
lead_paragraph: The sinking of the Alabama by the Kearsarge appears to have been a source of very great mortification among the foreign friends of the rebels. It is amusing to read the comments of the English papers which represent that class, and to see the misstatements which they make, the contradictions of each other, which they are not careful enough to avoid, and the shifts and excuses which they are fertile in, to lessen, if possible, the pain of the blow. They universally agreed at first that the Kearsarge was badly disabled in the fight. In fact, to read the accounts, one would think that her victory was quite accidental. They also were in one accord that the Alabama was entirely overmatched, and that the Kearsarge had "higher steam power and rate of speed, a crew nearly double that under Capt. SEMMES," and heavier guns.

abstract: Morris, Gen Geo P; Reeder, Ex-Gov A H, of Kansas
snippet: Morris, Gen Geo P; Reeder, Ex-Gov A H, of Kansas
lead_paragraph: GEORGE P. MORRIS died at his residence at 1 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, the 6th inst., aged 62 years. Mr. MORRIS was born at Philadelphia on the 10th of October, 1802. At an early age he removed to New-York, where, when in his fifteenth year, he commenced his literary career by writing verses for the New-York Gazette. In August, 1823, in conjunction with SAMUEL WOODWORTH, he commenced the publication of the New-York Mirror, a journal which employed some of the best literary talent of the country, and was one of the most prominent periodicals of its class, until Dec. 31, 1842, when it was discontinued under the financial disasters of the times. In 1843, he associated himself with Mr. WILLIS in the publication of the New-York Mirror. In 1844 he established a daily paper called the Evening Mirror. At the close of 1845 he commenced alone a weekly journal called the National Press, the title of which he changed in 1846 to that of the Home Journal, and from that time until his death he and Mr. WILLIS conducted it. Though well known as a journalist, he was much more widely known as a song-writer, and as such was one of the most popular of his day. Millions of copies of his "Woodman Spare that Tree" are said to have been circulated, and, with others, as "We Were Boys Together," "Land, Ho!" "Long Time Ago," "The Origin of Yankee Doodle," "My Mother's Bible," &c., proved sources of great profit to their publishers. The Melodies for many of his songs were written by BALFE, Sir JOHN STEPHENSON and other distinguished English composers, and have been sung in public by MALIBRAN, RUSSELL, Madame ANNA BISHOP and many other celebrated vocalists. Various editions of his poems have been published, including one in 1840 with illustrations by WEIR and CHAPMAN. In 1853 he published a volume entitled "The Deserted Bride and other Poems," and he afterwards edited a volume of "American melodies." In 1837 he produced a successful drama, entitled "Brier Cliff," founded on incidents in the American Revolution. In 1842, he wrote the libretto of the opera of "The Maid of Saxony." He has also published a volume of prose sketches, entitled The Little Frenchman and his Water Lots. Mr. MORRIS was for some time a Brigadier-General in the New-York State Militia. For many years he resided at Undercliff, a country seat on the Hudson, nearly opposite West Point.

abstract: 1st Anniversary Dinner of Alumni
snippet: 1st Anniversary Dinner of Alumni
lead_paragraph: FIRST ANNUAL DINNER OF THE ALUMNI OF ST. JOHN's. -- The first annual dinner of the Alumni Association of St. John's College was given last evening at Delmonico's. About sixty gentlemen, including invited guests, sat down to an elegant entertainment, which was enlivened by numerous toasts and speeches. Among the guests were Bishop ROSECRANS, of Cincinnati; Bishop BAYLEY, of Newark; Col. MARTIN MCMAHON, of Gen. DIX's Staff, and Rev. Mr. DALY. Mr. THEBAND, President of the association, opened the festivities with a congratulatory address to the alumni of the college, and gave as the first toast the President of the United States, which was drunk with great enthusiasm. The remaining toasts related exclusively to the college, its founders and patrons.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR in response to the call of the President for 12,000 militia from this State, to serve for one hundred days to repel the rebel advance into Maryland, telegraphed on Wednesday to Gens. SANDFORD and DURYEA, to make arrangements to comply with immediate "marching orders." Inspector-General MILLER is now at the Metropolitan Hotel, where officers of our City regiments who desire to tender their commands can report. It is expected the interior counties of the State will furnish, this year, their portion of the 100 days' militia. The record shows that on former occasions every call for militia, with two exceptions, has been met only by New-York and Brooklyn regiments. Under the call of 1861 for three months' men, the 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 12th, 55th, 69th, 71st and 79th responded. Under the call of 1862, the 7th, 8th, 11th, 12th, 22d, 37th and 71st entered the service. Under the call of 1863, for 30 days' men, the 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 12th, 22d, 37th, 55th, 69th and 84th responded. In 1861 the 22d and 37th Regiments were not organized, and of course could not respond to the call of that year. The 84th was organized in 1863, and entered the service soon after. With the exception of the above regiments and the Brooklyn regiments, but two militia regiments, (the 20th from Ulster County, and the 25th from Albany,) have left the State under the call of the Governor. Several of the above regiments, upon their return home after their temporary term of service had expired, reorganized and enlisted for the war. Gen. SANDFORD has returned from Albany, whore he has been in consultation with the Governor, and this morning at 10 o'clock a meeting officers of the First Division will be held at the General's headquarters to designate the regiments that are to serve in the present emergency. The different commands of the division have reported over 10,000 men ready for duly, of which, probably, not more than 5,000 will be required to enter the service. Although the call was for 100 days' men, still negotiations are pending between the State and National authorities as to the time of service, and it is not yet settled whether the service will be for 30, 60 or 100 days. The matter, it is expected, will be definitely arranged to-day, when Gen. SANDFORD will issue an order designating the time the regiments are to serve.

abstract: The attempt on the part of Gen. SMITH to carry one of the enemy's salients in his front on Thursday night, resulted in more casualties than was at first believed. Not less than 150 men were wounded, principally by shells, and, with scarcely an exception, the injuries were of a most terrible character.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met yesterday. The Board of Aldermen referred a resolution to give E. JONES & CO., Corporation Printers, the Common Council printing, at prices heretofore paid. The Comptroller was requested to pay the beneficiaries of the Relief Fund for the time intervening between the recent exhaustion of the fund and its replenishment, by the issuance of the No. 9 bonds. A proposition from D.D. BADGER, to clean the streets for $300,000 per annum, provided that he can have the sweepings, was referred. A message was received from the Mayor, recommending that market stalls be let by auction, instead of prescribed rates per foot of frontage. Referred. A communication was received from District-Attorney A.O. HALL, stating that the executrix of the will of the late JOHN ALLAN possesses an original letter from Washington to the Common Council of New-York, which is believed to have been surreptitiously abstracted from the City archives, and suggesting that the Corporation Counsel be directed to take steps for its recovery. The letter was bid for recently, Mr. HALL states, by an autograph-gatherer, at the price of $2,050, which was declined, in consequence of the doubtful question of ownership. Referred to the Committee on Law. Both boards declared vacant the position of Assistant Engineer of the Fire Department, held by JOHN BAULCH, now in the Government service at Fortress Monroe, and confirmed the nomination of BERNARD KINNEY, made by the Fire Department, to fill the vacancy. Mr. BAULCH's resignation of the office was misdirected to the Board of Representatives, and therefore could not be received by the Common Council. Both boards adopted resolutions of respect to the memory of the late JOHN CLANCY, and in the Board of Aldermen Mr. JONES made an eloquent speech eulogistic of the character of the deceased. The Board of Councilmen adopted resolutions expressive of regret at the death of Col. PATRICK KELLY, killed at Petersburgh; and also adopted the resolution to aid families resident here of volunteers credited to Brooklyn, provided the Brooklyn authorities will reciprocate by aiding families resident there of volunteers credited to this City. Both boards adjourned to Thursday next, at 2 P.M.

abstract: The Invasion of
snippet: The Invasion of
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a variety of reports, by telegraph and by mail, purporting to supply some details of the progress of the rebel raid on the Upper Potomac. The most direct and apparently authentic of these reports represents the rebels in considerable force near Frederick City. Five miles from that place an engagement or skirmish took place yesterday, and late reports represent the rebels as being within one mile of the town where Gen. WALLACE is said to have checked their progress -- the sick and the Government stores, meanwhile, having been removed to avoid capture. Apart from this report, however, the stories received by telegraph are sufficiently conflicting to bewilder any one seeking intelligible information. The only way in which we could expect to be furnished with trustworthy detailed intelligence is, for the moment, closed against us. The telegraph wires are either cut or in possession of the rebels both east and west of Maryland Heights, where Gen. SIGEL has posted himself; and the opportunity that officer has of watching the enemy's movements is practically lost, so far as enabling the military authorities or the general public to judge of the real nature of the emergency. We assume, however, from all that is yet reported, that Gen. SIGEL holds Maryland Heights without difficulty, and that, even if HUNTER is not already close upon the rear of the rebel raiders, there is no danger of any disaster to the force under SIGEL's command. The position is one of no common natural strength, and it would not be worth while for EWELL or EARLY, or whoever commands the rebel army, to waste time and strength in assailing it. From the accounts before us we can form, as yet, only a vague conjecture as to the numerical strength of the invading army. The more sober statements place it at 7,000 cavalry and infantry. The sensational reports fix it at from 30,000 to 40,000. The readiest way to bring these figures to a common-sense test is to ask, what the rebels -- be they many or few -- have been about since Saturday last? All the accounts agree that they have been plundering indiscriminately at every point they have touched; that they have shown almost a total disregard of everything like regular army discipline, such as even marked their former raids; and, beyond all, that they have been seen driving large herds of horses and cattle across the river above and around Hagerstown, toward the entrance to the Shenandoah Valley. All this certainly goes to prove anything but the presence of a large and thoroughly organized corps of regulars. Or at least it would seem to prove anything but a deliberate scheme of invasion, having any higher object than the recruitment of a used-up cavalry division or two, and the procurement of food and clothing for a few thousand of the starving ragamuffins who were sent in pursuit of HUNTER. At Washington, reports of the rapid advance of HUNTER toward the rebel rear appear to be fully credited. On what foundation these reports rest we find it utterly impossible to divine. They may be thoroughly trustworthy; but we are not disposed to be sanguine about it. The chances seem at the moment not unfavorable for EARLY'S escape whenever he pleases to go, with a very considerable amount of plunder, as it is open to him, we should judge, to take whichever side of the Blue Ridge may seem most advantageous in his retreat.

abstract: tit-for-tat; Ship Florence case
snippet: tit-for-tat; Ship Florence case
lead_paragraph: We spoke, a short time since, about the decision of the English Court of Queen's Bench in the case of the pirates of the J.C. Gerity, and about the construction placed by that court on the Extradition Treaty between our country and England, and we showed that the effect of that decision, if followed by our courts, was to make the treaty inapplicable even to the crimes specified in it, when they were committed on the high seas, and that our courts, if they followed that decision, must change the views of the treaty on which they had hitherto acted.
headline: {'main': 'The Extradition Treaty Tit for Tat.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Extradition Treaty Tit for Tat.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. P.L. ROGERS, well known in this City as an enterprising clothing merchant, died on Wednesday last, in consequence of injuries received by being thrown from his carriage while riding, near New-Rochelle, on Monday, July 4. The horse which Mr. ROGERS was driving was a spirited animal, and becoming frightened at a passing carriage shied suddenly, throwing Mr. ROGERS and the boy with him violently to the ground. The boy escaped injury, but Mr. ROGERS fell upon his head, breaking his collar-bone and sustaining a concussion of the brain, which resulted in his death. Mr. ROGERS was an Irishman by birth, having been born in the North of Ireland in 1814. When about twenty years of age he came to this country and established himself in the clothing business. His energy and industry in time established for him a reputation of which an ample fortune was the reward. He leaves a wife and large family to mourn his untimely death.

abstract: and Gen Gov; Gen Dix and Marshall Murray; Conflict of Authority
snippet: and Gen Gov; Gen Dix and Marshall Murray; Conflict of Authority
lead_paragraph: The conflicts between the State and National authorities which are taking place in the cases of Gen. Dix and Marshal MURRAY, illustrate very thoroughly the extent of the misfortune under which the country labors now, and has labored ever since the beginning of the war, in having no honest and respectable "opposition." There has been no such thing as criticism of the acts of the Government by men who were known to be sincerely desirous of attaining the same ends by different means, and of whose political integrity, patriots of all parties could feel satisfied. There is nothing in the whole history of the war clearer or more undoubted, than that the party which, during the last two years, has claimed for itself the status and honors of a "Constitutional opposition," was at the outset openly, and is still secretly, opposed to any attempt to restore the Union, by any means which do not involve an alteration of the Constitution under Southern dictation. We all know that nine-tenths of those who now assail the Administration, ostensibly for the alleged unconstitutionality of its acts, are persons who, in 1861, heartily approved of secession, and defended the right of the South to break up the Government. There is hardly one of the Democratic orators or writers who now occupy themselves in "expounding and defending" the organic law, and making their professed reverence for it a shield for their attacks on the Administration, who did not in 1861, either publicly or privately, express his deliberate approval of the attempt of the South to destroy our political system.
headline: {'main': 'New-York and the General Government The Conflict of Authority.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'New-York and the General Government The Conflict of Authority.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The English seem to be gradually waking up to the fact that we far excel them in naval matters. The Manchester Examiner admits the superiority ...
lead_paragraph: The English seem to be gradually waking up to the fact that we far excel them in naval matters. The Manchester Examiner admits the superiority of the Kearsage and the worth of the "chain armor" used by her in the fight with the Alabama. It also mentions the fact that not a vessel in the British Navy carries a 11-inch gun, while the Kearsarge has two of them. It also imagines that when she was recently at Cork, and examined by the Commander of H.M.S. Hawke, who reported to the Admiralty that she had no more effective guns than the ordinary 68-pounders of the British Navy, that she used the special contrivance she is fitted up with for raising and lowering her great guns, and kept them snugly stowed away below deck.
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Evening Post of Thursday proposes that Mr. ADAMS should demand the delivery of SEMMES and of the other prisoners rescued by the yacht Deerhound after the sinking of the Alabama, and that, failing compliance, he should demand his passports and we should go to war.
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post of Thursday proposes that Mr. ADAMS should demand the delivery of SEMMES and of the other prisoners rescued by the yacht Deerhound after the sinking of the Alabama, and that, failing compliance, he should demand his passports and we should go to war. Provoking as the conduct of the Deerhound was, and richly as it may deserve punishment, there is, however, no use in our losing our senses over it. In our quarrels with England, as well as with everybody else, we must keep within the law, as, situated as we are at present, we might, more than anybody else, suffer from disregard of it. There is no law on which we could base such a demand as the Post suggests.

abstract: The Asia's mail, which arrived yesterday, brought much additional matter of interest, relating in great part to the engagement between the Kearsarge and the Alabama.
lead_paragraph: The Asia's mail, which arrived yesterday, brought much additional matter of interest, relating in great part to the engagement between the Kearsarge and the Alabama. We publish ample details of the different views and speculations to which the fight has given birth on the other side of the Atlantic. By telegraph from Port au Basque, in the St. Lawrence, we have European news brought by the Nova Scotian, which left Liverpool on the 28th, two days later than the Asia. By way of Cape Race, the Peruvian brings news two days still later than the Nova Scotian. Both vessels belong to the Montreal line; the first-named having taken the place of the disabled steamer, (reported by the Asia.) The news is meagre, and as relates to the vexed Dano-German question, altogether misty and unsatisfactory. It seems, judging from the tone of the London Times, that the British Government are backing down from their supposed determination to stand by Denmark. The Tories, taking advantage of this indecision, have resolved on bringing on a question of non-confidence in Parliament; but, as we gather from the Peruvian's skeleton report, they are not likely to command a majority -- so that Ministers are probably safe for the time. A Paris paper gives a report that two rebel cruisers are off Cherbourg watching for the Kearsarge.

abstract: In the House of Commons, June 23, Sir J. HAY asked the Secretary to the Admiralty whether the attention of Her Majesty's Government had been drawn to the report of an action which took place last Sunday between the United States frigate Kearsarge and the Confederate ship Alabama; and whether they ...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, June 23, Sir J. HAY asked the Secretary to the Admiralty whether the attention of Her Majesty's Government had been drawn to the report of an action which took place last Sunday between the United States frigate Kearsarge and the Confederate ship Alabama; and whether they had considered the report of the Commander-in-Chief at Devonport on the preparation for battle of Her Majesty's ship Research; whether, as the last-named report showed that this class of ship would not fight her guns with advantage, and the first-named report showed that she would easily be destroyed in action, Her Majesty's Government would continue to build ships which could not be expected either to fight or swim; and further asked, as the advantage of guns of large calibre had been so clearly shown in the above-named action, whether Her Majesty's Government would at once obtain a proper supply of large rifled guns for the service of the navy.

abstract: The second supplementary draft in the Third Congressional District, to make up the deficiency in the quota under the last call for troops, was made yesterday morning, at the headquarters of Provostmarshal BOOTE, in Washington-street.
lead_paragraph: The second supplementary draft in the Third Congressional District, to make up the deficiency in the quota under the last call for troops, was made yesterday morning, at the headquarters of Provostmarshal BOOTE, in Washington-street. There was no excitement, and in fact very little interest taken in the drawing. The deficiency was but twelve, and 100 per cent. additional was added, making the entire number of names drawn twenty-four. The Second Ward was first drawn from; one thousand seven hundred and twenty-eight names being placed in the wheel, from which twelve were drawn, as follows:

abstract: THE BROOKLYN CHURCHES. The Second Presbyterian Church is to be closed until September.
lead_paragraph: THE BROOKLYN CHURCHES. -- The Second Presbyterian Church is to be closed until September. The pastor, Rev. Dr. WEST, is spending his vacation in the country. The pulpit of the First Presbyterian Church (Rev. Dr. VAN DYKE,) will be supplied during the present and next month by Rev. Dr. PLUMMER, of Baltimore. The State-street Congregational Church will dispense with Sunday evening service in July. Rev. Dr. ROCKWELL, of the Central Presbyterian Church, and Rev. C.S. ROBINSON, of the Henry-street Presbyterian Church, intend to leave next week for a trip to Lake Superior. Rev. Mr. LOWRY, of the Hanson-place Baptist Church, expects to be absent during August, and Sunday evening services during that month will be omitted.

abstract: Although our correspondent tells us that "all quiet" is still the formula of the reports from the Army of the Potomac, and although there has been a long pause in the operations of the main force under GRANT's immediate eye, we are led ...
lead_paragraph: Although our correspondent tells us that "all quiet" is still the formula of the reports from the Army of the Potomac, and although there has been a long pause in the operations of the main force under GRANT's immediate eye, we are led to infer that the "quiet" will be broken before long, and that the comparative inactivity of the past few weeks will give place to offensive action, regardless of the strategic movements of LEE to compel the withdrawal of troops for the defence of the national capital, or in order to repel the so-called invasion. The public may be safely assured that Gen. GRANT has not withdrawn his mind even momentarily from the immediate task before him, on account of the actual raid itself, or the sensational reports of nervous State officials and excited newsmen.

abstract: New-York; Woman Killed by Machinery
snippet: New-York; Woman Killed by Machinery
lead_paragraph: FRIGHTFUL ACCIDENT -- A WOMAN KILLED BY MACHINERY. -- A woman, aged about 30 years, whose name was unknown, yesterday called on Mr. D.G. McCUTTER, of No. 110 Liberty-street, for the purpose of obtaining employment as a domestic. She had been recommended by the Superintendent of the Flatbush Railroad to Mr. MCCUTTER, and the latter engaged her on condition that his wife was satisfied, and the woman left for the avowed purpose of calling upon the wife. It appears, however, that she proceeded to the rear basement of premises No. 112 Liberty, (next door,) descended a dark stairway, and while groping her way her clothes caught on an upright shaft which was at the time revolving at the rate of about fifty revolutions per minute. This shaft was a part of the machinery of Messrs. ALLEN & TAYLOR's saleratus manufactory. The terrible shrieks of the unfortunate woman speedily brought the engineer to the spot, and as soon as possible the engine was stopped. Life, however, was extinct, and the body and limbs were most shockingly mangled. From the investigation made by Coroner RANNEY, it would seem that her hoop-skirt was caught on the shaft, and in that situation she was whirled round and round for the space of two or three minutes. Seven or eight steel hoops of her skirt were found twisted into a rope and wound, by the force of the machinery, so tightly around her lower limbs, that one of them was cut off and the other nearly so. Deceased has left one child which is at a charitable institution in Flatbush. Her husband died several months since.

abstract: -- There was something not very easily understood in the first accounts of the Alabama and Kearsarge fight, when it was represented that a shot from the former "penetrated the sides of our ship till it struck the chain-plating." The affair is explained however, in the telegraphic abstract of Capt. WINSLOW's letter which we get by the Nova Scotian. Capt. WINSLOW says that, in "defence of the engines on the outside, the Kearsarge had 'stopped' up and down her sheet chains. These were stopped with marline and eye bolts, which extended some twenty feet. This was done by the hands of the Kearsarge. The whole was covered by light plank, to prevent dirt collecting. It was for the purpose of protecting the engines when there was no coal in the upper part of the bunkers, as was the case when the action took place."
lead_paragraph: -- There was something not very easily understood in the first accounts of the Alabama and Kearsarge fight, when it was represented that a shot from the former "penetrated the sides of our ship till it struck the chain-plating." lead_paragraph: Were William street the criterion, we should say that the Northern mind had lost its power of foresight. The doings there are just such as might be expected of men as blind as bats to what may happen next month or next week -- of bipeds who have somehow lost the great attribute of humanity, the "large discourse looking before and after."

abstract: Conference of Sovereigns, the
snippet: Conference of Sovereigns, the
lead_paragraph: The recent meeting of the sovereigns of Austria, Russia and Prussia, at Kissingen, is viewed by Western Europe with suspicion, despite the assurance of its being a mere social reunion. The meeting of the rulers of these identical States at Verona, in 1822, had, it was avowed, no more political significance than the present one, and yet it led to the formation of a great coalition, and to the overthrow of constitutionalism in Spain.

abstract: Five locomotives and about one hundred cars are running continually between City Point and Clark's Station -- six miles out on the Petersburgh Railroad -- transporting supplies and forage for men and animals. Other preparations are being made at that point to a permanent occupation of City Point. A frame building, containing four rooms, about fifteen feet square, is being erected near the dock, to accommodate the United States mails and the employes of the railroad, which is one good-sized straw showing the direction of the wind.

abstract: Springfield, Mass; Dan Mace vs Gen Butler; Trot
snippet: Springfield, Mass; Dan Mace vs Gen Butler; Trot
lead_paragraph: The contest between these two renowned trotters, which took place on the Fourth, attracted a large crowd of spectators, owing to the fame of the competitors, and the determination evinced by each to carry off the prize which was a purse of $1,000 -- $800 to the winner, and $200 to the loser. The conditions of the trot wore that, Dan Mace should go under the saddle, and Gen. Butler in harness. By the summary which we append it will be seen that the former won in three straight heats, which is not to be wondered at as the track is only a half mile one, and a horse under saddle has a great advantage over one in harness in making the turns.

abstract: REARREST OF A NOTED THIEF. CHARLES PATTERSON, who for a long time past has been known as a desperate thief in that part of the Seventeenth Ward known as "Mackerelville," was rearrested on Friday night, last on a bench-warrant, issued by the Court of General Sessions. The arrest was made by Sergeant McGIVENS of the Seventeenth Precinct, on the charge is highway robbery. PATTERSON with an...
lead_paragraph: REARREST OF A NOTED THIEF. -- CHARLES PATTERSON, who for a long time past has been known as a desperate thief in that part of the Seventeenth Ward known as "Mackerelville," was rearrested on Friday night, last on a bench-warrant, issued by the Court of General Sessions. The arrest was made by Sergeant McGIVENS of the Seventeenth Precinct, on the charge is highway robbery. PATTERSON with an accomplice was first taken into custody on the 28th of December last for robbing Mr. MARTIN BALLARD of One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street, at the corner of Third-avenue and Eighth-street, and was indicted by the Grand Jury. BURNS, his accomplice, was convicted and sent to Sing-Sing. PATTERSON was admitted bail, which he forfeited, but was rearrested. While awaiting trial he was claimed as a deserter by the military authorities and given up so them. He was sent to the Park Barracks, but made his escape after he had been confined there three days. Since then he has been at large, but kept out of the way of the Seventeenth Precinct police, who had the warrant for him. Friday afternoon, Sergeant MCGIVEN saw him walking along Fourth-avenue, and hailed him. PATTERSON immediately started to run, followed by the Sergeant in close pursuit. After an exciting chase, MCGAVEN was gaining on the fugitive so rapidly that PATTERSON ran into an oyster saloon at the corner of Broadway and Twelfth-street, and sat down at a table as unconcerned as possible, and called for refreshments. Here the Sergeant followed and arrested him. MCGIVEN deserves much credit for his prompt and daring action on this occasion, as the desperate character of PATTERSON was well-known to him. Fortunately for the officer his prisoner was unarmed, which is contrary to his usual custom. Capt. BROWN and Sergt. MCGIVEN, conveyed the prisoner before Mr. HALL, the District Attorney, who committed him to the Tombs to stand trial at the Sessions.

MOZART, May 13, 1766,' and 'a symphony for two violins, two violoncellos, two hau[???]s, two herns, and three basses, by MOZART; Vienna and Olmutz, 1767;' a 'concerto for piano and orchestra, dedicated to the Emeperor LEOPOLD, Vienna, 1784,' and several symphonies composed at Salzburg."

abstract: Manifesto and the Facts
snippet: Manifesto and the Facts
lead_paragraph: We find in the manifesto recently put forth by the Rebel Congress, a striking instance of that willful misstatement of, or entire blindness to, the real facts of the position of the struggle between us and them, which we have all so often noticed. They might be perhaps excusable for making mistakes and miscalculations in regard to us, but surely with regard to themselves, in a document publicly put forth with a view "to enlighten the public opinion of the world," one would not expect to find misstatements, palpable and gross, and which can be shown to be such by a little calculation -- at least one would not expect such a course of any ordinary people, governed by ordinary rules of common sense and morality; but the rebels seem to have thrown off all regard for these qualities, as well as for the well settled principles of popular government and of civilization.

abstract: -- The Royal Society of London have now in preparation, under the supervision of a committee, an undertaking of great importance to the literary and scientific world. It is a systematic index to all the articles contained in the transactions and proceedings of the learned societies of the world. It will include the titles of papers published by the academies of Russia, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands, Germany, Switzerland, France, Spain, Italy, the States of North America and Great Britain. These titles now fill sixty-two manuscript volumes. They begin with the year 1800 and are brought down to 1861. It is difficult to estimate the amount of waste of time and labor of the student arising from ignorance of what has already been achieved in the several departments of science, and none but those who have endeavored, in the investigation of perhaps a single subject, to explore the contents of scientific periodicals, can judge of the weariness and discouragements of the task. These will all be obviated by the systematic index which is to be printed without any unnecessary delay. The largest collection of those academic transactions and proceedings in America is undoubtedly that contained in the library of the Smithsonian Institute at Washington. Particular attention has been paid to complete it by purchase and exchange, and the index above-mentioned will furnish a key that renders the contents available to students throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: -- The Royal Society of London have now in preparation, under the supervision of a committee, an undertaking of great importance to the literary and scientific world. It is a systematic index to all the articles contained in the transactions and proceedings of the learned societies of the world. It will include the titles of papers published by the academies of Russia, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands, Germany, Switzerland, France, Spain, Italy, the States of North America and Great Britain. These titles now fill sixty-two manuscript volumes. They begin with the year 1800 and are brought down to 1861. It is difficult to estimate the amount of waste of time and labor of the student arising from ignorance of what has already been achieved in the several departments of science, and none but those who have endeavored, in the investigation of perhaps a single subject, to explore the contents of scientific periodicals, can judge of the weariness and discouragements of the task. These will all be obviated by the systematic index which is to be printed without any unnecessary delay. The largest collection of those academic transactions and proceedings in America is undoubtedly that contained in the library of the Smithsonian Institute at Washington. Particular attention has been paid to complete it by purchase and exchange, and the index above-mentioned will furnish a key that renders the contents available to students throughout the country.

abstract: "The steam vessel Yeddo," says the Gironde, of Bordeaux, "which has just been constructed in the building yard of M. AHMAN, of this city, and which is supposed to belong to the Confederate Government, left the roadstead yesterday morning. She had made a trial-trip on Monday last, and completed her preparations on the following day. The Yeddo measures 682 tons, and has a crew (entirely French) of 65 men. She is commanded by Capt. PATER, who is a native of France also, and was for a long time master of vessels belonging to Bordeaux. She is freighted with different kinds of goods, and is dispatched by M. ARMAN himself, through M. CAUSSE, ship broker. The Yeddo is bound for Amsterdam; everything concerning her departure, and the object and aim of her voyage, remained a profound mystery. To the last moment, the freighters, officers and seamen maintained an absolute silence to all the questions put to them."

abstract: -The feelings of the loyal residents of this city have been somewhat excited within a few days, by the conduct of a rebel Lieutenant-Colonel now in this city on parole, who has been rendering himself very obnoxious by public avowals of his treason, and his anxiety to return to the South and resume his warfare against the Government. He has been-lounging about the bar-rooms of one or two public houses, singing rebel songs, praising Capt. SEMMES' recent letter concerning his captures, denouncing President LINCOLN, &c. The "Colonel," who rejoices in the high-sounding name of "THOMAS JEFFERSON STANTON," says he is from Natchez, Mississippi, where he left a wife and family, the former of whom has since died. He and four brothers entered the rebel service, and he was taken prisoner by Gen. BUTLER at New-Orleans, and from thence sent to Fort Warren, where he was confined 14 months and then released on parole, being required to report to Gen. DIX in New-York City every week. STANTON says he has endeavored several times to be exchanged but his efforts have been always unsuccessful. He has disposed of a gold watch and other articles since his sojourn North, and is now nearly destitute. He freely avows his desire to fight again in the rebel cause, and loses no opportunity to insult the loyal feeling of our people by his treasonable sentiments.

abstract: British Army and Navy Gazette
snippet: British Army and Navy Gazette
lead_paragraph: The recent fight between the Kearsarge and the Alabama, which has cost the Confederate Government the loss of a vessel as valuable as an army, should be, as Sir JOHN HAY remarked, a warning to us, not to be too confident with untried vessels. Here was a sloop manned by a picked crew of as brave hearts as ever were borne upon the ocean, conquered by a vessel of similar size, and sunk with comparative impunity. The armament of the Kearsarge consisted of 2 11 inch Dahlgren guns and 6 32-pounders, with a small rifled piece for a chase gun, &c. That of the Alabama of the same number of 32-pounders, a ri[???]ed 100-pounder, and a solid 8 inch shot gun (68-pounder.) It seems to us that Capt. SEMMES had too high an opinion of his so-called 100-pounder, because it was a rifled gun -- ignorant probably that it was the size of bore and largeness of the powder charge which constituted the power of the gun. Measured by this standard, the rifled pivot 100-pounder was not half as effective as his 8-inch solid-shot pivot-gun, which in its turn, was not half so powerful as either of the Kearsarge's two 11-inch pivot-guns, and probably not one-third as effective when fired against a wooden ship entirely unprotected by armor. The 32 pounders on each side were about equal, and of comparatively small account as to influencing the fate of the action, which was evidently decided by the pivot-guns. In addition to his vessel's carrying a much more powerful armament, the Captain of the Kearsarge had taken the wise precaution to make use of temporary armor, consisting of chain cables fastened along her sides to some distance before and abaft the engines and boilers, which were thus so effectually protected that the Alabama's shell broke up against it and fell back harmlessly into the sea; her round shot, being of cast-iron, fared no better; and, beyond stripping off a little of the thin wooden sheathing which covered over the cable of the Kearsarge, this vessel appears to have received no damage.

abstract: Parliament Debate on Irish Enlistments; Irish Emigration and American Enlistments
snippet: Parliament Debate on Irish Enlistments; Irish Emigration and American Enlistments
lead_paragraph: It is noteworthy that in a parliamentary debate on the question of emigration from Ireland to the United States, which must have occupied four or five hours of the time of the House of Commons, not one of the speakers seems to have spoken from any authentic knowledge of the condition of the emigrent after his arrival here. Such a debate took place in the House of Commons on the 21st ult. Mr. HENNESSY, Sir ROBERT PEEL, Mr. MCGUIRE, Lord PALMERSTON, and others, spoke at great length and adduced many statistics of more or less painful interest, respecting the condition of large portions of the Irish peasantry. But with the exception of Lord PALMERSTON, none of the speakers seemed to strike directly home at the cause of the constant outflow of population from Ireland.

abstract: Dano-German Crisis; The
snippet: Dano-German Crisis; The
lead_paragraph: The failure and dissolution of the London Conference, leaves the Danes and Germans at liberty to renew the conflict whenever they please; but whether it will expand into a great European war, depends on the action of England. The ministerial statement relative to the course which the British Government means to pursue, was waited for with intense anxiety. The nation at large is clamorous for war. The Times, however, thinks that, as the proposition of the neutral Powers was rejected by both belligerents, England is not bound to interfere as long as the struggle is confined to Schleswig, and such may be the opinion of the Cabinet, which is evidently most reluctant to embark in the conflict, and would gladly avoid doing so. Nor is this to be wondered at. From the days of MARLBOROUGH, the German States have been the steady allies of England in her wars against France. At Blenheim, at Ramillies, at Waterloo, Teutons and Britons were fellow-soldiers and fellow-conquerors, and the laurels gathered on those fields belong in common to the two peoples. It is not improbable, therefore, that the remembrance of these things influences British statesmen not a little, and makes them pause ere appealing to the arbitrament of the sword. England can easily rush into the war -- can easily find powerful supporters among the disaffected subjects of Prussia and Austria -- but would the reannexation of Venetia to Italy, or the reestablishment of the Hungarian kingdom, or the reconstruction and resuscitation of Poland, compensate England for the partial dismemberment of the great German Powers, and their reduction to the condition of second-rate States?

abstract: MEXICO. -- The New-Orleans Era has a report from Mexico that the Emperor MAXIMILIAN reached the City of Mexico on the evening of June 8, where an immense torchlight procession had been got up for his reception. Before the show was over a shower extinguished the torches, and during the darkness, as MAXIMILIAN and his escort were passing a house, a vessel filled with nuisance was cast from the roof, and the oderiferous contents were spattered profusely upon the august person of His Majesty and one or two of his friends. The inmates of the house were immediately arrested.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO. -- The New-Orleans Era has a report from Mexico that the Emperor MAXIMILIAN reached the City of Mexico on the evening of June 8, where an immense torchlight procession had been got up for his reception. abstract: -The Lock-port Journal tells the following horrible story: A woman living in Mercer, C.W., the wife of Mr. WM. EVERS, has for four years past been afflicted with a singular diffculty in her stomach. Her complaint has until within a short time past, baffled the skill of physicians. The complaint commenced about four years since, with a tickling and uneasy sensation about the pit of the stomach. The same sensation has continued to increase in severity from that time. A few months since it became the incontrovertible opinion of the most skillful physicians, that the increasing difficulty has been the growth of a snake in the stomach. It has grown so large now that it distends the stomach so as to produce a bunch upon the outside as large as a quart bowl. Upon pressing this bunch with the hand, the reptile recoils and produces great distress in the stomach. When fish or meat is being cooked in the room, if the snake is not satisfied with food, it rises up in the throat producing strangulation. When desiring food it manifests it by rising up in the throat. Physicians can see no way in which the snake can be removed without certain death to the woman. Mrs. EVERS is about 35 years of age. She is, of course, feeble in health now, but is around the house.

Upon pressing this bunch with the hand, the reptile recoils and produces great distress in the stomach. When fish or meat is being cooked in the room, if the snake is not satisfied with food, it rises up in the throat producing strangulation. When desiring food it manifests it by rising up in the throat. Physicians can see no way in which the snake can be removed without certain death to the woman. Mrs. EVERS is about 35 years of age. She is, of course, feeble in health now, but is around the house.

abstract: Admiral LEE, commanding North Atlantic Blockading Squadron, in a dispatch to the Navy Department, under date of July 1, says that since July 24, 1863, forty-two steamers have been captured or destroyed by the blockaders of his squadron. Taking the average tonage of these vessels at 300 tons, and assuming the capacity of an army wagon at one ion, there has been a loss inflected on the rebel supply system equivalent to the capture or destruction of a train of 12,600 wagons.

abstract: To-day has been one of unparalleled excitement in this city. From early dawn it had been rumored that the rebels were only a few miles from the city, and that they would soon enter and occupy it. The arrival of couriers and wounded from the fight beyond Middletown, bringing the news that our small force engaged in holding the rebels in check -- about three hundred men of the Eighth Illinois Cavalry and two pieces of Capt. ALEXANDER's Baltimore Artillery -- were unable to cope with the superior force of the enemy, and were slowly falling back toward this city, fighting all the way, added fuel to the flame, and by noon business was suspended, stores closed, and many leaving the city by every possible conveyance.

abstract: Union Home and School, N Y
snippet: Union Home and School, N Y
lead_paragraph: This beneficent institute was organized on May 22, 1861, "for the maintenance of the children of our volunteers who may be left unprovided for," and has had charge of about 500 till the present time, of whom 125 still remain at the Home, the rest having been adopted or apprenticed out. The originators of this institution were Mrs. Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, Mrs. DRAKE MILLS, Mrs. HOYT, and Mrs. OLIVE M. DEVOE -- the latter being the Treasurer, and not only devoting her time, but thousands of dollars of her private means, in furthering its success. Besides receiving private aid from numerous individuals and firms, either in money or supplies, it has received donations of $3,000 each from the Common Council and Legislature, $5,000 from the Supervisors, and payments from the Family Aid Fund. The institution (which has since been chartered) was formed to prevent the children of soldiers being sent to the Alms-house as paupers. This has long been carried out in England, where a princely institution was endowed by the Duke of York, at the beginning of the present century, for the reception of children of soldiers. Why cannot some more comprehensive plan be adopted by our General or State Government, for the same object as the one instituted by the lady managers of the Union Home and School? An extensive plot of ground might be given to it where land is cheaper, and it could then be in a position to be more useful. The names of the officers and managers are:

abstract: THE DRAFT IN THE FIFTH DISTRICT. -- A supplementary draft to fill a deficiency in the Fifth Congressional District, will take place at Newark on Monday next. abstract: The news this morning concerning the rebel raid is of a very exciting character, and develops the fact that the rebel force is strong enough to make a formidable resistance against Baltimore and Washington. A dispatch from Secretary STANTON, announces that Gen. WALLACE fought the enemy yesterday at Monocacy River, and after a severe battle, our forces were compelled to retreat in disorder,...
lead_paragraph: The news this morning concerning the rebel raid is of a very exciting character, and develops the fact that the rebel force is strong enough to make a formidable resistance against Baltimore and Washington. A dispatch from Secretary STANTON, announces that Gen. WALLACE fought the enemy yesterday at Monocacy River, and after a severe battle, our forces were compelled to retreat in disorder, before the overpowering numbers of the enemy, whom he estimates to be at least twenty thousand strong. At last accounts Gen. WALLACE was falling back on Monrovia, a station several miles east of Monocacy. Much excitement existed in Baltimore last evening, and the city was being placed in thorough defensive order. The Governor and Mayor had issued proclamations calling on all citizens to arm themselves and report for duty.
