abstract: THE SECOND DIVISION STATE MILITIA. -- A meeting of the officers of the Second Division, State Militia, was held at Major-Gen. DURYEA's office (Brooklyn) yesterday morning, at which it was decided to call out the Ninety-third. Eighty-ninth and Nineteenth, and one regiment of Gen. RYDER's brigade, from Orange, and other up-river counties, to answer the call of the President for 12,000 men from this State to resist the invasion of Maryland. The quota required of the Second Division's District is 1,850 men. If these regiments do not furnish the quota, then the Fifty-second and Fifty-sixth regiments of Brooklyn are to be called upon to make up the deficiency. It is the object of the State military authorities to keep the National Guard at home, having previously done good service, and it was thought best not to tax them too much.

abstract: Alabama; Semmes, Escaped Drowning in 1846
snippet: Alabama; Semmes, Escaped Drowning in 1846
lead_paragraph: -The escape of SEMMES from a watery grave in the Alabama is not the first peril of the kind through which he has passed. In 1846, he commanded the United States brig Somers, when she foundered off Vera Cruz, and carried down with her thirty-two of the fifty persons on board. SEMMES was picked up floating, in the last stage of exhaustion, on a plank, by a boat which went back the second time, against the remonstrances or others, thinking that possibly all the survivors had not been seen by the boats which were sent out to the wreck.
headline: {'main': 'ANOTHER ESCAPE FOR SEMMES', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ANOTHER ESCAPE FOR SEMMES', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. Grant's Testimony
snippet: Gen. Grant's Testimony
lead_paragraph: NESS. -- A story has been widely prevalent that after the battle of the Wilderness Gen. MEADE advised falling back across the Rapidan. It was for intimating something of this kind that Gen. MEADE ordered the correspondent of a Philadelphia paper to be sent out of the army. A gentleman of Boston, who had heard the report indirectly from an army officer, wrote a letter of inquiry to Gen. GRANT, and has just received the reply from Lieut.-Col. THEODORE LYMAN, Vol. A.D.C., who states that the letter "asking about the truth or the falsity of the calumnious report," has been duly received, and forwarded to Major-Gen. MEADE, with an indorsement, of which the following is a copy:

abstract: -- On Saturday last the connection between the eastern and western divisions of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad was completed by the laying of the last rail -- and thus a continuous iron track was opened up from the Delaware to Lake Erie. This desideratum, so long sought and so often deferred, will, we feel assured, be hailed by our citizens with peculiar satisfaction at this time. The petroleum trade of northwestern Pennsylvania has been rapidly leaving us to find shipment at New-York, because of the influence of the branches of the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad in that region, Philadelphia meantime having no direct railway connection with the oil wells. Now, however, by the completion of this Philadelphia and Erie Railroad the tables are turned, and Philadelphia has the shortest and most available line for the trade. -- Philadelphia N. American, July 6.

abstract: A SERIOUS AFFRAY. -- Two men, named DOMINICK CONNOLLY and MICHAEL HEENY, were arrested Friday, by the Forty-fifth Precinct Police, for having, with others, engaged in a bloody affray. From the statements made by the injured parties, it appears that on Tuesday evening, DOMINICK CONNOLLY, MICHAEL HEENY and his wife. MICHAEL ADAMS, and THOMAS GIBBONS, entered a tenement house on North Eighth-street, near First, and proceeded to the rooms occupied by WM. CONNOLLY and family, and brutally beat his wife, on account of some family difficulty. A young man named THOMAS MCDONALD, being present, interfered, when they turned upon and beat him in a shocking manner, and then left. Yesterday morning the parties returned, and attacking WM. CONNOLLY, dragged him into an alley way where, as he alleges, DOMINICK CONNOLLY knocked him down with a slung shot and left him for dead. Several persons who interfered were also attacked. HONORA CONNOLLY and MARGARET MCDONALD were severely beaten, the latter being badly bruised, her eyes nearly closed up, and the bridge of her nose broken, and she is considered in a very critical condition. The prisoners were committed to await an examination.

CONNOLLY and family, and brutally beat his wife, on account of some family difficulty. A young man named THOMAS MCDONALD, being present, interfered, when they turned upon and beat him in a shocking manner, and then left. Yesterday morning the parties returned, and attacking WM. CONNOLLY, dragged him into an alley way where, as he alleges, DOMINICK CONNOLLY knocked him down with a slung shot and left him for dead. Several persons who interfered were also attacked. HONORA CONNOLLY and MARGARET MCDONALD were severely beaten, the latter being badly bruised, her eyes nearly closed up, and the bridge of her nose broken, and she is considered in a very critical condition. The prisoners were committed to await an examination.

abstract: Crawford Allen et al. vs. John Bradly and Henry Hone. -- This was an action brought to recover the value of certain goods alleged by the plaintiffs to belong to them. They had sent the goods to the firm of Byerly & Co., who had sold and delivered them to the defendants. On the trial of the cause before the jury the Judge directed a verdict for the defendants, on the ground that it appeared that Byerly & Co. had authority to sell the goods. The plaintiffs moved for a new trial on a case.

abstract: Alabama and Kearsarge Fight and the Deerhound
snippet: Alabama and Kearsarge Fight and the Deerhound
lead_paragraph: -- There is a good deal said of the lesson in naval warfare taught by the recent engagement of the Alabama and Kearsarge. Something will undoubtedly be learned in that line, but one thing which our naval officers will certainly not forget, is never again to trust the honor of a British sailor present as a spectator. Some of that class might and probably would be honorable men, but the safest way will be never to trust them. Capt. WINSLOW, when he found the Deerhound making off with his prisoners, ought to have ordered her back by a shot across her bows, and if that had not proved effectual he should have given her another amidships. Probably he would have done so if he had suspected either her character or purpose.
headline: {'main': 'THE LESSON OF THE FIGHT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE LESSON OF THE FIGHT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the 1st of July, 1864, the postage on letters mailed in the United States for transmission in the British mail, via Southampton, to the Colonies of Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, Tasmania, South Australia, and Western Australia, or to New Zealand, was increased to forty-five cents per single rate of half ounce, prepayment required. Letters for Australia or New Zealand, when specially addressed by "private ship," may be forwarded in the mail to great Britain, and from thence to their destination by private ship, at a reduced charge of twenty-nine cents per single rate, prepayment also required.

abstract: We publish this morning some thirty telegraph  ic dispatches, relating, more or less directly, to the rebel raid in Maryland and Southwestern Pennsylvania. The most alarming of these telegrams will be found to be that which we repro  duce from yesterday's issue, and which takes the form of an official dispatch from the War Department, at Washington.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning some thirty telegraph ic dispatches, relating, more or less directly, to the rebel raid in Maryland and Southwestern Pennsylvania. The most alarming of these telegrams will be found to be that which we repro duce from yesterday's issue, and which takes the form of an official dispatch from the War Department, at Washington. It is founded, as most of our city readers doubtless learned yesterday on Gen. WALLACE's report of a rather obstinate fight which took place on Saturday at Monocacy Bridge, between a considerable rebel force, supposed to be BRECKENRIDGE's division, and a small body of our troops that had been sent to occupy Frederick City. The fight, it will be seen (and it is the only fight this raid has produced thus far), lasted probably about eight hours or so. We lost a thousand men in round figures, and Gen. WALLACE found himself compelled to retreat, leaving his dead and wounded, or most of them, we regret to say, behind him. A part from this fair, stand-up fight the reports we have of the rebel movements continue to be a mere mixture of bald and meagre statements from eye-witnesses at fifty different points, and a batch of conjectures as absurd, as it is possible to conceive. The rebel infantry can only be to-day a few miles farther down the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, than they were on Saturday at the close of the fight. They may possibly have got within forty-eight or fifty miles of Baltimore, if they are traveling in that direction. The rebel cavalry are here, there, and everywhere. A portion, under MOSBY, is in Fairfax County, south of the Potomac, and around Edward's Ferry. A portion was seen yesterday by a mail-carrier, at the village of Rockville, about fourteen miles from Washington. Another squad was reported yesterday at Ellicott's Mills, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; but this is probably untrue, since we find Gen. WALLACE dating a dispatch from that place yesterday, to Secretary SEWARD, announcing the safety (contrary to the previous official report) of Col. SEWARD. Still another portion of the rebel cavalry have crossed the Northern Central Railroad at Cockeysville, burning a bridge and doing promiscuous damage at that point. Doubtless there are many other points along the railroad lines where the rebel cavalry have already shown themselves; without waiting to fight or even to carry off plunder. From the flying movements they execute, it is impossible to reckon their numbers. There comes a rumor -- very absurd in character -- that LEE himself is in command. Respecting the movements of our own forces we can speak positively, if we speak briefly. Even if a portion of HUNTER's force has not yet reached Martinsburgh, as is reported, Gen. COUCH is in strong force at Hagerstown. Gen. WALLACE has been reinforced so as to make a sudden advance on Baltimore by any large body of infantry impossible; and more important than all, a body of veterans of the national army is now at a point within easy reach either of Washington or Baltimore, in case of further signs of trouble. The latest dispatch from Baltimore represents everything quiet in that city, and the train running through from Washington with no interruption whatever. To all this it may be added, that Gen. GRANT is in no way moved from his propriety by the so-called invasion.

abstract: Worms and the Fifth-avenue Genus
snippet: Worms and the Fifth-avenue Genus
lead_paragraph: -Cut down the trees. This is what may be called the radical style of treatment. We see that some brilliant genius on the Fifth-avenue is trying it with distinguished success. After waiting until the worm season is over, he has gone to work to take effectual precautions against the return of the vermin next year. He has already cut down four or five magnificent elms, a foot and a half in diameter, and the most graceful and beautiful trees in the City, and will probably make a clean sweep of everything green in his neighborhood -- except himself. People who cut down trees to save the trouble of keeping worms off them, would probably cut off their children's heads whenever they happen to be a little troublesome.
headline: {'main': 'HOW TO GET RID OF WORMS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HOW TO GET RID OF WORMS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Prof. MCDOWELL, who professes surgery in the College of Missouri, is writing some very ferocious letters to Rev. H.W. BEECHER. He says he knew him many years ago, when he was an "impudent boy," and that if he does not pause in his career of wickedness, the knife which hitherto has "never been turned on the human family but in kindness and mercy, shall be keenly whet in justice and vengeance." We hope Mr. BEECHER will "pause," for we should be very sorry to have a good scalpel spoiled. Prof. MCDOWELL adds that Rob Roy was his cousin. We would congratulate one of them on the relationship, if we could decide which.

abstract: A very important decision has just been made by the Provost-Marshal-General in regard to substitutes, which will tend very much to facilitate recruiting for the army, and enable the substitute market to be easier, to use a commercial phrase. Mr. LEWIS AUDENRIED who is himself free from the draft, but desires to furnish three substitutes, applied to the Provost-Marshal if he would accept as representatives for parties not liable to do military duty, such citizens as are themselves enrolled and liable. Mr. AUDENRIED wishes to send his representatives to the Army of the Potomac, and has suggested this plan to accomplish the object. The reply was as follows:

abstract: -- We present our readers this morning with the result of the labors of Congress on the Tax Law, in the form of tables of taxes, conveniently arranged for reference. It will be seen that the rates have been largely increased on most articles. We have delayed the publication of these tables until after receiving from Washington correct and authentic information respecting the changes made and concurred in by the Conference Committee -- preferring to submit to this necessary delay rather than mislead the people by premature publication of incomplete laws.

abstract: Invasion of; the Meaning of
snippet: Invasion of; the Meaning of
lead_paragraph: What is the real magnitude and meaning of this new rebel invasion of Maryland? -- Just a week ago to-day the news of an advance movement of a large rebel force up the Shenandoah Valley astonished the incredulous country. The thing seemed so much out of keeping with the position of affairs elsewhere, that few people paid any serious attention to it. It was generally ridiculed as preposterous in itself, and the excitement along the border was thought to be but a great popular scare, produced by the sudden apparition of a few hundred Confederate cavalrymen. Even after the retreat of SIGEL from Martinsburgh to the north side of the Potomac, the appearance of the rebels in Hagerstown and Frederick, and down through all the rebel movements to the close of last week, the whole matter was treated by the people as a great fright rather than a great fact. The very excited, absurdly exaggerated, and entirely contradictory character of the telegraphic dispatches that followed each other in quick succession from Maryland and Pennsylvania, was in great part the cause of this want of faith and of serious feeling. It was only yesterday, on the publication of Secretary STANTON's official bulletin, that people could be induced to do anything but laugh at the "great rebel invasion." The effect of that bulletin was very sudden, and induced those who had previously been most hilarious over the affair to be most lugubrious over the new aspect of it.

abstract: -- Mrs. ROBERTS, wife of M. ROBERTS, keeper of a cigar store at No. 44 Newark-avenue, Jersey City, swallowed a dose of laudanum on Saturday forenoon, and was soon after found lying in an insensible condition. Medical aid was called in, but she was beyond recovery, and died about 9 o'clock in the evening. Coroner FARREL held an inquest yesterday, when a verdict of suicide by taking poison was rendered. No cause assigned for the act.

abstract: Albany Legislation and Improvements
snippet: Albany Legislation and Improvements
lead_paragraph: Every one knows that all the really useful departments in our City Government, and those which are evidently conferring blessings upon us every day, have been created for us in Albany. They are not the products of the suffrage of the City. They are the fruits of violating or deviating from our system of universal suffrage as the law of all society. Despite the howlings of the so-called Democratic organs, and against our cherished theories, we have been determined to attain the practical object in view, and it has been done by withdrawing certain powers from the people of this City. It is the highest evidence of the practical good sense of this community that they have done so.

abstract: Proclamation on Reconstruction
snippet: Proclamation on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: The failure of the President to sign the bill providing for the reorganization of civil government in the reclaimed States, has been attributed to a disapproval of its features. Had it, indeed, been true that there was a serious variance between the executive and legislative branches of the Government on this subject, it would have been very unfortunate. To hasten a general reconciliation, it is important that the reclaimed States should be relieved of military rule, and returned to their old positions in the Union, just as soon as they can be trusted. But neither the President nor Congress singly can do the work necessary to such restoration. The President, as Commander-in-Chief, has the power to appoint and maintain Military Governors, during the war, as long as in his judgment the military situation requires it. Congress, under the clause of the Constitution which gives the two bodies the exclusive right to determine the qualifications of their members, has the sole power to decide when the States shall be reinstated in the national councils. To make the restoration a substantial thing, there must be conjoint action between the President and Congress. The want of it would produce mischievous, if not disastrous confusion.
headline: {'main': "The President's Proclamation on Reconstruction.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Proclamation on Reconstruction.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- An aged lady named WELDON, widow of the late JOHN WELDON, died suddenly on Saturday evening, at the residence of her brother-in-law, at Bergen. The inmates of the house attended to family prayers as usual, and at the close it was observed that deceased remained kneeling, with her head resting upon a chair, and upon being raised up life was extinct. Disease of the heart was the cause. Mrs. WELDON was 76 years of age.

abstract: Lancaster, Mr, of the Deerhound; Letter by
snippet: Lancaster, Mr, of the Deerhound; Letter by
lead_paragraph: Mr. LANCASTER, the owner of the Deerhound, has been led, by the strictures upon his conduct, to write and publish a letter explanatory of it, and, as very often happens in such cases, he has put himself in rather a worse attitude than he was in before. He does not deny any of the facts of the case, viz.: that Capt. WINSLOW requested him to do what he could to save the Alabama's crew, and that he having picked up SEMMES and the rest, set off with all speed for the shores of England. But he says, "I was not aware then, and I am not aware now, that the men whom I saved were, or ever had been, Capt. WINSLOW's prisoners." If he had only said that he was not aware then that such was the fact, we should have understood him as saying that he did not know that SEMMES had surrendered, which would not have been entirely improbable. But when he says that he is not aware of it, as he writes, he shows that he means that he is not aware that a man who has surrendered is a prisoner. He will hardly make people believe he is so ignorant as that. The man may escape afterward, but he is none the less a prisoner when he surrenders. And SEMMES was a prisoner as soon as he hauled down his flag. He undoubtedly had the right to try to escape; but so have all the rebels whom we hold here in safe keeping. He succeeded, and they have not; but he was as much a prisoner as they until he did succeed.

abstract: Invasion, the, of
snippet: Invasion, the, of
lead_paragraph: No collision of any moment has taken place between our forces and the enemy in Maryland since the affair of Saturday last on the Monocacy. But the rebels have, for the last two days, been dashing freely and furiously around Maryland -- approaching to within half a dozen miles of Baltimore, and an equal distance of Washington -- destroying railroad bridges, capturing railroad trains, (two,) burning the houses of prominent men like Gov. BRADFORD and the elder BLAIR, harrying the horses and cattle of the farmers, and creating confusion among peaceable folks generally. In no instance does it seem that any portion of our cavalry, or infantry, or artillery has come in contact with any part of these rough riders, or tried to stop their career, or thwart their schemes; but we are entertained with the intelligence that a gunboat, somewhere in a stream close to Baltimore, has fearlessly opened upon them with great fury. We trust that this gunboat, which has come so opportunely to our and Baltimore's relief, will unflinchingly do its whole duty in the emergency, and pursue these rebel ruffians from the Monumental City, across the mountains, and down the Shenandoah Valley, to the very presence of JEFF. DAVIS. There is nothing like horse marines.
headline: {'main': 'The Invasion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Invasion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The officers of the Fifty-sixth Regiment, Col. J.Q. ADAMS, held a meeting last evening, at which orders were issued to the company commanders to fill up their companies to one hundred men as speedily as possible. If the regiment cannot recruit the whole number speedily, the companies will be filled up from the other city regiments. It is probable that to furnish the quota of 1,800 men required, one or two of the city regiments will be ordered out. The Major-General Commanding is in the country, and nothing definite can be known until he returns. The Twenty-eighth Regiment, also designated to go, is making arrangements to fill up the ranks.

abstract: The board held a regular meeting last evening. The Street Commissioners sent in a communication calling attention to the condition of the streets as left by the street contractors, plumbers, men employed to lay gas-pipes, &c. An ordinance was presented in connection with the subject requiring all persons who tear up the streets, for whatever purpose, to replace the same in good order, and cart away the dirt. The ordinance was adopted. The Mayor sent in two communications -- the first vetoing the Brooklyn and Rockaway Railroad Grant, and the second disapproving of the resolution passed July 6, authorizing the purchase of 400 globe gas-lamps, to replace those now in use. The reason for the first veto was that citizens objected to railroad tracks in streets on the Heights; and the second, because the globe lamps were a mere experiment, and still required to be tested in cold weather. Both communications were appropriately referred.
lead_paragraph: The board held a regular meeting last evening. The Street Commissioners sent in a communication calling attention to the condition of the streets as left by the street contractors, plumbers, men employed to lay gas-pipes, &c. An ordinance was presented in connection with the subject requiring all persons who tear up the streets, for whatever purpose, to replace the same in good order, and cart away the dirt. The ordinance was adopted. The Mayor sent in two communications -- the first vetoing the Brooklyn and Rockaway Railroad Grant, and the second disapproving of the resolution passed July 6, authorizing the purchase of 400 globe gas-lamps, to replace those now in use. The reason for the first veto was that citizens objected to railroad tracks in streets on the Heights; and the second, because the globe lamps were a mere experiment, and still required to be tested in cold weather. Both communications were appropriately referred.

abstract: New-York; Pier No 1 North River and steamship John Potter burned; Fashion Course; Jim Goff, >amp;c; Trot
snippet: New-York; Pier No 1 North River and steamship John Potter burned; Fashion Course; Jim Goff, >amp;c; Trot
lead_paragraph: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on board the steamer John Potter, owned by the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, and at the time lying at Pier No. 1 North River. She was heavily laden with merchandise of various kinds, having just arrived at her dock, and owing to the highly inflamable nature of some of the articles on board, the flames spread with great rapidity through the vessel. In about half an hour from the time the alarm was given, the steamer and contents were wrapt in a sheet of fire. Soon the flames extended to the Pier (No. 1) against which the John Potter was lying. This pier was 600 feet in length, and was inclosed and roofed over from one end to the other with wood. A large amount of valuable property, consigned to various parties, and consisting of cotton, hemp, tobacco, hardware, and divers kinds of dry goods, was stored thereon. When the fiery element made its grasp on these articles of merchandise, the scene throughout all the lower part of the City became grand and sublime. The burning steamer and contents, the long dock with its wooden roof and sides, and the vast piles of highly combustible merchandise, with which it was crowded, all encircled in a sheet of flames. To add to the grandeur of the occasion, a heavy shower of rain came on just at this time. Amid the storm of rain, thunder and lightning, the fire-bells throughout the City pealed forth their solemn tones, fire-engines rattled down Broadway and along the side streets, and the firemen (those ever watchful guardians of the City) hurried rapidly on their way to the place of the conflagration.

abstract: As a Naval Fighter
snippet: As a Naval Fighter
lead_paragraph: Firing at long range is the peculiar office of a rifle gun. "A quarter of a mile," even three-quarters of a mile, cannot be called long range. Why Capt. SEMMES thought fit to throw away the greatest advantage he possessed over Capt. WINSLOW, is a mystery. We would have noticed the fact before this, but there were no proofs to hand that the Alabama really had a rifle gun on board. It was known that, when in the West Indies, such a weapon was stowed in her hold, but no one could say positively that it was mounted and constituted part of her battery. Privateering does not need pieces of very long range, except they be such articles as are used by Custom-house officers in searching for contraband goods in passengers' trunks; or by pirates in hooking out costly furs from the wardrobe of the honest skipper's wife. T.A. BLAKELY, the English gun-maker, whose heavy artillery was reported to be a great failure in the hands of BEAUREGARD at Charleston, settles the point as to the Alabama's possession of a rifle. Writing to the London Times, under date of June 22, 1864, he says:

abstract: We give prominence, this morning, to an extraordinary communication addressed by his Honor the Mayor to Gen. SANDFORD, and intended to be specially applicable to the emergency which the rebel raid has created. suggestions from an official of the importance of Mr. GUNTHER ought to command attention at such a time as this.
lead_paragraph: We give prominence, this morning, to an extraordinary communication addressed by his Honor the Mayor to Gen. SANDFORD, and intended to be specially applicable to the emergency which the rebel raid has created. suggestions from an official of the importance of Mr. GUNTHER ought to command attention at such a time as this. The Mayor takes the ground that self-interest is the synonym of patriotism, and having relieved himself of this axiom, he proceeds to tell Gen. SANDFORD what interpretation he puts upon the self-interest of New-York, and what is, thence, to be considered patriotic duty on the part of her citizens. In brief, Mr. GUNTHER protests against the State troops of New-York being removed from the City at the call of the Government, and gives as a reason for his protest the extreme probability of a recurrence of such riots as occurred last July -- aggravated in the present instance by the dearness of provisions, and the suffering endured by the workingmen of New-York from a depreciated currency.

abstract: Arrested wearing part of a Union soldier's skull
snippet: Arrested wearing part of a Union soldier's skull
lead_paragraph: Mrs. HOUGH, wife of WARWICK HOUGH, Adjutant General of the State of Missouri under CLAIR JACKSON, and more recently Captain and Assistant Inspector-General on the staff of the late Gen. LEONIDAS POLK, was arrested in this city yesterday by Capt. TALLON's detectives, and taken before the Provost-Marshal-General. She stated that she was on her way to Jefferson City to see her mother, who she heard was sick. Mrs. HOUGH was closely questioned by Capt. BURDETT, Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, and was quite frank in some of her replies. In her trunk a number of letters were found, and a small piece of the skull of a Union soldier, on which was written "Wilson's Creek, December 31, 1861." Mrs. HOUGH said she had preserved this as a memento of the battle. She was sent to the Female Prison, and will be further examined by a military commission. The fact of a lady of refinement carrying about with her a piece of the skull of a human being, as an Indian wears the scalp of a slain enemy in his belt, is so repulsive to the finer feelings of our nature that we must regard Mrs. HOUGH as little better than savage. A short stay in the female Prison may modify her rancor toward Union soldiers, and teach her a lesson which she appears to have forgotten. -- St. Louis Democrat, July 8.

abstract: The bankers and brokers of Baltimore, says the Clipper, are about constructing a telegraph between this and all other leading cities. The line will be over 550 miles in length, and an extra number of conducting cables will be sunk in rivers, so that if one or more should be dragged up or injured by a passing vessel, there will still be enough left to prevent the business from being interrupted. In the cities of New-York, Philadelphia, Washington and this city the company will have a complete system of city lines, and will have in each city from six to ten offices, in positions where they will be most likely to command business. There will also be "way" offices established at the principal intermediate points, and the routes will be through some of the largest interior towns of Pennsylvania, New-Jersey and Maryland. The proposed lines will have direct connection with three other lines, one of which, extending to Hagerstown, is now nearly completed and doing a profitable business, and the other two will be erected in a short time. Four wires will be put up and in operation at once, and more will be added as the business of the company increases.

abstract: on the Maryland Raid; Florida, the, on Our Coasts
snippet: on the Maryland Raid; Florida, the, on Our Coasts
lead_paragraph: The privateer Alabama has just been sent to the bottom of the sea, near the shores of France, when suddenly her piratical partner, the Florida, turns up near our own coast. Beside the exciting military news of the day, we have the naval intelligence that on Friday last the Florida made her appearance near the mouth of Chesapeake Bay and the Maryland shore, where she, up to Sunday morning last, captured one schooner and six barks, all of which she burnt, except one that was ransomed, and on Monday she captured the steamer Electric Spark, bound to New-Orleans, which is also believed to have been burned. How much more damage she has done since then it is impossible to say; but, undoubtedly, she is in a region where, for a few days, she can commit great havoc among the coasting and other vessels running from New-York, Boston and other places, to the ports of our Southern seaboard. If she can move quickly, however, so can we. The fact of her appearance can at once be communicated by telegraph to Fortress Monroe, and from thence conveyed to our vessels along the Southern coast; and some of our swiftest armed vessels engaged in the blockading and transport service, as well as such other gunboats as may have been dispatched by the Navy Department, will at once give chase to the rebel.

abstract: The operations of the rebels in Maryland and on the borders of the States of Delaware and Pennsylvania, assumed apparently a graver aspect yesterday than they had previously done. Much of the extra excitement produced by their enterprise yesterday was due to the peculiar nature of the work in which they occupied themselves, and to the unexpected points they succeeded in reaching. They succeeded in cutting the telegraph line between Philadelphia and Baltimore early in the day. And while this was going on, a band of their cavalry, said to be not more than two hundred strong, under the command of "HARRY GILMORE," arrived at Magnolia Station, which is 18 miles south of Havre de Grace, and less than that distance from Baltimore. This band succeeded in capturing the 8:30 A.M. passenger train from Baltimore. The 10 o'clock morning train from Baltimore was also captured. In one of these trains (we are unable to make out which) Major-Gen. FRANKLIN and a number of officers and privates were passengers, and were all made prisoners. The other passengers were plundered of whatever valuables they possessed. Subsequently, the raiders set fire to Gunpowder River Bridge. By the same party, or others immediately cooperating with it, the residences of Gov. BRADFORD, near Baltimore, and of Gen. CADWALLADER, near Magnolia, were set on fire and completely destroyed, with all their contents. More serious than this, apparently, is the news from Washington and its surroundings. If we are to believe an informant of the Star, the rebels are forty-five thousand strong on this side of the Potomac, and LONGSTREET is following with another supplementary corps. Skirmishing was going on yesterday within a short distance of the fortifications of the capital. All the reports agree in representing Washington as being thoroughly prepared for the emergency.

abstract: TUR, ALA. -- By an officer who arrived in the city last night from the [???]on[???], we learn that the rebel Gen. RODDY, with a large force, is threatening Decatur, Ala. Gen. GRANGER is in command of the post, and he is making every preparation to hold his position. Regiments are being hurried to his support as rapidly as possible. If RODDY makes an attack upon the place he will meet with a surprise as complete as his repulse will be decided. He was well aware that the post was feebly garrisoned, and when he started his columns toward the town, he expected to meet with a very slight resistance. By this time Gen. GRANGER is fully prepared to welcome him. He feels secure in his position, and will prevent the rebel General from executing any flank movement in his rear. -- Louisville Journal, July 8.

abstract: The Conference has ended. It has failed. There is a formal meeting to-day to exchange protocols and say good-bye, but the quarreling is over. The armistice is not extended, so that to-morrow the absurd fight begins again. The Danes blockade the German ports. The German proceed to take Alsen. The English newspapers threaten to send a fleet to the Baltic. RUSSELL and PALMERSTON do not say that.

abstract: THE AMERICAN SHIP ALBATROSS. -- A paragraph appeared in the Times of the 14th inst., in reference to proceedings before the Newport magistrates against the two mates of the American ship Albatross for several acts of alleged cruelty to the seamen on board. The charges against the mates were then dismissed, the alleged offences having been committed on the Atlantic, and, consequently, the cases and not come within the jurisdiction of the magistrates. The latter, however, expressed a hope that the American Consul would inquire into the matter. In compliance with this request, an investigation has since been held before Mr. K[???]PP, the Consul. After hearing the witnesses on both sides, the Consul reports that the charges were entirely unfounded, and that the crew were induced by designing persons to make complaints of cruelty in order, if possible, to extort money. London Times, June 28.

abstract: Some months since we referred to the fact that Mr. SPENCER B. DRIGOS whose name will be familiar to our readers in connection with the piano-forte and improvements he has made in its construction during the last ten years had entered into an arrangement with a number of capitalists for the manufacture of instruments under his patents.
lead_paragraph: Some months since we referred to the fact that Mr. SPENCER B. DRIGOS -- whose name will be familiar to our readers in connection with the piano-forte and improvements he has made in its construction during the last ten years -- had entered into an arrangement with a number of capitalists for the manufacture of instruments under his patents. The matter has since crystalized into a very solid corporation. The "Driggs Patent Piano Company," with a capital of half a million dollars, is already in active operation, and promises speedily to become one of the leading manufacturing interests of the metropolis. The warerooms of the company are at No. 3 Union-square, where, if circumstances should be favorable to the inquiring mind, it may be possible for the curious to see a few of the new pianos. The demand at present is so far in advance of the supply that it is with difficulty a stock of instruments is retained for the supply and satisfaction of the public. The Drigg's Patent Piano Company have, we believe, three manufactories, and will, in a short time, be able to turn out twenty-five or thirty pianos a week. Capital cannot materially hasten the mode of production, although in the end it has everything to do with the number produced. Every piano must go through a series of processes which require time for their completion. Especially is this the case with Mr. DRIGG's instruments, which are professedly constructed on a principle that insures their improvement with age, like the violin. The labor market has not been in a very satisfactory condition of fate. It has been disturbed by strikes and combinations for advanced prices that have -- to say the least -- been harassing to the manufacturer. These are now, fortunately, at an end. We learn with satisfaction that the Driggs' Company will, in a short time, be able to supply the market with a fair proportion of their wares. The importance of the piano trade can hardly be over-estimated. Now that a tax has been imposed on the use of the instrument, it is destined to be a source not only of pleasure to the community, but of very considerable income to the Government. Ten years ago it was calculated (rather liberally we think) that the piano trade of the United States amounted, or would soon amount to $50,000,000 per annum. However this may be, we trust that Mr. DRIGGS will come in for his just share of all that it is worth. For a number of years, extending over a period of three apprenticeships such as are usually considered sufficient to learn how to practice a craft, calling or profession, he has devoted himself to the one object of improving the piano. He has invented and reinvented almost every part of its internal structure, and, more than any other maker, has contributed to radical changes being brought into common acceptance and use. The originality of his ideas was of course a source of ridicule to other makers, and, in fact, it required a vast amount of hardihood and conscious knowledge for a gentleman with a theory to insist so tenaciously that the practice of the business for years had been a blunder. It remained only for the judicious mechanic to deny the soft impeachment, and first abuse and then use the ideas that offended him. A man of a less hopeful temperment than Mr. DRIGGS would have succombed to the hostility thus shown to every effort. Mr. DRIGGS, on the contrary, paid but little attention to the attacks made upon him. By a system of induction based on an original theory of acoustics, he quietly sought for truth in his own way, and found it. How to produce a large human sound from the piano -- more grand and continuous than any yet known -- was an early discovery with him. He had a glimmering of the idea in the tone producing plan of the Cremona violin, and quickly adapted it to the requirements of the piano. But there was so wide a difference in the nature of the two instruments that the work of regeneration only commenced here. The perfected Driggs piano of to-day is a novelty in almost every particular of its construction, and represents the ripened fruits of many years of unflagging perseverance; the slow but steady growth of a living idea that could not be killed by the chilling blasts it had to encounter. It is strictly and truly an American piano; simple and effective in its general principles, and ingenious in all its details. The pianos now being made by the company are of the square and oval kinds, and from a careful examination of their merits we are persuaded that they cannot be surpassed. The tone is unusually rich and full; equaling in power an ordinary grand piano, and yet absolutely free from the harshness that is too often a concomitant of strength. Great improvements have also been effected in the "action;" the one now used possesses many recommendations, and is pleasant and easy to the touch. Indeed, the many merits of the new instrument should be tested by all who take an interest in this highly important friend of the home circle. It will bear examination, and therefore we direct attention to it.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- To produce a piece called the "Sea of Ice" on such a night as last night, was a mockery, a snare and a delusion. All the rigors of the scenic artist failed utterly to impart the slightest coolness to the frozen zone, and it was quite apparent that Barabas, and the child, and the heroine, although pretending to be mortally stiff from exposure to hyperborean blasts, were, in fact, in a condition of exceeding limpiness, and might have been wrung out and dried with complete comfort to themselves. It was in the tropical scenes that the illusion became perfect. The fervid breath of the equator, laden with the delicate aroma of paint-pots and the seductive odor of newly-stirred dust, came gently through the house, and suggested that, after all, the people thereabouts might know what it was to be warm -- which in itself was cooling. Fictitious ice on a very warm night is an affront to which the many draughts of Niblo's Garden cannot reconcile us. A good pantomime were preferable, because we know that the people who present it must suffer more than we do; whilst in such a play as the "Sea of Ice," the pretence of superior coolness is aggravating and intolerable.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- To produce a piece called the "Sea of Ice" on such a night as last night, was a mockery, a snare and a delusion. All the rigors of the scenic artist failed utterly to impart the slightest coolness to the frozen zone, and it was quite apparent that Barabas, and the child, and the heroine, although pretending to be mortally stiff from exposure to hyperborean blasts, were, in fact, in a condition of exceeding limpiness, and might have been wrung out and dried with complete comfort to themselves. It was in the tropical scenes that the illusion became perfect. The fervid breath of the equator, laden with the delicate aroma of paint-pots and the seductive odor of newly-stirred dust, came gently through the house, and suggested that, after all, the people thereabouts might know what it was to be warm -- which in itself was cooling. Fictitious ice on a very warm night is an affront to which the many draughts of Niblo's Garden cannot reconcile us. A good pantomime were preferable, because we know that the people who present it must suffer more than we do; whilst in such a play as the "Sea of Ice," the pretence of superior coolness is aggravating and intolerable.

abstract: Invasion, the, of; Border States and Self-Reliance
snippet: Invasion, the, of; Border States and Self-Reliance
lead_paragraph: Whatever reason there may be to alter any opinion heretofore expressed as to the scope of the so-called invasion, there can be none whatever as to the needlessness of the alarms which have been rung at every village station where a rebel scout has made his appearance. The alarmists have put us to an enormous cost in the mere matter of telegrams. Our news columns bear witness that we have been compelled to give up, repeatedly, as much as half a page to what a close scrutiny has proved to be a mere mass of verbiage detailing over and over again, ad nauseam, some petty story of the burning of a railway bridge, or the destruction of some obnoxious citizen's private property.

abstract: The Rebel Prisoners Under Fire at
snippet: The Rebel Prisoners Under Fire at
lead_paragraph: -- The Charleston Courier of the 25th ult. heads one of its articles, "Three Hundred and Fifty-first Day of the Siege," and our guns at Cummings' Point continue to shell the place, notwithstanding the announcement of the rebel SAM JONES that fifty Union officers, held as prisoners, have been placed within range of our fire. Gen. FOSTER, however, has now an equal number of rebel prisoners under the fire of the rebel forts. Those who have been selected for this dangerous position are Maj-Gens. Edward Johnston and Frank Gardner, Brig.-Gens. J.J. Archer, George W. Steward and M. Jeff Thompson; Cols. Wesley R. Carter, M. Cobb, Basil Duke, M.J. Ferguson, J.M. Hanks, Richard C. abstract: -- A peculiar and serious accident occurred at the covered bridge near Wilmington, Del., on Sunday night, in which JACOB CHRISTOFFER, Company E, Tenth Regiment Veteran Reserve Corps, had his right foot torn off, and breaking the leg above the knee. It appears that the unfortunate man fell asleep, and while in that state pushed his foot through the open car window, and it coming in contact with the bridge, it was broken and torn off in the most terrible manner. The severed foot came through the next window, flying across the car, and struck one of the passengers, who, in the excitement of the moment, picked it up and thre[???] out of the car. Fortunately, Surgeon J.T. BURL[???]E, Thirteenth New-York Cavalry, was on board the train, who, in the absence of all instruments or bandage, tied up the shattered limb with a collection of handkerchiefs, and in that state the sufferer remained until the train reached Havre de Grace, where he was taken in charge by the Surgeon of the Post. It was feared that the wound would prove fatal. This is not the first accident of the kind that has happened at this bridge. A child, in the hands of its mother, was killed a short time since, and a man was dragged out bodily and crushed to death but a few months ago. Travelers cannot be too careful on railroad bridges. -- Baltimore American, July 11.

abstract: What is the real military importance of this rebel movement North? Does it materially change the military situation, which was previously regarded to be very favorable? These questions are important, for the Cop- perheads are doing their best to make the invasion a means of disheartening and disgusting the people with the war.
lead_paragraph: What is the real military importance of this rebel movement North? Does it materially change the military situation, which was previously regarded to be very favorable? These questions are important, for the Cop- perheads are doing their best to make the invasion a means of disheartening and disgusting the people with the war. They always use every unpleasant turn of affairs to make it appear that the rebellion cannot be overcome. Some of them, in view of the interests of their party, avoid making this argument in set terms, but they, none the less, take good care to shape their language to produce that impression. There are many faint-hearted, yet well-meaning, men, who have no broader faith in the final issue than what passing events supply. The opponents of the Government seize every opportunity to play upon the fears of these people, in one way or another, and often with considerable effect, as the ballot-box shows.

abstract: The news from Maryland this morning is meagre and indefinite. At 1 o'clock yesterday the rebels made their appearance on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at Bladensburgh and Beltsville, seven and twelve miles respectively from Washington, and interrupted telegraphic communication, since which time there have been neither dispatches nor trains.
lead_paragraph: The news from Maryland this morning is meagre and indefinite. At 1 o'clock yesterday the rebels made their appearance on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at Bladensburgh and Beltsville, seven and twelve miles respectively from Washington, and interrupted telegraphic communication, since which time there have been neither dispatches nor trains. The latest information from Washington is brought to Baltimore by a gentleman who left the former city at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time there was no fighting going on. Philadelphia furnishes its usual quantity of wild sensation reports, even going so far as to telegraph last evening that Washington had been captured. Telegraphic communication has been promptly restored between Philadelphia and Baltimore, and the damage to the Gunpowder Bridge is ascertained to be four hundred feet entirely burned, and about four hundred partly damaged. It is estimated that the repoirs will require frome four to seven days. The rebels appear to have moved away from the vicinity of the railroad, and from the immediate neighborhood of Baltimore. Yesterday morning, our cavalry dashed into Frederick City, routed the rebel guard of one hundred men left there, and recaptured the place. But little damage had been done ta the place, the citizens having paid a ransom of $20,000. From Hagerstown, it is reliably reported that there are no rebels west of South Mountain, and that Gen. HUNTER's forces are active. Gen. HOWE is in command at Harper's Ferry, and communication between Cumberland and Martinsburgh has been reopened.

abstract: Particulars of Death
snippet: Particulars of Death
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlanta Register of the 16th ult. gives the particulars of the death of Lieut.-Gen. LEONIDAS POLE, which do not differ materially from the accounts we have already published. He was in company at the time with Gens. JOHNSTON, HARDEE and JACKSON, upon Pine Mountain, in the rear of the batteries of the Washington Artillery from New-Orleans. They had all dismounted, and with their respective staffs had walked out to observe the Federal position, which was about 900 yards distant. Some one suggested that they would be apt to attract an unfriendly fire, and a few moments afterward a shell fell a little short of the party. The order was given to disperse, and the party divided and walked off in different directions, JOHNSTON and POLK together; the latter exposed himself by walking somewhat higher upon the brow of the hill, the former being below him. It was in this position and Gen. POLK was struck by the second shell which was fired. It went entirely through his breast, shattering the left arm about the elbow, crushing the breast and spine terribly, and shattering the right arm as it passed out. Col. YALE, his son-in-law and member of his staff, seeing him fall, rushed toward him, but, save a slight quivering of the chin as the Colonel raised his head from the earth, all other signs of life had fled. The Register states that after this the firing was continued, but our information leads us to believe that only the two shells were fired, as Gen. SHERMAN's object was entirely accomplished when he dispersed the group of officers who were making the reconnoissance of his position. Gen. POLK had in his coat pocket when killed his prayer-book and three copies of the Rev. Dr. QUINTARD's little work, entitled "Balm for the Weary and Wounded," which were intended as presents for Gens. JOHNSTON, HARDEE and HOOD, as their names were inscribed on the fly-leaves, with "the compliments of Lieut.-Gen. LEONIDAS POLK, June 12, 1865," They were all stained with the blood which flowed from his wound.

lead_paragraph: The Third, Ninety-fifth and Ninety-ninth Regiments are holding themselves in readiness to march at an hour's notice. Yesterday the commands of most of the military organizations in the City assembled at their armories for the purpose of consultation. It was decided by the different Colonels to tender the services of their respective regiments to the Government, to answer any call that may be made on them. The Fourth Regiment, 500 strong, leave to-day for Washington. Four hundred marine artillerists from the Navy-yard left yesterday, ex route for the capital.

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE, AUBER'S opera of "Fra Diavola" was revived here on Monday evening, and attracted a good and fashionable audience. It has evidently been put on the stage in great haste, and without that regard to preparatory rehearsal, which the light but delicate music of the French composer demanded.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE. -- AUBER's opera of "Fra Diavola" was revived here on Monday evening, and attracted a good and fashionable audience. It has evidently been put on the stage in great haste, and without that regard to preparatory rehearsal, which the light but delicate music of the French composer demanded. Some of the principal singers were at fault, and the concerted music generally hobbled rather than moved. "Fra Diavolo" makes a rather serious demand on the limited resources of the company. The caste involves not only good leading artists, but very good secondary ones, and these in the present state of the musical market are difficult to supply. At the Olympic they are exceedingly bad. The gentleman who played the part of Lord Allcash must have been selected by mistake, and under the impression that the burlesque and not the opera was to be performed. The Lorenzo, too, was tender to a degree of absolute softness. Mr. CASTLE's Fra Diavolo was less angular than his Don Caesar, and his dress, if possible, more absurd. The music of the role does not lie in the best part of his voice, and hence in the concerted pieces the latter was not heard to advantage. Still the performance indicates improvement. Mr. CAMPBELL's Beppo was the best sustained part in the opera. His make-up was excellent. The Zerlina of Made. BORCHARD was good, but a little too mature for the "Innkeeper's lovely, daughter." The graceful vivacity which characterised this lady's acting whilst at the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, seems to have deserted her now that she is on a somewhat larger stage. Miss LOUISA MYERS, as Lady Allcash, acted very prettily, but is scarcely equal to the musical requirements of the part.

abstract: It is quite impossible this morning to specu- late intelligibly or to any purpose upon the military news and rumors furnished by tele- graph.
lead_paragraph: It is quite impossible this morning to specu- late intelligibly or to any purpose upon the military news and rumors furnished by tele- graph. The interruption of telegraphic and railroad communication with the National Capital causes all operations in that vicinity to be screened from our view, or only to be seen at such a distance, and through such a distorted and befogged medium, as to render confusion worse confounded. On the one hand, the rebels are reported as retreating across the Potomac, and on the other, fighting is reported to be in progress at the immediate outposts of Washington.

abstract: - When Punch, some years ago, published the picture showing how to guard against railway accidents, by strapping a couple of Directors upon the engine, the idea was laughed at as a capital joke, but nobody had the least thought of its ever being practically illustrated. This war, however, amid all marvels which it has brought out, the new inventions and new applications of old ones which it has produced, has actually made that flight of fancy a fact. Gen. "WASHBURNE, commanding at Memphis, has realized that joke. He found  that his railroad trains were liable to an accident against which the utmost care of those who were running the trains, could not guard, viz: that of being fired into by rebel guerrillas. He found also, that instead of such accidents, when they occurred,being followed by the disapprobation of the rebel public, there were some of the citizens of Memphis who publicly applauded the ruffians who caused the disaster, and other persons along the line of the road who approved of the accidents and encouraged them. It was not difficult to draw a conclusion that there was some connection between those who caused and those who applauded these accidents, and the General not only drew this conclusion, but concluded that he would use these friends of the guerrillas as protectors, and therefore, by an order dated July 6, he has directed that forty of these sympathizers with guerrillas be compelled to do protective duty, twenty each day riding on the train "in the most conspicuous positions. The General adds that quarters will be fitted up for these new-fashioned guards "where they will be tenderly cared for when not on duty on trains." We wonder if he is a reader of IZAAK "WALTON; for this part of his order reminds one of that frog whom the patient angler, as he sewed his mouth up to make him a proper bait, was to treat "as though he loved him."
lead_paragraph: - When Punch, some years ago, published the picture showing how to guard against railway accidents, by strapping a couple of Directors upon the engine, the idea was laughed at as a capital joke, but nobody had the least thought of its ever being practically illustrated. This war, however, amid all marvels which it has brought out, the new inventions and new applications of old ones which it has produced, has actually made that flight of fancy a fact. Gen. "WASHBURNE, commanding at Memphis, has realized that joke. He found that his railroad trains were liable to an accident against which the utmost care of those who were running the trains, could not guard, viz: that of being fired into by rebel guerrillas. He found also, that instead of such accidents, when they occurred,being followed by the disapprobation of the rebel public, there were some of the citizens of Memphis who publicly applauded the ruffians who caused the disaster, and other persons along the line of the road who approved of the accidents and encouraged them. It was not difficult to draw a conclusion that there was some connection between those who caused and those who applauded these accidents, and the General not only drew this conclusion, but concluded that he would use these friends of the guerrillas as protectors, and therefore, by an order dated July 6, he has directed that forty of these sympathizers with guerrillas be compelled to do protective duty, twenty each day riding on the train "in the most conspicuous positions. The General adds that quarters will be fitted up for these new-fashioned guards "where they will be tenderly cared for when not on duty on trains." We wonder if he is a reader of IZAAK "WALTON; for this part of his order reminds one of that frog whom the patient angler, as he sewed his mouth up to make him a proper bait, was to treat "as though he loved him."

snippet: Florida; Electric Spark Captured by the
lead_paragraph: At the especial request of Capt. CASE, Commander of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, we refrain this morning from the grateful task of chronicling the herculean efforts, made since our last impression, by the naval authorities to hurl back the tide of invasion. It is deemed best not to publish, in detail, movements already partially in progress. Suffice it to say, that an immense amount of men and material has been forwarded to posts of danger in the best possible manner, within the last forty-eight hours; and that the abundant resources of ships, officers, sailors and marines at the disposal of Navy-yard commands have been wisely used.

abstract: Militia, the Necessity for a National Reserve of
snippet: Militia, the Necessity for a National Reserve of
lead_paragraph: We cannot help hoping that, if anything will ever serve to open the eyes of the public to the defects of our militia system, it will be the events now taking place in Maryland and Pennsylvania. This is the third time that these States have been invaded, and every time the enemy has found them totally unprepared to receive him, although the Governors possess full power, under the existing law, to put every able-bodied man under arms. Year after year, with full knowledge of the fact that a "rebel raid" across the Potomac was one of the likeliest incidents of each campaign, the people of these States have waited in perfect tranquillity until he had made his appearance in large force. The appearance of parties of cavalry, or even of a division, is not sufficient to rouse them. There has to be "reliable" information of the arrival of a corps or two before the great "rush to arms" is made, or the war meetings are convened. The Governor first calls for regiments; but as the regiments do not appear with the necessary rapidity, or, in fact, appear at all, the enemy continues to advance, harry and lay waste. The Governor then offers to receive volunteers by companies, and companies begin to be raised, but just at this moment telegraphic communication is suspended, and the curtain falls on a great mob of "citizens," running into the towns for shelter, and threatening the rebels with vengeance dire, if he does not immediately run away, which he never does till the United States have been gathered from all quarters of the Union to repel him. What makes this all the more inexcusable is, that there is little doubt that the present raid will cost more to Pennsylvania and Maryland, in the destruction of property and the suspension of business, than it would have cost to have kept 60,000 militia under arms for the last four years.

abstract: The American Club the leading one or our City organizations for Summer encampment in the country gave a grand entertainment on Monday evening, at their club-house and grounds at Green- wich, Conn., on the occasion of opening the same for the season of 1864. The guests were very numerous, upward of 2,000 visitors being present, of whom a large share were ladies.
lead_paragraph: The American Club -- the leading one or our City organizations for Summer encampment in the country -- gave a grand entertainment on Monday evening, at their club-house and grounds at Green- wich, Conn., on the occasion of opening the same for the season of 1864. The guests were very numerous, upward of 2,000 visitors being present, of whom a large share were ladies. The entertainments offered this large assemblage were varied, and gave delight to all. At 6 P.M., there was an Indian clam bake; at 9 o'clock an exhibition of fireworks, interspersed with the performances of a brass band; at 10 1/2 o'clock dancing was the order for the remainder of the night, except an intermission at 12 o'clock for a substantial supper, crowned abundantly with ice-cream. The club-house is located on a charming promontory, on and overlooking Long Island Sound, and is surrounded with a spacious and pleasant grove. The dancing took place upon a broad platform in front of the house, and in a large hall level with the platform, and opening upon it with several doors and windows. The pyrotechnics were fired from a small island about six hundred feet out from and directly in front of the club-grounds. The intervening space of water heightened the effects of the exhibition in a high degree. Supervisor WM. M. TWERD, President, Ex-Alderman CHAS. H. HALL, Secretary of the Club, and Street Commissioner CORNELL, Aldermen JONES, SHANNON, and FOX, and Councilmen KEENAN, BRADY, and HAGERTY, and also Police Justices HOGAN and SHANDLEY, who are connected with it, were indefatigable in efforts to promote the comfort and pleasure of the guests, who departed with high opinions of the personnel of the Club, and filled with admiration at the neatness and taste everywhere exhibited about the house and grounds. It should be added that the Club the next morning extended their bounteous hospitality to several hundred of the guests who remained, in the welcome shape of a good breakfast.

abstract: The steamer Etna, from Liverpool June 29, via Queenstown June 30, arrived here yesterday with one day's later news, but there is nothing in her advices. A meeting of the opposition members of the House of Commons had been held, at which was submitted a resolution of censure of the Government for its course on the Denmark war question.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Etna, from Liverpool June 29, via Queenstown June 30, arrived here yesterday with one day's later news, but there is nothing in her advices. A meeting of the opposition members of the House of Commons had been held, at which was submitted a resolution of censure of the Government for its course on the Denmark war question. On the same evening the in House of Commons Mr. DISRAELI gave notice that he intended to move the resolution on the Fourth of July. The papers generally declare that the adoption of the resolution would result in expelling the present ministry. The tone of the London press was gradually becoming more warlike. The reported capture of the Island of Alsen by the Prussiana is confirmed; the Prussians suffering but small loss. The Danes lost several guns. The United States war steamer Sacramento was at Table Bay, Cape of Good Hope, May 5, and the Wyoming on May 17.

abstract: - There seems to be now no doubt of the capture of Maj.-Gen. FRANKLIN by the rebels, in Maryland, on Monday. He recently returned from Louisiana, on sick leave of thirty days. He was wounded in the leg at the battle of Sabine Cross Roads, and his health was still feeble. He had just made a brief visit to the Army of the Potomac in front of Petersburgh, and was on his way from Philadelphia to Washington, when the train in which he was a passenger was captured.

abstract: Sergt. JAMES LAWRENCE ALLEN, named after Commander LAWRENCE, of "Don't give up the Ship" memory, whose death was recorded in our paper of yesterday, although only eighteen years of age when he was killed at Petersburgh, Va., a fortnight ago, had already been in the service over three years, and had reenlisted for a second term. He was made First Sergeant of Company D, Seventh Connecticut Volunteers, for good conduct, Large in stature, when fifteen years old, he readily passed the mustering officer at the beginning of the war. He has an only brother, but a few years older, who is a Captain in the Seventeenth Connecticut Volunteers, now at St. Augustine, Fla., and his father. Capt. WILLIAM ALLEN, is Commander of one of our gunboats in the Gulf Squadron.

abstract: -- Mr. A. MORTON, the eminent manufacturer of Gold Pens, has at length been compelled by the continual advance in nominal values caused by the inflation of our currency, to advance the prices of his goods. He has stood out through many months, incurring heavy losses in the hope that the end of the war would speedily enable him to boast that he had sold his pens throughout at peace prices; but he gives notice to-day that he can stand out no longer, and must henceforth charge enough for his goods to cover their cost.

abstract: - Our Paris correspondent chronicles the death at the Cherbourg Hospital of the brave fellow, GOWAN, who had his thigh crushed while serving one of the big guns of the Kearsarge. WINSLOW, the Surgeon of the Kearsarge gave an account of the bravery and fortitude shown by this gallant Yankee tar, and the company at once subscribed a handsome sum to build him a monument -- the Surgeon charging himself with carrying out the desire of the donors.

abstract: -- The telegraph informs us that the Democratic party of Indiana met in convention in Indianapolis, on Tuesday, and put in nomination an entire State ticket, headed by Hon. JOSEPH E. MCDONALD for Governor. For the other offices the present incumbents were renominated, which fact is sufficient to overwhelm he ticket with inglorious defeat. It will be opposed alike by the members of all parties interested in the financial policy of the State -- banks, bondholders, &c. With a treasury full to overflowing, they refused to pay the interest upon the funded debt of the State, denied support to the blind, deaf and dumb, and insane, whose care and education the State had assumed. Not a dollar could be had to succor the sick and wounded soldiers who had so gallantly maintained the honor and elevated the reputation of the State, while serving the cause of our common country; and, indeed, their principal business for the past two years appears to have been devoted to unsuccessful attempts to embarrass Gov. MORTON in the discharge of his legitimate and constitutional duties, as well as to render abortive his attempts to assist the national authorities in the suppression of the rebellion.

Not a dollar could be had to succor the sick and wounded soldiers who had so gallantly maintained the honor and elevated the reputation of the State, while serving the cause of our common country; and, indeed, their principal business for the past two years appears to have been devoted to unsuccessful attempts to embarrass Gov. MORTON in the discharge of his legitimate and constitutional duties, as well as to render abortive his attempts to assist the national authorities in the suppression of the rebellion.

abstract: Thackeray's Denis Duval; Bartlett's, J R, Bibliography of Rhode Island
snippet: Thackeray's Denis Duval; Bartlett's, J R, Bibliography of Rhode Island
lead_paragraph: This is an important publication, not only for the State, the materials of whose history are in it so carefully analyzed and recounted, but for all the other States in the Union, who are here presented with an example that each should follow -- a model that all should emulate. The absolute inutility of piling book upon book, while no guide is preferred to inform the student of their existence even, was never displayed more forcibly than in the United States, where the publicity attending all State proceedings, the general habit of reading and writing, among all classes, and the facility of printing -- combine to create a mass of documentary evidence greater in bulk and superior in authenticity to the archives of any other nation. How much of this is utterly unserviceable to the historical inquirer for want of proper bibliographical guides, is obvious to all. The neglect of this essential aid is the more remarkable when the passion (or mania, as it may almost be called,) for possessing and collecting rare books, tracts, manuscript, &c., on American history at prices that seems almost fabulous, is considered. But there is extant no general list of books on America, no catalogue of the legislative documents or Congressional papers of the United States Government, and until the publication of the volume before us, no State had taken the trouble to enumerate and classify the materials from which its history must be gathered. The Spaniards, even, are centuries before us in this matter. As early as 1629, Don LEON PINELO published a catalogue of writers on the Spanish possessions in America and the East, which, as enlarged by BARCIA, in 1726, forms three volumes in folio. England, too, has the American Bibliographies of WHITE KENNETT, (1713,) and REID, (1789,) and France can adduce the "Bibliotheque Americaine" of TERNAUX COMPANS, (1837.) We have nothing to compare with these but the "Bibliotheca Americana," by Mr. O. RICH, which, though the work of an American, was written and printed in England, and two productions of a German scholar, M. LUDWIG, who devoted himself to the pursuit with ardor, and died prematurely, after preparing his "Literature of American Local History," and of "American Aboriginal Languages.' So comparatively unoccupied is the field in which Mr. BARTLETT appears as a gleaner, and though his labors are confined to a corner of its vast extent, it is only by a similar partition of industry that anything satisfactory can be accomplished. The plan of his bibliography is to give the title of every printed book and pamphlet that relates, in any way, to the State of Rhode Island, including the biographies of men prominent in its annals, and of natives of the State distinguished in public life, or who, by their virtues and good deeds, deserve to be remembered. The abundance of material afforded by this State, so small in geographical extent, may be judged when it is seen that the present bibliography contains nearly three hundred handsomely and closely printed pagesembodying, at a rough calculation, about two thousand titles of distinct works and editions, most of which are accompanied by the interesting bibliographical or literary notes of the laborious editor. Mr. BARTLETT is already most favorably known to the historical world by the noble publication of the Early Colonial Records of his native State, in ten volumes, an undertaking set on foot and most ably edited and superintended by him, in his official capacity of Secretary of State. The same industry and diligence are visible in every page of the Rhode Island Bibliography, and it leaves nothing to be desired in respect to printing and style of "getting up." It is printed by order of the General Assembly, and only a limited number are reserved for miscellaneous sale. It will undoubtedly, at no distant day, become a scarce book.

abstract: on Patriotism and Enlightened Self-interest
snippet: on Patriotism and Enlightened Self-interest
lead_paragraph: "In times of general and local peril, enlightened self-interest is emphatically the synonim of patriotism," says Mayor GUNTHER. He probably meant his own patriotism. As a definition of the patriotism of the loyal men of the country, we repudiate it. It is bastard and beggarly. It is all of a piece with the patriotism of FERNANDO WOOD in saying in Mozart Hall "Loyalty is a monarchical derivation. It is a European extract. No loyalty for me; I know no such word." The Copperheadism of the day comes mainly from just that low idea of the relation of the citizen to the nation.

abstract: The Cunard steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 2d and Queenstown on the 3d of July, arrived here yesterday. A seaman's boarding-house keeper in Liverpool had been brought before the Police Court, on a warrant from the Treasury, charging him with obtaining seamen for the rebel cruisers Georgia and Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 2d and Queenstown on the 3d of July, arrived here yesterday. A seaman's boarding-house keeper in Liverpool had been brought before the Police Court, on a warrant from the Treasury, charging him with obtaining seamen for the rebel cruisers Georgia and Rappahannock. The case was sent to trial. An iron-plated vessel, supposed to be intended as a successor to the Alabama, had gone out from Bordeaux. From a statement made in the House of Commons, it appears that orders have been sent out to canada to have the British forces stationed in that Colony concentrated at Quebec and Montreal. An attempt to get a vote of censure on the British Government, in connection with their policy in Japan, was made in the House of Lords on the 1st inst., and failed by 30 to 11. On the third reading of the Oxford University Tests Bill in the House of Commons the Government were defeated, the vote being 171 for the bill, and 173 againts. The British revenue returns for the year ending June 30, 1864, show a net decrease of £690,000 sterling as compared with the receipts of the year preceding. Particulars are given of the capture of the Island of Alsen by the Prussians. Two thousand four hundred Danes were taken prisoners. Sonderborg was partly burnt down. The London Liberal press reiterates an expression of its belief that a "Holy Alliance" has been formed between Russia, Austria and Prussia. We publish an interesting letter from our Paris correspondent, which supplies some additional particulars of interest relating to naval affairs in European waters. A complimentary dinner had been given by Mr. DAYTON to Capt. WINSLOW, who was on a visit to Paris. The Emperor, it is said, has taken occassion to show his sympathy for Capt. SEMMES.

abstract: Parliamentary Test Vote
snippet: Parliamentary Test Vote
lead_paragraph: -- The British mail, received yesterday by the Australasian brings no new facts bearing on the proposed party test vote which was to be taken in the House of Commons on Monday, the 4th of July. We have some new and ingenious calculations, however, as to the strength the Conservatives will show on that occasion. The highest figuring gives them 271 votes, which would be all they want. But there appears to be not even the shadow of a chance of their showing any such a front. The policy on the Dano-German question turns out to be practically the same as that of the Whigs, to talk much, and talk sympathizingly of Denmark, but do nothing. The debate, however, will afford an opportunity for the indulgence, to the fullest extent, of that trenchant criticism of which Mr. DISRAELI is so thorough a master. His speech will doubtless be the chief feature of the discussion, as nearly everything the Government can say in self-justification has already been said by Lord PALMERSTON, in presenting the result of the Conference deliberations to Parliament.

abstract: Honors to
snippet: Honors to
lead_paragraph: - If it be true, as French journals assert, that the privateer SEMMES is at once to have another ship; and if it be correct, as is stated, that a French-built cuirassed corvette is to be furnished him as a war-ship, then the Kearsarge may soon have an opportunity of testing itself against a French naval vessel and guns, as it has just tested itself against an English-built vessel and guns. The gallant crew of the Kearsarge have now such confidence in their powerful engine and their 11-inch columbiads, that they would fight any first-class cuirassed frigate of European build without fear. The practice we have just had and may still have with English and French-built naval ships, may possibly convey salutary lessons to them as well as to us.

abstract: I must write again to-day about naval affairs in European waters. You will see how wide an extension the discussion has taken in England, especially about the fight between Capts. WINSLOW and SEMMES, and you will understand that, independent of the personal question in dispute, in regard to the escape of the prisoners, the affair has an immense scientific importance for England.
