abstract: The Magnolia Raid
snippet: The Magnolia Raid
lead_paragraph: -- We publish an intelligent account of the rebel raid on Magnolia Station, on Monday last, from a gentleman who was a passenger on one of the captured trains. He puts the number of rebels engaged in this affair as very small -- less than a hundred; and shows that it was simply of a predatory and plundering character. The rebel robbers carried on operations after the true classic style of highwaymen. They protested that they would in no way interfere with the private property of passengers, and then coolly proceeded to rob all the folks aboard the train. They broke open and rifled trunks, valises and carpet-bags, stole money, watches, shirt-studs and everything they could lay their paws on. They stole eight hundred dollars from a sailor boy just discharged the service, and two dollars and fifty cents from a poor old man -- every farthing he had. All this time they were loudly proclaiming their honorable intentions. They also burned and robbed houses after the same fashion. The raid had no military object whatever. It was quite akin in character to the operations of a gang of Mexican guerrillas, though they did not carry the matter quite so far as is frequently done by the latter, who, often after robbing a train, strip the clothing from the passengers, and send them into the city in the costume in which Job came into the world. The rebels, however, will soon get to this point, we have no doubt.

abstract: Possibility of
snippet: Possibility of
lead_paragraph: The rebels, in the course of this war, have made many movements and fought many battles of a desperate character. This last movement of theirs is of that nature. We have pointed out more than once of late the immense strength Of GRANT'S position on the Appomattox. It has appeared, we think, conclusively, that if our great army but remain firmly planted where it now is, and if our cavalry arm operate constantly and trenchantly upon the communications of the rebel capital, it will be quite impossible for LEE and his army, or JEFF. DAVIS and his Government, to remain long in Richmond. "A city invested is a city taken," for the simple reason that if the besiegers can but maintain their lines, the garrison must ultimately succumb from want. Richmond has never yet been, and is not now, invested, technically speaking; but the military axiom just quoted is perfectly applicable to it, if Gen. GRANT, from his impregnable position in its rear, can, by his cavalry arm, describe a line around it sufficient to cut off from it the essential supplies derived from the great producing regions of the Confederacy. Now, in the first place, Gen. GRANT has shown, within the past fortnight, that this is perfectly feasible and practicable; and in the next place, on the other hand, Gen. LEE perfectly comprehends the impossibility of dislodging GRANT from his present ground, either by direct assault upon it or by manoeuvering round it.

abstract: --Maj. E.T. SULLIVAN, of the rebel army, yesterday visited the office of Capt. OVER, Commander of the post, and took the oath of allegiance to the United States Government. He belonged to the Second Texas Infantry, but is a resident of Kentucky. When the rebels came to Harper's Ferry on their recent raid, SULLIVAN was sent up the railroad toward Duffield's Station, in command of a battallion to destroy the track. After the work of destruction had been performed the command returned to Harper's Ferry and SULLIVAN remained a short time and proceeded to Maryland. He is quite lame having been wounded some months ago in the Southwest. He is sick of the rebellion and the war, and is going home to retire from the strife. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, July 11.

abstract: A SOLDIER RESCUED FROM DROWNING, Yesterday afternoon, a little after 5 o'clock, as the steamboat Empire State was leaving Pier No. 3 North River, a wounded soldier, belonging to the Twentyseventh Massachusetts Reqiment, jumped from the dock on to the guards of the boat, and missing his hold, fell into the water, Catching hold of a rops which was hanging overboard, he saved himself from sinking, out was dragged about 400 feet out
lead_paragraph: A SOLDIER RESCUED FROM DROWNING, -- Yesterday afternoon, a little after 5 o'clock, as the steamboat Empire State was leaving Pier No. 3 North River, a wounded soldier, belonging to the Twentyseventh Massachusetts Reqiment, jumped from the dock on to the guards of the boat, and missing his hold, fell into the water, Catching hold of a rops which was hanging overboard, he saved himself from sinking, out was dragged about 400 feet out into the stream, Officer THOMPSON of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, and Officer HANFORD of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, were on the dock at the time of the accident and rendered all necessary assistance. Officer THOMPSON told him to let go of the rope and he would save him, but finding him too much frightened to follow this direction, the officer ran cut to the end of the pier and hailed the tug propeller Arctic, which immediately went to the rescue of the drowning man, and saved him just as he was on the point of sinking from exhaustion. Much praise is due to Capt. H.H. MARTIN and the crew of the Arctic, and also to Mr. E. LITTLEFIELD, Agent of the Fall River Line, who hired a wagon to take the man to the hospital on the Battery, and directed that he should be comfortably cared for at his expense. He was taken in charge by the hospital steward and treated to a warm suit of clothes, a good supper and lodgings for the night.

abstract: - Mr. WEST, President of the Fishermen's Club and proprietor of the Franklin House, Tarrytown, was in the City yesterday. He brought with him the six-pound brook trout caught by Mr. E.R. abstract: The "invasion," the "raid," or whatever it may be called, is evidently at an end. The latest news from Washington, with which place telegraph and railroad communication was reestablished yesterday, announces that on Tuesday the rebels demonstrated feebly in front of Fort Stevens, ...
lead_paragraph: The "invasion," the "raid," or whatever it may be called, is evidently at an end. The latest news from Washington, with which place telegraph and railroad communication was reestablished yesterday, announces that on Tuesday the rebels demonstrated feebly in front of Fort Stevens, annoying our forces somewhat with their sharp-shooters. Our troops at length took the defensive and charged upon the enemy, driving him precipitately from the position. The rebel column, it seems, at once took up its retreat, passing through Rockville at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, on the march to Poolesville and Edward's Ferry. At the latter place, the dispatch says, the rebels were engaged in crossing their wagons and plunder collected during the raid. Our loss in the fighting on Tuesday was about two hundred killed and wounded. The rebels left over one hundred of their wounded at Silver Spring. There was no damage done to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad on the Washington branch, and the rebels failed to destroy the iron bridge over the Monocacy, on the main stem. Both Gens. TYLER and FRANKLIN have escaped from the enemy, and the former has arrived in Baltimore.

abstract: From a journal (The Nor' Wester) published at Red River Settlement, in the Hudson's Bay Territory, we learn that Dr. RAE, the Arctic Explorer, and a fellow-enterpriser, Mr. SWEIGER, arrived at that place on the 20th of last month, in the capacity of pioneer surveyors of an intended line of telegraph which is to stretch from Red River to the Pacific, on British American territory. Dr. RAE talks confidently of rich gold fields in prospect on the Saskatchewan, and he hints that Imperial money will be got to open up the proposed line of communication. The obstacle in the way of realizing these dreams of progress in the Northwest is the anomalous form of local administration under which the Territory is held. Until a regular Government on the colonial or some other system is formed, telegraph and other enterprises fall into the category of purely visionary projects.

abstract: The Academy of Music was crowded last evening, upon the occasion of the twelfth annual commencement of the Free Academy. Gerard, Esq., Brlg.-Gen. Hays, Prof. Lieber, of Columbia College, Prof. Peaslee, of Dartmouth College, Hon. Gulian C. Verplanck, and others. The exercises commenced at 6 1/4, with appropriate music, and after prayer by Rev. Dr. CHAMBERS, the published programme was proceeded with.

abstract: "Hostilities around Washington and Baltimore have ceased," says one of this morning's dispatches from Washington. "The great rebel raid is over," says another. "The main force of the rebels is now (Thursday) in full retreat, trying to save their booty," it is further added.
lead_paragraph: "Hostilities around Washington and Baltimore have ceased," says one of this morning's dispatches from Washington. "The great rebel raid is over," says another. "The main force of the rebels is now (Thursday) in full retreat, trying to save their booty," it is further added. These are the great facts of the morning's news, though there are other matters of interest, such as the reopening of telegraphic and railroad communication with Washington, and the escape of Gens. FRANKLYN and TYLER.

abstract: GEORGE WEIRICK, late an active member of Engine Company No. 19, while proceeding to the fire in Baxter-street on the 12th instant, was almost instantly killed by the collision of Hook and Ladder No. 5 and a City railcar in Chatham-street. The funeral service will be held in the Third-street Church, near Avenue A. The Fire Department will form in Third-street, right resting on Avenue A. The Fire Department banner to be in charge of the delegates from each company. The fire-alarm bells will be tolled during the moving of the procession, commencing at 9 o'clock A.M. The body will be interred in Calvary Cemetery.

abstract: The Corporation propose to have the street lamps, at the points nearest to the hydrants, fitted, with red-stained glass, as indicators to the firemen at night. Emulating this proposed improvement, Postmaster WAKEMAN, we are told, is about to issue orders to have the letter-boxes attached to the lamp-posts painted red and lettered white, with the names of the different stations inscribed on them. The Postmaster, we understand, is also about to extend the convenience of the lamp-post boxes to the upper part of the City, for the accommodation of the suburban population, whose numbers and whose wants are increasing at so rapid a rate.
lead_paragraph: The Corporation propose to have the street lamps, at the points nearest to the hydrants, fitted, with red-stained glass, as indicators to the firemen at night. Emulating this proposed improvement, Postmaster WAKEMAN, we are told, is about to issue orders to have the letter-boxes attached to the lamp-posts painted red and lettered white, with the names of the different stations inscribed on them. The Postmaster, we understand, is also about to extend the convenience of the lamp-post boxes to the upper part of the City, for the accommodation of the suburban population, whose numbers and whose wants are increasing at so rapid a rate.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The latest news from the rebels in Maryland, is that they will probably escape across the Poto- mac in the vicinity of Edwards' Ferry, without serious loss our forces evidently not being strong enough, or not being concentrated soon enough to attack the enemy with assurance of success.
lead_paragraph: The latest news from the rebels in Maryland, is that they will probably escape across the Potomac in the vicinity of Edwards' Ferry, without serious loss -- our forces evidently not being strong enough, or not being concentrated soon enough to attack the enemy with assurance of success. It is now more clearly demonstrated than ever that the rebels were purely on a plundering expedition, and that they had neither the strength nor the intention to seriously menace either Washington or Baltimore. There was very little injury done to any of the railroads, the Baltimore & Ohio, even on the main stem to Harper's Ferry, being but slightly damaged. Trains are running as usual to Washington. In the fight on Tuesday, which resulted in compelling the enemy to retire from before Washington, our loss was about 300. We give very full details this morning of the entire affair, from our special correspondents.

abstract: Officers Under Fire at Charleston
snippet: Officers Under Fire at Charleston
lead_paragraph: We have accounts from our army before Charleston of one or two attempted operations in that locality, which have not proved as perfectly successful as might be desired, though we have lost a considerable number of men by them. As there is no very desperate haste in operations there, it is desirable that the outlines and details of all projected movements should be carefully prepared, and that experienced and efficient officers be appointed to the execution of each of them, so that there shall, if possible, be few or no failures from the faults of subordinates.

abstract: Our Charleston correspondent gives the names of the rebel officers, prisoners in our hands, who have arrived at Hilton Head, to be placed under the fire of rebel guns in retaliation for a similar proceeding with Union prisoners on the part of the enemy. There are two Major-Generals, three Brigadier-Generals, fifteen Colonels, and the remaining thirty are Lieutenant-Colonels and Majors. These rebel officers, though under fire, are very close to their own lines, and some of them will doubtless make desperate efforts to escape. Among them are some very sharp and adventurous fellows, accustomed to all sorts of tricks -- such as JEFF. THOMPSON, the old guerrilla chief of Missouri, and BASIL DUKE, who was the right-hand man of JOHN MORGAN, as long as he was a successful raider. There is no doubt that Gen. FOSTER will keep a sharp eye on these chaps.

abstract: By the steamship Liberty, which arrived here from Havana, at a late hour on Wednesday night, we have Mexican news to the 2d inst. and Havana dates to the 9th. It is said Gen. URAGA, with his whole army, has given in his adhesion to MAXMILIAN, and that this example has been followed by Gen. DOBLADO.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Liberty, which arrived here from Havana, at a late hour on Wednesday night, we have Mexican news to the 2d inst. and Havana dates to the 9th. It is said Gen. URAGA, with his whole army, has given in his adhesion to MAXMILIAN, and that this example has been followed by Gen. DOBLADO. Both statements are feebly contradicted. It is more than probable they are true. The guerrillas between Toluca and Morelia, are in sufficient force to rob the mails and to drive the stages from the route. The Spanish Consul at Oajaca had been murdered. A military commission is appointed to arrange for the organization of the new Imperial army. The Emperor has appointed Don FRANCISCO MORAN to announce his accession to the throne of Mexico at the courts of St. Petersburgh, Stockholm and Copenhagen. A minister is also named to Turin. Several resignations had taken place in one or two departments of the civil administration. A grand ball had been given in honor of the Emperor and Empress by Gen. BAZAINE. It is described as having been an affair of refined taste and magnificence.

abstract: The rebel raid, which was looked upon as being too insignificant to require serious attention, has exceeded all others in magnificent daring. Judging from the results so far, it is a greater achievement than HUNTER'S. They are at the very doors of two cities, fortified as strongly, perhaps, as engineering skill could devise, destroying property in the outskirts with perfect impunity, regardless, apparently, of any force we can send against them.

abstract: and Harmony of Union Party; Harmony a Prime Necessity
snippet: and Harmony of Union Party; Harmony a Prime Necessity
lead_paragraph: We greatly regret to see a disposition in some quarters of the Union party to keep up old bickerings. Even were there any principle involved in them, they would be inexcusable, since the party, through its accredited representatives, has settled all its essential principles at Baltimore. But so far as we have been able to discover, there is not a particle of any principle in dispute. The strife is all personal. We are ashamed to say that it seems to spring entirely from personal jealousies and personal grudges. One set catches up with eagerness every occurrence that makes against another set, which, in turn, loses no opportunity to recriminate. This thing has gone on until, latterly, portions of the Union party are as much given up to scandalous wrangling as was ever the Greek camp in the Trojan siege.
headline: {'main': 'The Harmony of the Union Party a Prime Necessity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Harmony of the Union Party a Prime Necessity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Popular Practice of
snippet: Popular Practice of
lead_paragraph: An in telligent and experienced military correspondent, writing from Newport, urged recently, through our columns, the importance of the introduction of target practice with the long-range rifle, as a pastime or national amusement. In the Tyrol, Switzerland, and many parts of Germany, rifle-shooting is a constant and popular sport. In England, the organization and drill of the Rifle Volunteers have developed through the country a very respectable amount of skill in the use of this arm. We now stand in fearful need of a better proficiency in the use of the long-range rifle. It does not differ in its construction, necessarily, from our old hunting rifles, except in the sight and the form of the projectile. The Swiss military rifle, according to Maj. MORDECAI's report, is essentially an American hunting rifle, with an elevating sight, and an elongated but simple projectile. The bore is quite small, being only about what is called seventy to the pound. The shot weighs about half the weight of our new rifle musket shot -- say 257 grains. This rifle has the longest range, and the most deadly flight, as well as more accuracy, than any military small arm in the world. An arm possessing every possible accuracy and good quality can be made in this country, in ordinary times, for about $30, and by the quantity for much less.

abstract: It has so often appeared certain that the Hudson's Bay Company's monopoly of seventy thousand square miles of territory, on this continent, was about to be overthrown, when in reality the Company was only about to acquire a new lease, that the public, both here and in England, have ceased to believe in any official promises given in the premises. Mr. ARTHUR MILLS succeeded in getting this subject brought up for discussion, a few days ago, in the British House of Commons; and speaking for the Colonial Department Mr. CARDWELL repeated the old story, that the Imperial Government was in correspondence with the authorities in Canada, to endeavor, if possible, to arrange for the habitable portion of the territory being ceded to that colony. The trouble, we believe, is, first, that the commutation claims of the company, founded on their spurious title to the territory, will not be recognized by the Canadian people; and next, that the Red River colonists are themselves by no means eager to become a dependency of a dependency, as they would do, were they annexed to Canada. Many of the most influential residents at Red River prefer to such a fate annexation to the United States. There is a barren waste between Canada and the Northwest Territory of 500 miles.

abstract: -We are enabled to contradict, on good authority, the statement that has been sent from Mexico, through French sources, that the Republican General, URAGA, had turned traitor to his country, and submitted to the intervention. He has not done so, but is at the head of a respectable force in the State of Jalisco, in the western part of Mexico. The French assertion that Gen. DOBLADO had deserted the Republic is also false. He commands a force at Monterey.

abstract: Invasion of; Annual Scare on Border
snippet: Invasion of; Annual Scare on Border
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvanians and Marylanders have now had their annual "scare." All the bells in the two States have been duly rung; all the citizens have duly assembled in the market places, and duly volunteered to serve for as many days as the rebels might choose to stay on Northern soil; the annual "war meeting" has been held in Independence Square in Philadelphia, and the male members of the audience have made their yearly offer "to fly to arms;" the clergy have, as their annual custom is, duly "worked on the fortifications under a broiling sun." The Governorhas issued his annual call to arms, containing his annual reminder of the necessity of driving "the insolent invader" from the sacred soil, and letting the world see what 25,000 undisciplined and enraged Pennsylvanian are capable of achieving. The "reliable gentleman" and "well known citizens," have come in from the front, as their wont is, and made us all acquainted with the doings of the rebel cavalry - - the cattle lifting, horse stealing, house burning, to which these gentlemen are in the habit of treating themselves every Summer, during the hot weather, in the neighborhood of Philadelphia and Baltimore. In short, the annual tribute from Pennsylvania and Maryland to the rebel commissariat has been duly paid, and by this time EARLY and his raiders are across the Potomac with at least the greater part of their booty. Of course the new levies are hard on their track, and are "surrounding,'" and "cutting them off," and "getting in their rear," and slaughtering them, as their annual custom is. It is well known that after each Pennsylvania levy en masse, the butchery of the rebels is frightful.

lead_paragraph: WHOLESALE ROBBERY BY A FEMALE -- $2,500 WORTH OF GOODS RECOVERED. -- A woman who gave her name as MARIA FISCHER, was taken into custody yesterday by Officers FIELD and WALLING, of the Fifth Precinct, by orders of Capt. PETTY. MARIA was found at Union Hill, New-Jersey, with three large and well stored trunks in her possession. WHOLESALE ROBBERY BY A FEMALE -- $2,500 WORTH OF GOODS RECOVERED. -- A woman who gave her name as MARIA FISCHER, was taken into custody yesterday by Officers FIELD and WALLING, of the Fifth Precinct, by orders of Capt. PETTY. MARIA was found at Union Hill, New-Jersey, with three large and well stored trunks in her possession. An examination of the trunks was made, and several gold watches, silk dresses, and other property, valued in all at $2,500 were found therein. All of the above specified property is known to have been stolen from persons in this City. Louis BERGER, clothier, No. 58 Bowery L. MYEES, No. 61 Fulton-street; MARIA WIESS, No. 51 Fifth-street, Hoboken; ELIZABETH LOSS, of No. 117 West Nineteenth-street, and several others, are said to have suffered by the theits of the accused, MARIA has been fully identified by several of the victims. Many of the stolen articles are now at the Sixth Precinct Station-house, for which owners are wanted. A man named FERDINAND VOGHT, who is suspected of having been an accomplice of MARIA FISCHER, has been arrested. They are both held for trial.

abstract: The latest news from Maryland brings no intelligence of any further fighting. The rebels are said to be across the Potomac, and pursued by our forces, but the latter statement needs confirmation. The reports from various portions of Maryland which were visited by the enemy, all agree as to the ravages which the rebels committed. Horses, cattle, hogs and sheep were swept clean, and much personal robbery and thieving was also indulged in.

abstract: The Albany papers of Tuesday announce the death on that day of MARCUS T. REYNOLDS, who, although for several years past withdrawn from active life, has in his day been one of the most distinguished members of the bar of this State. Mr. REYNOLDS was born in Florida, Montgomery County. He received a liberal education -- graduated in 1808 at Union College -- studied his profession at Johnstown, in the office of the late Attorney-General HILDRETH and Judge HARRIS, the latter of whom still survives, and in 1811 commenced the practice of the law at Amsterdam, then in the same county. At a bar composed of such men as DANIEL, CADY, DANIEL PARRIS and men of that class, he soon rose to distinction. In 1828, having previously married a daughter of Dr. SAMUEL DEXTER, of Albany, he removed from Amsterdam to that city, and for the next quarter of a century he occupied the very first rank of his profession -- had a large and lucrative practice -- and was engaged in a large proportion of the most important cases that came before the higher courts of this State.

abstract: It is obviously a proper time to show those persons at borne and abroad, who have been ridiculing the Government for Its construction of some fifty monitors and harbor iron-clads, that the United States has also a formidable fleet of sea-going armored vessels in course of active preparation, nearly half of them being afloat, and that they were built while numerous writers were stoutly lamenting the neglect of the authorites in providing impregnable craft for the protection of our commerce on the deep. It is well known that the Government never intended the thirty-eight turreted vessels, now nearly all on active service, for cruising. They were improvised for harbor defence, and no specification in any contract required that they should be able to do ocean service. Many of them were indeed, simple iron and wooden hulls, fastened to a sort of raft, and their torte was to be fighting, not sailing. Other ships were ordered for other purposes, and they will soon be tested, when the country and the press will have an opportunity to judge of their merits. In a few days one of them will go to sea, in command of one of the best sailors in the United States regular navy, and the New-York journals will doubtless record her behavior.

lead_paragraph: The ground we have recently and repeatedly taken as to the feasibility of reducing the rebel capital by operating trenchantly upon its lines of communication and supply from our superb position at Petersburgh, is well sustained by an astute military writer in the London Star of the 27th ult. He says that the problem which Gen. GRANT has to solve is one of the hardest in war -- viz., how to take a city, not a fortification in the ordinary sense of the term, which can be invested, but the centre of an intrenched camp, occupied by an army of one hundred thousand men. It is the very problem which all but baffled the united forces of England, France, Sardinia and Turkey, during the Crimean war. Nothing can exceed the strength of LEE's position, which is that of a General who has fallen back upon his base, to which the whole South is more or less open for the purpose of supplies in man, provisions, ammunition, hospital stores, clothing, and the various requirements of an army. Practically it would be impregnable to an army assaulting it from the north side, unless that army were nearly double in point of numbers, and even then the only omnipotent weapon would be the spade. The superiority of the James River as the Federal base consists mainly in its relation to Lee's line of supplies and retreat. The difficulty and apparent helplessness of the Allies at Sebastopol, lay in their inability to get at the routes by which the vast resources of Russia were poured into the city -- so much so that they were glad to act on the principle that half a loaf was better than no bread, and be content with the conquest of the southern portion only.

lead_paragraph: There are three species of Copperheads. Those who, like ALEXANDER LONG, are for abolishing the war and recognizing the independence of the Confederacy outright. Those who, like FERNANDO WOOD, are for abandoning the war and trying to negotiate the Secessionists back into the Union. Those who, like Gov. SEYMOUR, profess to be for the war, but are for prosecuting it with milder means and methods.

abstract: The steamship Caledonia, which arrived from Glasgow at Cape Race, yesterday morning, brings intelligence from Paris to the 5th, and from London to the 6th inst. The news is meagre and unimportant.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Caledonia, which arrived from Glasgow at Cape Race, yesterday morning, brings intelligence from Paris to the 5th, and from London to the 6th inst. The news is meagre and unimportant. The rumor is repeated that the Florida is waiting for the Kearsarge outside of Cherbourg. The only item of interest relative to the war in Denmark is that the Swedish squadron had received orders to put to sea immediately. An insurrection is reported in Andalusia. CHANG-CHOW-FOO has been captured by Maj. GORDON.

abstract: -Dr. NICHOLAS, of New-York, who has, since the outbreak of the war, been among the most able and indefatigable workers of the Sanitary Commission, and who has for some time past been at the head of the chief hospital of the Commission in Washington, received a woupd in the arm from a minie ball in the skirmish before Fort Stevens on Monday afternoon. Dr. NICHOLAS had gone out to the skirmish line to attend to the wants of some of our wounded soldiers, and it was while la discharge of this duty that he received his own honorable wound. It was at first reported that the Doctor had suffered amputation of the arm; but we are happy to state that this is not so. Though, severely wounded, it is hoped it will not be necessary for him to lose his arm. This contradiction is made to relieve the anxieties of a large circle of friends who have been deeply grieved at the affliction of one Of the most self-sacrificing of Christian patriots.

abstract: Sanitary Commission and Unauthorized Collectors
snippet: Sanitary Commission and Unauthorized Collectors
lead_paragraph: The war has given birth to voluntary associations for purposes of benevolent enterprize, such as have had, confessedly, no parallel in history. Among these associations, the Sanitary and Christian Commissions bear a peculiarly representative character; the one having its origin in that growing devotion to the problems of social science which forms, as it were, a distinctive feature in cotemporary scientific research; and the other being the offspring of that practical missionary spirit which has of late begun to find scope for its labors within the boundary of native heathendom.

abstract: -An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner RANNEY, on the body of CHAS. MURE, a native of Canada, aged 32 years, who died from the effects of poison which, by mistake, he took from a bottle that he supposed to contain gin. Deceased resided at No. 380 East Tenth-street, and was by occupation a mechanic. He was engaged to make some repairs on the steamship Fire Queen, which cleared for China on the 8th inst., but which is now reported to be in Halifax. The steamer was to sail at 12 o'clock on Saturday last, and at 11 o'clock deceased went Into the engineer's room for the purpose of making some repairs. He saw a bottle on the engineer's table, filled with what he supposed to be gin. He seized the bottle and asked a man that was with him to partake, but the invitation was declined. MURE thereupon took a drink from the bottle. He was immediately taken ill, and lingered in great agony until Thursday. Dr. JOHN BEACH made a post-mortem examination, when he found that deceased had died from the effects of corrosive poison, (supposed to be sublimate,) and the testimony all showed that this poison was contained in the bottle that deceased thought was gin. The bottle and contents left for China on Saturday last.

abstract: A correspondent writes from Guaymas, Mexico, June 29, that official information has been received there of a conspiracy to seize one or more of the steamers on the coast for privateers, and that a party had been sent from Secessia for that purpose. abstract: Promptitude of
snippet: Promptitude of
lead_paragraph: The Washington Chronicle of Friday says: "The mail receipts at the Post-Office are at present the largest ever known in Washington. Dates up to the 13th have been received from New-York. Nine malls were due from all the principal cities North and West, and the amount of mail matter received filled seven wagons and two hundred and eighty mail pouches, and one hundred and seventy-five bags. This is the largest mail over received at one time in Washington. The enormous amount of work thus entailed upon the various departments of the Post-office will necessitate as much patience from the public as it will unremitting application in the Post-office employes. When it is remembered that the mails have to be separated, that the army mails have to be opened and assorted, first according to States and then to regiments, some adequate idea of the amount of labor to be accomplished can perhaps be formed.

abstract: Crowded as the history of the American civil war will be, with romantic incidents and stirring adventures, there will be few more interesting than the capture of Maj.-Gen. WILLIAM B. FRANKLIN by the rebels, and his subsequent escape. Even the brief account telegraphed from Baltimore reads like a chapter out of a romance, and it was so good, and so nearly Correct that it is scarcely worth while to say more on the subject.
lead_paragraph: Crowded as the history of the American civil war will be, with romantic incidents and stirring adventures, there will be few more interesting than the capture of Maj.-Gen. WILLIAM B. FRANKLIN by the rebels, and his subsequent escape. Even the brief account telegraphed from Baltimore reads like a chapter out of a romance, and it was so good, and so nearly Correct that it is scarcely worth while to say more on the subject. But the General himself, in his conversation, mentions many new facts, some of which are worth putting into print.

abstract: -We have looked with some curiosity over the accounts given by the crews of the vessels recently captured by the Florida, of the state and condition of things on board that famous vessel, and we regret to state that, from what they say, there seems strong reason to believe that the stories published about her by the Columbia (S.C.) Carolinian some time since, and vouched for as derived from Mr. S. VOGEL, one of the officers on board the Florida, were not in all respects correct; but that Mr. VOGEL had, with that playful fancy which is a universal characteristic of the sailor ashore, been humbugging his Carolinian friends with yarns only fit to be told to the marines.

abstract: Domiciliary Visits to Houses of Liberals
snippet: Domiciliary Visits to Houses of Liberals
lead_paragraph: Freedom cannot be numbered among the blessings which the Empire confers on France. Every Englishman's house may be his castle, but the domicile of the Frenchman is not thus privileged. Into the minions of power can enter at all hours, and under the most frivolous pretences. A few months ago the residences of some of the leading citizens of Paris were forcibly entered by the police, their guests dispersed and their papers seized, because they had presumed to assemble to discuss the prospects of the approaching political campaign; and now again a similar outrage has been perpetrated on the same individuals because of offences still more venial.
headline: {'main': 'French Freedom.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'French Freedom.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A CARMAN HANGS HIMSELF. JAMES TAMNEY, a carman, residing at No. 158 Washington-street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself by the neck from the top of a door on the second story of the premises, by means of a leather strap.
lead_paragraph: A CARMAN HANGS HIMSELF. -- JAMES TAMNEY, a carman, residing at No. 158 Washington-street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself by the neck from the top of a door on the second story of the premises, by means of a leather strap. Deceased bad been living unhappily with his wife for some time past. He recently attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat, and upon another occasion soon after, he swallowed a dose of poison for the same purpose of self-destruction. About a week since he commenced drinking to excess, and continued to be under the influence of liquor up to the time of his death. Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest on the body, and the jury rendered a verdict of death from suicide by hanging. Deceased was a native of Ireland, aged 45 years.

abstract: Memminger and Rebel Gov Brown on Little Ada's Clearance; Rebel Gov Half Share of Runner's Profits; and Memminger, on Little Ada's Cargo
snippet: Memminger and Rebel Gov Brown on Little Ada's Clearance; Rebel Gov Half Share of Runner's Profits; and Memminger, on Little Ada's Cargo
lead_paragraph: The rebel papers publish a correspondence between Mr. MEMMINGER and the Governor of Georgia, from which it appears that Gov. BROWN'S views of State rights bring him into collision with the Confederate authorities in reference to other matters than the Georgia railroads, which JOHNSTON was going to destroy as he was "drawing" SHERMAN toward Atlanta, but did not because of Gov. BROWN'S protests. It seems that the Rebel Congress some time since passed a law that every vessel which took cotton out through the blockade should take half of her cargo on account of the Confederacy. This was a very good move, because it enabled the rebel Government to get its cotton out in order to raise funds to buy supplies. Some of the State authorities also desired to export cotton, but they did not think it proper that this prohibition should be extended to the vessels owned or chartered by a Sovereign State -- and so the Governors of Georgia, Mississippi, Alabama and North Carolina, in April last, joined in a representation to the rebel Congress, stating that, when they desired to send out cotton in this way, they were met by an order from Mr. MEMMINGER preventing the vessels from clearing unless they had taken half their cargo for the Confederacy; and the Governors argued the question not only on grounds of expediency, but also on Constitutional grounds, denying that the power "to regulate commerce among the States" gave the rebel Congress power to put such a restriction upon the States, although they do not seem to have denied its power to apply the same restriction to individuals, and they boldly declared that when it was "in their power to assist the Confederate Government with State vessel they would do so with great pleasure, but they would not consent to do it under compulsion," not though State vessels were as plenty as persimmons.
headline: {'main': 'State Rights in Rebeldom.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'State Rights in Rebeldom.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: National Guard; the Regiments to be Formed
snippet: National Guard; the Regiments to be Formed
lead_paragraph: An erroneous impression exists in the minds of many concerning the movements of the militia under the new call. It may be generally stated that all regiments sent from the City in answer to the call of the Government for one hundred days' men will be held until the expiration of their term of service. Those regiments which proposed to enlist for thirty, sixty and ninety days, to repel the invasion of Maryland, will probably not be called into the field. The regiments ordered to march to Washington are making preparations for their departure. Information has been obtained from headquarters that none of them will leave before to-morrow. The work of recruiting is going on rapidly. Supervisor BLUNT averages about twenty-five enlistments per day, and Col. NUGENT has obtained nearly one hundred men who are to enter the army as substitutes for commuters. This means of filling the ranks of the army has been largely made use of by patriotic gentlemen exempted from draft. In several instances men over sixty years of age have subscribed for substitutes. The preparations for the State draft, ordered by Gov. SEYMOUR, to fill up the National Guard regiments, are going forward, under the superintendence of Col. S.R. PINCKNEY. It is expected the work will be completed this week, when the enrollment lists will be ready for correction. Brig.-Gen. A.S. WEBB has been detailed by the Secretary of War as superintendent of recruiting of the Second Corps in this State, and will visit Albany and Elmira with a view to organizing Hancock recruiting committees in those cities. The following important order relative to 100 days' men has been issued by Gen. SPRAGUE:

abstract: Denmark and Earl Russel's Explanations; Earl Russell's Policy Toward; Claybanks, Charcoals and Paw-Paws
snippet: Denmark and Earl Russel's Explanations; Earl Russell's Policy Toward; Claybanks, Charcoals and Paw-Paws
lead_paragraph: The explanations of the British Ministry touching the course which England has pursued, and means to pursue, in relation to Denmark, are of a most unsatisfactory nature. According to those explanations, the conduct of the British Government has been from first to last altogether blameless. The sole object of Earl RUSSELL was to bring Denmark to reason, and to allay the irritation of Germany; and when he could not accomplish one or the other of these things, and war broke out, he philanthropically called a conference to effect a compromise, and to induce both parties to settle their differences. The conference, however, could no more accomplish this feat than Earl RUSSELL himself, and so the armistice is at an end, and the conflict has been renewed. But why should England be held accountable for these unfortunate results, or be bound any more than Russia, Sweden, or France, to succor the Danes? The great interests of England everywhere constrain her to remain at peace -- the looming up of a vast military and naval Trans-Atlantic Power requires her to act with circumspection. Were the Danish isles indeed in the possession of the allies, and were Copenhagen beleaguered, then England might interpose between King CHRISTIAN and his enemies, but while the war is confined to the continent she must decline to engage in it.
headline: {'main': 'England and Denmark.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and Denmark.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The promptitude of Gen. WALLACE, commanding the Department of Maryland, in advancing from Baltimore to meet the rebels at Frederick when they first appeared, and his bold attempt to defeat on hold in check the whole invading force with the small body of men which he hastily collected, are generally recognised. Though he had but a limited force at his disposal, and though his command did not extend to the other side of the Potomac, he took what troop he had, marched with them to the Monocacy, and instantly gave the enemy battle. And though his small force was insufficient to defeat them in the field, it is a fact that after that fight their infantry made no farther; advances in the direction of Baltimore, but struck southward to Washington. He appreciated his duty at the right moment and executed it promptly and bravely. Had there previously been as vigorous action on the other side of the Potomac, the invasion would never have extended over Maryland as it did. He still retains command of the Middle Department.

abstract: United States vs Schooner Darby; What is a Rebel Port?
snippet: United States vs Schooner Darby; What is a Rebel Port?
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner George Darby and her Cargo. The Collector of the Port on Sept. 26, 1863, seized the above vessel and cargo anchored in the harbor, having commenced to depart from this port, destined on a voyage to Beaufort, N. C. The next day a libel of information was filed against the vessel and cargo in the cause, demanding the forfeiture of the vessel and cargo and their condemnation to the use of the United States because of the violation of the acts of Congress of July 13, 1861, and May 12, 1862, (12 Stats. at L., 257 and 404,) and the proclamations of the President of Aug. 16, 1861, and May 3, 1862, and the rules and regulations of the Secretary of the Treasury of May 12, 16 and 23, and of Aug. 28, 1862.

abstract: Florida the; Mr Vogel's Glowing Account of; North and South--Baltimore and Richmond
snippet: Florida the; Mr Vogel's Glowing Account of; North and South--Baltimore and Richmond
lead_paragraph: It has been commonly remarked that the women at the South have done a great deal to aid the rebellion and to encourage the rebels have borne privations and hardships, and accomplished labors, which have done them infinite credit, and have given no small assistance to the rebel cause. This matter has been dwelt upon not a little abroad, and rid little sympathy has been obtained for that cause in England and elsewhere by persistent talking about the enthusiasm of the rebel women. In fact, to read the talk of some of the papers and their correspondents, one would think that it was only the rebel women, North or South, who have shown any enthusiasm at all -- at least it is theirs which is dwelt upon.

abstract: Raid; News Abroad
snippet: Raid; News Abroad
lead_paragraph: The Arabia, one of the slowest of the Cunard vessels, which has temporarily taken the place of the Persia, took out the news of the interruption of communication with Washington, on Wednesday last. On that morning the streets of New-York were filled with the wildest kind of rumors. Gold had been quoted as high as 281 on Tuesday, and sales were made of sterling bills at 295 and 298. The morning journals (Wednesday) were compelled to surrender each a page or more to the sensation newsmen of Philadelphia, Baltimore, Havre de Grace and Harrisburgh. The wildest possible scope was given to every sort of report, and to every species of rumor. And to add to the general riot among the vast crowd of alarmists, not a line could be had by mail or telegraph from Washington for over thirty-six hours. It was high carnival time among the prophets of evil. They had foreseen it all. They bad spoken one to another, and it had come to pass even as they had said. They knew what would be the upshot. But their words had seemed an idle tale. Now, however, truth was vindicating itself. A corrupt Administration was to succumb and give up, and be utterly overthrown on the very scene of its deepest atrocities, suffering the last penalty of its crimes at the hands of those whom it had hoped to crush.

abstract: It is gratifyingto know that the frigate Neshamony, which is intended to operate against privateers, and which, by reason of her size, model and powerful machinery, is expected to do good service, is rapidly progressing, and that she will be ready for launching in the month of August. The frame of the frigate has been strengthened in a way that insures great resistance to ordinary-sized shot and shell; and as her boilers will be entirely below the water line, there is no fear of their being touched by any shot that may penetrate her hull. The Neshamony will be able to carry as large in armament as any vessel afloat, she being about 350 feet long and 4,000 tons burden. A large force is now engaged upon the frigate, and the Government desires her to be completed as soon as possible. Should she not be delayed by her machinery, she may be got ready for sea by the early part of the Fall. Several vessels of the same class are being constructed at other ports. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 11.

abstract: Having been a radical Abolitionist from the time I began to know anything, it is not to be expected that I would regard a temporizing, milk-and- ...
lead_paragraph: Having been a radical Abolitionist from the time I began to know anything, it is not to be expected that I would regard a temporizing, milk-and-water policy, with reference to Slavery, with more patience than other radicals, especially in a crisis like that through which our country is now passing, And yet I am compelled to differ with many, If not most, of the old Abolitionists, in respect to the estimate they place upon Mr. LINCOLN's wisdom in dealing with the recognized cause of all our troubles.

abstract: The situation of affairs at Washington is again one of quiescence. The news from the pursuit of the rebels into Virginia is neither full nor definite.
lead_paragraph: The situation of affairs at Washington is again one of quiescence. The news from the pursuit of the rebels into Virginia is neither full nor definite. It is generally understood that we have a large force in the rear of the enemy; but it is not expected that the retreating foe can be made to stand and fight. He is too richly laden with booty to risk battle, unless he gets into a bad fix, which can scarcely happen in the broad valleys of Virginia. Everything is reported quiet in front of Petersburgh, with a promise of interesting news soon.

abstract: A telegram from Copenhagen of June 30, says: "The Danes have withdrawn beyond Horup-Hav skirmishing during the retreat. No further pursuit occurred, and they reached Vollerup in good order at noon yesterday, where they have since embarked."
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Copenhagen of June 30, says: "The Danes have withdrawn beyond Horup-Hav skirmishing during the retreat. No further pursuit occurred, and they reached Vollerup in good order at noon yesterday, where they have since embarked." A telegram July 2, says: The loss of the Danes in the retreat from Alsen is officially stated to amount to from 2,500 to 3,000 men, most of whom being killed and wounded; among them are 81 officers. The remainder of the troops and the war material are now being brought away from Alsen. Very considerable contributions have been imposed upon the inhabitants of Jutland.

abstract: The French in; M. Massera's Programme; M. Dommartin's Colonization Scheme
snippet: The French in; M. Massera's Programme; M. Dommartin's Colonization Scheme
lead_paragraph: The ingenious author of the Programme of the Empire in Mexico, recently published in this City, would have us believe that the Imperial policy toward that country was dictated by the purest and most unselfish philanthropy. According to M. MASSERAS, the paternal heart of the usurper, who waded to his throne through blood, was wrung with grief at the spectacle of a land desolated by internal feuds, and rapidly sinking into a state of irredeemable anarchy. No unworthy motives of personal or national ambition entered into his designs. His sole object in invading Mexico was to restore a wasted land, and to lead back a distracted and well-nigh ruined people into the pleasant paths of peace, prosperity and national greatness.
headline: {'main': 'The French in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The French in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A letter in the Charlottsville Chronicle, dated Camp near Martinsburgh, 5th instant, says:  "After skirmishing with the enemy at Bunker's Hill, the division of Gen. , with GILMORE'S cavalry in the advance, entered Martinsburgh on the evening of the 3d instant. Up to 10 o'clock of the 3d, no intimation had been received by the enemy of the ad- ...
lead_paragraph: A letter in the Charlottsville Chronicle, dated Camp near Martinsburgh, 5th instant, says: "After skirmishing with the enemy at Bunker's Hill, the division of Gen. , with GILMORE'S cavalry in the advance, entered Martinsburgh on the evening of the 3d instant. Up to 10 o'clock of the 3d, no intimation had been received by the enemy of the advance of our infantry, who thought the movement only one of MOSBY's. The enemy, some seven thousand strong, all one hundred day men, with the exception of seven hundred men, regular cavalry, retreated hurriedly from Martinsburgh on the Harper's Ferry road. Immense quantities of supplies fell into our hands -- with one million's worth of medical stores, and an unbounded quantity of quartermaster supplies including one hundred thousand bushels of corn and oats.
headline: {'main': 'FROM MARTINSBURGH.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FROM MARTINSBURGH.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival of the Illinois here yesterday, we are in possession of later news of interest from Central and South America. There is a report that France asks reparation for the insults offered to her Consul at Panama, while M. SALAZAR, the Spanish Commissioner to Peru, was his guest. From Peru there is intelligence of active naval and military preparations in view of the Chincha Island difficulty with Spain, resulting in war between the two countries. abstract: STRIKE OF CAR-DRIVERS. -- On Saturday, the drivers on the Jersey-City and Bergen Horse Railroad demanded an increase of wages to two dollars, and, being refused, they left off work. Consequently, the cars on the different routes run quite irregularly during the day. It was reported yesterday that the company had acceded to the demands of the drivers.

abstract: -- The rebels, if we may judge by the late Richmond papers in our possession, seem to have been about as much astonished at the raid, when they heard of it, as the people of the North were when it occurred. They are, of course, rather hilarious over it, and over the panic it caused on the border. But they evidently knew little or nothing about it beforehand, which, we think, is a proof that the force engaged in it was not very enormous, and perhaps, also, that the whole thing was undertaken on the spur of the moment, when EWELL found that Gen. HUNTER had retired from Lynchburgh. Of course, both Gen. LEE and EWELL would have liked to take Washington, even though they could have held it but a day; but we do not believe the invading party left Richmond with any such prospect.

abstract: Miss AVONIA JONES and the members of the Wallack company return to the standard drama tonight -- the lady appearing as Juliet in SHAKESPEARE's "Romeo and Juliet." The admirers of Miss JONES will be glad of this opportunity of seeing her in some of her best parts. At Niblo's Theatre the programme remains unaltered. The "Sea of Ice" will probably run through the entire engagement of Miss LUCILLE WESTERN. The next "star" at this establishment will be Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL. At the Olympic Theatre the English Opera Company continue to draw fashionable audiences. BALFE's inevitable "Bohemian Girl" is to be produced to-night. Although slightly hackneyed, it is more within the reach of the artists than AUBER's "Fra Diavolo." Another and charming work by the same composer, called the "Rose of Castile," is in preparation and will be brought out next week. Mr. REIFF, the conductor, displays a rare amount of industry, and all the artists work hard for the small amount of success they have obtained. Last week's programme is unchanged at the Broadway Theatre -- Miss HELEN WESTERN appears nightly in the military drama of the "French spy" and the farce of "A Devilish Good Joke." At Barnum's Museum the pantomime company has been received with great favor, and "Mazuim, or the Night-Owl" is to be repeated until further notice. The Mud-fish, the nove musical instrument called the "Orchestrion," the giant and a thousand other novelties are still among the attractions of this popular place of Summer resort.

abstract: The Times, of Monday, says: "The programme for debate is a matter not always in the hands of either Government or Opposition. Any independent member may throw himself athwart the battle field and compel the fight to take his course. It was the wish of her Majesty's Ministers to meet Mr. DISRAELI's resolution with a decided negative, but Mr. KINGLAKE unexpectedly occupied the ground with a resolution which raised a new issue, Here were thus, therefore, two distinct questions before the House. Mr. KINGLAKE was accordingly urged to withdraw his amendment, in order to leave the Government the exclusive command of a reply to be made to Mr. DISRAELI. Mr. KINGLAKE would not give way. It is needless to observe that this is really a question of confidence, and so understood by both supporters and opponents of her Majesty's Government."

abstract: Alabama; The French Officers' Visit to
snippet: Alabama; The French Officers' Visit to
lead_paragraph: -- The excitement in French military and naval circles concerning American ships and guns has been on the increase ever since the Kearsarge and Alabama fight. A commission of French officers recently visited the Kearsarge and were permitted to inspect her thoroughly. After examining the guns, and listening to the explanations of the Executive officer of the Kearsarge, one of them exclaimed, "We haven't a gun in the French navy worth a rush." On further examination they were "astonished," and subsequently their "astonishment bordered on incredulity." It seems that this combat, like that between the Monitor and Merrimac, is going to create in Europe a second revolution in naval warfare.

abstract: CHARGE OF PASSING COUNTERFEIT MONEY.  ANN DOOLEY, an Irishwomen, residing at No. 99 West Houston-street, was arrested on Saturday night by Officer CHUTKOWSKI, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, charged with attempting to pass a ten dollar counterfeit bill, of the Bank West Winfield, NewYork State, at the grocery store of Mr. HENRY WELLBROOK, No. 32 Bedford-street, in pay for groceries.
lead_paragraph: CHARGE OF PASSING COUNTERFEIT MONEY. -- ANN DOOLEY, an Irishwomen, residing at No. 99 West Houston-street, was arrested on Saturday night by Officer CHUTKOWSKI, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, charged with attempting to pass a ten dollar counterfeit bill, of the Bank West Winfield, NewYork State, at the grocery store of Mr. HENRY WELLBROOK, No. 32 Bedford-street, in pay for groceries. Upon being brought before Justice DODGE, ANN plead not guilty. She stated she was a housekeeper and a collector of rents, and that she took the bill alluded to from one of her tenants. Judge DODGE required her to find bail in the sum of $500, in default of which she was committed. FRANCES CHATTERTON, a young woman 26 years of age, and a native of Richmond, Va., was arrested by Officer BARBER, of the Fifteenth Precinct, charged with passing a similar bill on Miss ELIZA DRUMMOND, at the store of M[???]me. ALIXE DOUBLET, NO. 697 Broadway, in payment of a head-dress. She was taken before Justice DODGE, and stated that she was not guilty, that she resided at No. 15 Carroll-place, and that she did not know the bill was a bad one when she offered it. She was ordered to find bail in the sum of $500 to answer, which she did, Mr. CHARLES F. WEBBER, of No. 42 Grand-street, becoming her surety.

abstract: Markets a d Currency
snippet: Markets a d Currency
lead_paragraph: The occurrences of the past few days in the produce and money markets show pretty conclusively how completely we may rely, after all, on the operations of the laws of trade to protect the public against the machinations of the speculators. For manyweeks back almost all the necessaries of life have been bought up in enormous quantities, and "held for a rise," by a number of large operators. Prices did rise accordingly, and the consumers, and especially the poor, who have to make their purchases from day to day, suffered accordingly. As is usual after a period of great speculation, there followed what is termed a tightness in the market -- that is, difficulty in borrowing money at all, or at any but high rates of interest. The banks found themselves obliged to contract their loans, partly as a measure of prudence, and partly of necessity. The enormous rise in prices of course called for a greater quantity of currency to do the work of exchange, and the rashness of the speculators naturally inspired greater caution in dealing with them. When the price of things doubles, it of course needs -- not double the quantity of the circulating medium -- for the quantity required depends partly on the rapidity of circulation, or, in other words, the multiplicity of transactions -- but a very much larger quantity than before, to enable people to carry on their business. The speculators in this case calculated on having this required addition supplied by the Treasury in the shape of a fresh issue of legal tenders. But this relief has not come; in other words, the laws of trade have been left to take their course. They hoped to be able to borrow in order to enable them to continue to hold, and they relied on a fresh expansion of the currency to carry the prices up to the point at which they desired to sell. They have been disappointed in both cases, and have been left to get out of their scrape precisely as they would have had to get out of it in the old days of specie payments. Like all speculators, they have saddled themselves with more goods than they were able to pay for, and finding it impossible to borrow money to meet their engagements, there is nothing left but to sell out. Once this process begins, a panic of course sets in, and prices fall with a daily accelerating ratio. We have accordingly had a fall of thirty per cent. in gold, and from ten to twenty per cent. within the last three or four days in nearly every species of produce.

abstract: Carleton's Library Ed???ns, Miss Bronte, Miss Muloch, >amp;c.; Miller's Elements of Chemistry; Part 1; Carlyle's Frederick the Great; Vol 4; Chase, S P, (The Ferry Boy and the Financier); Furman's Medical Regis er of New-York; Wax Flowers; Skeleton Leaves; Ferry Boy, the, and the Financier; Haunted Hearts; Da Costa's Medical Diagnosis; Central Railroad of New-Jersey; Guide to; Wilson, Dr Bird; Birnson's Memorial of
snippet: Carleton's Library Ed???ns, Miss Bronte, Miss Muloch, >amp;c.; Miller's Elements of Chemistry; Part 1; Carlyle's Frederick the Great; Vol 4; Chase, S P, (The Ferry Boy and the Financier); Furman's Medical Regis er of New-York; Wax Flowers; Skeleto...
lead_paragraph: With the success that often rewards persistent effort, Mr. CARLYLE has at last brought both English readers and the English press into a somewhat slavish state of submission to his literary vagaries. They are not only a little blind to his faults, and very kind to his virtues, but in their indiscriminate admiration they seem to have lost all power of distinguishing between these two classes of qualities. Hence his arrogant and insolent treatment of all former laborers in the same track, passes current for honest intrepidity of speech; his tedious and vapid pedantry is accepted for humor, and the "mud volcano" of unsavoring epithets, that bespatters the unfortunate subjects of his wrath, is the outpouring of a righteous indignation to those who regard him as the most finished historian, the profoundest philosopher, and the most nervous writer of the age. There are many, no doubt, not prepared to go to these preposterous lengths, who will look with interest on this new installment of a work that will always command respect as a monument of strenuous labor, however great its misapplication. It embraces about thirteen years of FREDERICK the Great's life, including the Second Silesian War, Ten Years of Peace, and the First Campaign of the Seven Years' War. Just thirty years of a career always eventful in incident remain to be treated of, and these must demand at least three additional volumes, and may, at the uncertain pleasure of the author, be made to furnish material for a much greater number. The first duty of a historian is to write what will be read. Unless this point is secured everything else goes for nothing. Now, it is perfectly safe to say that a work in seven or eight volumes, of the style and composition of the History of Frederick, cannot possibly maintain its place among the standard living literature of the language, but must drift aside, and merely serve in the end to increase the number of the "dry-as-dust sand heaps," "unsifted marine stories," &c., that clog the way of the historical inquirer, and excite the measureless scorn of Mr. CARLYLE himself. For what results from his painful labors, in their dusty regions, that call forth groans so interminable from their self-appointed explorer? Are the matertals thus collected used for the construction of a symmetrical work of art; a book, in short, such as the world is always ready to welcome, displaying competent knowledge of its subject, and written with the honest aim of elucidating a portion of the history of the past? Nothing of the kind is to be found in CARLYLE's Frederick. It is simply a new tossing about of the contents of those "sad Prussian Repositories," and "dismal Literary Diatribes," in defiance of all human arrangement, and in a spirit so partial and strong in its prepossessions' that no student could safely accept its conclusions without a reviewal of the whole mass of authorities. The uncouthness of the form under which the writer's deductions are presented, is too well-known to all readers to need dwelling on, but his utter incompetence to grasp any but the coarsest lights and shades of FREDERICK's character is well illustrated in this volume, where the great King's legal and economic reforms -- the measures that gave his realm the strength necessant to support its existence through the awful crisis of a seven years' struggle -- are dismissed in two or three pages, as belonging to an "orthodox dismal science" that the writer has no sympathy with, while a closely printed chapter of twenty-two pages is devoted to M. VOLTAIRE's "powerful Jew law-suit," a wretched and obsolete stock-jobbing squabble; and his indecorous relations with his "divine EMILIE" (Madame DU CHATELET) are investigated with equal minuteness in another. In spite of his denunciations of "garbage" and "demon reporters," matter of this kind is not wanting in various portions of the book. Mr. CARLYLE's intellectual position is an unfortunate one. With all the fervor of wrath and stubborn obstinacy of opinion that inspired his countrymen, the old Covenanters, his philosophy has led him far away from their stand-point and their belief in the immediate divine government of the world has given place to mere "inarticulate shriekings" about "the destinies," "the immensities," &c., and with all the passions of a devotee nothing remains for his worship but an empty shrine, where his false gospel of "brute force" is installed, and hymned with uncouth praises of her favorite sons, the Cromwells and Fredericks, whom CARLYLE especially delights to honor; of course, one who formerly wrote so well cannot, even when willfully perverse, bring out a book without many striking touches of description, graphic bits of character painting, dramatic scenes, &c., and for the sake of these the pages of FREDERICK's life will be turned over by lazy readers, who enjoy the excitement afforded by a good hater; but for one who derives his idea of the Prussian King from CARLYLE's laborious farrago, a thousand will draw their impressions from the brilliant sketch -- unfortunately not completed -- that MACAULAY has devoted to his life and history. What is clear is often condemned as superficial, and the shallow profound will always have its admirers; but in this case the clamorous and turbulent research of the one writer has produced nothing that need modify the estimate of his hero formed by the other, whose exquisite art in the concealment of an was never more favorably displayed than in this memorable article. Messrs. HARPER's edition of The Life of Frederick is favorably distinguished from many American editions by the possession of all the illustrations, military maps, &c., of the English copy and a complete index.
headline: {'main': 'NEW BOOKS.; HISTORY OF FRIEDRICH THE SECOND, CALLED FREDERICK THE GREAT. By THOMAS CARLYLE. Volume 4. 12mo. New-York: HARPER & BROTHERS. abstract: Wants of; Christian Commission at
snippet: Wants of; Christian Commission at
lead_paragraph: The first thought probably with most practical people when the work of the Christian Commission for the army is mentioned, is that it is a well-meaning, sentimental enterprise, rather than anything very real and substantial. Many persons come to look at an army as something by itself, outside of American life, and not very much open to any influence of a religious organization. We shall all understand the army and the work of the two Commissions better, if we simply reflect that this great and historic body of men is made up of young men, very much like the brother or son or kinsman of any one of ourselves. Each soldier has his past individual history, his own private struggles with the problems of life, his temptations, his hopes, his loneliness and heart-sickness, his desire for a more manly character, and his looking forward to the unseen and eternal, just like any one of our own nearest friends. His individuality is not destroyed in the army; on the contrary, it is often more developed. And, just as for our young boy or brother or cousin in camp, we would wish certain influences upon his character -- just as, if he were lying wasting with dysentery on the hospital pallet, or wearing the long hours away as the bullet-wound slowly heals, or recovering from the deep depression and prostration of the typhoid, or dying lonely in some sick ward, with only strangers around him, we would be glad to have cheering words spoken to him of the best and truest things, and the way of life pointed out, and the hope of immortality held up, and a prayer breathed out to sweeten the last moments, so we may wish for the whole army, and so we may understand the nature and value of such labors as those of the Christian Commission.

abstract: The faithful and benevolent women and men throughout the land who are laboring in works of charity for the benefit of the soldiers, must never for a day relax their efforts. It may seem a long time to labor, month after month, and year after year, as many good people have done for the last three years, making lint, sewing shirts, making jellies, collecting money, and so forth, for the sick and wounded soldiers in camp and hospital. But compare the application to these light and pleasant duties with the continuous and terrible struggles of the soldiers themselves in the Virginia and Georgia campaigns. And when the comparison is made, let there be a still more noble devotion to the work. The demand from the army is increasing, and the supply of material also should be ceaseless. A gentleman, who is on a visit to the soldiers' hospitals in Portsmouth, Virginia, writes to the TIMES from there, under date of Wednesday last:

abstract: Kearsarge; The Chain Armor of; Richmond Dispatch on
snippet: Kearsarge; The Chain Armor of; Richmond Dispatch on
lead_paragraph: Capt. WINSLOW, as is well known, hung part of his ship's cable over the sides of his vessel to protect her machinery from the Alabama's shot during the fight. This act greatly enrages the chivalrous knights of the Richmond Dispatch. "Had such a foul advantage," says that journal of the 13th, "been taken over one knight by another in the days of chivalry, the perpetrator would have had his spurs hacked off by the common hangman, his arms reversed, his name stricken from the roll of honor, and his carcase stretched by the neck, between sun and earth, until the birds of the air had torn his eyes from their sockets." This is certainly very severe upon the gallant Captain. But did not the rebels take an equally "foul advantage" of us when they used "masked batteries," or torpedoes, or when by deception they surprised us, as in the late Maryland raid? What can they say in defence of the naval rams which they were the first to use in this war, and by which they took foul advantage of our ships in the Passes of the Mississippi; or of the iron plating of the Merrimac, by which they took advantage of the Cumberland and our other wooden vessels in Hampton Roads? What, in fact, can they say in defence of war, which, in short, is a system of taking all possible advantages of your enemy, foul or fair? This Richmond rebel is certainly very amusing.

abstract: THE RECENT DISASTROUS FIRE AT THE FOOT OF JORALEMON-STREET.--The scene of the recent fire on the dock at the foot of Joralemon-street was visited, yesterday, by hundreds of persons who were anxious to see the result of the late disaster. The goods remain as they were left on Friday evening, after the fire. Nothing appears to have been removed. The
lead_paragraph: THE RECENT DISASTROUS FIRE AT THE FOOT OF JORALEMON-STREET. -- The scene of the recent fire on the dock at the foot of Joralemon-street was visited, yesterday, by hundreds of persons who were anxious to see the result of the late disaster. The goods remain as they were left on Friday evening, after the fire. Nothing appears to have been removed. The large quantity of hides on storage is burned to a crisp, the guano is exposed and looks like a heap of dust, the sugar and molasses are mingled with the dirt, and the nitrate of soda, what there is left, lays about loose. Several persons anxious to try experiments as to the explosive qualities of nitrate of soda, satisfied themselves a little before noon yesterday. Some bags, which had been saturated with water, were tried. Matches were applied, and the result was -- a fire. There was a puff, and flame, and smoke arose sufficient to attract the attention of the Fire Department, which turned out very promptly. It was reported that the experimenters were blown overboard, but such is not the fact. They became convinced, however, that nitrate of soda would ignite on the application of fire. It is not definitely known in what manner the original fire was caused. Some of the workmen state that the men in the office threw stumps of cigars out of the windows, which fell among the explosive materials, while others think that it originated in some other way, which they cannot explain. The workmen were at dinner at the time the fire originated, and thus escaped harm. The buildings along Forman-street show the effect of the numerous explosions. The rear doors and windows were broken, the chimneys were tumbled down, and everything in the houses trembled with the concussions. The debris caused by the falling of the ceilings has since been carried into the street, and still lies there in remembrance of the disaster. The insurance on some of the property destroyed is as follows:

abstract: Rebel Writer on the Folly of
snippet: Rebel Writer on the Folly of
lead_paragraph: -- A Georgian rebel writer condemns in very severe and proper language the damage that arises from the too-common practice of holding out fictitious prospects of immediate and glorious triumph. The words are applicable on this as well as on the other side of the rebel lines. "Let us," he says, "earnestly beseech our people to faithfully and steadily work and hope for results, but let us not imitate the enemy in vain and premature boasts. Let us not make ourselves a laughing stock of Europe, by winning victories on paper not yet won on the field. Let us not quicken the popular pulse at home with dreams and prophecies of glorious victory; for no expected evil harms half so much as the blood that leaps forth in the ecstacy of triumph, ebbing back in sick convulsion upon the disappointed heart. Often have our people been deceived by false and delusive hopes, gotten up with the best intention in the world, by those who think they help our cause by proclaiming victory in the thickest of peril. God help them to have, more judgment for they surely do not realize the sickening sense of utter despair, the utter crushing of bright dream flowers, which is the inevitable result of those believed-in prophecies of sure success, when followed by inevitable disaster."

lead_paragraph: Gen. SANDFORD received an order yesterday from the War Department, which directs him to ac cept the militia of his division according to their re- gimental organizations. The Seventy-seventh, Col. THOMAS LYNCH, will probably be the first regiment of the 100 days' men in the field. Col. LYNCH has been indefatigable in his exertions to perfect his organization. He has now under his command about 500 men. At a recent meeting Capt. THOS. NORTON was elected Lieutenant-Colonel of the regiment, and Capt. P.A. MCMAHON Major.

abstract: An Englishman tells the London Times an entertaining story of his adventures as a blockade runner, which we copy. He finds it difficult to say which of the available routes to the South, by land or water, is, on the whole, the best, as he made a voyage from Richmond by way of Washington and New-York to England in twenty days, and returned from England to the Confederacy by sea in just the same length of time. He attempts to show the great ease of running the blockade by ship to Wilmington, but his own experience to that port was sufficiently perilous and he subsequently speaks of our blockade as the "only blockade on a large and imperial scale which has been established since the introduction of steam navigation."

He attempts to show the great ease of running the blockade by ship to Wilmington, but his own experience to that port was sufficiently perilous and he subsequently speaks of our blockade as the "only blockade on a large and imperial scale which has been established since the introduction of steam navigation."
