abstract: On the 5th inst., a very extraordinary scene took place before the Lords' Committee to whom had been referred the Belfast Improvement Bill. In 1855 a suit was instituted by the Attorney General for Ireland, at the relation of Mr. JOHN REA, solicitor, against certain members of the Bellast Corporation, for having exceeded their borrowing powers, and the ...
lead_paragraph: On the 5th inst., a very extraordinary scene took place before the Lords' Committee to whom had been referred the Belfast Improvement Bill. In 1855 a suit was instituted by the Attorney General for Ireland, at the relation of Mr. JOHN REA, solicitor, against certain members of the Bellast Corporation, for having exceeded their borrowing powers, and the Lord Chancellor declared the defendants responsible for the sums overborrowed, amounting altogether to £183,000. Since that time several attempts have been made by the corporation and its friends to obtain the consent of their opponents, who are all of the Liberal party, to a bill of indemnity, but Mr. REA and those who act with him have declared that, inasmuch as the corporation has hitherto been exclusively in the hands of the Tories, who have used their influence to disfranchise their opponents, the only terms on which they will consent to an Indemnity Bill are the complete polical reorganization of the to loan council, to be followed, as they confidently assert it will, by the return of Liberal representatives for many of the constituencies in Ulster that now return Conservatives. Several bills introduced into Parliament to legalize the excessive expenditure have been vigorously opposed by the Liberals; and up to this time not less than £30,000 has been spent on either side, in a contest which has now lasted over nine years. In 1862 the matters in dispute were submitted to arbitration, the Right Hon. the Colonial Minister, who was the Chief Secretary for Ireland, acting as umpire, and a bill was introduced during the present session, and passed through the Commons, confirming the award, on condition that a public bill should be introduced to prevent, if possible, the further disfranchisement of Liberal ratepayers, and to remedy the other grievances complained of. The public bill introduced by Sir HUGH CAIRNS being considered wholly inadequate, no fewer than five petitions were presented to the House of Lords against the Private Indemnity Bill, and referred to a committee, consisting of Earl GREY (chairman), Lords NELSON, RIVERS, WROTTESLEY, and MELVILLE.

abstract: Bavis vs Bayard; Wool Suit at Cleveland
snippet: Bavis vs Bayard; Wool Suit at Cleveland
lead_paragraph: -- A suit of some interest to dealers in wool is likely to come before the next term of the United States District Court. The facts of the case, as alleged in the statement of the plaintiff, are that H.C. DAVIS, the plaintiff in the suit, a wool-dealer of Philadelphia, contracted to purchase a considerable amount of wool from D.B. BAYRD, of Stark County, O. After the contract had been made, the price of wool advanced, and eigteen thousand pounds of wool, included in the contract, were sold by BAYRD to another person at a price above that for which it was contracted by DAVIS. But wool advanced still further, and BAYRD, instead of delivering to either first or second buyers, sold the wool to still another person at still higher rates. On learning these facts, DAVIS commenced proceedings in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, and Deputy United States Marshal SIMMONS went down and replevined the wool while in transit to the last purchasers. It was taken to Alliance by the Deputy Marshal, and shipped to Cleveland. About an hour after SIMMONS left with his prize, another suit of replevin came from the second purchaser, but it came too late. The suit is of considerable interest, from the fact that there has been considerable looseness of ideas among some owners of wool and other property as to what constitutes a bargain -- Cleveland Herald, 8th.

abstract: The Army Relief Association, which has done so much to alleviate the sufferings of our sick and wounded soldiers, is about to be incorporated, and will conduct its future operations under the supervision of the Masonic Order. By a recent arrangement with the War Department, the army nurses sent out by the association will receive regular pay, and will he placed under the control of the army surgeons. In order that they may be easily recognized, they will wear a neat uniform, consisting of a blue jacket with bright buttons, a tunic of moderate length (Indian style and no hoops,) and pants. The costume will be appropriate, modest, and much more convenient than the naval female dress for a nurse in attendance at the hospitals.

abstract: The Second Article
snippet: The Second Article
lead_paragraph: It is a remarkable fact that the nearer you get to the front the more hopeful is the spirit; so that the moral atmosphere of these hospitals is better than the atmosphere of New-York. Of all places, you always expect to find in a military hospital discouragement and despondency. Whatever there is of low spirits in an army will be sure to be concentrated there. The great disease of the camps -- typhoid -- always lays its hand first on the hopeful tendencies of the man; then the forced inactivity, the weary hours, the time for thought and the pain of a sick bed, do not usually strengthen the will or raise the cheerfulness of the patient; so that, if there is any cause for discouragement, you will be sure to learn it in a hospital. I have been visiting now in the work of the Christian Commission, hundreds of these suffering men from the regiments of almost every free State. The soldiers of Maine and Minnesota, Maryland and Iowa, lie side by side. They must be in every respect a very fair representation of the Army of the Potomac, and I think I may say from scarcely one have I ever heard a word of doubt or despondency about our cause. A Maine lumberman, with his foot shot through said yesterday, with that kind of light in his eyes which means earnestness, that he would give the world to be back again and "help it through." Last week, I saw a Pennsylvanian from Luzerne County, whose father left a prosperous business and went to the first Bull Run, where he was killed, and who was followed successively by seven sons, every one of whom had been shot, or had died in the war, except my informant, the last of the family, and he had been wounded fourtimes. Three of his brothers, he said, were in the Chickahominy swamps. One died at Yorktown, another on the Mississippi, and so on. And yet he meant to see the thing through! He was one of those quiet, determined, religious men, who had evidently entered on this war, from duty, and did not mean to give up, while a hope was left.

abstract: Declaration of Independence, and the War; Richmond Dispatch on
snippet: Declaration of Independence, and the War; Richmond Dispatch on
lead_paragraph: The history of the progress and growth of the great principles which have brought improvement into the world shows that they had their tides and their eddies that, though they might be at one time loudly proclaimed and perhaps generally accepted, that did not prevent them from being again called in question whenever the attempt was made to give them a new application. The struggle with Slavery has furnished us a very clear instance of this kind. When our fathers sought to sustain themselves against oppression, they planted their feet upon the firm rock of that principle which has ever since been the crowning glory of the Declaration of Independence -- the principle of the equality and freedom of man -and with that principle to support them they succeeded in the struggle upon which they had entered, and established a Government whose aim was announced to be "to secure the blessings of liberty for themselves and their posterity."

abstract: Moran vs Morrissey; Gambling Suit; Opdyke vs Marble; World Libel Suit; Ellison vs Brig David Caroline; Breakage
snippet: Moran vs Morrissey; Gambling Suit; Opdyke vs Marble; World Libel Suit; Ellison vs Brig David Caroline; Breakage
lead_paragraph: James B. Elliman et al. vs. The Brig David Caroline. -- This was a libel filed to recover damages for loss and injury to some retorts and tiles shipped on board the brig at Antwerp, to be brought to this port. The libelants alleged that the loss was occasioned by insufficient care in the stowage and carriage of the goods. The bill of lading, which was dated April 25, 1862, acknowledged the receipt or the cargo on board in good order, and engaged to transport the same to New-York, and deliver it in like good order, the perils and fortunes of the sea excepted, on payment of freight. And indorsed upon the bill of lading were the words "weight and contents unknown. Ship not accountable for leakage, breakage nor rust."

abstract: -- The transfers of rebel Prisoners from Gen. SHERMAN's front to the military prison, North, are again becoming lively. The late brilliant movements of our army on the Chattahoochee placed a large number of prisoners in our hands, and they are being hurried rapidly from the front to the rear. Yesterday, 950 rebel soldiers, captured from JO[???] JOHNSTON, were shipped to the different prisons north of the Ohio River. Advices from Nashville are to the effect that several trains loaded with prisoners, said to number 3,000, are on their way to this city. We presume that they will be received in [???] over the Nashville road, as our military prison is not large enough to accommodate so large a force. A train loaded with rebel prisoners arrived in the city on Wednesday night. While en route from Nashville to Louisville, one of the captives attempted to make his escape. He jumped from the train while the cars were in motion, and, turning a few double somersaults, he struck head foremost and broke his neck. Not a very profitable jump, that! Though in point of rations, the question may be differently viewed and admit of argument. -- Louisville Journal, July 15.

abstract: Blackberry Root Tea a Cure for
snippet: Blackberry Root Tea a Cure for
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. LARSON, of Brooklyn, who served for two years as a private in DURYEA's Zouaves, states that his regiment suffered much from the above complaint. Tea made from blackberry roots proved to be a certain cure, and in many instances within his knowledge suffering soldiers were speedily relieved by its use. Two tablespoons full should be taken three or four times a day.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments front the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: New Call for Troops, the
snippet: New Call for Troops, the
lead_paragraph: The effervescent enthusiasm that characterized popular feeling in the first stages of the war, has in a great measure passed away. The national purpose is now more fixed, stronger and less demonstrative than formerly. We comprehend the work, and have deliberately settled down to accomplish it. The calls for troops are not filled with such alacrity as at first, but still the ranks of our army are continually being replenished from enlistments all over the land.
headline: {'main': 'The New Call for Troops.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Call for Troops.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is well known in military circles that militia regiments entering the United States service during the call for one hundred days' men, will be expected to serve their full time, "unless sooner discharged,' and that thirty, sixty and ninety days' men will not be accepted. There is considerable stir among the regiments incident to their being mustered into service, and preparations are being made for their early departure, it is generally understood our militia are to garison the defences round Washington, in order to relieve several hundred veterans, who will join Gen. GRANT's army.

abstract: More Attempts at in Ky, >amp;c.
snippet: More Attempts at in Ky, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The war telegrams this morning are once more devoted in part to the forecasting of rebel raids. The Maryland affair having collapsed, we are introduced to a new set of raiders, "variously estimated at from five thousand to fifteen thousand," who have entered Kentucky via Pound Gap, and at last accounts were at Martindale, in Floyd County; Louisville, however, is to be defended to the last. Along with this intelligence from Kentucky, we have reports of the reappearance of formidable bodies of guerrillas in Western Missouri. And from the Southwest comes the news that the rebels have a large force stationed on the west bank of the Atchafalaya River, nine miles in the rear of Morganzia and parallel to the Mississippi. We have no doubt, judging from the past, that the reports appertaining to these incursive movements will expand into larger proportions each successive day for a limited period; and we have equally little doubt that, whether or not they be made incidentally profitable to the rebels as foraging expeditions, they will serve the temporary purpose, which is by no means unimportant, of distracting public attention for the moment from the main points of military operations; of nettling the public temper in those border districts which are termed "loyal;" of giving foreign sympathizers a new cue for their chorus of applause; and of deceiving the unthinking everywhere as to the expansive energy of the military organizations of rebeldom.
headline: {'main': 'More Raiding and New Attempts to Distract Public Attention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'More Raiding and New Attempts to Distract Public Attention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival at Nather Point of the steamship Damascus from Liverpool, we have advices from that port to the 7th instant. Rumors unfavorable to Gen. GRANT were prevalent in London, and caused a slight improvement in the Confederate loan. The Kearsarge was to leave Cherbourg on the 5th, to cruise in the channel for rebel privateers. There is a report that the Yeddo, lately built at Bordeaux will be completed at Amsterdam and commanded by SEMMES, and a contrary statement to the effect that this vessel belongs to the Prussian and not to the Confederate navy. The proceedings in Parliament on the 6th were unimportant, the debate on DISRAELIS motion of censure standing, adjourned until the 7th. It is reported that pacific negotiations were going on between Denmark and Prussia, and that, pending these, no attack would be made. There is no other news of importance in regard to the Danish war.

abstract: The President has issued his order for five hundred thousand men to serve for one year, to be obtained by draft, immediately the the 5th of September next, if not previously obtained by volunteering. The draft will take place accord-
lead_paragraph: The President has issued his order for five hundred thousand men to serve for one year, to be obtained by draft, immediately the the 5th of September next, if not previously obtained by volunteering. The draft will take place according to the terms of the new Enrollment Act. Elsewhere we publish this act; also, the official regulations for recruiting in the rebel States.

abstract: Marsh, Nathaniel
snippet: Marsh, Nathaniel
lead_paragraph: NATHANIEL MARSH, Esq., President of the New-York and Erie Railroad, died at his residence on Staten Island on Monday night, after a lingering illness of many months. Mr. MARSH was a native of Haverhill, Mass. He was educated at Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H., and studied law in his native State. After his admission to the bar he removed to New-York. He was First Assistant Postmaster of this City under JOHN L. GRAHAM, and was afterward made Secretary of the New-York and Erie Railroad, of which he was subsequently elected President. Mr. MARSH was an able and faithful officer, and during a period of more than twenty years devoted himself so zealously to the interests of the great work in which he was engaged as to wear himself out, so that he died an old man a little past middle age. His associates and employes, and all who knew him, will deeply deplore his death.

abstract: In England a lawsuit is in progress between Messrs. SAMPSON, Low & Co., English publishers of the copyright edition of "Haunted Hearts," and ROUTLEDGE & Co., whom Messrs. SAMPSON, Low & Co. denounce as pirates -- they having issued an English edition reprinted from the American. Authors will look with interest to the decision, as settling the question if a copyright can be secured on both sides of the Atlantic. -- Boston Traveller.

abstract: The Custom-house authorities at San Francisco discovered a very ingenious Chinese trick, which led to the seizure of another lot of smuggled opium. Among the cargo of the bark Ceres were 400 tubs, invoiced as eggs, value stated at $1 each. The eggs were coated with a peculiar kind of varnish to preserve them. One of the officers, in examining the eggs, scraped off a little varnish and disclosed a metallic case, egg-shaped, filled with opium. Each metallic egg is worth $300. So far as the examination has proceeded, five hundred have been found.
lead_paragraph: The Custom-house authorities at San Francisco discovered a very ingenious Chinese trick, which led to the seizure of another lot of smuggled opium. One of the officers, in examining the eggs, scraped off a little varnish and disclosed a metallic case, egg-shaped, filled with opium. Each metallic egg is worth $300. So far as the examination has proceeded, five hundred have been found.

lead_paragraph: The progress of the war has vastly simplified its operation. Instead of being waged in detail at a multitude of points along border lines and coast lines, with intervals of hundreds, and even thousands of miles, it now is made to bear almost exclusively upon two positions Richmond and Atlanta the one recognized to be the key to the northeastern, the other to the southwestern, portion of the "Confederacy."

abstract: Guerrillas seem to be thick as hops in Kentucky, and they keep the newspapers, if not the State, very lively. In opening yesterday the Louisville Democrat of the 16th, our eye first fell upon an article headed "Guerrillas in Western Kentucky," followed by an account of "Guerrillas" in Henderson. The adjoining column led off with an account of a guerrilla "Skirmish near Brandenburg," which was followed by "Guerrilla Operations near Nashville." The next column had an article on "Guerrillas on Green River," and paragraphsabout a "gang of guerrillas on the rampage," about "four guerrillas," about "guerrillas firing at the trains," and about danger to tobacco from "guerrillas." The remaining columns of the page are filled with advertisements, and the reader may peruse them without any danger of coming in contact with guerrillas. We turn to other pages and find "skirmish with guerrillas," "robberies by guerrillas," "surprise and capture of guerrillas," and so on till the subject becomes intolerable. We should think it was time for Kentucky to take rather stringent measures with these cut-throats and brigands.
lead_paragraph: Guerrillas seem to be thick as hops in Kentucky, and they keep the newspapers, if not the State, very lively. In opening yesterday the Louisville Democrat of the 16th, our eye first fell upon an article headed "Guerrillas in Western Kentucky," followed by an account of "Guerrillas" in Henderson. The adjoining column led off with an account of a guerrilla "Skirmish near Brandenburg," which was followed by "Guerrilla Operations near Nashville." The next column had an article on "Guerrillas on Green River," and paragraphsabout a "gang of guerrillas on the rampage," about "four guerrillas," about "guerrillas firing at the trains," and about danger to tobacco from "guerrillas." The remaining columns of the page are filled with advertisements, and the reader may peruse them without any danger of coming in contact with guerrillas. We turn to other pages and find "skirmish with guerrillas," "robberies by guerrillas," "surprise and capture of guerrillas," and so on till the subject becomes intolerable. We should think it was time for Kentucky to take rather stringent measures with these cut-throats and brigands.

abstract: Recruiting in the City, although not as brisk as when the last quota was being filled, is rapidly becoming more lively -- and, if the increase be according to the present ratio, there will be no draft on the 5th of September. It must be remembered, however, that great exertions are necessary to bring about so desirable a result it may be said in praise of Supervisor BLUNT, that he is making every effort on behalf of the Volunteer Committee to fill our quota, which will not fall far short of 19,000. The County has already a credit of about 3,000 over enlistments under the last call.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting in the City, although not as brisk as when the last quota was being filled, is rapidly becoming more lively -- and, if the increase be according to the present ratio, there will be no draft on the 5th of September. The County has already a credit of about 3,000 over enlistments under the last call.

abstract: A newbuilding, to be used as a recruiting depot, has been erected on the Battery, and will be ready for use next week. An effort was made by the Chairman of the Volunteer Committee to have the building connected by a covered way with Castle Garden; but permission was refused by Mr. CASSERLY, on behalf of the Commissioners of Emigration, who had previously denied an application of txtMr. BLUNT to establish a branch recruiting office in Castle Garden.
lead_paragraph: A newbuilding, to be used as a recruiting depot, has been erected on the Battery, and will be ready for use next week. abstract: By the arrival yesterday of the steamship Europa at Halifax, from Liverpool, we have advices from that port to the 9th inst. The debates in the British Parliament had resulted in a majority of 18 for the Government in the House of Commons, and in a majority of 9 against the Government in the House of Lords. The Danish news is unimportant. The Kearsarge arrived off Dover on the evening of the 6th inst. from Cherbourg. Nothing was seen of any rebel cruisers. The mystery about the steamer Yeddo still continued. Her arrival at Amsterdam, for which port she cleared from Bordeaux on June 22, had not been reported, and there are suspicions afloat that she will soon be heard from as a rebel privateer. Among the passengers by the Europa were Lieut. PREBBLE, of the Kearsarge, and Lieut. KELL, Executive Officer of the Alabama.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival yesterday of the steamship Europa at Halifax, from Liverpool, we have advices from that port to the 9th inst. abstract: This morning we were astonished as much as army people allow themselves to be astonished, at the sound of heavy ordnance in an unexpected quarter. It commenced as early as 7 o'clock in the direction of the James River, between the landing at Bermuda Hundred and the fortified position held by Gen. FOSTER'S, command, on the north side of the river, near Jones' Neck. An explanation of the disturbance soon reached Gen. BUTLER'S headquarters.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE PETERSBURGH, SATURDAY EVENING July 16, 1864.

abstract: The date of my letter is suggestive. It reminds me most vividly of the excitement and exhilaration in which I participated on the 15th of June just four weeks ago to-night when those marvelously strong works in front of Petersburgh were wrenched from the rebels, and seized by the Union army with a determined and unrelenting grip, which must in time strangle the rebellion, or, at least, make the evacuation of Richmond a necessity.

abstract: In common with many portions of our country we are suffering from a severe drought, having had no rain of any amount since the 10th of June. As a consequence, crops of all kinds are parched, and must be a small yield.

abstract: The Supply and Demand
snippet: The Supply and Demand
lead_paragraph: On this day four years ago we quoted cotton in our commercial columns at 10 @10 3/8 cents per pound. To-day our quotation is $1.64 per pound, which after reducing the currency to a gold standard makes the present price of raw cotton in New-York as near as may be seven times its price on the 20th of July, 1860.

abstract: The news from the army before Petersburgh presents nothing of striking interest. Siege preparations continue with unrelenting vigor. SHERIDAN is reported to have started on another of his terrible raids into the heart of Virginia. An engagement occurred on Saturday between a rebel battery and the gunboat Malvern, when the battery was driven away. On the same day twelve large torpedoes were found in James River, some distance below our present position. Great surprise was exhibited as to how they could have been put in that position.

abstract: This regiment was the first to organize under the call of the Governor, in compliance with the requisition of the President of the United States for 12,000 volunteers for 100 days' service. They were ready on Sunday last with 600 men, but in consequence of a misunderstanding between the mustering officer and the Colonel of the regiment as to the number of men required, another inspection was ordered for Monday. An inspection was made on. Fort Greene on Monday evening, when it was found that one company, after excluding boys, had less than the quota required, and the inspection was suspended. The men of the regiment are now running about loose. There are no orders, and it is doubtful whether it can ever be got ready to march. There were doubtless too many boys, who had been enlisted as substitutes for regular members, and altogether unfit for service; but there were a sufficient number of men to make up the amount requisite, in accordance with the State militia laws -- namely, 320, as the minimum number. The military authorities appear to be discouraged with this turn of affairs, and it is doubtful whether any energetic efforts will be made to fill the quota. The Fifty-sixth Regiment is substantially used up, and the Twenty-eighth has made but very little progress so far. The filling of the quota from Kings County will therefore be very uncertain.

abstract: The steamship Northern Light, Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, arrived at this port this morning from Aspinwall, which port she left on the 10th inst. She reports, July 17, at 4 P.M., lat. 34°, long. 74°, made a fore-and-aft schooner-rigged propeller steering to the westward under steam and canvass. As soon as he espied our steamer he altered his course, so as to out us off; be continued to change his course for that purpose till the alteration in his course amounted to 16 points, or from west to south, and then to east; had the English flag flying; was an English built vessel with a short bowsprit and long billet head: carried foresail, mainsail and jib; the masts were in one stick; no topmasts, and pilot-house forward, American style. We carried a heavy pressure of steam, ascertained by the lifting of the safety valve, when the vessel rolled. We saw at the same time a topsail schooner, with short foremast, and a herm. brig. The schooner tacked and stood after us, when the steamer made for us. Taking it altogether, the manoeeuvres of these vessels were suspicious, to say the least. We altered our course from time to time to keep the steamer at a respectful distance. When nearest to us, we were about four miles off. When the chase was given up, which continued for one hour and fifteen minutes, the propeller steered away South.

abstract: Florida; Will She Go to Europe?
snippet: Florida; Will She Go to Europe?
lead_paragraph: It seems by the news from Europe Chat the Florida was expected to arrive in European waters during the early part of this month. The Kearsarge was on the lookout for her, and the Niagara put to sea very suddenly, in order to be on hand for her. We should not wonder if there had been some real foundation for this expectation. What if it had been planned by the Florida and Alabama to meet each other there, and together to attack the Kearsarge, or some other of our vessels? What if in pursuance of this plan the Florida left Bermuda, and ran round by our coast burning vessels as she was doing a short time since, and then kept on north and east across the Atlantic? If this was their plan, it has been frustrated. Whether because Capt. SEMMES did not count upon being ordered out of Cherbourg so soon, or because the Florida did not. come round in time, their joint arrangement, if any such there was, has been spoiled by the sinking of the Alabama; and instead of there being two rebel vessels to attack one of ours, the Captain of the Florida will find, if he goes there, that he has two of our vessels to escape from instead of one. The London Globe speaking of this says, that no doubt the Captain of the Florida will see to it that he is not caught between two fires. No doubt he will if he can. Indeed, we have no doubt that he will avoid exposing himself to one fire, to say nothing of two. He will have learned of the fate of SEMMES and of the "great dissatisfaction" which was felt in England because he lost the Alabama, and he will be careful how he exposes himself to that dissatisfaction by exposing his vessel to the shot of a ship-of-war. We may be quite sure that he will have no thought of fighting, but rather of "living to rob another day." Our only hope is that he may rely too much upon the aid and assistance of our neutral friends, and may put his vessel into a spot where the Kearsarge or the Niagara may get a chance at her.

abstract: aged 21 years, was taken into custody yesterday by Officer KELLY, of the Third Precinct, on the charge of having forged the names of Messrs. HURD & HOUGHTON, booksellers on Broadway, to an order for three volumes of Shakespeare. The accused gave the forged order to a boy named ROBERT COLES, and directed him to go to a bookstore in Grand-street, get the books, and deliver them to him at the corner of Nassau and Ann streets. Upon the bogus order the books were delivered. When the fraud was discovered DRAKE was taken and committed.

abstract: London Index on Grant's Position
snippet: London Index on Grant's Position
lead_paragraph: We published some days since an article from the Georgia Constitutionalist on GRANT'S position before Richmond, which was interesting, as confirming our views of the straits into which that position compelled the rebels. We find these views fortified also from another quarter, and one, too, whose confirmation is strong, because nothing favorable to us is to be looked for there. We refer to an article in the Index, the rebel organ in London. The article was written, it is true, upon the news that Petersburgh was in our hands, and is more despondent on that account than it had reason to be from actual facts. The writer, assuming that GRANT held Petersburgh, proceeded to discuss his future movements, arguing that he would move on the line of railroad, by which he would have "at any rate secured this advantage that he has interrupted one line of LEE's communications with the South." Then, after discussing the strength of Drewry's Bluff, he proceeds:

abstract: Howard, Major-Gen., Anecdote of Kindness of
snippet: Howard, Major-Gen., Anecdote of Kindness of
lead_paragraph: -- A private letter from Marietta, Ga., June 23, to a gentleman in Cincinnati, gives the following characteristic incident of Gen. HOWARD: "On the 23d of June, while the battle, or move forward, was going on, a young man, mortally wounded, was being taken back on a litter. Gen. HOWARD, who was riding by, stopped, inquired to what regiment he belonged; then dismounting, he took the boy (he was a mere boy) by the hand and conversed with him, there in the road, kneeling down by the litter, the others around doing the same, uncovering their heads. The General then offered a fervent prayer for the boy, after which he pressed his hand, and kissed him. This shows the man we have as Corps Commander.

abstract: Wilson's Raid at Staunton Bridge--A Hint to Border Towns
snippet: Wilson's Raid at Staunton Bridge--A Hint to Border Towns
lead_paragraph: We would respectfully recommend to those citizens of Hagerstown, Frederick, Greencastle and Chambersburgh, who are annually plundered by rebel raids, the following instructive occurrence: Gen. WILSON recently led a corps of some six thousand cavalry on one of his destructive expeditions. His horsemen are among the bravest men of the national army, the terror of the rebels, and truly a formidable force. They swept on, harrying and destroying, till they reached the Staunton Bridge, near the Roanoke. If they had crossed this, almost the whole of North Carolina would have been open to them; or if they had burnt it, one of the most important links of rebel communication would have been destroyed. Even a delay there exposed them to the risk of capture on their return. The rebels had collected on the other side of the bridge some six hundred militia, and as many old soldiers, with three pieces of artillery. We had 6,000, with sixteen pieces. After some lively skirmishing, Gen. WILSON found that we could not carry the bridge by storm without considerable loss, and that an artillery fight would take too much time, so he was compelled to retreat. He could, indeed, have flanked the position, but that would have cost two days' time, and given the enemy a chance to concentrate in his rear. So three cannon and a few hundred men drove off this brave and active little army, and the delay brought our cavalry back, just so as to fall into the rebel trap at Ream's Station.
headline: {'main': 'A Hint to the Border Towns.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Hint to the Border Towns.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SIR: Called to the high and important dignity of Chief of Finance, fearful in its responsibility, with a depleted treasury, in the midst of a sanguinary civil war, the Government in want of funds, things generally out of joint, the land covered all over with enemies, the money centres filled with financial traitors, cunning artifice and fraud resorted to by the enemy, yet fear not, be of good cheer, the people are with you.
lead_paragraph: SIR: Called to the high and important dignity of Chief of Finance, fearful in its responsibility, with a depleted treasury, in the midst of a sanguinary civil war, the Government in want of funds, things generally out of joint, the land covered all over with enemies, the money centres filled with financial traitors, cunning artifice and fraud resorted to by the enemy, yet fear not, be of good cheer, the people are with you. If you place your trust in God and them, they will keep their powder dry and come to your rescue with alacrity and zeal.

abstract: Gen. W.B. FRANKLIN arrived in the city on the noon train of Saturday. On Saturday evening a vast concourse assembled in front of the United States Hotel, where the United States Infantry Band played a few pieces, after which the band marched to the residence of Gen. FRANKLIN on High-street. The streets on the route were lined on both sides with ladies and gentlemen, and the gathering in front of the General's dwelling was immense. Here the band performed a number of pieces, followed by lively cheers by the crowd. The General made his appearance in the door-way and briefly and happily acknowledged the compliment. After a few more pieces by the band and rousing cheers for the General, the throng dispersed. It was a spontaneous and hearty tribute to a brave and gallant officer. -- Portland Advertisers July 18.

abstract: Desertions from the Rebels
snippet: Desertions from the Rebels
lead_paragraph: We are once more threatened with an inundation of deserters from the enemy's lines. LEE'S men, it would appear, are forsaking him at all points "in squads," and as usual "the deserters come principally from Georgia, Florida and Alabama;" and "report a scarcity of provisions especially vegetables." The hordes of these Alabama and Georgia men that used to come crowding within our lines in the Southwest in the days of POPE and ROSECRANS, we should have thought would have considerably thinned the rebel cohorts belonging to those States. We imagine it would not be difficult to show, from "the most reliable sources," that about half a million of these military vegetarians have deserted at one time or another. They are generally, as in the present instance, in search of something green, and no doubt they find it. The strange and the painful part of the business is that they come in these miraculous droves almost invariably when there is an immediate prospect of a great battle. They did so, we remember, before Murfreesboro; they did so before Chickamauga; and although they were fewer in number, the desertions which preceded the battles of Fredericksburgh and the Wilderness formed the subject of a pleasing prologue, before we received the reports of these battles themselves.
headline: {'main': 'Desertions from the Enemy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Desertions from the Enemy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Party Politics and the Rebellion
snippet: Party Politics and the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: We presume there is abundant circumstantial evidence to show that Lord PALMERSTON owes his majority in the Commons, on the late party test vote, to the desire of the great Liberal element in his following to avoid an open quarrel with the United States. But for the fear -- almost approaching to certainty -- that Lord DERBY and Lord MALMESBURY are so far committed to the London Secessionists, and especially to the cause of Free-trade in privateering as interpreted by LAIRD, that their accession to power would be followed by an open violation of the existing neutrality laws such as they are -- but for these contingencies, we say, there can be no question that the House of Commons would have formally recorded its censure upon the timid, vacillating, and deceptive conduct of the Foreign Office in its dealings with Denmark.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebellion and British Party Politics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebellion and British Party Politics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: St George vs New-York, at Hoboken
snippet: St George vs New-York, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the second elevens of these clubs played a match on the St. George's ground, at Hoboken, which resulted in the defeat of the New-Yorkers by the amount of the first innings, which stood 37 to 73 for the St. George's. In the second innings the St. George's scored 102, and the New-Yorkers made 104, for the loss of six wickets, leaving 35 runs to be gotten by the other five men to win, which probably would have been achieved had time permitted, as the St. George's bowling seemed to be completely collared.

abstract: The Baltimore American says that a very considerable portion of Gen. RICKETTS' command were for several days encamped in Druid Hill Park, in that city, and it is to the credit of both men and officers that they took pleasure in the beauty of the place, and sedulously protected it from the slightest damage. Gen. RICKETTS said that his men could appreciate such a beautiful resort as thoroughly as any citizen of Baltimore, and his soldiers showed that their commander understood them. Not a tree was cut down, a road injured, or any part of the grounds disturbed, and it has not unfrequently occurred that a large pic-nic party has left more signs of their presence than these soldiers did after several days' occupancy. The fact is creditable to these veterans of the Sixth Corps, and ought to be known.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore American says that a very considerable portion of Gen. abstract: The Government has official information from Gen. SHERMAN, to the effect that his army crossed the Chattahoochee at several different places, and that the movement was made with such facility as to surprise the enemy, and his resistance was therefore feeble. Our cavalry was at once sent to operate on the railroad east of Decatur, the object being to cut off all communication between Atlanta
lead_paragraph: The Government has official information from Gen. SHERMAN, to the effect that his army crossed the Chattahoochee at several different places, and that the movement was made with such facility as to surprise the enemy, and his resistance was therefore feeble. Our cavalry was at once sent to operate on the railroad east of Decatur, the object being to cut off all communication between Atlanta and Augusta, thus preventing the reinforcement of JOHNSTON. Our main army was within a few miles of Atlanta. Gen. BRAGG had arrived at Atlanta, with a view, it was believed, of exercising a special supervision over the further movements of the rebel army.

abstract: -- The body of an unknown man, aged about 30 years, was found floating in the water at the foot of Twenty-third-street, East River. Deceased was about 5 feet 8 inches in height, was dressed in two white muslin shirts, dark vest, black cloth business coat, woolen pants, shoes and cotton socks. He had evidently been in the water three or four months. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body, and a verdict of death by drowning was rendered.

abstract: Recruiting; Official Returns Wanted
snippet: Recruiting; Official Returns Wanted
lead_paragraph: It would be satisfactory for the public to receive some regular official statement of the progress of recruiting at the different agencies. If the Provost-Marshal-General is not now put in possession of regular weekly, or semi-weekly returns of the number of new recruits reported at the offices of his various deputies, he ought to order these returns. And after they have been summarized, they should be regularly communicated to the public, say once a week, through some official or semi-official organ, so that they may be copied into the press generally and circulated among the people.

abstract: RAILROAD. -- Mr. L.N. SHEAR, formerly proprietor of the Newspaper Express, has purchased of the Central Railroad, for the sum of $5,000, the exclusive right to sell papers at all the depots and stations on the road. It remains to be seen whether this arrangement will interfere with the sale of local papers printed on the line. Mr. SHEAR's business is the delivery and sale of the New-York daily papers. -- Buffalo Courier.

abstract: It is not extensively known that there is now in course of construction, for our Government, one of the largest fleets of screw steamers of war, added to any navy at one time. It numbers over twenty immense vessels, some of them equal in tonnage and steam power to the great screw fleets of England and France, while their offensive attributes -- that is, the quality and calibre of their guns -- have no rival in the world. Their strength and resisting force may be imagined from the fact that their timbers are heavier and better braced than those of any yet built by us, since HENRY ECKFORD completed the Ohio.
lead_paragraph: It is not extensively known that there is now in course of construction, for our Government, one of the largest fleets of screw steamers of war, added to any navy at one time. abstract: A SERIOUS CHARGE OF THEFT AND SWINDLING.-- JACOB T. SMITH was arrested yesterday by Officer MCARTHUR, of the Second District Police Court, by virtue of a warrant issued on the complaint of HERMAN S. EMMONS, of No. 108 Greene-street. SMITH, it appears, is the proprietor of a saloon at No. 171 Spring-street. A short time since, EMMONS, as he alleges in his affidavit, saw an advertisement in one of the morning papers, which stated that any one depositing $100 at SMITH's place in Spring-street, would "receive steady employment and good wages." EMMONS made application, deposited the $100, and for a while received $5 per week. He further testifies that there was nothing doing at this place, and that he, and several others who had been induced to go there and deposit money on the pretence that they would be furnished with employment, had nothing to do but to walk around. Complainant further says that at different times, he was robbed in that place of money amounting in all to over $1,000; that a few evenings' since he went to SMITH's place with the sum of $147 in money in his pocket; SMITH invited him to drink, which he did, and afterward went to sleep on the lounge. When he awoke in the morning his money was all gone. He further swears that in his opinion SMITH's place is kept open for the sole purpose of swindling and theft. The accused was taken before Justice DODDE, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and held to answer in the sum of $500 bail.

abstract: Opposition M C's Address to the People
snippet: Opposition M C's Address to the People
lead_paragraph: Forty-three Opposition members of Congress have united in an Address to the people, to show that -- to use their own words -- "there is good reason for changing the Administration and policy of this General Government." They make the production stretch through near ten newspaper columns -- thus avowing the extreme difficulty of the work. We have read it all! It is a dog-day job, that would be the death of nine men out of ten. It is for our physician to be told how we feel; our readers will ask what we found.

abstract: A VETO. -- At the meeting of the Jersey City Common Council, on Tuesday night, Mayor CLEVELAND sent in a communication vetoing a supplementary ordinance extending the time prohibiting the running of dummy cars in the streets of Jersey City for six months. The Mayor claims that this is a subterfuge of the dummy company for the purpose of gaining time to obtain the passage of a law by the legislature to override the ordinance passed by the city. The veto was laid on the table.

abstract: On and after to-day, until further notice, the price of the NEW-YORK TIMES will be FOUR CENTS for each single copy. To mail subscribers, $10 per annum; including Sunday morning edition, $12. This increase is rendered absolutely necessary by the enormous and constant advance in the price of white paper, and, indeed, of everything else that enters into the manufacture of a newspaper. It is intended only to meet a temporary difficulty, which, we hope, will not be of long continuance.
lead_paragraph: On and after to-day, until further notice, the price of the NEW-YORK TIMES will be FOUR CENTS for each single copy. To mail subscribers, $10 per annum; including Sunday morning edition, $12. This increase is rendered absolutely necessary by the enormous and constant advance in the price of white paper, and, indeed, of everything else that enters into the manufacture of a newspaper. It is intended only to meet a temporary difficulty, which, we hope, will not be of long continuance.

abstract: Hopper, John T
snippet: Hopper, John T
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN T. HOPPER, son of ISAAC L. HOPPER, the well-known philanthropist, died suddenly at his residence in Milton, Ulster County, Monday evening, at 11 o'clock. He had been building a house at Milton for his future residence, and was busily employed Saturday and Monday morning in transporting furniture to it from the landing on the Hudeon River. About 11 o'clock he complained or oppression of the head, lay down to rest, and died a few moments afterward.

abstract: Matter of Mary F. Barnes, an Infant. -- In this case a writ of habeas corpus was allowed, requiring Elizabeth Barnes to produce the body of Mary F. Barnes, an infant of four years of age. The petition alleged that the child was illegally detained by the respondent, F.T. Welden, and asked that the relator might be given its custody. It also set out that Weden had been duly appointed the Infant's guardian by the Surrogate. Mrs. Barnes, the respondent, made return to the writ that she was the grandmother of the child, which was an orphan, and that it had been, placed in her care and custody by the will of its father.

abstract: -- An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner COLLIN, at No. 201 Broome-street, on the body of CHARLES BOLLEN, a native of Holland, 27 years of age, who committed suicide by hanging himself with a piece of clothes line which he attached to some fastenings on the porch, in the rear of the premises above-mentioned. When discovered by the inmates of the house at an early hour yesterday morning, he was suspended by the neck, and life was entirely extinct. No motive is assigned for the commission of the deed. Deceased was a machinist by occupation, and is reputed to have been a sober and industrious man.

abstract: Regiment New-York Volunteers was formally received and reviewed by the City authorities yesterday. The regiment numbered about one hundred rank and file, and was under command of Lieut.-Col. RAFFERTY. For some reason or other, these veterans were without muskets, and a considerable delay occurred before they could procure them, in order to be reviewed in the Park. Here a large crowd of citizens welcomed them with much enthusiasm, and the review passed off well. The veterans were escorted on this occasion by the Seventy-first Regiment New-York State National Guard, which turned out some four hundred strong, and presented a highly creditable appearance. Col. TRAFFORD was in command. After the review both regiments marched to Jefferson Market, and partook of an excellent collation provided under the auspices of the Committee on National Affairs.

abstract: the Inevitable, Gone to Atlanta
snippet: the Inevitable, Gone to Atlanta
lead_paragraph: The most encouraging piece of news which has reached us with regard to SHERMAN's position in Georgia, is that Gen. BRAGG has gone to Atlanta to exercise a personal supervision over the movements of the rebel army. This only is sufficient to remove all doubts as to the ultimate success of SHERMAN's operations. There are not many Generals to whom the Union cause is more deeply indebted than to Gen. BRAGG, and the assistance which he has rendered it is all the more creditable to him, as his sympathies must of course be altogether on the rebel side. No matter how this war may end, no true Unionist can ever forget the valuable cooperation which Gen. ROSECRANS received from, him in Tennessee, during the retreat from Murfreesboro; and it was, in fact, in no small degree to the masterly combinations of the Confederate leader that we got into Chattanooga without firing a shot. If we were indebted to him for no other service than this, the burden of our obligations would be great; but he did not stop here. Finding our army was in great straits at Chattanooga for supplies, he generously let us have Lookout Valley, and believing that LONGSTREET's presence on Missionary Ridge was probably embarrassing us, he dispatched that officious and turbulent personage to Knoxville, and left himself for Dalton, when requested to do so by Gen. GRANT. There has, in short, not been a single stage in this excellent man's career since this war began, in which he has not afforded us valuable facilities for the accomplishment of the great work which our armies have before them.
headline: {'main': 'The Inevitable Bragg.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Inevitable Bragg.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The case of R.D. OGDEN, a British subject, whose services are claimed by the Government upon the ground that he has become subject to military duty by having been for a long time domiciled in the South, will be argued before Judge HALYBURTON to-day. This case is one of peculiar interest, and involves the result of numerous similar cases. On the 15th of January, 1862, Attorney-General TUCKER, in response to a resolution of inquiry from the House of Delegates, reported that the public law of the country, since 1792, has settled that while the voluntary service of an alien in the army will be accepted, military service will not be compelled and exacted of any but citizens of the State. An alien may contract to serve, but will not be compelled to do military duly to the State. He is of opinion that this practice, established by State law for seventy years, must be taken to settle the views he should take as to the law of nations operating upon the subject in this State. He gives the same answer in regard to persons transiently here for pleasure, health or business, and with regard to such even as have declared their intention to become citizens. A contrary policy would, he says, be injurious to ourselves and ungracious to the alien.

abstract: On Sunday night, as Capt. MOSES, with fortyseven men of the Second Colorado, was scouting near Fredericksburgh, Clay County, Mo., they came upon 300 bushwhackers. abstract: There can hardly be a doubt, says the Mobile Tribune, that Gen. CANBY is rapidly preparing an expedition to move on this city. From what we hear it will number some fifteen or twenty thousand men. What direction it will take is probably not so well known; but it is likely that it will move from the coast, and be supported by the fleet of FARRAGUT, so far as that can give it support.

abstract: Ritchie's Series of Union Portraits
snippet: Ritchie's Series of Union Portraits
lead_paragraph: The civil and military heroes of the war are at last in a fair way to have their faces handed down to posterity in a manner worthy of their fame. Messrs. DERBY & MILLER, of No. 5 Spruce-street, send us as an earnest of a work which they have undertaken, magnificent steel plate engravings of President LINCOLN and of Gens. GRANT and HANCOCK As regards the fidelity of the likenesses, it is enough to say that they are after photographs by BRADY, and that they are engraved by Mr. A.H. RITCHIE. It is safe to predict that neither as pictures or portraits will this series be surpassed. Notwithstanding the recent rapid advance in labor and material, each likeness is to be sold at the low price of $1.

abstract: The "peace negotiations " which have attracted public attention for a few days past, are further elucidated this morning by the publication of the correspondence between Messrs. HORACE GREELEY and SANDERS, CLAY and HOLCOMBE, the rebel emissaries at Niagara Falls.
lead_paragraph: The "peace negotiations" which have attracted public attention for a few days past, are further elucidated this morning by the publication of the correspondence between Messrs. HORACE GREELEY and SANDERS, CLAY and HOLCOMBE, the rebel emissaries at Niagara Falls. The published correspondence does not go as far as previous dispatches indicated, and ends in a general "blow" of indignation at the only terms mentioned by either party, viz.: those addressed "to whom it may concern" by the President, and which embody as conditions precedent to the consideration of any propositions for peace, that they must embrace the restoration of the Union in all its territorial rights, and the extinction of Slavery.

abstract: Rebel Press; Comments on; a Disapment
snippet: Rebel Press; Comments on; a Disapment
lead_paragraph: The news from Maryland, as found in the Chronicle of the 14th, gave much disappointment to the sanguine portion of the community. Whether the capture of Washington was the object of the expedition or not, its fall was most anxiously expected by the community until last Saturday, when the telegram from Petersburgh brought to the knowledge of the public the fact that, according to the Chronicle of the 14th, the "rebels" had withdrawn from the front of Washington. While disappointed in not hearing of the capture, it was nevertheless very gratifying to know how badly scared the enemy were, and for the world to see how easily the capital of Yankee land can be frightened out of its wits.

abstract: -- About 5:30 o'clock yesterday, an East Broadway omnibus, passing up Chatham-street, came in collision with a Third-avenue car, driving in an opposite direction. The pole of the stage was thrust into the car, and before the vehicles could be checked the 'bus was thrown com pletely over, causing many an involuntary summerset on the part of the inmates. Fortunately nothing more serious than the bleeding of one passenger's nose was occassioned, though the stage was well filled with both sexes. Both car and 'bus were damaged. Much laughter was indulged in at the expense of the unlucky passengers who were unexpectedly hurled over.

abstract: Strength; The Concealment of
snippet: Strength; The Concealment of
lead_paragraph: While conjecture is still employed to find a correct estimate of the rebel force recently north of the Potomac, it is worth while calling to mind that all that is to this day known of the actual strength in numbers of the armies, in the invasions of 1862 and 1863, is the product of tolerably feasible guessing. We know, with something approaching to certainty, that particular corps and particular divisions fought at South Mountain, at Antietam, and at Gettyshurgh, and upon these ascertained facts we have founded some approximate estimate of the number of men LEE brought over the river on each occasion, and of the number he took back. And these estimates must supply the place of reliable returns, until the Confederacy itself, with all its official arcana, is fairly turned inside out. For it has been from the very outset of the war a fundamental point in the military policy of DAVIS and LEE to deceive as to the actual rebel strength, wherever such deception was possible, either in great actions, or in what might be called such by-play as the late Northern incursion.

abstract: Niagara Conference, the End of; and Democratic Dilemma; Peace Movement; Rich Examiner on; Chicago Convention and Niagara Conference
snippet: Niagara Conference, the End of; and Democratic Dilemma; Peace Movement; Rich Examiner on; Chicago Convention and Niagara Conference
lead_paragraph: There seems to be strong reason for believing that the great Peace Conference which is being held, or talked of, at Niagara, is neither more nor less than an electioneering dodge on a great scale, intended to lighten the burdens of the coming Chicago Convention. The task which this body has before it is one of no ordinary magnitude and difficulty. It has to find a candidate that there is some chance of electing, and plan out a policy which will satisfy at least a majority of the members of the party; and the prospect opened up by the pressure of these obligations is by no means a pleasant one. The candidate has to be a well-known man of war, who is decidedly in favor of peace; a strong upholder and admirer of Slavery, who believes Slavery had better be abolished; a firm believer in the theory of secession, who believes that the practice of secession ought to be resisted at any cost; an opponent of the rebellion, who believes that the South is fully justified in rebelling; a firm supporter of the "Constitution as it is," who does not blame JEFF. DAVIS for trying to overthrow it; a great admirer of the military and political ability of the Southern leaders, who is fully satisfied that the State militia furnishes the best army that can possibly be put into the field; an opponent of the Conscription Act, and of all volunteering for the war, who thinks our armies ought to be stronger; a good old-school Democrat, who thinks the humble origin of LINCOLN and JOHNSON a complete disqualification for either the Presidency or the Vice-Presidency; in short, a man who would like everything done differently, and yet is opposed to all change; who wants everything that he cannot get, and who, while agreeing with everybody, differs from all the rest of the world. The General Committee is anxiously engaged in searching for a gentleman possessing the above qualifications, and hope to find him in time for the convention. So far they have not succeeded; but we believe the difficulty is due to the fact that both the peace men and the conditional war men have to agree upon the selection.
headline: {'main': 'The Democratic Dilemma The New Peace Movement.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democratic Dilemma The New Peace Movement.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Tugboat Owners' Convention--Prices Fixed
snippet: Tugboat Owners' Convention--Prices Fixed
lead_paragraph: the proprietors of tugboats was held at No. 12 South-street, on Wednesday evening. Capt. BOYOE was elected Chairman, and Capt. BERRY, Secretary. It was decided to settle the internal discussions of the Association by a Committee of Arbitration, instead of by appeal to the courts, and the rates for towing rafts were fixed at from $12 to $15 her hour according to the size of the tug. The meeting was then adjourned.

abstract: The Tory raid into Western North Carolina has been but briefly alluded to for want of information by the newspapers. It seems that the villians did considerable damage. The pursuit of them, which occurred after they had done the damage, ended at Yellow Mountain, at a place known as the winding stairs, a narrow foot-path crossing the mountains in Mitchell County. Here all the advantages were on the side of the raiders, who escaped, carrying with them most of their prisoners and plunder. The editor of the Salisbury Watchman says:

abstract: The Marion (Miss.,) Clarion gives a brief military biography of this officer, recently appointed Lieutenant-General. He is a native of South Carolina and a graduate of West Point, where he was honored with a diploma in 1854. He was a classmate of Gens. J.E.B. STUART, J.B. VILLEPIGUE, W.D. PENDER and HORACE RANDALL. After leaving West Point, he entered the regular service as Second Lieutenant or the Fourth Artillery, and was subsequently promoted First Lieutenant of the First Regiment of Regulars. Shortly after his native State, left the old Union, Gen. LEE resigned his position in the service of the United States, and repaired to South Carolina, where he entered the army of that State as Captain, early in March, 1861. He served with BEAUREGARD in the taking of Fort Sumter, and after the strife was fully inaugurated and a hostile army on the soil of the Old Dominion, he repaired to Virginia with a battery of light artillery, and there, with the legion of HAMPTON, figured conspicuously and honorably in many of the sanguinary engagements. He was soon honored with the rank of Major, next Lieutenant-Colonel and then Colonel. He commanded a battery on the Potomac for some time; was in the battle of Seven Pines and the seven days' fight around Richmond; was next assigned to duty as Colonel of the Fourth Virginia cavalry and subsequently to a battery of artillery that gained distinction in the second battle of Manassas and at Sharpsburgh. When a commander was needed for the defences of Vicksburgh in the Fall of 1862, President DAVIS sent him to defend the stronghold of Mississippi, having conferred upon him the rank of Brigadier-General. He commanded at the battle of Chickasaw Bayou, above Vicksburgh, where, in December, 1862, he whipped SHERMAN and MORGAN SMITH, who brought a large force against his heroic little band. At the battle of Baker's Creek he commanded a brigade of Georgians, and during the siege of Vicksburgh held that portion of STEVENSON's line so furiously assaulted on the 19th and 22d of May. Shortly after the surrender. Gen. LEE was appointed to the rank of Major-General, and assigned to the command of all the cavalry in the Mississippi Department.

abstract: We are requested to state that hereafter the United States postage charge, without regard to distance, on letters addressed to or received from the British West Indies, Cuba, Aspinwall, Panama, or any other foreign place or country to and from which different rates of postage have not been established by international postal convention or arrangement, will be ten cents the single rate of half an ounce or under, which must be prepaid on letters sent, and collected on letters received. Also, that the United States postage charge on newspapers and other printed matter sent to or received from the countries and places referred to, will, in future, be as follows, viz.: Two cents each on newspapers; and the established domestic rates on pamphlets, periodicals and other articles of printed matter, which must in like manner, be prepaid on matter sent, and collected on matter received.

Also, that the United States postage charge on newspapers and other printed matter sent to or received from the countries and places referred to, will, in future, be as follows, viz.: Two cents each on newspapers; and the established domestic rates on pamphlets, periodicals and other articles of printed matter, which must in like manner, be prepaid on matter sent, and collected on matter received.

abstract: The movements of the State Militia under the call for 100 days' men have been somewhat retarded by certain questions which have arisen. The officers of several regiments claim that the call was for volunteers, as per General Orders No. 13, and that their organizations cannot be compelled to leave the State. Nothing further has been developed concerning the reported arrest of Col. MAIDHOFF, of the Eleventh Regiment; but if the case is tried, it will settle all the questions now mooted between the Governor and the Commanders of Divisions. It will be seen by the following order that those who enlist in the 100 days' service will be exempt from the coming draft:

abstract: Eighty-one rebel prisoners have been brought here from Sandy Hook, Md. They state that they were in charge of one of the plunder trains, and were overtaken near Snicker's Gap by a portion of the pursuing force under Gen. CROOK. A fight immediately followed; but the train guard, finding it impossible to save the train, destroyed it by fire, and retreated, leaving the teamsters and others at the mercy of our forces.

abstract: The clerks of this City, engaged in the dry goods and other business, are about to appeal to their employers for an increase of salary. We understand that there has been so general increase in the rate of compensation for this hardworking and intelligent class of the community since the opening of the war. The price of board, the price of clothing, and the cost of living generally, has nearly doubled within the last two years; and many clerks with families or relatives dependent upon them find it really difficult to pay their way. The clerks propose no strikes, no combination and no offensive movement of any kind, but simply to ask that their liberal and prosperous employers give their case consideration and mote out to them a measure of justice.

abstract: Rebel History of
snippet: Rebel History of
lead_paragraph: The Elmira Advertiser says the train containing the rebel prisoners not killed at Lackawaxen reached that place about 10 o'clock Saturday night. They numbered about 800. Lieut.-Col. EASTMAN, Commandant of the post, with wise foresight had made every preparation for the reception of the injured, as well as the uninjured. He had ordered twelve military baggage wagons, the bottoms deeply lined with hay, to be in readiness to receive the rebel wounded. The work was easily accomplished by a detachment of colored substitutes, in case of all who were unable to move themselves, while those who were able to walk and help themselves in a measure were carefully helped by their comrades and others, to their places in the wagons.

abstract: on Future Rebel Incursions; the Career of
snippet: on Future Rebel Incursions; the Career of
lead_paragraph: Now that Gen. Jo. JOHNSTON's career seems to be nearly closed, we may say that he affords one of the best examples on record of a great military reputation based on nothing better than college success. JOHNSTON had never won a battle, or done anything else by which soldiers acquire reputation, when he was appointed to the command of the force that was to relieve Vicksburgh; and yet it was the universal opinion both North and South that he was an able officer, and was capable of great things. It is hardly possible that his march from PATTERSON's front, and timely arrival at Bull Run, or his conduct during the brief period he had command of the main rebel army on the Peninsula, two years ago, had anything to do with this. The only service he rendered the unfortunate PEMBERTON, at Vicksburgh, was to send him some concise lectures on the art of war, just when it was too late to profit by them. When BRAGG had manoeuvred ROSECRANS from Nashville into Chattanooga, JOHNSTON was put in his place, and was immediately invested with the same unbounded and utterly baseless confidence as before. The Southern people expected to hear every day that he had destroyed SHERMAN's army, without being able to assign a single reason for it, beyond the opinion formed of him by his comrades at college. It is to be hoped that by this time the public, both North and South, is beginning to be aware of the wide interval which separates the brilliant student from the successful soldier, the strategist of the closet from the strategist of the field, and to recognize the large share which the moral qualities have in making an able General.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Johnston's Career.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Johnston's Career.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The splendid steam frigate Susquehanna sails to-day for active service. Her addition to our cruising navy is, at present, very opportune. She is now in admirable order, and it is doubtful whether any naval vessel ever left our shores better conditioned for the exigencies of war and peace. Her battery is of the most perfect description, and consists of the heaviest guns vessels of her class can carry with safety.
lead_paragraph: The splendid steam frigate Susquehanna sails to-day for active service. Her addition to our cruising navy is, at present, very opportune. She is now in admirable order, and it is doubtful whether any naval vessel ever left our shores better conditioned for the exigencies of war and peace. Her battery is of the most perfect description, and consists of the heaviest guns vessels of her class can carry with safety.

abstract: The interest in the war news now centers with Gen. SHERMAN, either before or in Atlanta. An apparently well authenticated report of the evacuation of Atlanta, and of its occupation by Gen. SHERMAN, was re-received at noon yesterday. But later dispatches did not confirm this, though they did assert that Gen. SHERMAN was successfully pushing back the rebels into their defences; that our shells could reach the city; that our troops could see it; and that railroad communication eastward to Augusta, and thence to Richmond, had been severed. A latter dispatch announces in general terms that a battle has been fought, and that the enemy were defeated; a still later dispatch says that the Government has nothing about any battle before or at Atlanta, while a note from the office of the Associated Press, says the Western Union Lines were receiving dispatches over their wires from Atlanta yesterday. Our readers can take their choice.

abstract: Yesterday was a quiet day. There was no booming of cannon, no heavy masses of smoke on the Southern horizon, and no exciting rumors from any quarter. T[???] fact that the flags of the Yankee shipping in James River were at half mast on Monday caused many to give credit to the report of GRANT's death, and this topic and the removal of Gen. J.E. JOHNSTON from the command of the Army of Tennessee, were the topics that chiefly occupied men's minds. Though no one believed his death would be of any great benefit to us, vet every one would have been glad, on general principles, to have been assured of his death. The Yankees think too much of him, and that is sufficient to make us rejoice over any misfortune that might befall him.

abstract: The damage done to the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal by the rebels in their late raid, taking the work in its whole length, is very serious. President SPATES has just returned to Washington, by way of Bedford and Harrisburgh, from a trip of observation of the line beyond Harper's Ferry. He found the Antietam aqueduct, twelve miles west of the Ferry, practically "gone up," the raiders, as he learned, having had a force of nearly two hundred men engaged in its demolition for about forty-eight hours. The aqueduct is a stone structure, and though the piers stand formidably as before, the masonry of the side walls forming the trunk has been thrown off, and large holes are dug through the bottom or archways. Much damage was done to the locks of the canal between Antietam and Williamsport, comprising that region of the canal from which comes the chief flour, grain and produce trade. Lock No. 40 is entirely destroyed, while the gates of the others are generally injured so as to be rendered useless at present. Beyond Williamsport to Cumberland the damage is but slight. The eastern end of the line has not yet been sufficiently well explored to determine the nature of the injuries, but they are thought to be more in the form of obstructions, by the sinking of canal boats, &c. than otherwise. A great drawback is the difficulty ofprocuring labor to effect the repairs in a reasonable time and at reasonable cost.

abstract: -- On the last Monday evening of June, a singing meeting was opened at the church, corner of Lafayette-place and Fourth-street, to be held every Monday evening, and to continue for one hour. The first was a decided success, and at the second, held last Monday evening, the lecture-room was crowded. It has already proved itself to be the right thing in the right place, and on each occasion increases in interest. This meeting, it may be interesting to state, was started through the instrumentality of J.C. LANPHIER, Esq., missionary of the Collegiate Dutch Church, and is already attracting the warm sympathy of many prominent citizens. WM.B. BRADBURY, Esq., the well-known musical publisher, whose Christian zeal, liberality and love for children everywhere manifests itself, has loaned one of his best pianos to be used at these services. A.S. BARNES, Esq., the publisher, has loaned books until one for permanent use has been selected. The next meeting will be held at the same place, on the 25th inst., between 8 and 9 P. M., on which occasion all disposed are invited to attend, and remain as long as their business inclination or convenience will permit.

abstract: The New, Effect of on the War
snippet: The New, Effect of on the War
lead_paragraph: The immense reinforcements which will be secured to the National armies by the last Proclamation of the President, of course have a most important military bearing. They will make these armies irresistibly superior to any force which the "Confederates" can possibly bring against them. If LEE's and JOHNSTON's armies have not been able to prevent GRANT, and SHERMAN from fighting their way through the most difficult and most defensible parts of the "Confederacy" with the old levies, it is a sound military conclusion that when the new levies are added to them, it will be in our power to penetrate to any part of the South, and to drive the rebellion to its last ditch.

abstract: Labor System
snippet: Labor System
lead_paragraph: A City cotemporary finds occasion to condemn the labor system instituted by Gen. BANKS in Louisiana, by reason of the fact, among others, that the negro laborer is underpaid. It will doubtless interest those of our readers -- and we presume they are not few -who have felt the pinch of high prices and limited incomes in these times, to learn what Gen. BANKS' scale of remuneration for unskilled, labor, which is thus assailed, actually amounts to.

abstract: Peace, his Duty and Policy on
snippet: Peace, his Duty and Policy on
lead_paragraph: In December last President LINCOLN issued a Proclamation promising pardon to every person in rebellion against the Government of the United States, (with certain specified exceptions,) who would swear to support the Constitution of the United States, and all valid acts of Congress and proclamations of the Executive in regard to slaves. In the message accompanying this document the President took occasion to say that it was not intended, by specifying these terms of restoration, to exclude all others. "It is not said," he remarked, "that other classes and other terms than those designated will never be included." At that time the President invited men in rebellion to return to their allegiance, and promised pardon on certain specified conditions -- holding himself perfectly free to change and modify those conditions at any subsequent time, according to his own sense of justice and of public policy.
