abstract: Rebel Generals and Fortunes in
snippet: Rebel Generals and Fortunes in
lead_paragraph: -- We took occasion yesterday to speak of the approaching close of Gen. JO. JOHNSTON's military career in Georgia. It now seems that his career had closed when we wrote, for we have through the Richmond papers his farewell order to his army, dated on Sunday last. Gen. HOOD, who was for a long time in command of a Texan brigade, and who has figured frequently in battles both in Virginia and the Southwest, is JOHNSON's successor.
headline: {'main': 'REBEL GENERALS AND REBEL FORTUNES IN GEORGIA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'REBEL GENERALS AND REBEL FORTUNES IN GEORGIA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This committee held its regular meeting (which was largely attended) at the corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, on Thursday evening, the 21st inst. Arrangements were set on foot to hold a monster mass meeting in a short time, to indorse LINCOLN and JOHNSON. GEORGE TERWILLIGER was unanimously elected Treasurer of the committee, and resolution's were passed to make the committee an efficient auxiliary in securing a Union triumph at the coming election. Resolutions were also offered and unanimously adopted deploring the decease of EDWARD W. COLLIN, late member from the Eleventh Ward, and brief and eloquent eulogies were delivered by Messrs. THOS. ROBINSON and D. LICHTENHEIN.
lead_paragraph: This committee held its regular meeting (which was largely attended) at the corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, on Thursday evening, the 21st inst. Arrangements were set on foot to hold a monster mass meeting in a short time, to indorse LINCOLN and JOHNSON. GEORGE TERWILLIGER was unanimously elected Treasurer of the committee, and resolution's were passed to make the committee an efficient auxiliary in securing a Union triumph at the coming election. Resolutions were also offered and unanimously adopted deploring the decease of EDWARD W. COLLIN, late member from the Eleventh Ward, and brief and eloquent eulogies were delivered by Messrs. THOS. ROBINSON and D. LICHTENHEIN.

abstract: This favorite line, connecting this City with Boston, has lately undergone a thorough reorganization, which, it is believed, will result in adding greatly to its facilities for accommodating the public. According to the new programme, which is advertised in another column, the steamer Commonwealth will leave this City on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, and the Plymouth Rock on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. The fact that the steamers of this line take the inside passage, thus avoiding Point Judith, it is claimed, enables them to make sure connections with Newport, the watering-places on the north and south shores in Massachusetts, the great eastern routes for Maine, and for the White Mountains. Regarding the facilities for eating and sleeping, old travelers only need to be told that the advertisement promises that under the new arrangement they shall be made better than ever before.

abstract: The Federal war steamer Kearsarge arrived in Dover Roads on Wednesday evening. It had been stated in some of the French papers that a successor to the Alabama would probably be in waiting off Cherbourg when the Federal vessel left that port, and that another naval engagement might take place, in which the South would have an opportunity of retrieving its late defeat.
lead_paragraph: The Federal war steamer Kearsarge arrived in Dover Roads on Wednesday evening. It had been stated in some of the French papers that a successor to the Alabama would probably be in waiting off Cherbourg when the Federal vessel left that port, and that another naval engagement might take place, in which the South would have an opportunity of retrieving its late defeat. No new Alabama, however, seems to have yet appeared; but it is asserted that a steamer, the Jeddo, which left Bordeaux on the 22d June, is to take the place of the notorious privateer. On this subject the Geronde of the 4th says: "It will be recollected that a mystery surrounded the departure of the Jeddo. This mystery seems likely to be maintained. In fact it was Wednesday, the 22d June, that the Jeddo quitted our port for Amsterdam; the voyage between the two cities being ordinarily four days, we ought five days ago at least to have heard of the arrival in the Dutch port of the steamer built and armed by M. ARMAN. But no commercial journal that we know of has said a word on the subject. The voyage of the Jeddo has certainly something strange and unusual about it, and the future will soon show that the anticipations, respecting her were only too well founded." The Opinion Nationale asserts that the vessel here referred to will soon reappear, fully armed and manned, and with the Confederate flag flying. Capt. SEMMES, it is said, is too ill to take the command of her. This duty will consequently devolve upon the first lieutenant of the late Alabama, whose appointment is expected to arrive about the middle of the present month. If the statements of the French papers are to be relied on, there will soon be no lack in the channel of war vessels belonging to the opposing Powers. According to those statements, the Florida is already there; the Jeddo, as we have seen, is being got ready; and "the South is probably preparing a display of fresh forces;" while on the other hand, we learn that the Federal steamer Niagara left Antwerp on the 2d instant, to cruise in the Channel, and that a new Federal steamer, the Macedonian, built upon the same model as the Kearsarge, and armed with heavy guns, is expected. The Presse thinks that a far more "dramatic engagement than that in which the Alabama perished" may accordingly be looked for at no distant date.

abstract: Portogallo, Iron Frigate; Description of
snippet: Portogallo, Iron Frigate; Description of
lead_paragraph: Our harbor is again ornamented by an iron-clad frigate of the Italian navy. The new and splendid two-decker Re de Luizi de Portogallo, sister ship to the Re d'Italia, has been turned over to the representatives of King VICTOR EMANUEL by Mr. WILLIAM H. WEBB, who built her. The officers and crew have arrived from Italy and are now on board, their ship being in commission and preparing rapidly for a trial trip, prior to her departure for Naples. Unlike that of the Re d' Italia, the coming trip will be made under the special supervision of the Italian officers, and no conflict of authority can therefore beget unpleasant consequences during its progress.

abstract: A cowhiding affair took place in Allegheny on Thursday evening, in which a man name [???] ROBERT SHORTS, well advanced In years, received some slight chastisement at the hands of a woman where daughter, it was alleged, he had attempted to abduct. The girl is a young miss of thirteen years, and [???] alleged that SHORTS has lately been so attractive to her, that he succeeded in winning her confidence, though it is not claimed that anything improper ever passed between them. On Thursday evening Mr. SHORTS invited the fair one to take a walk with him, and started in the direction of East Common. The girl's mother noticing their departure, armed herself with a cowhide, and started after them. She met them on the Common, and after giving the elderly over a lecture, proceeded to administer to him a service castigation. SHORTS not relishing the flogging, turned upon the indignantmother, and was endeavoring to take the cowhide from her, when the lady's [???] and appeared, and commenced making offensive demonstrations. SHORTS then drew a pistol, at the sight of which the attacking party withdrew, taking their daughter with them, and leaving the old man master of the field. A warrant was subsequently issued for the arrest of SHORTS of a charge of attempted abduction, that the end is not yet. -- Pittsburgh Chronicle.

abstract: Law provides that when state Banks become National Banks, any of the stockholders, by making demands for the value of their stock, within thirty days of the transfer, shall be paid the same from the assets of the bank. The law further provides that the Bank Commissioners shall make an estimate of the value of the stock, based upon the fair market value of the assets of the bank. Recently, some of the stockholders of one of the banks of this State, which has become a National Bank, have demanded the value of their stock. An important question in connection with their value is, whether the market premium on the gold owned by the banks, at the time of the transfer, shall be counted among the assets. As the State Banks immediately upon becoming National Banks dispose of their gold, and the premium is added to their assets, we think the Commissioners will be justified in considering the the premium an element of the value, in making their estimate. -- Boston Traveller.

abstract: The installation of the Most Rev. JOHN MCCLOSKEY, D.D., to succeed the late Archbishop HUGHES, is announced to take place in St. Patrick's Cathedral on Sunday, Aug. 21. A large number of bishops and other dignitaries of the Church, including the clergy of this and other dioceses, will be present and participate in the exercises. Prof. GUSTAV SCHUITZ, the recently-appointed organist of St. Patrick's, has, it is understood, composed music expressly for the occasion, and it will be performed by the best artists whose services can be obtained. A Te Deum and Jubilate are to be sung, and the Most Rev. Dr. MCCLOSKEY will deliver his first archiepiscopal sermon. The ceremonies of installation, comprising one of the grandest of the rituals of the Roman Church, are of very rare occurrence. They will of course be witnessed by a crowded congregation; but the capacity of the great cathedral will be entirely insufficient to accommodate the multitudes who will seek admission.

abstract: The underwriters' agents are availing of the present fine weather to raise as much as posible of the wreck as it now lies on Daunt's Rock. A large float or barge has been procured from the ship-building yard of ROBINSON  Co., and is furnished with a crane of some power for the work of lifting.
lead_paragraph: The underwriters' agents are availing of the present fine weather to raise as much as posible of the wreck as it now lies on Daunt's Rock. A large float or barge has been procured from the ship-building yard of ROBINSON Co., and is furnished with a crane of some power for the work of lifting. One of the masts and a quantity of copper piping and other materials have been removed, and brought into the harbor during the past few days, and all the intervening fittings will have to be removed before an attempt can be made to lift the boilers, which will be the first of the heavy portion of the wreck worked upon. At low water the ship's quarter is still visible, an[???] as the sea dasi[???]es in through the aperture of the hu[???]l a column of spray is projected up through the deck to a height of about forty feet, something after the manner of the "puffing holes" at Kilkee.

abstract: Electioneering Plot Spoiled
snippet: Electioneering Plot Spoiled
lead_paragraph: Two problems press upon the rebel mind: How to whip GRANT and how to defeat LINCOLN. The more they are baffled in the first, the more anxiously they set to the second. It is plain that to accomplish this latter, any indirect means can be employed. Votes only can defeat LINCOLN, and rebels have no votes. The point, then, is: How to secure the votes of others? or, in other words, how to augment the opposition party of the North? The great strength of Mr. LINCOLN is, that he represents the only genuine war spirit of the country. Therefore to prevent his reelection, some device must be found that shall, for a time at least, disconcert this war spirit. The first, attempt in this line has just been tried on the Canadian frontier.

abstract: The news from Atlanta is still full of doubt as to the occupation of the city by Gen. SHERMAN, Dispatches from Nashville and Louioville assert that it is true beyond a doubt. But the Government has not yet received any such information. A dispatch received at Washington yesterday says that Atlanta is not ...
lead_paragraph: The news from Atlanta is still full of doubt as to the occupation of the city by Gen. SHERMAN. Dispatches from Nashville and Louioville assert that it is true beyond a doubt. But the Government has not yet received any such information. A dispatch received at Washington yesterday says that Atlanta is not yet ours, but that we are in possession of a part of the city, the enemy holding the rest. An official dispatch from Gen. SHERMAN to the War Department gives further particulars of the battle of Wednesday last, when the enemy assaulted our lines. Gen. HOWARD buried two hundred dead rebels in front of his corps. Gen. HOOKER, while advancing the lines of his corps, met the enemy in the open field, and a terrible battle ensued, in which the enemy were badly defeated. At the close of the engagement Gen. HOOKER announced to Gen. SHERMAN that he had buried four hundred rebels, and that four thousand wounded lay in his front.

abstract: FATAL STABBING AFFRAY IN SOUTH BROOKLYN. -- Two men, named THOMAS DURPHY and ROBERT GILLINGTON, were arrested yesterday morning by Officers LENT and GILLIGAN, of the Forty-third Precinct Police, on the charge of causing the death of THOMAS MCGRATH, by stabbing. The parties were machinists, and engaged in the construction of a United States gunboat at the foot of Van Brunt-street. On Friday evening they were in company at the Sumter House, kept by Mr. RILEY, in Imlay-street, near Ewen. They drank several times at that and other places. After leaving the house, they got into a quarrel, in which MCGRATH was stabbed by one of the parties in the left breast with a knife. The wound was about half an inch in length, and caused death in a few minutes. RILEY, seeing the affray, ran up and was just in time to hear MCGRATH exclaim, "I am stabbed." The accused parties ran off in different directions, and could not be found by the officers until next morning. The body of deceased was picked up and taken to his residence in Van Brust-street. He leaves a wife and two children. Coronel NORRIS will investigate the circumstances this afternoon.

abstract: State Rights, the Old Doctrine of; Seat of Government, The
snippet: State Rights, the Old Doctrine of; Seat of Government, The
lead_paragraph: To the old Southern doctrine of State Rights, as is very well understood by our people, we are largely indebted for the rebellion, and it will be always held in abhorrence by them on this account. The true doctrine of State Rights they will never abandon, and they never should, but the old doctrine, which would make the Union a mere rope of sand, which taught that every citizen's duty was first to his State, and then if it pleased, to the United States, which ignored the clause in the Constitution which provides that the Constitution and laws of the United States shall be the supreme law of the land, but gave State authority the right to release every one from his duty to that Constitution and those laws -- that doctrine of State Rights can never be accepted again either North of South.
headline: {'main': 'The Old Doctrine of State Rights.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Old Doctrine of State Rights.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Civil War in; Arrest of the Editor of
snippet: The Civil War in; Arrest of the Editor of
lead_paragraph: The order of Her Majesty's Government, forbidding British officers to remain any longer in the Imperialist service, not having reached Pekin at latest dates, Major GORDON was still prosecuting the war vigorously against the Taepings, who, though continually losing ground, are defending themselves with the courage of despair, and have recently inflicted a severe repulse on the Anglo-Chinese troops. This occurred at Chang-chow, the most important, after Nankin, of all the rebel strong, holds, and which GORDON, in conjunction with the mandarin forces, is besieging. When the Major arrived before this city, he found it invested on three sides by about 60,000 Imperialists, who had breached the wall in seven places, but not yet ventured on an assault. The Commander of the mercenaries at one determined to put an end to this state of if action by storming certain earthworks held by the rebels, outside the west gates. These were all carried by the 26th of April. Then batteries were planted to widen the breaches which the native artillerists had made, am on the morning of the 28th a general onset was ordered. But the assailants encountered so desperate a resistance that, after the fight had continued for half an hour with the utmost fury, they had to retire, with the loss of some 400 officers and men killed and wounded. Notwithstanding this disaster, however, nothing can avert the capture of Chang-chow, and the overthrow of the rebels, save the speedy recall of GORDON. The rigid enforcement of the British order may once more turn the tide of victory in favor of the Taepings, but if the Commander of the Anglo-Chinese legion be left at its head for a few months longer, the Empire of Tien-wang will have vanished. Already, indeed, it is tottering to its fall, Kiang-soo being the only province where the rebels retain a semblance of power, and even there, three of the four cities which yet remain to them are beleaguered.
headline: {'main': 'The Civil War in China.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Civil War in China.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Court-Martial Convened
snippet: Court-Martial Convened
lead_paragraph: SPINOLA COURT-MARTIAL. -- The Court-martial for the trial of Gen. SPINOLA convened yesterday morning, at No.17 State-street. Gen. SPINOLA was present with his counsel, Mr. WaLDO HUTCHINGS and Mr. TALCOTT. JAMES T. BRADY is also engaged to defend him. The court is composed of Major-Gen. JOHN J. PECK, President; Major-Gen. G.L. Hartsuff, Brig.-Gen. S. Green, Brig.-Gen. Wm.H. Morris, Brig.-Gen. Webb, Lieut.-Col. James B. McGee, Sixty-ninth N.Y. Volunteers; Lieut.-Col. J.G. Hughes, Thirty-ninth N.Y. Volunteers; Lieut.-Col. Jasper H. Raymond, Second N.Y. Mounted Rifles, with Col. N.J. Hall, of the Seventh Michigan Volunteers, as Judge-Advocate. The Judge-Advocate having read the orders for the court-martial and a letter from Gen. PECK, stating he could not be present at all the meetings of the court, Gen. HARTSUFF suggested that as Gens. PECK and WEBB were then absent, it would be advisable to adjourn till Monday. The court then adjourned till to-morrow, at 11 A.M.

abstract: The Boston Transcript gives the following statistics of the Harvard Senior Class: In 1860 the admissions to the class of 1864 were 112. Subsequently the class numbered 144, but is now 96. Eleven entered the United States army and one went into the navy. Six of the former have fallen in battle or died in service. Of the whole number twenty-two belonged in Boston, twelve
lead_paragraph: The Boston Transcript gives the following statistics of the Harvard Senior Class: In 1860 the admissions to the class of 1864 were 112. Subsequently the class numbered 144, but is now 96. Eleven entered the United States army and one went into the navy. Six of the former have fallen in battle or died in service. Of the whole number twenty-two belonged in Boston, twelve to Cambridge and thirty-four to other places in Massachusetts. In religious belief, forty were [???] twenty Orthodox Congregational, eighteen Upiacopalian, eight Baptists and two "of no opinion;" six were of various denominations. In political sentiments 74 were Republicans, 12 Democrats, 9 Union, and 1 of "no opinion." The number voting at last Presidential election was 5; eligible to vote at next election 67. 16 of the class has been drafted. Of the whole number 61 smoke, 80 drink, 58 smoke and drank, 4 smoke but do not drink, 23 drink but do not smoke, and 12 neither drink or smoke. The average age is a little over 21 years and 10 months; the average height is about 5 feet 8 1/4 inches; the average weight is a fraction over 138 1/4 pounds; the average circumference of the chest nearly 38 inches. Of the whole, 28 are nearsighted. Seven out of eleven members of a temperance society during the Freshman year are set down as drinkers. Seventeen societies and clubs have been sustained by the class during their college connection. The class fund amounts to $513. The intentions of the class seem to predicate that 31 will engage in law; 18 in business; 10 in medicine; 5 in the army; 3 each in civil engineering, the ministry and teachings; 2 in literary affairs; 1 each in farming, as a naturalist, a farmer and a sheep raiser; 17 are undecided. Two of the ministers will be Orthodox and one Unitarian.

abstract: The English Opera Company at the Olympic Theatre announce that this will be the last week of their performances there. They have given, so far, three operas--all of them old and threadbare; still, the attendance has been highly respectable, both in numbers and character.
lead_paragraph: The English Opera Company at the Olympic Theatre announce that this will be the last week of their performances there. They have given, so far, three operas -- all of them old and threadbare; still, the attendance has been highly respectable, both in numbers and character. On Wednesday of the present week they produce, for the first time in this country, BAL[???]'s opera of the Rose of Castile -- an unpretending and charming work, which will, we are (sure, speedily become popular. With such an attraction in the repertoire, it would be a shame if the season came to the sudden termination mentioned. It will, we hope, be renewed after Saturday, and continued just as lung as the attractiveness of the programme merits and courts patronage. A correspondent, by the way, inquires if it would not be a good idea to revive BRISTOW's Rip Van Winkle. We think it would, and cheerfully make the suggestion to the management. On opera on a purely American subject, composed by a native musician of rare attainments, would certainly be acceptable to an American audience. Moreover, the opera was a success on its production by the Pyne & Harrison troupe, and is remembered with interest and favor by all who then heard it. To - night and to-morrow night the "Bohemian Girl" will be given for the last times this season.

abstract: The news from Gen. Sherman's army, this morning, although brief, is of the deepest interest It appears that up to Friday, desperate fighing has been in progress in front of Atlanta, and  during the severe contest of Friday, our army had the sad misfortune to lose Gen. McPherson, one of the most gallant, accomplished, and successful of the Union commanders, either East or West Gen. McPherson, according to one of the reports
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. Sherman's army, this morning, although brief, is of the deepest interest. It appears that up to Friday, desperate figthing has been in progress in front of Atlanta, and during the severe contest of Friday, our army had the sad misfortune to lose Gen. MCPHERSON, one of the most gallant, accomplished, and successful of the Union commanders, either East or West Gen. MCPHERSON, according to one of the reports which we publish, was shot through the lungs, so that his death mast have been instantaneous. In an official dispatch, which has not been published, Gen. SHERMAN gives the particular of his brave lieutenant's death. His remains were to be sent. home in charge or members of his staff. At the date of the latest reports from SHERMAN, it would appear that the fighting in front of Atlanta was still going on, and that Gen. SHERMAN had brought his siege guns to bear upon the city, a portion of which was on fire. We have letters from our correspondent with SHERMAN's army, which bring down the history of the campaign to the crossing of the Chattahoochee.

abstract: Brooklyn, McGrath, A, Stabbed by A Grinlinton
snippet: Brooklyn, McGrath, A, Stabbed by A Grinlinton
lead_paragraph: Coroner NORRIS held an inquest yesterday, upon the body of THOMAS MCGRATH, who came to his death on Friday night last, from a wound inflicted with a knife, by ROBERT GRINLINTON. From the evidence taken, it appears that GRINLINTON and THOMAS DUMPHY, both employed on a United States gunboat in the Atlantic Dock basin, left work at the usual hour on the above evening to go home. They called into DEPPERHAN's saloon, in Imlay-street, and took a drink. They met MCGRATH there. A soldier with a musket came in, and a conversation arose as to different styles of military tactics. They had several drinks, and all became more or less influenced by liquor. DUMPHY, who had seen in the English army, got into position to show some style of tactics, when MCGRATH pushed him over, and made a motion to strike him, when GRINLINTON interposed, and there was no further trouble. MCGRATH and GRINLINTON got into a conversation about work, and the latter promised to see the foreman of the boiler-shop, with the view of securing him a job. Taking another drink they walked together through Imlay-street, will talking about tactics, when MCGRATH turned and struck DUMPHY in the face several times, and knocked him down. GRINLINTON asked him not to kill DUMPHY when he [???] med "Yes, and you too." When that he struck GRINLINTON a blow, knocking him down. GRINLINTON got up and was seen to make a move toward MCGRATH, and making a thrust upward, as if with a knife. MCGRATH cried that he was stubbed. He fell and was picked up by some neighbors, who carried him to his residence No. 3 Van Brunt-street. He died soon after the injury. GRINLINTON then left. DUMPHY went home before the last [???]ray, it having been shown that he was so much under the influence of liquor that he hardly knew what he was about. No explanation was given why MCGRATH struck DUMPHY. One witness testified that MCGRATH was going toward GRINLINTON, and the latter was backing away from him about the time injury was inflicted. The wound was in the left breast, penetrating the heart. The jury, after hearing the evidence brought, in the following verdict:

abstract: A fire broke out in the barn of B.W. CURTIS, about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and consumed eight or ten buildings. Owing to the scarcity of water, it was with greet difficulty the firemen could work. The fire extended through to Washington-street, and destroyed the following buildings; Mr. SPILLET's barn and stable, Mr. BARTOW's house and stable, and Mr. G. MCGEE's house. Mr. WM. DURLING, stage proprietor, lost all his barns and their contents. His house, by the exertions of the firemen, was saved. The names of the other losers could not be ascertained at the time our informant left.

abstract: A letter from the Army of the Potomac, dated yesterday, says. Nothing of peculiar interest has occurred in the past two days. The skirmishing in BURNSIDE'S front Friday afternoon was quite lively, but without injury to our men. This is the only part of the line where it may be said the firing is almost unceasing, scarcely five minutes elapsing in the day or night, without hearing musketry yr artillery.

abstract: Marsh's, G P; Man and Nature
snippet: Marsh's, G P; Man and Nature
lead_paragraph: The writer of the present volume, though but a recent gleauer in the field of authorship, has won an acknowledged position that insures re spectful attention to any subject that he may think worthy of being brought before the public. America, indeed, can count few men like Mr. MARSH -- at once a scholar and a stateman -- who combines active and contemplative pursuits in a manner that scarcely meets with a paralell in our biographical annals. He has always been a profound and observant student of men, books and things, confined to no nationalities, but ranging from his great philological acquirements, over the most obscure and least known literatures of Europe, while equally familiar with those of the classic nations, ancient and modern. Great natural powers of mind, cultivated and heightened by this breadth and depth of erudition, have entitled him to speak on almost every topic of enlightened inquiry with the authority of an original investigator and discoverer. Unfortunately for his cotemporaries -- and as is too often the case with men of this encyclopedic stamp -- the passion for acquiring knowledge is over-mastering, and scarcely checked for a moment by the minor duty of communicating it. The chance delivery of his lectures on "Language," and on "Early English Literature," and their publication, first revealed to the world what had been hitherto only known to a circle of private friends. They have been received, both at home and abroad, with acclamation, and now take permanent rank among the most learned and philosophical contributions to the study of the elder literature of England that the present age has produced. Be it always remembered, too, that this was not with the author a special or exclusive pursuit, such as a College Professor lectures on and ponders over for long series of years. They were written almost "off hand," from a general fullness of thought and knowledge, and form a mere temporary episode in the life of a scholar, whose intellectual drag-net brings in turn all subjects of human or inanimate interest within his grasp. Somewhat similar in its relation to the writer is the volume before us. The first suggestion of the train of thought exemplified in "Man and Nature," was due to observations made in his New England home. Foreign travel deepened these impressions, and intimacy with a whole class of books devoted to similar inquiries, (which probably no American or Englishmen shares with him,) has led to the production of a work that opens a branch of research at once novel, interesting and important to the wellfare of civilized man.

abstract: to President Tyler on Politics; Letters of Theo Scott and H A Wise to; to President Tyler, and Latter's Indorsement
snippet: to President Tyler on Politics; Letters of Theo Scott and H A Wise to; to President Tyler, and Latter's Indorsement
lead_paragraph: The progress of our armies southward exhumes, from the private collections of Southern politicians, a good many private letters, which give interesting inside views of the troubles and perplexities of the political controversies of fifteen or twenty years ago. Many of these letters, which have come into our hands from our Southern soldiers or correspondents, are so purely private and personal in their character and contents, that their publication would be scarcely proper. Others relate wholly to public affairs, and form, properly enough, part of the political history of the day.

lead_paragraph: We do not ask whether peace is desirable. No public journal has supported the war more steadfastly than this. Through all the varying fortunes of the struggle, it has never for an instant bated one jot of faith or determination. But this has not been because we have loved the war for its own sake. None but a devil could do that. This sacrifice of blood, of treasure, this monthly making of widows and orphans by the thousand, this turning of acres by the hundred thousand into desolation, is dreadful work. We have upheld it only because it is a necessity -- because its only alternative is something more dreadful yet. It has been because the war alone can save the Republic, the last hope of popular government and human progress, and because if the Republic perishes it must be succeeded by an indefinite number of military confederacies with discordant interests and in endless conflict, that we have sustained the war and shall sustain it. We shall stand up to it unwaveringly so long as these reasons are in force. For all that, it is a thing to be deplored. Peace is a consummation most devoutly to be wished.

abstract: as a Military Force
snippet: as a Military Force
lead_paragraph: There were very few people at the North who did not at the outset of the war suppose Slavery to be, from a military point, a source of weakness, and only of weakness, in a State. There are very few now who have not seen reason to modify their opinion. It is quite evident that for the purposes of war, Slavery is neither an unmixed evil nor an unmixed good, but a compound of both. We all thought it probable that when the white men of the South raised the standard of revolt against the Government, the negroes would either raise the standard of revolt against their masters, or else would prove so insubordinate, that a strong force of "the superior race" would have to be left to maintain order, in every county in which slaves were numerous.

abstract: We have news from Europe by the extra Cu- nard steamer Marathon, three days later than that received by the Europa, and two days later than that brought by the Kangaroo, which arriv ed here on Saturday. The chief point of interest
lead_paragraph: We have news from Europe by the extra Cunard steamer Marathon, three days later than that received by the Europa, and two days later than that brought by the Kangaroo, which arrived here on Saturday. The chief point of interest in the news is the report that the King of Denmark having quarrelled with his Ministers (as was announced in the Europa's mails) they have resigned; that the King has summoned reactionary Ministers to his Council, and has sent Prince JOHN OF GLUCKSBURG to make terms of compromise with Prussia. The King's views would seem to be to make Denmark the German Naval Power. It is asserted that a suspension of hostilities has been agreed to. Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH has written a letter in the London Times' pictures of "Federal Cruelties," which we publish in another column. A murder of almost unparalleled daring and atrocity has been perpetrated in a London railway carriage, the victim being a respectable gentlemen connected with one of the London banks.

abstract: Two men, named JOHN W. ADDY and CHAS. WILLIAMS, were arrested at an early hour yesterday morning by Officer MALONEY, of the Fifth Precinct, on the charge of burglary. The scoused were found in the liquor store of MICHAEL RYAN, No. 164 West Broadway. Seventy five pennies, when they had stolen from RYAN's drewer, were found in their possession. The prisoners were committed for trial by Justice DOWLING, in default of $1,000 full each.

abstract: LARCENY BY BOYS. -- Two boys, named JAMES CARROLL (colored) and EDWARD MYERS, (white,) were arrested by officer RIGGS, of the Forty first Precinct Police, on Saturday on the charge of larceny. They were employed by Mr. BENJ SOLOMON in unleading crockery were at his store in Myrtle avenue. Having dropped a pocket-book containing $176 in the wagon, it was picked up by CARROLL, who, after taking $10 out, gave it to MYERS. The latter went home and gave the money to his father, who rewarded them with $2 each, and, as alleged, secreted the remainder of the money in a trunk, where it was subsequently found by the officers. The accused were held to answer.

abstract: -- The President of the United States having recommended that the 4th day of August be observed as a day of fasting and prayer. Bishop POTTER, of this Diocese, has issued an address to the energy and congregations under his charge. The Bishop, in his address, says: "That our past, as a nation, has been marked by acts of violence and rapacity toward the Weak. [???] must needs provoke the anger of heaven. Our present is characterized by a levity and presumptuous self-confidence; by a want of calm trust in God and the justice of our cause, which ill accord with our condition as dependent beings, or with the enormous sacrifices of life, and virtue, and property, through which we are called to pass. We need to be excited to more abstinence in pleasure and all luxurious expense, and to a clearer perception of the great ends of life. We need to reach a profounder sense of the insufficiency of all human wisdom and strength, when forsaken of God. We need, by earnest repentance and continued prayer, to invoke [???] pre[???] and aid, who alone can deliver from [???]tion, pr[???] conspiracy and rebellion, or restore us to that social, abiding and righteous peace, for which we long. Unless the Lord keep the city, the watchman wak[???] but in vain. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 28.

abstract: Tax Commissioners' Case; Search Warrant, and Books Found
snippet: Tax Commissioners' Case; Search Warrant, and Books Found
lead_paragraph: A SEARCH WARRANT ISSUED -- SEVERAL LOST BOOES RECOVERED BY THE POLICE -- ONE PERSON UNDER ARREST. -- At a late hour on Saturday afternoon, Mr. CHRISTIAN B. WOODRUFF, one of the Tax Commission ers of this City, went before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs Police Court, and made an affidavit to the effect that the Books of Record and Receivers' books o the following Wards were missing from the Tax Commissioners' office, viz.: the First, Second, Third, Ninth, Eleventh, Fifteenth, Seventeenth, Eighteenth, Twentieth, two volumes of the Twenty-first and Twenty second, and one volume of the Nineteeth Ward; also, two volumes of the lists of residents, and one volume containing the name of the taxable non-residents of this City; also a large number of affidavits and vouchers relating to the taxable properly of the City. The affidavit further states that these missing books and papers are the property of the City and County of New-York, that they were feloniously taken from the Tax Commissioners' office in the City of New-York, on or about the 3th day of May last, and that he (WOODRUFF) has cause to suspect, and does suspect that the same or a portion thereof are concealed in the house of Mr. THEODORE KARNER, at No. 278 East Seventy-fourth-street.

abstract: the Military Value of
snippet: the Military Value of
lead_paragraph: For three months, less a week, a column rivaling in strength the great Army of the Potomac, has been forcing its way toward the City of Atlanta, in Georgia, its progress being disputed at every step by the second great army of the Confederacy. What is the object whose possession justifies such an expenditure of both offensive and defensive force, when either antagonist needs every man and every gun it can muster, in front of the Confederate Capital? In the first place, it is Atlanta itself -- a modern, well-built city, now approaching its twenty-first year, but still sooner to reach its freedom birthday. Laid out in a circular form, with a radius of about a mile, it contains within its strongly intrenched circumference (now that the war has brought an accretion of a fourth to its numbers,) a population of about twenty thousand souls. From its protected situation, deep in the interior of the Confederacy, it was chosen at the outset as a great military depot of supplies and of material of war, and, furthermore, as a great military workshop. In this respect it has no equal in the central zone of the Confederacy. It is the Richmond of the West. Here are arsenals, foundries, furnaces, rolling-mills, machine-shops, laboratories, factories, which have been busily supplying the Confederacy with munitions of war for the past three years. Here the finest and largest rolling-mill in the South has been turning out iron rails for roads, and armor-plating for iron-clads, the latter in great abundance. Here are factories for shot and shell, for pistols, powder, cartridges and percussion caps, for gun-carriages, for small arms, for equipments, wagons and harnesses, shoes and clothing, and for many other purposes useful to the rebel commissariat. Here also, are railroad repair-shops of incalculable value to the enemy. At least two thousand people keep this valuable machinery in operation. We, with our surplus Springfields and Lowells, do not appreciate how illy the enemy can spare this single city. As a depot of supplies, also, as well as a manufactory, Atlanta has played an important part. But doubtless most of its stores and its completed goods, have already been prudentially removed.
headline: {'main': 'What is the Military Value of Atlanta?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What is the Military Value of Atlanta?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Resignation; Moses Taylor Invited to Succeed
snippet: Resignation; Moses Taylor Invited to Succeed
lead_paragraph: We understand that Mr. CISCO, on account of continued ill-health, persists in resigning his position as Assistant Treasurer, and that the President has invited MOSES TAYLOR to accept the office. No appointment could possibly be made which would reflect more credit upon the Government and at the same time give more confidence and gratification to the financial public than this. No man in this country holds a higher position for ability, independence and loyal devotion to the interests and honor of the nation, than Mr. TAYLOR; and his acceptance of this position would be universally regarded as one of the best possible guarantees for a wise and successful administration of the finances of the country.

abstract: The steamship Belgian, from Liverpool, on the 14th, and Londonderry on the l5th, arrived off Farther Point yesterday afternoon. Her news is two days later, but not specially important. Owing to advices received by speculators the rebel cotton loan had advanced to 74. The customary Ministerial dinner had been fixed for July 23, and Parliament would be prorogued about a week thereafter.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Belgian, from Liverpool, on the 14th, and Londonderry on the 15th, arrived off Farther Point yesterday afternoon. Her news is two days later, but not specially important. Owing to advices received by speculators the rebel cotton loan had advanced to 74. The customary Ministerial dinner had been fixed for July 23, and Parliament would be prorogued about a week thereafter. Various rumors were afloat of a naval conflict between the Kearsarge and the Florida, and the Sacramento and the Florida, but they were all improbable. As to the Dano-German war, the belief was quite general that a peace would soon he concluded. It is reported that King CHRISTIAN, of Denmark, proposes in the peace propositions to include the transfer of the Danish navy, on condition of his remaining King of Denmark, under the protection of the German Confederation. The London Times publishes details of the late disaster to the British troops in New-Zealand. It says it was peculiarly disgraceful and, perhaps, unprecedented. The men were surprised and fled, while nearly all their officers were killed or wounded in an effort to rally them.

abstract: A gentleman who has been engaged in recruiting for one of the wards in this city, in Tennessee and Virginia, has given us an account of the manner in which he was treated by parties in Ohio, while bringing his men through that State. He secured six colored men (contrabands,) who came in during HUNTER's expedition to Lynchburgh. He was furnished with proper passes by the military commandant of the post to take his men home. When he reached Portland, Ohio, he was arrested by a big, burly Dutch constable, who attempted to take him and his men from the cars; but he was too smart or him, and kept on his way. At Columbus and Chilticothe he was also arrested, and though he produced his passes, it was with difficulty that he got leave to proceed. When he reached Pittsburgh he found Capt. FOSTER, the Provost-Marshal, in waiting for him, and in compliance with a telegraphic request from the Provost-Marshal of Columbus to arrest him and his men and hold them, they were arrested and held while Capt. FOSTER telegraph to Columbus to know what the charges were against them. After w[???]ng four hours, and receiving no answer, Capt. FOSTER released the parties and allowed them to proceed. They arrived in this city safely, and the men have been duly accepted and must[???]ed in as a part of the quats of the ward. The Ohio officers, whose zeal outran their discretion may be gratified to know this [???], -- Boston Journal, July 23.

abstract: Nothing of importance transpired in this City yesterday relative to military matters. Maj.-Gen. SANDFORD, who went to Washington last week to confer with the authorities there about the departure the one hundred days' men, has not yet returned. It is stated that he has had an interview with the Solicitor of the War Department and the Provost Marshal-General, in relation to the decision of the latter, that the one hundred days' men are liable to the impending draft, but it is believed the interview was [???]uctive of any definite result. No positive information can be given, however, until Gen. SANDFORD returns.

abstract: -- Following the example set by JULIUS CESAR, it appears to be growing more and more the prevalent custom for military men to become the recorders of their own exploits, instead of leaving them to the chance commemoration of writers necessarily less well informed on the subject than the chief actor himself must be. Two remarkable works of this nature are about being issued, relating to the most interesting siege operations of modern times, those directed against the Cities of Charleston and Sebastopol. Mr. D. VAN NOSTRAND will be the medium through whom Major-Gen. GILLMORE's work will be issued to the public, it will contain his "Official Report of Operations against the Defences of Charleston Harbor, 1853, comprising the Descent upon Morris Island, the demolition of Fort Sumter, and the siege [???] induction of Forts Wagner and Gregg," with numerous illustrations. The other work referred to is a History of the Defence of Sebastopol, by Major-Gen. TODLEBEN, its heroic commander. His book is got up at the expense of the Russian Government, on a scale of imperial magnificence; the first portion, in two valumes quarto, (English price, eight guineas.) is all that is yet out. It comprises an account of the preliminary campaign, the battle of Alma, &c., and is written in a spirit of great candor and impartiality. It demonstrates the undoubted fact, that if the Allies had pushed on and attacked Sebastopol by a coup de main, the city must undoubtedly have fallen into their hands, as most of the defences which proved so formidable were not in existence at the time, but were extemporised by the brilliant-genius of the commander.

abstract: few facts about the Alabama; Alabama, the; a few facts about, by Edward Everett; Alabama; Semmes, Capt., Criminal Barbarity of; Edward Everett
snippet: few facts about the Alabama; Alabama, the; a few facts about, by Edward Everett; Alabama; Semmes, Capt., Criminal Barbarity of; Edward Everett
lead_paragraph: The pirate Alabama has at length met with a better fate than she deserved -- destruction in honorable combat with an equal adversary Hitherto, with a single exception,* she has been known only by her victories over the unarmed and defenceless. The courage and conduct, for which our neutral friends abroad bestow upon this alien traitor the honors usually paid to met who have served their own country with distinction, have been exhibited only by Mr. SEMMES in a piratical warfare on merchantmen and whalers, and these cheated into his power by the assumption of the colors of the United States; sometimes betrayed into his clutches while hastening to the relief of some burning vessel, set on fire at night for the inhuman purpose of more effectually betraying other vessels to their destruction.
headline: {'main': 'THE PIRATE ALABAMA.; A Few Facts Relative to Her Origin, Career, and End.BY EDWARD EVERETT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE PIRATE ALABAMA.; A Few Facts Relative to Her Origin, Career, and End.BY EDWARD EVERETT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The Court Journal says. A marriage, thoroughly a la Francaise, has just been get up in the theatrical world. M. LEON ARCHARD, a successful singer at the Opera Comique, suddenly be thought himself that he wanted a wife. On that day he said to a friend, "I am a prosperous man, I have a well-furnished house in Paris, and [???]notcer in the country, and I am making 60,000 a year by my profession; it is time for [???] to be married. I rare not [???] a fortune, but I am determined to have a young and pretty woman." Two days afterward, the friend in question escorted to a stage box in the Opera Comique a singularly beautiful young lady, M[???] LE POLTEVIN, the daughter of a partner. She there saw ARCHARD for the first time, singing on the stage, and was given to understand that he might, perhaps, make her an offer. The next day a dinner was arranged at which to introduce the parties. M. ARCHARD, on being presented, said at once, "M[???], will you marry me?" Her answer, without circum[???]ocution, was, "Yes, Sir." The wedding took place on the 6th inst.

abstract: New-York; Water-street Tenement House; Attempt to Burn
snippet: New-York; Water-street Tenement House; Attempt to Burn
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning, a bold and deliberate attempt was made to burn the large tenement house situated at No. 341 Water-street. From the investigations that have been made, we learn that JOHN JACKSON, who occupied rooms on the third floor of the premises, is the guilty person. He has of late been much addicted to drinking, and when in his fits of intoxication he has beaten his wife badly, and upon several occasions set fire to her wearing apparel. At a late hour on Sunday night he returned home, and finding his wife absent, be stated in the presence of BRIDGET CONNOR that he would destroy everything belonging to his wife, and then he would set fire to the building. Mrs. CONNOR looked through a window and saw JACKSON taking clothing, &c., from a closet, and at the same time heard him say, "I'll make a fire." Soon after, he went to her door, and inquired if she were awake, saying he was going to fire the house immediately, and she could get out if she wanted to. Mrs. CONNOR implored him not to do it, when he, in reply repeatedly said that he would soon put the building in flames. Shortly after this Mrs. CONNOR saw smoke and flame issuing from JACKSON's bedroom. An alarm was raised, and when the neighbors rushed to the scene they found JACKSON holding up linen and cotton wearing apparel, which he had already set on fire, and was trying to make it burn faster by exposing it to the air. The fire had already made considerable progress, when Roundsman BLAIR, of the Fourth Precinct, hearing the disturbance, went to the scene, and with the aid of some citizens, extinguished the flames. JACKSON was arrested and locked up, in default of $1,000 bail. It is said by Fire Marshal BAKER, who is engaged in making an investigation of the matter, that the prisoner has been but two or three months out of Sing Sing. Several of his neighbors are able to testify as to his acts of incendiarism, and also as to the brutality which from to time he has inflicted upon his family.

abstract: The number is now over twenty-seven thousand, says the Macon Journal and Messenger, and has been almost daily increasing. An addition of five acres has recently been made to the inclosure; but even with this it is already too much crowded, and the Commandant is endeavoring to receive no more. The mortality is considerable, being generally from fifty to sixty a day. A strange state of affairs seems to prevail among them, wholly of a domestic character of tacit own. There has been thieving, fighting and murders, and to secure some of them from damage from the others, about ninety have been kept outside the wails under guard. It is said that several will be hung by their comrades for the murders committed.

abstract: A curious, and by no means [???]mimportant case of Sea Wages, was decided yesterday by the presiding magistrate at the Thames' Police Court. Capt. W.A. BELL, of the barque Resolution, appeared to summonses taken out by aine of the crew of that vessel, claiming sundry balances of wages alleged to have been earned on a voyage from New-York to Jamaica, and thence to London. The men signed articles for $35 per month per man, and they claimed to be paid at the rate of 4s. per dollar, the standard price of the American dollar in London. It appeared, however, that the ship's articles contained the words United States currency," which, being applied to the payment of the wages, would make the difference between 4s. and 2s. 7d. the dollar, or between £7 and £4 10s. 5d. per month. A. question was raised as to whether this this proviso was inserted in the articles when they were signed by the crew. The magistrate held that it was, and that the men were bound by it, and could only claim payment of their wages according to the present value of the American dollar in New-York. In decl[???]ing that the intention of the agreement was, that the men should be paid in United States currency -- that is according to the current value of the dollar in America -- we have no doubt the magistrate was right; but should the payment be made according to the value of the dollar at the time the articles were signed or at the time the voyage was concluded Greenbacks, no doubt, as the magistrate observed, are current in America, as bank notes are here, but, unfortunately, they are liable to be occasionally at a discount, and the prolongation of the war has no had the tendency to increase their value. When the crew of the Resolution signed articles, therefore, at New-York, the value of the currency in which it was [???]pulated they should be pa[???] was considerably in excess of what it is now, and if the men were to be held to the strict letter of their agreement, they were entitled at least to the full benefit of its conditions. The difference of four months and six days, the period over which the voyage extended, makes, in the present state of affairs in America, a very great change in the value of every description of security in that country, and although greenbacks are a legal tender in America, and the Master of the Resolution had an admitted right to pay the crew's wages in that currency, the men, on their part, had an equal right to claim payment at the rate current when the agreement was entered into. The decision to this ease is important, because it shows the determination of the bench to be governed by the express meaning and letter of the agreement. It would have been most unjust to the Master of the Resolution or his employers to have denied him the benefit of an express supalation introduced into the articles, and which, it appears, the crew were cognisant of, and quite understood. On the other hand, as the proviso was applied literally and exactly, the men, as it seems to us, were entitle to claim their wages in the currency of the day when the articles were signed, if they thought proper to do so, The point, however, does not appear to have been raised on the part of the claimants, who have taken their wages at the current rate, namely at 2s, 7d. per dollar. And there the matter rests.

abstract: Composition of Objected to
snippet: Composition of Objected to
lead_paragraph: THE SPINOLA COURT-MARTIAL. -- Yesterday morning, the Court-martial appointed to try the case of Gen. SPINOLA, assembled at No. 17 State-street. Gen. PECK being absent, Gen. HAETSUFF presided. Gen. SPINOLA was present with his counsel. The detail, and Gen. DIX's order premulgating the same, were read by the Judge-Advocate, after which Gen. SPINOLA read a lengthy paper in which he protested against the composition and constitution of the court. He claimed that, as Gen. Dix was his accuser, his selection of the members of the court was not authorized, but was in violation of the principles of justice and the rules of law. An accuser could not designate the members of a court to try an accused. He further objected to the court on the ground that it should be composed of officers of his own grade, when they could be procured; and he contended that there were many such officers within reach of the Government not otherwise employed. In support of these objections he cited the act of Congress passed in 1861 relative to court-martials, and the 75th and 64th Articles of War. The paper being handed to the Judge-Advocate, the court was cleared for deliberation. Upon the reopening, the Judge-Advocate notified the reporters that an order had been made on the minutes that no part of the proceeding should be published. The members of the press then left. The Court finally adjourned to this morning at 11 o'clock.

abstract: Brady's Photographs from the Seat of War
snippet: Brady's Photographs from the Seat of War
lead_paragraph: The war which we are waging for our national existence is, in its attendant circumstances, as well as in its origin and its vastness, unlike any other known to history. One of its peculiarities is the copiousness of its contemporary records -- records not made from hearsay or inference, but by correspondents and combatants who actually saw that of which they write. Not the least interesting of these contemporary memorials of our great struggle are the photographs "from the front," which the eminent photographer, Mr. BRADY, brings back from, expeditions which carry him so far into the hurly-burly of the fight that they are only not military because he is not armed save with his camera. The fruits of his last visit to the seat of war in Virginia, made immediately after taking his remarkable series of views of the Metropolitan Fair which now adorn his gallery, are perhaps the most interesting of all that we owe to his enterprise, his taste and skill, and which he has now on exhibition and for sale. Among these some of the most noteworthy are, "The Great Pontoon Fridge," by which the Army of the Potomac passed the James River -- the longest ever made and thrown over the deepest water ever thus spanned; a view of "Belle Plain," a charming subject, worthy of KENSETT's pencil; the "Burial Place at Fredericksburg," where shrouded heroes lie prepared for their long sleep beneath the sod; "A Group of Wounded Men," at the same place; they sit upon the grass and talk cheerily together; views of "Port Royal and City Point;" a glimpse of "Burnside's Corps" in motion; "Rebel Prisoners at White House" -- a multitudinous and motley group; the "Battle-field at Fredericksburgh;" "COOPER'S First Pennsylvania Battery," and "Gen. POTTER and his Staff," both of which were taken under fire; in examining which the inexperienced observer will be surprised to see how quietly fighting men carry themselves under such circumstances. These photographs have one advantage ever many of a similar kind which come from abroad, in that, while they are sharp and clear, most of them are not too large to be placed in albums and portfolios that can lie upon the parlor table. To those of the kind above noticed Mr. BRADY has added groups of Gens. GRANT, MEADE, HANCOCK, and, in fact, all the principal corps and division Commanders of note, with their staffs, in camp and in fighting trim; thus enabling us who "live at home at ease" to see just how the men live and look who are fighting the battles of the Republic.

abstract: -- July 29 -Friday next -- is fixed for the students' regatta on Lake Quinsigamond, near Worcester, Mass. Boats from Harvard and Yale, and perhaps from other colleges, will take part in the contest. On the day following, Saturday, July 30, the citizens regatta will take place. There will be three races, as follows First race -- distance two miles -- single scull wherries, 1st prize $75; 2d, $25, Second race -- distance three miles -- four-oared boats, 1st prize, $100; 2d, $50. Third race -- distance, three miles -- six-oared boats, 1st prize, $150; 2d, $75, and a third prize of $50. Total amount of prizes, $525.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. Their session was short, and the business transacted was chiefly routine. The Mayor sent in two communications. One vetoed a resolution to permit the placing of a sign on the lamp-post on the corner of Broadway and Ann street, on the ground that the streets, being held for public uses, should not be given up to private individuals.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. Their session was short, and the business transacted was chiefly routine. The Mayor sent in two communications. One vetoed a resolution to permit the placing of a sign on the lamp-post on the corner of Broadway and Ann street, on the ground that the streets, being held for public uses, should not be given up to private individuals. The other message recommended an amendment of the Revised Ordinances of 1859, so that unclaimed property left at Police Headquarters by public cartmen and porters may be sold after the lapse of six months. The bills of the Messrs. EDGE, for fireworks furnished the city on the 4th inst., were presented and referred. They amount to $9,972. The largest item is for the City Hall exhibition -- $1,586. The price charged for the closing piece at this place is $600. The bills, which were made out with great respect to details, were referred. The Board adjourned to Thursday at 2 P.M.

lead_paragraph: A few details of the fighting before Atlanta on Friday and Saturday, have been received at Washington. It seems that on Friday the rebels assaulted our lines with great impetuosity, striking the right, which was held by the Fifteenth Corps, under Gen. BLAIR. This corps held its ground firmly until the Sixteenth Corps, under Gen. DODGE, came up, when the enemy were repulsed with very heavy loss. Gen. LOGAN, with the Seventeenth Corps, was also engaged. These three corps constitute the Army of the Tennessee, under MCPHERSON, and the news of the death of their Commander having been communicated to the men before they went into battle, they fought with great desperation, their battle-cry being "Remember MCPHERSON!" Gen. MCPHERSON, it seems, was killed by a rebel sharpshooter from an ambush, while he was making a personal reconnoissance of his lines, before the battle. The dispatches to the Government represent that the struggle ended by the repulse of the enemy along the entire line. It was arranged that on Saturday the dead of both armies should be buried, and the wounded removed under a flag of truce. Our troops buried one thousand rebels left on the field within our line; besides which the rebels buried many of their own dead themselves near their works. Our loss will reach about 2,500 in killed and wounded. It is reported, though it would seem to be inconsistent with flag-of-truce operations, about which there must be some misapprehension, that while the work of burying the dead and removing the wounded was going on on Saturday, SHERMAN's heavy artillery was playing upon the city. At the same time large fires were observed in different parts of Atlanta, supposed to be caused by the destruction of supply depots and other rebel property, which the enemy could not carry off, and did not wish to fall into our hands. Several rebel Generals are reported to be killed, but their names are not yet given.

abstract: The London Morning Post, in an editorial on the question of the alleged holy alliance, observes that "nobody can follow the remarks made on the documents lately published without arriving at the conviction, which is by degrees becoming more firmly established abroad, of their genuineness. How could the Prussian Minister admit that he wrote that dispatch, and yet expect to keep the peace? Of two evils he chose the least; nor will it be the first time in the history of diplomacy that a statesman has denied a fact to avert the disaster of a war, for such a war as France might wage against Prussia upon the strength of these dispatches, could not fall at the present moment to be most disastrous."

abstract: The invasion fever has been revived, and the war in the Valley of the Shenandoah has been renewed in a sudden manner. It seems that Gen. AVERILL, after his successful encounter with Gen. EARLY'S forces, pursued them to the mountain beyond Winchester, where EARLY made a stand, and after heavy fighting on Saturday and Sunday the rebels having in the meantime been reinforced Gen. AVERILL was compelled to fall back ...
lead_paragraph: The invasion fever has been revived, and the war in the Valley of the Shenandoah has been renewed in a sudden manner. It seems that Gen. AVERILL, after his successful encounter with Gen. EARLY's forces, pursued them to the mountain beyond Winchester, where EARLY made a stand, and after heavy fighting on Saturday and Sunday -- the rebels having in the meantime been reinforced -- Gen. AVERILL was compelled to fall back to Harper's Ferry, bringing with him the forces at Bunker Hill, and causing also the evacuation of Martinsburgh. The rebels appear to have pursued him in his retreat, and yesterday afternoon again occupied Martinsburgh, where they cut the telegraph wires, and commenced again the destruction of the track of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Various reports of the losses of Gens. CROOK, AVERILL and KELLY in this movement are in circulation, but they are entirely indefinite and unreliable. The object of the enemy in making this new offensive movement is not yet apparent. The reports that come from Baltimore are in a great measure speculative, and only give the tone and character of the rumors that are in circulation in that city. Railroad and telegraphic communication had been temporarily suspended to points between Harper's Ferry on the east and Cumberland on the west. Gen. HUNTER, whose headquarters are at Harper's Ferry, has also interdicted all use of the wires for news purposes, and so we are without particulars of the situation to any later hour than Monday night.

abstract: GRANT's campaign from the Rapidan to the James, in May and June, was one of the greatest campaigns of history, and ought to be thoroughly comprehended by every American. It is now, we perceive, being studied carefully by the military men of Europe, and it will be read of with wonder by soldiers and civilians for ages to come.

abstract: The Changes in
snippet: The Changes in
lead_paragraph: On looking over the act in relation to prize proceedings, which was passed at the close of the recent session of Congress, we notice several changes made by it in the law of prize, which will be of interest and importance to our navy. The law in relation to joint captures, for instance, is modified in this way: The law of July 17, 1862, provided that "when one or more vessels of the navy shall be within signal distance of another making a prize, all shall share in the prize." The present law provides that "all vessels of the navy within signal distance of the vessel or vessels making the capture, under such circumstances and in such condition as to be able to render effective aid, if required, shall share in the prize." There may be a question, perhaps, whether the former provision is so inconsistent with this as to be repealed, and if not, whether a vessel within signal distance would not be entitled to share, although not able to render any effective aid in the capture. The new limitation was doubtless intended to be made general, and if it applies, it leaves open for many cases a very interesting discussion as to what shall constitute the power to give effective aid.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Mr., DAN BRYANT's appearance here last evening attracted one of the largest audiences we have ever seen within the walls of this popular establishment Mr. BRYANT is already so great a favorite in another sphere of art, (i) that the audience, reinforced with the lieges thus obtained, was kindly not only to the gentleman himself, but to all his surroundings. As the surroundings were not of the best, they have every reason to be thankful to the lieges.

abstract: N Y, on Blockade and Cotton Loan
snippet: N Y, on Blockade and Cotton Loan
lead_paragraph: Some time ago we stated that the rebel "Cotton Loan" was selling in London at higher rates than United States six per cent. gold interest bonds, and we argued that this fact established, to a demonstration, the inefficiency of our blockade, since it was apparent that nothing but the capacity to supply cotton to pay the bonds could keep up their price. This conclusion the Post controverted at the time, and insisted that the belief in ultimate rebel success was the cause of the high price of rebel cotton bonds, and not the inefficient blockade, making it necessary for us to expose the fallacy, by showing that the rebel bonds, which had no cotton behind them, but which depended on rebel success, had no value in Europe whatever.

abstract: The steamer James White, from New-Orleans on the 18th inst., has arrived here.  She reports that the steamer B.M. Runyon, from Natches, struck a snag off Griffiths' Landing, fifteen miles below Greenville, Miss., on the 21st inst., and sank to the hurricane roof in about five minutes. She had near 600 people on board, including 440 of the Tenth Missouri Cavalry, 50 refugees, some furloughed soldiers, and quite a number of cabin passengers.

abstract: WM.H. BAILEY was taken into custody yesterday, by Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct Police, on the charge of forgery. The arrest was made by virtue of a warrant, issued on the complaint of Mr. PETER C. SCHULTZ, of No. 216 West-street. The latter in his affidavit testifies that on the 29th of June last he received from BAILEY two promissory notes, both purporting to have been drawn by the firm of Messrs. HOWLAND & ASPINWALL, of No. 54 South-street, payable to WILLIAM H. BAILEY, or order, at the North River Bank. One note was for $960, the other for $475, and made payable in six and four months respectively. The notes were duly indorsed by BAILEY and transferred to the complainant SCHULTZ, in consideration of which the latter gave BAILEY his check on the Merchants' Exchange Bank for the sum of $1,360. SCHULTZ further says that he has since learned that the notes are forgeries and are utterly worthless.

abstract: Banks an Depositories of Public Moneys; Treasury Regulations
snippet: Banks an Depositories of Public Moneys; Treasury Regulations
lead_paragraph: 1. Any Banking Association organized and doing business under the act entitled " An Act to provide a National Currency secured by the pledge of United States Stocks, and to provide for the circulation and redemption thereof," approved February 25, 1863, may qualify itself to become a depositary of the public moneys and a financial agent of the United States by giving security, as hereinafter specified, in any sum not less than fifty thousand dollars. The whole amount of security given may be, and not less than one-fifth must be, by a deposit with the Treasurer of the United States of an equal amount of six per cent. bonds of the United States; and the remainder, if any, by the personal bonds of the directors and stockholders of the Association, to be likewise deposited with the Treasurer of the United States. When a greater amount of security than one-fifth is given by deposit of United States Bonds, any portion of the excess may be withdrawn and personal bonds substituted on application to the Secretary, in accordance with his directious. Personal bonds may be joint and several, or at the option of the obligors, several only. Each several bond must be accompanied by proof, by the affidavit of the maker or otherwise, of the ability of the obligor to satisfy the penalty after the payment of all debts. And each joint and several bond must be accompanied by the affidavit of each obligor, of his ability, after the payment of all debts, to satisfy such amount of the penalty as may be stated in such affidavit; and the aggregate of the amounts must be equal to the penalty. The bonds thus executed will remain in force four years, and until renewal or substitution, unless the liability of one or more of the obligors be sooner terminated by notice; and must be seasonably replaced by renewal, or by like bonds of other obligors. And whenever the Secretary of the Treasury shall be of opinion that any bond so given shall have become insufficient, he may require such additional bond or bonds as he may judge necessary for perfect security.
headline: {'main': 'THE DEPOSITARIES OF THE PUBLIC MONEYS.; Regulations Respecting the Employment of Banking Associations as Depositaries of the Public Moneys and Financial Agents of the United States, adopted by the Secretary of the Treasury.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE DEPOSITARIES OF THE PUBLIC MONEYS.; Regulations Respecting the Employment of Banking Associations as Depositaries of the Public Moneys and Financial Agents of the United States, adopted by the Secretary of the Treasury.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Colored men who desire to enlist in the United States Army or Navy, either as substitutes or volunteers, should apply to VINCENT COLYER, Superintendent of Recruiting United States Colored Troops -- headquarters No. 350 Fourth-street, corner Broadway, up stairs. The bounty fee usually paid to the recruiting agent, which, in the case of substitutes, is frequently as high as $200, will be given to the colored man who presents himself, and every information and facility to enable the recruit to obtain the highest bounties will be given free of charge.

When I say perfectly well known, I mean to the Provost-Marshal-General ...

abstract: By the arrival yesterday, at this port, of the steamship Scotia, from Liverpool, with advices up to the 17th inst. The reported engagement between the Kearsarge and the Florida is acknowledged to be a canard. The Sacramento left Cherbourg on the 13th inst., and joined the Kearsarge off Dover. A rumor was current in Cherbourg that the Federal and Confederate naval officers have agreed to have a sea fight within the next ten days, between the Sacramento and the Niagara on the one side, and the Gen. Lee frigate and a Confederate corvette, which was lately seen in the Straits of Gibraltar, on the other. A deputation from the society for obtaining a cessation of hostilities waited on Lord PALMERSTON on the 14th, but was put off with a non-committal answer. Mr. MASON has also had an interview with his Lordship. Nothing of interest had transpired in regard to the Danish War. Some rioting took place at Belfast, Ireland, immediately after the great Orange demonstrations of July 12. The King of the Belgians was about to pay a visit to the Emperor NAPOLEON at Vichy.

abstract: Secretary Fessenden's Appeal for
snippet: Secretary Fessenden's Appeal for
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Secretary FESSENDEN to the management of the Treasury Department gave, we think we may say, universal satisfaction. His ability, his integrity, his devotion to the public service were everywhere recognized. The policy which he has announced against all further issue of paper currency, and in favor of depending upon loans only to supply all the necessities of the Treasury not met by the current revenues, is just what his public character had given the country reason to anticipate. The inevitable effect of inflating the currency, in deranging all values, confounding all business, and in destroying all credits, both public and private, had come home, in hard experience, to the understanding of every man. Secretary FESSENDEN, in inaugurating his financial administration by calling for a popular loan of two hundred millions, avoiding all makeshifts and labored scheming of every sort, has only done what commends itself at once to every intelligent man.
headline: {'main': 'The Appeal for the New Loan.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Appeal for the New Loan.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -A correspondent of the Washington Intelligencer, writing from Niagara Falls, gives a few facts concerning the "distinguished individuals from the Confederate States, who are termed Peace Commissioners." He asserts that their "tone of feeling is subdued," and that they "confidentially half admitted their weakness, and seemed to want to make a clean breast of their troubles and the tight place they were placed in by the victorious armies of Gens. GRANT and SHERMAN." He further tells us of their, anxiety to displace Mr. LINCOLN -- "one of the attaches saying he hoped almost any other man than ABRAHAM LINCOLN might be elected our next President; then they would submit to a proposition that even the State of Vermont would not reject."

abstract: A call is out, signed by a large number of the best known workingmen of the iron trade, for a meeting at Cooper Institute to morrow evening. The call states that after a careful investigation of the principles of the Citizens' Association, the signers have given to that association their most hearty approval. Their fellow-workmen are invited to attend in mass meeting to hear the best speakers from their trade set forth facts to the public's and the City's interest, and to unite in an earnest effort to secure the success of the association and its principles. That the meeting will be a large and interesting one, there is no doubt.

abstract: Movement; real drift of seen
snippet: Movement; real drift of seen
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the most prominent and influential actors in the Fremont movement are beginning to see its real meaning and drift. From the very outset it has been perfectly evident that there was nothing of principle in it, but that its object was simple personal and political revenge. FREMONT himself openly proclaimed his determination to aid in defeating LINCOLN by all the means in his power; he would accept a nomination himself, if necessary, to accomplish that object. This was the spirit of the whole movement. Every man hitherto a supporter of the Administration, or an advocate of its principles, who had suffered personal disappointments, whose advice had not been followed, or whose views of policy had not been adopted, availed himself of that occasion to seek his revenge. FREMONT, in his letter of acceptance, made a very bold and shameless confession of the spirit and motive which prompted the movement and gave it all its strength.
headline: {'main': 'BEGINNING TO SEE IT!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BEGINNING TO SEE IT!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The Thirteenth Connecticut Regiment, veterans, 300 strong, under command of Col. BLINN, arrived here yesterday morning, from New-Orleans, on the steamer Cambria. An excellent breakfast was immediately ordered on board by Col. JOHN H. ALMY, State Agent of Connecticut, to the great delight of the old soldiers. After the repast was over the regiment held a meeting and adopted a series of resolutions thanking the Colonel for his grateful attentions. The Thirteenth left last night on the Elm City for New-Haven, where a grand reception awaits them.
