abstract: Last evening there was a reasonably largely attended meeting of the Democratic Union Association held at the "headquarters" on Broadway, near Twenty-third-street. Mr. LUKE F. COZZENS, Chairman of the Association, presided. He stated at the opening of the meeting that it was the intention of the Association to invite the patriots of the City of New-York to congregate weekly with a view to the support of the Chicago nominees, whoever they might be. The first speaker introduced was Hon. JAMES W. SINGLETON, of Illinois. Mr. SINGLETON was very funny. He made a speech of nearly one hour and a half in length, in which he compared the Constitution of the United States to the marital relation. Considerable laughter was occasioned by the quaintness of his illustrations. He thought the Constitution provided a way for putting down a rebellion of the people, but not of the States. This was evidently considered a strong point by the audience, and vociferous cheers followed. Hon. D.W. VOORHEES, of Indiana, was expected to address the meeting, but up to a late hour had not made his appearance. Hon. JAMES BROOKS, JOHN MCKEON and other distinguished gentlemen of the Democratic party were present during the evening.

abstract: Marsh, >amp;c, Fort Lafayette Prisoners; Discharge Refused
snippet: Marsh, >amp;c, Fort Lafayette Prisoners; Discharge Refused
lead_paragraph: In the matters of the applications for the discharge of Marsh, Palmer and Binney, from Fort Lafayette. -- After the return of process this morning, Judge BETTS announced his decision in these matters. He said that he had been prevented by rheumatism from using his arm, and had, therefore, been unable to reduce his views to writing, but would do so as soon as possible. He proceeded to state his views, however, holding in substance that the act of Congress did not give a discharge in cases where the Grand Jury had no jurisdiction to take action; that these parties, as appeared by the papers and the admissions of counsel on the argument, were held by the military authorities for trial before military tribunals, and that the civil courts could not interfere to take them out of the jurisdiction of the military tribunals, any more than they could take them out of the custody of criminal tribunals, the country being in a state of flagrant rebellion, and the suspension of the habeas corpus having established martial law. He, therefore, denied all the applications. In Allen's case the papers had not been laid before him, and he therefore rendered no decision.

lead_paragraph: -- There was a further adjournment in the Spinola case, yesterday, in consequence of the absence of several members of the court. It is understood Gen. SPINOLA is in possession of the charges preferred against him by Gen. DIX. The Judge Advocate has not yet recinded his order refusing to allow reporters to be present, hence the public will have, for the present, to remain in ignorance of the proceedings.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. The new Board of Tax Commissioners sent in the assessment rolls of the Twelfth Ward, duly prepared and certified, and in the communication accompanying, state that they have recovered, by search warrant, the assessment rolls of the First, Fifteenth and Twentieth Wards. These had been only partially copied, but will be completed and presented to the board at their next meeting. The communication also details the efforts made on the part of the new Commissioners to effect a temporary compromise with the old board, whereby the Board of Supervisors could obtain the assessment rolls complete for the year. It appears that the old board declined the terms offered to them, and insisted that all proceedings should be terminated upon the delivery of all the books and papers to the Board of Supervisors. This arrangement was rejected by the new board, on the advice of Hon. WM. F. ALLEN, their counsel, and also that of Mr. DEVELIN, the Corporation Counsel, who held that the right of the new commissioners to their positions had been sufficiently established to entitle them to receive the withheld books, without compromising either the dignity or legal position of the members of the old board. Supervisor PURDY presented resolutions sympathizing with Major YOUNG, Clerk to the Board, on the loss of his wife, who died a few days ago. The resolutions were unanimously adopted. The board adjourned to noon on Monday, when they meet by law to appoint Inspectors and Canvassers of Election.

abstract: Early's Return
snippet: Early's Return
lead_paragraph: The telegrams which convey to us in snatches the news of the return of the rebels toward the Upper Potomac are apt to propagate a serious geographical error or a popular misconception of the latitudes. When these telegrams assured us ten days ago that the rebels had taken to their heels, were across the Potomac, were rushing down the Loudon Valley, and struggling to find a gap into the Shenandoah by which they might make a straight line for Richmond with some remnants of their plunder, people generally believed, no doubt, that EARLY's men had gone South -- at least had gone in a southerly direction.

abstract: When I undertook, nearly three years ago, to prevent the ruin of an entire navy, which this country was about to build, and which the new Secretary had decided to construct in violation of the well-established theory of the world, upon which all other navies and all private steamers are made, in order to comply with the crude suggestions of one of his engine-drivers, whom be had advanced to the position of Engineer-in-Chief, and to whom he had confided the construction of all new machinery, contrary to the established custom of the department, by which the engineering ability of the whole country and of the world had been employed and stimulated by competition, and by contingent compensation to produce its best results, I foresaw, and in my first public letter I foretold, that the reckless and desperate man, whose schemes of profit I was endeaving to thwart, would resort to the most deperate means for averting the consequences of the exposure; and, of course, I was prepared for every attack, even on my life, which such a person was capable of contriving, but I did not anticipate that he would have been able no far to entangle any possible Assistant Secretary of the Navy in his intrigues, as to use him and his office for his revenge. In this, however, I have been mistaken, as the following facts will show:

abstract: This gallant young officer, the report of whose death on the field of battle is not fully confirm, graduated with honor from West Point in 1853. At the outbreak of the rebellion he was First-Lieutennant in the Regular cavalry, belonging, we believe, to the Mounted Rifles -- a regiment then stationed in New-Mexico, and largely officered by men of Southern proclivities. When the troubles first became serious in the region of northern Texas and in Arkansas, Lieut. AVERILL was selected for the very hazardous work of journeying from New-Mexico by the route through northern Texas to Fort Smith, in Arkansas, and thence to Washington, with highly important information to the Government. This he did, and then returned as successfully as he had come. Subsequently he came back again, and was commissioned Colonel of Volunteers, in which capacity he raised the Third Pennsylvania Cavalry, and went through the entire Peninsula campaign under Gen. MCCLELLAN, serving with much ability in those days of an inefficient and lembryotic cavlary force. For this service he was made Brigadier-General of Volunteers, and remained with the Army of the Potomac, commanding a brigade of cavalry under Gen. STONEMAN, and when Gen. HOOKER consolidated the force into one corps, Gen. AVERILL received the command of a division, which he retained until about the 1st of June, 1863. Gen. AVERILL fought the first considerable cavalry engagement of the war, that of Kelly's Ford, March 17, 1863, where the Rappahannock River was crossed in the face of the enemy, and FITZ LEE's cavalry division forced back five miles. His loss here was nearly three hundred, and there had previously been no exclusively cavalry fights, where the loss reached a total of one hundred. Subsequently, in the Chancellorsville campaign, Gen. AVERILL took a prominent part, capturing Cul-pepper, and penetrating to the south bank of the Rapidan, In June, 1863, he was assigned to the command of all the cavalry forces in western Virginia. In this field he was eminently successful, securing the entire tranquility of that previously turbulent region. On the 8th of December, 1863, he started on his famous expedition to out the Virginia and East Tennessse Railroad, which was accomplished at Salem, on the 10th, and an immense amount of rebel supplies were destroyed. This is the first time this road was ever severed, and Gen. AVERILL's laconic sport to Gen. HALLECK, that he had "rode, swam and slid three hundred and fifty miles," will long be remembered. Gen. AVERILL has also participated in all the later operations in that valley, including the recent expedition of Gen. HUNTER upon Lynchburgh, in which he had command of one of the cavalry columns, the other being under Gen. CROOK. Gen. AVERILL was very active -- always in the saddle, brave, cool, of excellent judgment, and serving always with the strictest fidelity. He was very young, not over 27, and if he has fallen, the country may rest assured that the gallant young officer was rallying his columns in a charge against the enemy.
lead_paragraph: This gallant young officer, the report of whose death on the field of battle is not fully confirm, graduated with honor from West Point in 1853. At the outbreak of the rebellion he was First-Lieutennant in the Regular cavalry, belonging, we believe, to the Mounted Rifles -- a regiment then stationed in New-Mexico, and largely officered by men of Southern proclivities. When the troubles first became serious in the region of northern Texas and in Arkansas, Lieut. AVERILL was selected for the very hazardous work of journeying from New-Mexico by the route through northern Texas to Fort Smith, in Arkansas, and thence to Washington, with highly important information to the Government. This he did, and then returned as successfully as he had come. Subsequently he came back again, and was commissioned Colonel of Volunteers, in which capacity he raised the Third Pennsylvania Cavalry, and went through the entire Peninsula campaign under Gen. MCCLELLAN, serving with much ability in those days of an inefficient and lembryotic cavlary force. For this service he was made Brigadier-General of Volunteers, and remained with the Army of the Potomac, commanding a brigade of cavalry under Gen. STONEMAN, and when Gen. HOOKER consolidated the force into one corps, Gen. AVERILL received the command of a division, which he retained until about the 1st of June, 1863. Gen. AVERILL fought the first considerable cavalry engagement of the war, that of Kelly's Ford, March 17, 1863, where the Rappahannock River was crossed in the face of the enemy, and FITZ LEE's cavalry division forced back five miles. His loss here was nearly three hundred, and there had previously been no exclusively cavalry fights, where the loss reached a total of one hundred. Subsequently, in the Chancellorsville campaign, Gen. AVERILL took a prominent part, capturing Cul-pepper, and penetrating to the south bank of the Rapidan, In June, 1863, he was assigned to the command of all the cavalry forces in western Virginia. In this field he was eminently successful, securing the entire tranquility of that previously turbulent region. On the 8th of December, 1863, he started on his famous expedition to out the Virginia and East Tennessse Railroad, which was accomplished at Salem, on the 10th, and an immense amount of rebel supplies were destroyed. This is the first time this road was ever severed, and Gen. AVERILL's laconic sport to Gen. HALLECK, that he had "rode, swam and slid three hundred and fifty miles," will long be remembered. Gen. AVERILL has also participated in all the later operations in that valley, including the recent expedition of Gen. HUNTER upon Lynchburgh, in which he had command of one of the cavalry columns, the other being under Gen. CROOK. Gen. AVERILL was very active -- always in the saddle, brave, cool, of excellent judgment, and serving always with the strictest fidelity. He was very young, not over 27, and if he has fallen, the country may rest assured that the gallant young officer was rallying his columns in a charge against the enemy.

abstract: Gen. SANDFORD, who went to Washington some days since, to consult with the War Department, relative to the exemption of the 100 days' men from the draft, returned last evening, and goes this morning to Albany to consult with the Governor. It is stated that he succeeded in obtaining from the War Department a declaration that the 100 days' men, who will be in service at the time of the draft, will be exempt.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from twenty-eight different parties, inclosing forty-three bids, which aggregated but $758,000, for a loan of $1,000,000, on 6 per cent. bonds, to run over twenty years, to redeem the temporary loan to pay riot damages, made last summer, and which, with interest, is to be paid on next Monday. The result of the opening was surprising, although not wholly unexpected.
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from twenty-eight different parties, inclosing forty-three bids, which aggregated but $758,000, for a loan of $1,000,000, on 6 per cent. bonds, to run over twenty years, to redeem the temporary loan to pay riot damages, made last summer, and which, with interest, is to be paid on next Monday. The result of the opening was surprising, although not wholly unexpected. Of the sum bid for, $410,000 were at par, and the balance of $348,000 at premium rates of from 101.03 to 6 per cent. The introduction of the new "seven-thirties" to the public by Secretary FESSENDEN, fully accounts for the failure of an entire disposition of the County Loan. At the time it was put upon the market for bids, it was likely to be taken at good premium rates, long-time loans being highly desirable. The result is something of a poser to Comptroller BRENDAN, who is undecided whether to accept the par bids or not. He could, no doubt, get good premium rates by re-advertising all of the loan not bid for at less than 2 per cent., by increasing the interest to 7 per cent., but this he would not wish to do, having heretofore rigidly insisted upon not paying over 6 per cent. Indeed, neither the City or County have paid 7 per cent. interest in years, except on the Union Defence Fund Bonds and the first Family Aid Fund loan. Mr. BRENNAN may be able to decline the par bids by inducing reinvestments in the loan by the old bondholders, or he may decide to wait till the attraction of the "seven-thirties" wanes, and meanwhile use money from other available sources to pay off the matured bonds.

abstract: A Disunion Scheme
snippet: A Disunion Scheme
lead_paragraph: It is a curious and significant circumstance that every time there is any talk of peace, as the result of compromise or negotiation, the Democratic journals treat the public to whole columns of dissertation upon the feasibility of substituting two or more Confederacies on this continent for one; of maintaining freedom of commercial intercourse and union in the transaction of all business with foreign nations, while preserving the most complete independence and separation with regard to all internal affairs. These disquisitions are never put forth as the editor's own sentiments; nothing of the sort. They are usually elaborate expositions of Southern policy and opinions, written by somebody claiming more or less intimate acquaintance with the hopes and aspirations of Southern leaders.

abstract: Russell, W. H., on the War Situation
snippet: Russell, W. H., on the War Situation
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Gen. ULYSSES GRANT seems to us to be in what he would most probably term, in his own nervous diction, "a very tight place." It is quite true that in his present position he must give much anxiety to the enemy, and that he menaces the Confederate capital with a greater danger than any the tenacious and valiant Southerners have yet had to encounter from Federal foes; but it is scarcely possible that he can retain that position under the fire of the July and August sun, and as vet any attempt to improve it by advancing has not been attended with encouraging results. As a line is length without breadth, and as a circle is bounded by a line, Gen. GRANT may maintain that he has not departed from his pledge to fight out the possession of Richmond "on this line" by moving round the Capital, but it is difficult to perceive what advantage he has trained by approaching it now from the south side it he fails in his purpose of cutting the Confederate communications. That the combination on which he relied for that purpose has signally failed cannot be doubted. HUNTER may have done damage to the western lines, but he has suffered dearly for his interference, and the injury was speedily repaired. The cavalry, in which the Federals seem to have established a decided preponderance, have failed to effect permanent destruction; and an attempt made by an expedition, under WILSON, to break up the line between Richmond via Petersburgh and Weldon, must have ended badly if it be true that the Confederates intercepted the horsemen and forced MEADE to march a whole corps and a division to their assistance, with results yet unknown to us. SHERIDAN, from whom a good deal was expected, has not turned out to be a ZEIDLITZ, a MURAT, or even a PAGET. He failed in a very feeble endeavor to reach HUNTER, and he has since lost, we are told, upwards of 1,000 men in a scamper across the Peninsula, south of Richmond, with the view of getting his corps across the James River to aid the cavalry force belonging to GRANT's army. The next great Federal army on which the hopes of the North have so long been fixed promises to become a source of fearful anxiety. SHERMAN, if not retreating, is certainly not advancing; and, if the Confederates can interfere seriously with his communications, he must fall back as soon as he has eaten up all the supplies of the district. At Charleston all is quiet, and Mobile has ceased to care for FARRAGUT's flotilla. The blockade cannot keep out arms, supplies and special correspondents, or keep in cotton in the South. On every point of the ragged circle which the Federals seek to penetrate they are encountered by skillful, resolute and successful opponents. All the enormous advantages possessed by the Federals have been nullified by want of skill, by the interference of Washington civilians, and by the absence of an animating homogeneous spirit on the part of their soldiery. Some fight for pay, others because they can't help it; some fight for the Union, others for abolition; some for confiscated land, others because they dislike a slave owning aristocracy. Every Southerner fights because, conscript though he be, he hates his enemy, and is striking for the principle of States rights, which converts the land of his birthplace into a fatherland for him against all the world. Who can be a native of a Union? A native of Georgia or Virginia has something tangible to point to when he is asked where is his country. If the Union were destroyed formally to-morrow -- as we believe it has been practically long ago -- the man of Maine or Ohio could go back to his home, not much damaged in any way, except in a certain windy pride, and in the happiness derived from the contemplation of excessive size, which rendered him a disagreeable companion to the rest of the world. New-York, indeed, would lose some trade, and tariffs would be modified in some States, but there the mischief would cease. Far otherwise would it be with Georgia or Virginia; if the South were crushed he would become an outcast, a pariah, the scorn of bitter enemies. Therefore the Southerners light to the death against the invading revolutionary North and all their hordes, sustained by such a spirit as would have animated the people of England had the First Consul thrown himself on their shores at the head of a Republican and Jacobin army That, all things considered, the North had the elements of military superiority to such an extent as justified an impartial observer in predicting they would obtain possession of the principal strategic points, the ports, arsenals, large cities, railway termini, and rivers in the South, cannot reasonably be denied. It is true they are very far from the attainment of their object now, after all their losses in money and in men; nor does it look as if GRANT were going to achieve it. Even if Richmond fell the South would fight long and desperately. But Petersburgh bars the way and GRANT is still sitting in front of the Confederate carthwoiks, whittling slicks, as is his wont, filling the hospitals with the living, and fattening the rank soil with his dead.

abstract: Festival of and History of
snippet: Festival of and History of
lead_paragraph: The Germans have an intenser national fondness for social organizations than any other people. Go into the smallest German hamlet, and you will find the inhabitants combined into one or more societies or clubs, each of which has in view some pleasant social object. You will find the drinking club a quiet, orderly, sober organization, generally composed of the middle-aged men of the community, with the pastor or village burgomaster at the head. Every evening, after the labor of the day has ended, they wend their way to the village inn, where in Summer they gather under the shade of trees or arbors, and in Winter in a neatly sanded bar-room. There they talk, about the news of the day, retail the gossip of the place, and sometimes, under the lead of the pastor, discuss the deepest themes of theological lore. At an early hour, fixed by law in nearly all the towns and cities, they break up, and return home as sober as they came. Then there are the musical clubs -- there is probably not a town in Germany that has not a musical club -- to which the young people belong, and which, too, always meet in the vicinity of a good beer-house. There is something sensible in the way the Germans set about enjoying themselves. They have been called a "nation of thinkers and philosophers;" but they have a practical instinct that esthetic pleasures never set well on an empty stomach. An evening concert in the open air or in a beer saloon, without the accompaniments of eating and drinking, would be a cheerless affair in Germany; and even at the theatres in Munich, ice cream and cake are handed round between the acts.

abstract: The interdiction of all news about the operations in the vicinity of Harper'a Ferry, by the orders of Gens. HUNTER and WALLACE, leaves us with rather a limited amount of intelligence from that region this morning. Several reports have com to hand, none of which throw any positive light upon the enemy's movements. Harper's Ferry is still held by Gen. HUNTER, and it is reported that Martinsburgh, has been reoccupied by our forces.
lead_paragraph: The interdiction of all news about the operations in the vicinity of Harper'a Ferry, by the orders of Gens. HUNTER and WALLACE, leaves us with rather a limited amount of intelligence from that region this morning. Several reports have com to hand, none of which throw any positive light upon the enemy's movements. Harper's Ferry is still held by Gen. HUNTER, and it is reported that Martinsburgh, has been reoccupied by our forces. Gen. AVERIL's death is reiterated by way of Philadelphia, but the report does not yet seem to be definite enough to render it certain. In Baltimore the authorities are taking timely measures for the defence of the city. An enrollment of all the able-bodied colored men has been ordered, and they will be organized and armed as a part of the defensive force of the city.

abstract: All egress from the city is to-day suspended, or regulated by passes. Guards are stationed all around. Negroes are digging rifle-pits. Blood and other horses of rebel sympathizers and Unionists are being impressed, and certificates of indebtedness given. Their impressment began at daybreak. Droves of them are passing my window now, to mount the gallant Ninth Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Sunday, July 24, 1864.

abstract: ADVANCE OF $1 PER TON ON COAL. -- There was a large attendance at the monthly sale of coal, which took place yesterday at the Delaware and Lackawanna Company, No. 35 William-street, Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, auctioneer. The following prices were realized, which snow an advance of about $1 per ton on all descriptions since the previous sale: Five thousand tons of Liverpool coal sold at an average of $10 80, an advance of 97 cents since last month; four thousand tons steamboat coat at an average of $10 88, an advance of $1 14 since the same period; five thousand tons of grate or furnace coal at an average of $10 92, an advance of $1 09; three thousand five Hundred tons of egg coal at $11 10, an advance of $1 49 since last sale; five thousand five hundred tons of stove coal at an average of $12 39, being an advance of $2 08 on last month's rates; two thousand tons of chestnut at an average of $10 15, an advance of 76 cents.
lead_paragraph: ADVANCE OF $1 PER TON ON COAL. -- There was a large attendance at the monthly sale of coal, which took place yesterday at the Delaware and Lackawanna Company, No. 35 William-street, Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, auctioneer. The following prices were realized, which snow an advance of about $1 per ton on all descriptions since the previous sale: Five thousand tons of Liverpool coal sold at an average of $10 80, an advance of 97 cents since last month; four thousand tons steamboat coat at an average of $10 88, an advance of $1 14 since the same period; five thousand tons of grate or furnace coal at an average of $10 92, an advance of $1 09; three thousand five Hundred tons of egg coal at $11 10, an advance of $1 49 since last sale; five thousand five hundred tons of stove coal at an average of $12 39, being an advance of $2 08 on last month's rates; two thousand tons of chestnut at an average of $10 15, an advance of 76 cents.

abstract: New Regiments Under Last Call
snippet: New Regiments Under Last Call
lead_paragraph: The War Department has yielded to the pressure from Pennsylvania, and given authority for the organization of new regiments of one year troops under the last call. No State asks and receives so many special favors in the matter of raising troops, as Pennsylvania; and yet she never has a corporal's guard to keep the horse-thieves from crossing her borders. We thought the folly of new regiments was long ago exploded. But as it is again revived, there remains but one remedy. When Lieut.-Gen. GRANT gets these new regiments at the front, it will be perfectly legitimate for him to muster out the officers and put the men into the battle-thinned ranks of veteran Pennsylvania regiments that deserve to be filled up.

abstract: Erroneous Statements Authorized by
snippet: Erroneous Statements Authorized by
lead_paragraph: Mr. FESSENDEN well says that, "to lay heavy burdens on a great and patriotic people in such a manner as to be equal, and to occasion the least amount of suffering and annoyance, requires time and caution and vast labor." It requires not only these. It requires great wisdom in laying the burdens of taxation, and it also requires great care and honesty in administering the provisions of the law. Every dishonest or careless Collector works a wrong to the whole community, for that which he fails to collect or misappropriates must be made up by the rest of the people. And every dishonest or incapable Assessor works a similar wrong, for he is preventing the burdens from being equal.

abstract: Bellamy, J. of Broome-street Tea Store, Charged with
snippet: Bellamy, J. of Broome-street Tea Store, Charged with
lead_paragraph: A singular case of arson and an attempt thereby to defraud the insurance companies of this City, was brought to light yesterday, before Justice DOWLING, of the Lower Police Court. From the testimony given in court, it appears that on the night of the 15th ult. a fire occurred in the basement of the "Great North American Tea Store," situated in Broome-street, near Centre, kept by JOHN BELLAMY & Co. The firm consisted of JOHN BELLAMY, the accused, and the wife of a Mr. WM. GOODWIN. The wife was authorized to be a member of the firm by virtue of a power of attorney executed by Mr. GOODWIN, her husband. The loss sustained by the fire did not exceed $1,000. Soon after the event, Fire Marshal BAKER began an investigation relative to the occurrence, and from all the evidence in the case, he has been led to conclude that the fire was the work of as incendiary. The following is the substance of the evidence sworn to before Justice DOWLING:

lead_paragraph: A very brief special dispatch from Washington announces that the fighting in the army before Petersburgh and on the James has been renewed. The mail-boat which arrived at Washington yesterday morning reported very heavy firing when she left. Our dispatch, though given few particulars, announces a severe engagement on the north bank of the James, between a large body of the enemy and a portion of Gen. BUTLER's force, in which the rebels were defeated with a heavy loss, including the capture of four pieces of artillery.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, by special call, but scarcely more than a quorum of the members were present, so that the Family Aid Ordinance, No. 10, which will soon be needed to raise money for the Relief Fund, could not be passed. A special committee of five were appointed to learn and report why the heads of departments fail to send in their monthly pay-rolls ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, by special call, but scarcely more than a quorum of the members were present, so that the Family Aid Ordinance, No. 10, which will soon be needed to raise money for the Relief Fund, could not be passed. A special committee of five were appointed to learn and report why the heads of departments fail to send in their monthly pay-rolls to the Board, as requested by a resolution passed a short time ago. The Mayor vetoed the resolution to pay a bill of $2,400 for badges furnished to the members of the Common Council, on the ground that no appropriation had been made for the expense, that the committee had exceeded their power, and purchased staves of office, etc., besides badges, and that the badge is an "official decoration at variance with all ideas of that simplicity which belongs to democratic institutions." City Inspector BOOLE sent in a communication again urging a meeting of the Board of Health, to order the abolishment of the fat-melting nuisance, and arguing the right of the Board of themselves to convene without the call of the Mayor. It was referred, and a resolution by Mr. RYERS was adopted, that a Joint Special Committee of six wait on the Mayor to ascertain his reasons for declining to conveue the Board of Health. Commodore E.A. STEVENS sent in a petition, stating that, by virtue of a special act of the Legislature, parties owning the bulkhead south of the Hoboken Ferry at the foot of Hoboken-street, of which he is the lessee, are constructing a pier, and in such manner as to close his ferry, and he asks the Common Council to remove the obstruction. Referred. The Board adjourned without day, but probably will meet soon, to pass the new Relief Fund Ordinance. The Board of Councilmen had no quorum, and stand adjourned to Monday, at 2 P.M.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

snippet: Fat Boiling; Inspector Boole's Address to Comman Council on
lead_paragraph: City Inspector BOOLE has again addressed the Common Council to urge the convening of the Board of Health, to take measures for banishing the fat-melting business from the City. The Mayor declines to convene that body, of which he is the President, by virtue of his position as Mayor, believing that what the City Inspector wishes to do can be accomplished through the Commissioners of Health, and that no need exists for calling a meeting of the Board of Health. The City Inspector holds a contrary view, and is unremitting in efforts to obtain the authority of the Board of Health. The following communication, which came before the Board of Aldermen yesterday, and was referred to a committee, shows how the City Inspector thinks both the Mayor and the fat-melters may be overcome:

abstract: Men are not enlisting in this city near so rapidly as was expected, and unless a decided change is made very soon a draft must be made. We are now enlisting an average of twenty to thirty men, and there seems to be but little hope of our doing much better. If the Supervisors immediately appoint agents to recruit in the rebel States, it may help very materially. Madison County has appointed two agents, who will leave for their new field of operations to-day. Queens County has appointed WM. TURNER and _____ CARLL as agents to recruit men for the county, in the States of North Carolina. South Carolina, and Florida. These gentlemen also will leave for Newbern to-day, and are confident of obtaining all the men necessary to fill the quota of Queens County. The following is the authorization given by Gov. SEYMOUR:

abstract: Milk Advanced to Ten Cents a Quart
snippet: Milk Advanced to Ten Cents a Quart
lead_paragraph: The drouth which is apparent throughout the country by the yellowness of the sward, the withered leaves and the burning fields, has been manifest to the inhabitants of the City in a scarcity of berries and vegetables; in potatoes, small and poor, at $8 a barrel: in butter, at 55 cents a pound, and the like. Now comes a new demonstration in the reunion of the milkmen of the City, held to-day, at the Washington Hotel. They have, they say, in vain attempted to hold out a little longer than the drouth, until the time for the usual advance to Winter prices, against any increase in price, and have actually been furnishing milk at a pecuniary loss for several weeks, but the present second dry season has dispelled all doubts. The farmers have come to the City, and have stated their inability to produce any more, or even to continue at present rates, urging that their fat cows could now be sold for beef, at the present prices, so as to net them far more than they could otherwise obtain.
headline: {'main': 'Advance in Milk.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Advance in Milk.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A DARING BURGLARY AND THEFT IN THIRTEENTH-STREET TWO MEN ARRESTED. Two young men, named WM. BEAL and JOHN CHRISTY, were arrested yesterday by Officers, STILWELL and BOOKSTAVER, of the Fifteenth Precinct, charged with having burglariously entered the premises of Miss GAUDA LOUPE GARCIA, No. 2 West Thirteenth-street, and...
lead_paragraph: A DARING BURGLARY AND THEFT IN THIRTEENTH-STREET -- TWO MEN ARRESTED. -- Two young men, named WM. BEAL and JOHN CHRISTY, were arrested yesterday by Officers, STILWELL and BOOKSTAVER, of the Fifteenth Precinct, charged with having burglariously entered the premises of Miss GAUDA LOUPE GARCIA, No. 2 West Thirteenth-street, and stealing therefrom a gold watch and chain, worth $200, and $372 in money. A servant on the premises discovered the thieves just as they were in the act of leaving. She pursued them and gave the alarm. Officer STILWELL, who was patroling in that neighborhood, heard her cries of "Stop thief," and immediately gave chase. BEAL was followed to an unoccupied cellar, where he was found by the Officer secreted among some empty barrels. The cellar was searched, and the watch and chain found under some straw. One hundred dollars of the stolen money were found on the sidewalk, nearly opposite the cellar. CHRISTY was soon after secured by Officer BOOKSTAVER, of the Fifteenth Precinct. The prisoners were both taken before Justice DODGE at Jefferson Market, and, after an examination, were committed without bail. BEAL is 19 years of age, printer by occupation, and resides at No. 288 Second-street. CHRISTY is 18 years old, a tinsmith, and lives at No. 158 East Houston-street.

abstract: Possible Break-Up of
snippet: Possible Break-Up of
lead_paragraph: There seems to be the possibility of a break-up in the recent governmental arrangements made in Canada for reconciling sectional differences by an application of the federative principle to the constitutional system of the Provinces. One of the prominent Liberal Ministers -- the Provincial Secretary in the Coalition Cabinet -- has been defeated at the polls. His discomfiture will be laid at the doors of the Conservative electors; and the entente cordiale between the parties in the Executive Council is likely to be seriously impaired. Mr. GEORGE BROWN, the prime mover in the new arrangements, indeed, declared before this untoward election came off, that the rejection of the Provincial Secretary by his constituency would be almost a fatal blow at the coalition. Probably some expedient will be found to meet the difficulty temporarily, without breaking up the Government; but a popular defeat, so soon after the new political enterprise was set afloat, is ominous of future troubles which do not seem to have been very carefully weighed beforehand.
headline: {'main': 'THE BRITISH AMERICAN, FEDERATION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE BRITISH AMERICAN, FEDERATION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We will assume the capital of a bank to be paid in wholly in gold and silver, though it matters little, as will be hereafter seen, whether it be paid in this form or in the notes or checks of other specie paying banks. Upon the loaning of this capital the borrower would, as a rule, prefer, instead of receiving the specie, to receive the notes of the bank, or credits upon its books
lead_paragraph: We will assume the capital of a bank to be paid in wholly in gold and silver, though it matters little, as will be hereafter seen, whether it be paid in this form or in the notes or checks of other specie paying banks. Upon the loaning of this capital the borrower would, as a rule, prefer, instead of receiving the specie, to receive the notes of the bank, or credits upon its books entitling him, or any one into whose hands they might fall, to draw the specie at will, the bank in the meantime taking the risk and charge of its safe keeping. Such notes and credits would, of course, derive their value solely from the value of that which they represented. They would be simply symbols of property, or title deeds to a portion of the capital of the bank, and entitle their holder, at will, to make partition of the same, and convert a portion corresponding to the amount of notes and credits he held to his own use. Their delivery from hand to hand would transfer the title to and the right to demand an equal amount of gold and silver, and when, delivered in the purchase of property they would perform, as mediums of exchange, precisely the functions of the precious metals themselves.

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE. BALFE'S opera of the "Rose of Castile" was produced here on Thursday evening to a good house and to an audience that was so enthusiastic that the performance did not terminate until a late hour. It was to have been submitted...
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE. -- BALFE's opera of the "Rose of Castile" was produced here on Thursday evening to a good house and to an audience that was so enthusiastic that the performance did not terminate until a late hour. It was to have been submitted to the public on Wednesday, and in fact did proceed to an agreeable part of the score on that evening, when the sudden and unmistakable indisposition of Mme, BORCHARD rendered a postponement absolutely imperative. The curtain dropped, and Mr. BAKER, the stage manager, came forward and announced, with an agony that can be appreciated but not described, that the money would be returned at the door to such unflinching economists as felt disposed to demand it. The same audience was, to a large extent, present on Thursday evening, and the favorable impression the music had created was widened in the fact that many pieces in the first act, which had passed without a recognition on the first night, were vociferously encored on the second.

abstract: No particulars have been as yet received from Gen. GRANT's army which tend to throw light upon the design of the recent movement to the north side of the James River. Whether it was made simply with a view to counteract the manoeuvres of the enemy as detailed in our telegraphic dispatches, or whether, as surmised by one of our correspondents, it was intended to surprise the rebel Capital, and capture it by a coup de main, are matters which farther developments must decide.

The reports include a boastful address by Gen. FORREST to his troops, in which he says he met...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamer Fung Shuey at this port, yesterday, we have New-Orleans papers to the 21st inst. The news of chief interest is contained in rebel reports from Mississippi and elsewhere, published in the Picayune, which was recently permitted to resume publication. The reports include a boastful address by Gen. FORREST to his troops, in which he says he met SHERMAN's force in its raid into Mississippi, "and drove him howling back in ignominy and shame, broken and demoralized." He then recites how, "with conspicuous gallantry," his men won the "bloody victory" at Fort Pillow, "and either killed or captured the entire garrison, a motley herd of negroes, traitors and Yankees." He closes with the Sturgis fight, and says, "You drove the boasted minions of despotism in confused flight from the battle-field." Under the heading, "Bishop ELLIOTT at Gen. POLK's Funeral," it gives some interesting remarks. These consist of a malediction upon the Northern people and the Union army. Following this is a letter to the Mobile Register, which rings all the changes in praise of FORREST, and denunciation of our colored soldiers, whom it styles "brutal negroes," and accuses the "Federal Government" of forcing them "to murder white men and ravish white women." This letter closes with a half expressed wish for the appearance of yellow fever. The batch of "Late Southern News," closes with the following. "The Columbus South Carolinian says it is stated on semi-official authority that the Hon. JOHN A. CAMPBELL, of Alabama, formerly one of the Supreme Bench of the old United States, and since the war Assistant Secretary of War, will, in all probability, be appointed as the successor of Mr. MEMMINGER, it being regarded as certain that the latter will resign."

abstract: Rockland Female Institute Commencement
snippet: Rockland Female Institute Commencement
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was a gala day at Nyack, the Commencement of the Rockland Female Institute drawing a crowd of residents and strangers -- a customary annual and brilliant occasion memorable in the region roundabout. After the steamboats and cars had landed their visitors -- pilgrims from the city enjoying a day's breath in the country, as well as a literary treat -- the stream of pedestrians and carriage-riders added a new picturesqueness to a picturesque village. The audience was crowded and brilliant, the music admirable and the graduating exercises spirited and successful. The programme divided the day into a morning and an evening meeting. In the morning the graduating classes, consisting of seven young ladies, tastefully dressed in white, delivered their essays, many of which were remarkable for excellence of thought and skill of expression. The salutatory was by Miss Josephine Leonard, of Rockland Lake; subject -- "Life, not Years, but Action;" Miss Susie B. M'Graw, of New-York City, followed on "The Spirit of the Nineteenth Century."Miss Anna J. Benneson, of Quincy, Ill., "Round the World at Sunset;" Miss Alice A. Benneson, "Silent Lives;" Miss Alice G. Price, Elizabeth, N.J., "Acting;" Miss Kate A. Nichols, Nyack, "Hawthorne and Thackeray." The valedictory -- appropriate and touching -- was by Miss CASSIE LEONARD, of Rockland Lake. In the presentation of the diplomas, Rev. L.D. MANSFIELD, Senior Principal, made a fit and touching address to the young ladies, drawing tears from many eyes. The farewell hymn of the graduates, words by Miss LOUISA B. HENDRICKSON, and music by Prof. VAN OECKELEN, was the closing exercise of the morning.

abstract: It has been stated  that the distinguished soldier, Gen. McPHERSON, who was killed during the battle before Atlanta on Friday of last week, was in command of a corps under Gen. SHERMAN. This is a mistake. When GRANT became Lieutenant-General, SHERMAN succeeded to the com-...
lead_paragraph: -- It has been stated that the distinguished soldier, Gen. McPHERSON, who was killed during the battle before Atlanta on Friday of last week, was in command of a corps under Gen. SHERMAN. This is a mistake. When GRANT became Lieutenant-General, SHERMAN succeeded to the command of the "Military Division of the Mississippi," and MCPHERSON to the command of SHERMAN's Army of the Tennessee. It embraced not less than three corps.

abstract: The Board of Commissioners of Health met yesterday at the Mayor's Office, The Health Officer. Dr. SWINBURNE stated that the reports of deaths from fever on board the United States steamer Tehoma were exaggerated; that no new cases had occurred on board that vessel or among her passengers and crew for the last four days; that nothing had been landed from her except the Purser's papers, which had been thoroughly fumigated. He recommended, on the suggestion of Mr. HALL, the Agent of the Associated Press, that no reports should be published in the newspapers which did not come through the medium of the Associated Press. In this recommendation the Commissioners of Health united.

abstract: the Reported
snippet: the Reported
lead_paragraph: We shall require a great deal more evidence than we have yet seen to become convinced that the Order of "American Knights" is such a formidable body of traitors as some of our Western cotemporaries represent. That there are thousands of men in nearly every loyal State who would readily join any secret organization calculated to bring the war to a close, is certain. That there are politicians malignant and desperate enough to engineer, if possible, such an organization into positive resistance to the National Government and overt treason, is just as undeniable. But that all this has been actually going on, for months, both through the West and the East, so that now the numerical strength of the Order is "over half a million," embracing many of the leading men of the party opposed to the Administration, is utterly improbable. The Provost-Marshal-General of the Department of Missouri, we dare say, is a very sharp fellow, but it don't follow that every other loyal man is an idiot. Likely enough he has "been taking testimony for months," but other people have not been all that time napping. We think that plenty of eyes and ears beside his own have been open, and that had this traitorous work been carried on to anything like the extent represented, somebody else would have got wind of it too. "Over half a million of men" -- some of them married doubtless -- are a great many to keep a dead secret. Flatly, we don't believe it.
headline: {'main': 'The Reported Conspiracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Reported Conspiracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Magazines for August
snippet: Magazines for August
lead_paragraph: -- Harpers' New Monthly Magazine, (NewYork, HARPER BROS.,) has secured a potentally in CHARLES DICKENS, whose current story, "Our Mutual Friend,"reaches the New World through its pages. The present number for August, contains the third monthly installment, and displays the author's usual characteristics. The plot is, as yet, scarcely devoloped, and the interest depends, not on incident, but on the display of character and humorous description. Unfortunately, DICKENS seems to think it necessary, perhaps on the principle of contrast, to sandwich his high and low life scenes, offering alternately a slice of one and of the other, in each number. In one range he is supreme; in the other just as feeble. All the graphic reality and genuine humor displayed in Mr. Boffin and his friends, which have the force of actual transcripts from humanity, give place to a shadowy, would-be sarcastic, sketchy, style of treatment, where nothing is so conspicuous as the author's inaptitude for his theme when he touches on fashionable follies. In the hard-worked Curate and his wife, we have a study of her character, for DICKENS, showing how many veins yet remain unworked in the world of London, where his strength chiefly lies. The conclusion of THACKERAY's "Denis Duval," and of Miss MULOCH's "Unkind Word," are the other most important articles of fiction. The Editor, Dr. GUERNSEY, furnishes an analysis, copiously Illustrated, of READE's flippant book on Western Africa. "The Military Hospitals at Fortress Monroe," by its exposition of that admirable system of management, will cheer the hearts of thousands whose nearest and dearest may be indebted to their ministrations for kindly help. "The SHAKESPEARE Tercentenary" is the record of an eyewitness, and pleasantly relates the sayings and doings at Stratford, when that quiet burgh arose from its usual drowsiness, on the 23d of April last. The "Editor's Drawer," and "Talk" are as amply furnished as usual.
headline: {'main': 'THE MAGAZINES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE MAGAZINES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Extravagance and Economy
snippet: Extravagance and Economy
lead_paragraph: We Americans are the most wasteful and extravagant people in the world. We waste fearfully in food, in clothing, and in extras. We waste on every secular day of the week, and waste a double amount on Sundays. Men waste shamefully, women shockingly; boys and girls, too, are permitted to waste wofully. Wastefulness is one of our worst national vices; for if economy be a virtue, then extravagance must be a vice. The English don't waste half as much as we do; the French not a quarter; and the Germans (while in Germany) don't waste at all.
headline: {'main': 'A Virtue Needed in America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Virtue Needed in America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Telegrams from St. Louis announce the shooting, in Wyandotte, Kansas, of Mr. SAMUEL HALLETT, General Manager of the Eastern Division of the Union Pacific Railway, by an engineer named TALCOTT, with whom he had had a sharp dispute regarding financial matters. Mr. HALLETT was born in the western part of this State, whence he came to this City some years ago, and entered into business. Some time ago Mr. HALLETT went to Spain, where he achieved an extraordinary financial feat by inducing a number of prominent Spaniards, including the Duke of SALAMANCA, to subscribe largely to the extension of the Erie Road to St. Louis. More recently Mr. HALLETT became prominently engaged in banking operations in this City, and a few months ago he went West to look after the construction of the Union Pacific Railway, in which he was largely interested.
lead_paragraph: -- Telegrams from St. Louis announce the shooting, in Wyandotte, Kansas, of Mr. SAMUEL HALLETT, General Manager of the Eastern Division of the Union Pacific Railway, by an engineer named TALCOTT, with whom he had had a sharp dispute regarding financial matters. Mr. HALLETT was born in the western part of this State, whence he came to this City some years ago, and entered into business. Some time ago Mr. HALLETT went to Spain, where he achieved an extraordinary financial feat by inducing a number of prominent Spaniards, including the Duke of SALAMANCA, to subscribe largely to the extension of the Erie Road to St. Louis. More recently Mr. HALLETT became prominently engaged in banking operations in this City, and a few months ago he went West to look after the construction of the Union Pacific Railway, in which he was largely interested.

lead_paragraph: The Central Railroad of New-Jersey opened the extension of their railroad from Elizabeth to Jersey City, and their new ferry from Jersey City to New-York, yesterday. A large number of prominent gentlemen from New-York and Jersey City look the noon train from the foot of Cortlandt-street, and joined the excursion at Elizabeth. Several members of the New-Jersey Legislature, and other invited guests, came on from Flemington and other points, the train making in all a long line of cars, filled with over 1,200 passengers.

abstract: Georgia Campaign; a Clear View of; Georgia Campaign, a Clear View of
snippet: Georgia Campaign; a Clear View of; Georgia Campaign, a Clear View of
lead_paragraph: Thoughtless critics are apt to fancy that the grand two-fold campaign of 1864 can end only in the total and final destruction of the Confederacy. But the real and immediate military object of that campaign is the defeat and overthrow of one or other of two great insurrectionary armies, and the seizure and possession of one or other of two vital strategic points -- the cities of Richmond and Atlanta. In the result, should the great structure of rebellion tumble, and, "like the baseless fabric of a vision, leave not a rack behind," there would be such rejoicing as follows the overplus of victory. But it wrongs our gallant soldiers to ask of them, in the brief compass of a single campaign, more than three previous years of war have accomplished. Should either city fall into our hands, with the invaluable region it commands, the campaign will be a success: should both, a triumph.

abstract: International Enterprises
snippet: International Enterprises
lead_paragraph: There could be no more agreeable relief from the sombre record of the war, which monopolizes so large a portion of the columns of the daily press, than the news of the progress made by the enterprisers in the great international telegraph lines. The line which is to bind Europe, Asia and America by way of the Amoor River, British America and Oregon, is now fairly on the way. The submarine portion of it will be laid down in about seven months from this date, and by that time the overland connecting links will be thoroughly completed both within the Russian territory bordering on the Amoor, and the uncompleted sections necessary to connect our continental lines with the Pacific terminus.

abstract: Rebel Deserters in Jones Co., Miss.
snippet: Rebel Deserters in Jones Co., Miss.
lead_paragraph: The Natchez (Miss.) Courier, of the 12th inst., gives an account of a curious "Republic" which was organized in Jones County, Miss., a year or so ago. It appears that numbers of rebel deserters having congregated in the swamps of that county, determined to form a government for themselves. A rebel Col. MOWRY, with a considerable force, was sent to disband them, and it was supposed had succeeded, but it now appears that the malcontents offered a desperate resistance, dispersing the assailants, killing and wounding and capturing a considerable proportion of them. At last accounts the "Republic" was still in the enjoyment of health and strength, and determined to resist to the death the encroachments of the Confederacy. It is not likely, however, that the "Republic" will long survive. The Confederates, unless speedily driven from Mississippi, will absorb it, and if they do not, another authority will.

abstract: Union Yacht Club, 1st Annual Regatta
snippet: Union Yacht Club, 1st Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: The first annual regatta of the Union Club took place on Wednesday last, under the most favorable auspices for a commencement, although the prospects were marred at the outset by an accident to the Lillie, which occasioned much chagrin to her owner, Commodore JULIAN JAMES, and the members of the club. On Tuesday she was hauled on the beach at Hoboken to be scraped and otherwise prepared for the race, but on Wednesday morning, owing to a westerly wind and low tide, it was found impossible to get her off in season, which was a great disappointment, as many yachtsmen expressed the belief that she would have proved the winner, being a notoriously fast sailor and the wind being exactly suitable to her.

abstract: New-York; Devlin's Clothing Store by Employe
snippet: New-York; Devlin's Clothing Store by Employe
lead_paragraph: For several months past, the firm of Messrs. DEVLIN & Co., doing business at Nos. 459 and 461 Broadway, extensive dealers in clothing, has missed large quantities of goods in so mysterious a manner as to cause the proprietors of the establishment to take active measures to ferret out the guilty persons, and to recover the lost goods. Application was made to JOHN S. YOUNG, Chief of the Detective Force, a few weeks since, and officers RADFORD and KELSO were detailed to work up the case, and, if possible, secure the thieves and the property. The officers above named immediately commenced a system of espionage which is known only to New-York detectives. They worked long and vigilantly. They set a close watch over all the clerks in the establishment, and when it is remembered that there are over one hundred clerks in that establishment, it will be seen that the task was not an easy one. Day after day men in citizens' dress walked through that extensive store, and yet, with all their watchfulness, they for a time were unable to detect the culprit. Meantime the proprietors almost every day missed quantities of valuable clothing, Coats, vests and pantaloons disappeared in an unaccountable manner. As a general thing the goods taken were of the finest and most expensive character, and on some days properly to the amount of $100 was taken. After long and tedious watching and waiting, the detectives, Messrs. RADFORD and KELSO, came to the conclusion that there was only one thief in the business, and that he was an employe in the store REUBEN DECKER, a clerk of Messrs. DEVLIN & Co., was the person suspected. He was accordingly arrested. He was caught in the act of selling a new suit of clothes, which he had taken from DEVLIN's store to a couple of Frenchmen named PETER MAROCIER and JOHN DAGLO, whom he met at a lager-beer saloon, in Broome-street. The Frenchmen, as well as DECKER, were taken into custody.
headline: {'main': 'Extensive Robberies in a Broadway Clothing Store.; A CLERK AND TWO RECEIVERS ARRESTED ON SUSPICION SOME OF THE PROPERTY RECOVERED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Extensive Robberies in a Broadway Clothing Store.; A CLERK AND TWO RECEIVERS ARRESTED ON SUSPICION SOME OF THE PROPERTY RECOVERED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Late on Sunday evening, a policeman brought to the Central Police Telegraph Station a bright little boy of about two years of age. He had been found in South Front-street, where a lady, instead of sending him to the nearest station-house, or leaving word that she had him, had kept him until the officer took charge and removed him to the Central Office. There had been inquirers during the day from the Third Ward for the child, and when he was brought in, word was immediately sent to the parents. The child fell asleep in the station-house, on the lounge. Shortly before 12 o'clock, a woman entered and inquired for a child, and the moment she saw the little fellow she claimed him as her own, and commenced a series of lamentations and endearments in true motherly style. But the operators at the telegraph station are very careful in regard to the release of children, and, perhaps, without any clear idea that the woman was an imposter, commenced questioning her as to the time and place the child was lost. Her answers soon established that she knew nothing about the child, and the operators at once charged her with being an imposter, to which she gave the most vehement denial. They refused to allow her to depart, and a few minutes after 12 o'clock the father entered and claimed his boy. He disclaimed all knowledge of the woman, although she insisted that he knew her. She was removed to a cell and locked up for the night, and yesterday was sent to prison. She was in liquor, although that fact could not at first be discovered. The child continued asleep through all the dispute. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 26.

abstract: Justice BARNARD, yesterday, granted a writ of habeas corpus, directing Gen. Dix to produce the body of Theodore Allen, the bounty broker now confined in Fort Lafayette. The petition for the writ sets forth that the alleged swindling of recruits is not an offence punishable by military law or authority, and consequently is not included by the President's proclamation suspending the writ of habeas corpus. Ex-Judge Stewart and Abraham S. Cohen appeared for the petitioner, and will argue the on Monday, when the writ is made returnable.

abstract: The public will remember that some weeks since the wife of Brig.-Gen. CRAWFORD VAUGHAN, Confederate States America, of Monroe County, East Tennessee, was arrested at her house and sent North by the military authorities for her many and persistent acts of flagrant rebellion. This fact becoming known to the rebels in Upper East Tennessee, they determined to arrest the wife of some prominent Union man, to be held as a hostage, and singled out Mrs. JOHN NETHERLAND, of Rogersville, Hawkins County, East Tennessee. Her election coming to the ears of Mrs. NETHERLAND, she at once determined that she would not be swapped in that way, and placing her children in charge of their aged grandmother, she took a horse, and by two nights' and a day's ride, reached her husband, Col. NETHERLAND, in safety. Col. NETHERLAND was the Whig candidate for Governor in 1859, in opposition to ISHAM G. HARRIS, and his many friends throughout the country will be pleased to hear of the escape from the rebels of his most estimable lady, by an act of daring bravery which deserves, and will receive, the admiration of everyone who appreciates true heroism. -- Chatta -- nooga Gazette.

abstract: At the moment when a fearful outrage has fixed the attention of the public on the insecurity of the present conditions of railway traveling, we are opportunity able to present our readers with the re[???] [???] of a [???] analysis of the same difficulty form a French [???] of view. A similar anxiety has been roused in France, and a Commission which was appointed in [???] by the French Minister of Public Works, has among the subject of its inquiry, reported upon the very question which has just become so unhappily prominent -- the possibility, that is of establishing communication between the passengers and the officials of a train. The Commission addressed questions to seven important French Railway Companies, and they obtained a report on the system adopted on the railways of Germany. They discussed the evidence thus obtained, and found on it one or two recommendations. Lastly, on the 1st of February, in this year, the Minister of Public Works addressed a circular to the French Companies, the directions of which are, we presume, founded upon the inquiries of the Commission.

abstract: A case was commenced in the Chancery Court, York, on Thursday, and concluded yesterday, involving a serious charge against a clergyman of the Church of England. The promoter was Mr. T.S. NOBLE, and the suit was instituted against Rev. G.A. COCKBURN, Vicar of Pickering. Dr. TRISTRAM and Mr. MAULE, who wore specials retained, were advocates for the promoter, and Mr. SHEPHERD was the advocate for the defendant. The proceedings had been commenced in this court by virtue of letters of request from the Archbishop, presented under the authority of the Church Discipline Act. On the 16th of September last the defendant had been cited to answer certain articles charging him with having, within two years past, acted toward a female known by the name of JENNY WARDELL, with an unbecoming familiarity and in an indecent manner, thereby causing great scandal to the Church, and also with having committed adultery with the said JENNY WARDELL. who is between 20 and 30 years of age. In March, 1858, the defendant was instituted to the vicarage of the parish church of Pickering, and JENNY WARDELL had resided in the market-place of that town. The articles, twenty in number, alleged that on the 19th of June, 1862, the defendant was for some time alone with JENNY WARDELL in the kitchen of the house, and put his arms round her waist, and repeatedly kissed her. That, on the 21st of October in the same year, the Pickering Rifle corps attendee battalion drill at Scarbro', where the defendant met her, and after the drill he entered the railway station with her, deporting himself toward her with great familiarity and levity, and that he traveled in the same carriage with her between Malton and Pickering. That, in December, 1862, the defendant took, or attempted to take, an indecent liberty with JENNY WARDELL whilst she was standing on some steps in the church, at Pickering, engaged in decorating the chandelier. That, in November or December, 1862, he went into JENNY WARDELL bedroom whist she was in bed, and remained with her alone for a considerable time. That on four nights in July, 1863, she entered the private garden attached to the vicarage house, and that the defendant, who remained with her alone there for a considerable period. It was also alleged that on several occasions in 1862 and 1863. the defendant was in her house with her alone for long periods; that several of his parishioners had expressed openly and in his hearing, strong disapprobation; that since September, 1863, the defendant has been carrying on an [???] intercourse with JENNY WARDELL., and that the average attendance at the Sunday morning's service, by reason of the defendant's conduct has not during the past years exceeded fifty persons, whereas the congregation had previously [???] to five hundred. The twentieth article contained a prayer that the defendant be ca[???]ly and duly corrected and punished, having regard to the fact that the living of PICKERING is [???] sequestration, and also be condemned in costs. The defense of Mr. COCKBURN was in effect a total denial of the whole of the charges, and an allegation that they had been brought maliciously by his enemies. The hearing of the case occupied the court the whole of Thursday and yesterday, when the Chancellor gave judgment. The Chancellor said: Scandal was a fair ground for action against a clergyman who might have been guilty of habitual insurrection and indifference of opinion to his flock. What did the ordination services dictate but that a clergyman should frame and fashion his family, as much as in him it lay, [???] as to become wholesome examples and patterns to the flock of Christ? As to the defendant, he said that there was the gravest [???]cion that [???] familiarities had been brought home to him by [???]qute proof of most of the articles, and after a [???] warning which had been given by the archdeacon. Had the charge of adultery been brought home to him, he should have felt is this duty to have altogether deprived the defendant, whose conduct be could only say was suggestive of infatuation. He then spoke of the fair manner in which the case had been conducted, and briefly reviewed some of the strongest features of the evidence which had been tendered, and particularly that where it had been shown that the interview after the [???] warning took place in the rector's garden. There was not the s[???] pretence of business or official duty, he observed, proved to have been promotive of the intercourse which took place. As to the lady, he [???] she had not given way to the defendant's [???], and he had no reason to say that which would impeach her virtue; but there were the gravest reasons to impute indiscretion He trusted she would learn nothing worse at [???] than she had learned at Pickering. Under all the circumstances, and looking at his responsibilities, he had been led to hesitate whether, under any circumstances. he should be justified in allowing the defendant to resume his ministerial functions. But as a matter of comparative severity, and looking at the ordinary rules by which courts or justice had been guided, and the hope he entertained that a person after serious punishment, and with more time for consideration, might reflect on the evil which he had done, and turn over a new leaf and make himself more useful in the future than he had done in the past, he should content himself with the hope that it would prove a serious warning, and sentence the defendant to five years' suspension, and condemn him in costs, Notice of appeal was given.

abstract: Rumors thicken in regard to the new invasion of Pennsylvania by the rebels, but nothing absolutely definite has as yet been ascertained respecting the strength or the designs of the invading force. A vague estimate puts their numbers at 30,000; but we have no reliable information on this point. It is thought at Harrisburgh the invasion of the State is of a character too gigantic to be regarded any longer as a mere raid. Chambersburgh has been occupied, and the rebels are said to be advancing on Harrisburgh. It is reported that Gen. AVERILL has been repulsed in an attack upon their centre, and compelled to fall back. In response to a call from Gov. CURTIN, an immense meeting was held yesterday at Harrisburgh, and the people seem to be thoroughly aroused to the necessity of arming in the defence of their homes. But we reiterate that the rumors, alarming as they appear, are rumors merely, and the new invasion may be only a repetition of their former raid.

abstract: The Future of Denmark
snippet: The Future of Denmark
lead_paragraph: The inability of the conference to bring about a compromise between the belligerents, and the indisposition of the Western Powers to succor King CHRISTIAN, have proved fatal to the autonomy of Denmark. There can no longer exist a Danish Monarchy in the old sense of that term. If the war continue, the Cimbrian realm will be soon as completely dismembered as Poland; will be soon as utterly blotted out of the map of Europe, politically, as is the unfortunate country of Sobieski; and even though the Glucksburg mission to Berlin should lead to peace, still that peace will have to be purchased by concessions on the part of Denmark which will destroy her independence and nationality.

abstract: The Pensiero, a paper published in Naples, in its issue of the 9th of June last, declares that GRECO, the Italian recently accused of engaging in a conspiracy against the life of the Emperor NAPOLEON III., has been sent under guard to this country, on his simple parole to return no more to Europe, he having promised that when he reaches America he will enlist in the army of the Southern Confederacy, and never leave the military service.

abstract: -- The bounty-jumpers, who fill up quotas by enlisting for every district and fighting for none, have as many ingenious methods for operating as the confidence men. The last dodge is reported by an Elmira paper. Three Canadian substitutes, who left that place a few days since for Camp Distribution, Washington, have turned up among the rebel prisoners sent there lately. They deserted from the camp at Washington, presented themselves as deserters from the rebel army. desirous of taking the oath of allegiance, and in this character they were sent back to Elmira, where they were identified. They will now try some other dodge and succeed.

abstract: The Chicago Times gives the following account of the lake tunnel: The work was commenced on the 17th of March,and since then the progress made in the construction of the tunnel has been such notwithstanding the tremendous difficulties which have had to be overcome as to astonish all who have watched the operations. On descending the shaft, the first feature that strikes one with astonishment, is the solidity and finish of the masonry.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Times gives the following account of the lake tunnel: The work was commenced on the 17th of March,and since then the progress made in the construction of the tunnel has been such -- notwithstanding the tremendous difficulties which have had to be overcome -- as to astonish all who have watched the operations. On descending the shaft, the first feature that strikes one with astonishment, is the solidity and finish of the masonry. At the entrance there is an immense iron cylinder, nine feet in diameter, extending downwards thirty feet. The remaining portion of the shaft to the bottom, seventy-eight feet below the surface, is built round with brick -- so finely finished in the building that it seems almost equally smooth around the sides with the cylinder. Standing at the bucket -- holding on firmly to the rope -- looking upward at the daylight shining over the shaft, and rendering the opening like a great moon overhead -- one glides down the immense abyss, which becomes momentarily darker as he descends. In a little time there is a sudden slack in the cable; the bucket touches ground; far above appears the round gleam of upper day; and far out under the lake there is a seemingly interminable labyrinth, along which shadowy figures flit to and fro, bearing lamps which glimmer like fire-flies in the distance. Above, the waters of the lake are lashing impetuously, or sleeping in perfect quiet beneath the heavens -- blue as themselves.
headline: {'main': 'The Chicago Lake Tunnel.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Chicago Lake Tunnel.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Dr. Studley's Reminiscences of
snippet: Dr. Studley's Reminiscences of
lead_paragraph: In after years when the events which are now convulsing this republic have passed into historical record, not the least interesting of those annals will be the prison-life-of Forts Lafayette and Warren. Already the incarceration from time to time of some of our enemy's most active representatives has attached an interest and an awe to their frowning and grim-visaged walls, something akin to that which we feel when we read of MARY in Loch Leven, or of the bars and batlements and clanking drawbridge of prison castle in feudal times. Already their whilom and temporary inmates have told their tales of in justice, suffering and barbarity in such plaintive measures and with such gnashings of indignation, that it would be difficult to decide from them as criterion whether a WOOD did not excel a NERO in cruelty, or a BURKE far transcend a JAVERT in his conceptions and executions of official duties. With characteristic dignity our Government has never attempted any self-vindication or asked of others any exculpation or defence. One set of stories have been re[???]erated and rehashed until, even at the North, a anothered sentiment is entertained in some circles that we are fostering within our bosom a worse than a French Bastile or a Spanish Inquisition under some Cardinal XIMINES.
headline: {'main': 'Reminiscences of Fort Lafayette.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reminiscences of Fort Lafayette.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Letters have been received from Dr. W. HUGH PIERSON, of Orange, New-Jersey, who was a surgeon on board the Water Witch at the time of her capture by the rebels. He was taken to Savannah, and having offered his services was detailed to attend upon the Federal prisoners at that place. The letter was written three days after his capture, and sent North by a flag of truce.

abstract: Spence to London Times on American War
snippet: Spence to London Times on American War
lead_paragraph: The unwearied Mr. SPENCE, not satisfied with his recent call on Lord PALMERSTON, to urge him, purely in the interests of humanity, to interfere and save the slaveholders from the ruin which their own arrogance and folly has brought down upon them, has written a long letter to the London Times on the same subject. He devotes a large portion of it to showing the utter incompetency of Gen. GRANT, and the entire failure of every movement which he has made. Mr. SPENCE thinks that GRANT has governed his movements "by studying not the art of war, but the New-York papers;" but we must disclaim this praise entirely. Mr. SPENCE, perhaps, might learn something, if he would, by studying our journals, but Gen. Grant has relied upon other sources of inspiration in this campaign, as he did in his campaign at Vicksburgh, which the rebels and their friends pronounced an utter failure, as they do this one.
