abstract: Nativity and Occupations of People of
snippet: Nativity and Occupations of People of
lead_paragraph: No people on earth have came together more suddenly, or illustrated more clearly the improvement of the social condition by colonization, than those of the United States. Europe has forced forth her people to colonize America, and for the same reason which moved the Goths and Huns -- to better their condition. In fact, scarcely any people would leave their homes to find new ones, but for the strongest of motives. In some cases persecution has driven them forth, as when Holland, England and Germany received the best of the French artisans and manufacturers on the revocation of the edict of Nantes. In general, however, the pressing sense of physical wants, the instinct to provide better for themselves, has caused the movement of the greater number of emigrants. This is particularly the case with the people of Ireland, especially when the potato disease reduced the supply of food below the actual demand. Emigration from Ireland was quite large before this, but since the famine year of 1847-8 the migration from Ireland, especially to the United States, has been enormous. The population of Ireland has been reduced two and a half millions, who have left that island merely because they were cramped and furnished by the impossibility of supporting eight millions of people (which Ireland at one time had) in good and comfortable condition, on a space less than half the surface of Ohio. They were compelled to seek food and a better condition. The migration still continues, and the British Government has the folly to think that our Government is seducing them here to become soldiers. But neither the British nor the American Government can stop that migration while the cause remains.

abstract: Manhattan College Commencement
snippet: Manhattan College Commencement
lead_paragraph: The week preceding the Fourth of July was a busy one for the College of the Brothers at Manhattanville, nearly every evening being devoted to public examinations prior to the vacation. The pupils were examined in all the different branches of instruction and acquitted themselves very creditably of their task. The examinations were of a varied and highly interesting character and always attracted many visitors, who were very kindly and courteously accommodated with seats by the Brothers. Especially on Friday the spacious hall of the college was densely crowded, a large and fashionable audience having assembled to witness the distribution of prizes at the close of the examination.

abstract: -- O.H. ORTON, of Madison, son of Judge ORTON, passed through our city Saturday, on his way home from Washington. He brings with him BRADLEY JOHNSTON's revolver, which he picked up at the woods near the Maryland Agricultural College, early in the morning after Gen. JOHNSTON halted there. JOHNSTON sent one of his rebels back after it, who failed in his mission because of the darkness. The prize is a valuable one, the revolver being one of the largest and most costly of COLT's manufacture. -- Milwaukee Wisconsin, July 27.

abstract: Complain was laid before U.S. District Attorney KEASER on Saturday, against HENRY MCALPINE for enticing a soldier to desert. The deserter was his son, 17 years old, by whose affidavit it appears that MCALPINE was released from the State Prison in New-York in June last and came to New-York, where he met his son in the street, prevailed on him to accompany him to Newark, and there induced him to enlist as a substitute, having previously arranged with the boy a plan to enable him to desert at the first opportunity. The father instructed the child to desert on his first march, and to telegraph to him, promising to meet him and have him enlisted again, and as often as he could effect his cause. The boy deserted but was arrested in New-York, when he stated the above facts. Gen. DIX sent the boy to Provost-Marshal MILLS and the father was held in custody until the matter could be submitted to the District-Attorney here. Application was at once made to U.S. Commissioner WHITEHEAD, who issued a warrant, and MCALPINE was brought here on Saturday night and lodged in jail. -- Newark Advertiser, July 25

abstract: Since the party  fight over the Danes and Germans in both Houses of the British Parliament, the ferocious excitement of the nation over the wrongs of Denmark has died away as effectually as if everything had been set to rights with that unfortunate country.
lead_paragraph: -- Since the party fight over the Danes and Germans in both Houses of the British Parliament, the ferocious excitement of the nation over the wrongs of Denmark has died away as effectually as if everything had been set to rights with that unfortunate country. Judging from the tone of the Liberal press -- including in that category Punch -- one would suppose that Lord RUSSELL's diplomacy had put European affairs generally upon a satisfactory basis. The congratulations of the multitude of friendly organs which Lord PALMERSTON appears to have at his service, seem to vary between a pleasing conviction that England has been kept out of war, and a quiet feeling of exultation that the Tories have been well beaten in a party fight. Copenhagen correspondents of the London press represent that this sort of thing is but indifferently well relished by the Danes. But that is a small matter. The self-complacency of the better portion of England is satisfied; and Punch's principal cartoon gives a perfect illustration to the prevailing popular feeling, by representing DISRAELI, the bully of St. Stephen's Academy and the plague of poor JOHNNY RUSSELL, in full receipt of a sound thrashing from GLADSTONE, the young chevalier of the school, and the protector of helpless urchins of the Russell class generally. DERBY looks on, through his spectacles, in the distance, sullen and discomfited, and DISRAELI, as usual, gets some drops of comfort from Mrs. Gamp, the inspiring genius of the Standard newspaper.

abstract: The weather has been decidedly cooler during the past-week, the range of the thermometer having been 55  to 65 , during the nights, and 68  to 80  during the daytime. The causes of this marked change of temperature was a heavy rain which fell in the Northwest, though there has been no rain in the Ohio Valley, and the crops, including corn, grass and potatoes, are suffering for the want of it.
